condescended to help him (Noah). Mr. Sowerberry came down soon after. Shortly afterwards, Mrs. Sowerberry appeared. Oliver having
`caught it,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
in fulfilment of Noah's prediction, followed that young gentleman down the stairs to breakfast.

`Come near the fire, Noah,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.
`I saved a nice little bit of bacon for you from master's breakfast. Oliver, shut that door at Mister Noah's back, and take them bits that I've put out on the cover of the bread-pan. There's your tea; take it away to that box, and drink it there, and make haste, for they'll want you to mind the shop. D'ye hear?' (Charlotte)

'D`ye hear, Work`us?' said Noah Claypole.

`Lor, Noah!' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
`what a rum creature you are! Why don't you let the boy alone?' (Charlotte)

`Let him (boy) alone!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.
`Why everybody lets him (Noah) alone enough, for the matter of that. Neither his (Noah) father nor his (Noah) mother will ever interfere with him (Noah). All his (Noah) relations let him (Noah) have his (Noah) own way pretty well. Eh, Charlotte? He (Noah)! he (Noah)! he (Noah)!' (unknown)

`Oh, you queer soul!' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte, bursting into a hearty laugh, in which she (Charlotte) was joined by Noah; after which they both looked scornfully at poor Oliver Twist, as he (Noah) sat shivering on the box in the coldest corner of the room, and ate the stale pieces which had been specially reserved for him (Noah).

Noah was a charity-boy, but not a workhouse orphan. No chance-child was he (Noah), for he (Noah) could trace his (Noah) genealogy all the way back to his (Noah) parents, who lived hard by; his (Noah) mother being a washerwoman, and his (Noah) father a drunken soldier, discharged with a wooden leg, and a diurnal pension of twopence-halfpenny and an unstateable fraction. The shop-boys in the neighbourhood had long been in the habit of branding Noah in the public streets, with the ignominious epithets of

`leathers,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
`charity,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
and the like; and Noah had bourne them without reply. But, now that fortune had cast in his (Noah) way a nameless orphan, at whom even the meanest could point the finger of scorn, he (Noah) retorted on him (Noah) with interest. This affords charming food for contemplation. It shows us what a beautiful thing human nature may be made to be; and how impartially the same amiable qualities are developed in the finest lord and the dirtiest charity-boy.

Oliver had been sojourning at the undertaker's some three weeks or a month. Mr. and Mrs. Sowerberry--the shop being shut up--were taking their supper in the little back-parlour, when Mr. Sowerberry, after several deferential glances at his (Sowerberry) wife, said,

`My dear--' (wife)
He (Sowerberry) was going to say more; but, Mrs. Sowerberry looking up, with a peculiarly unpropitious aspect, he (Sowerberry) stopped short.

`Well,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry, sharply.

`Nothing, my dear, nothing,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Mr. Sowerberry.

`Ugh, you brute!' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry.

`Not at all, my dear,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Mr. Sowerberry humbly.
`I thought you didn't want to hear, my dear. I was only going to say--' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)

`Oh, don't tell me what you were going to say,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
interposed Mrs. Sowerberry.
`I am nobody; don't consult me, pray. _I_ don't want to intrude upon your secrets.' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
As Mrs. Sowerberry said this, she (Sowerberry) gave an hysterical laugh, which threatened violent consequences.

`But, my dear,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Sowerberry,
`I want to ask your advice.' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)

`No, no, don't ask mine,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
replied Mrs. Sowerberry, in an affecting manner:
`ask somebody else's.' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
Here, there was another hysterical laugh, which frightened Mr. Sowerberry very much. This is a very common and much-approved matrimonial course of treatment, which is often very effective. It at once reduced Mr. Sowerberry to begging, as a special favour, to be allowed to say what Mrs. Sowerberry was most curious to hear. After a short duration, the permission was most graciously conceded.

`It's only about young Twist, my dear,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Mr. Sowerberry.
`A very good-looking boy, that, my dear.' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)

`He (Sowerberry) need be, for he (Sowerberry) eats enough,' (the lady)
observed the lady.

`There's an expression of melancholy in his (Sowerberry) face, my dear,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
resumed Mr. Sowerberry,
`which is very interesting. He (Sowerberry) would make a delightful mute, my love.' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)

Mrs. Sowerberry looked up with an expression of considerable wonderment. Mr. Sowerberry remarked it and, without allowing time for any observation on the good lady's part, proceeded.

`I don't mean a regular mute to attend grown-up people, my dear, but only for children's practice. It would be very new to have a mute in proportion, my dear. You may depend upon it, it would have a superb effect.' (the lady)

Mrs. Sowerberry, who had a good deal of taste in the undertaking way, was much struck by the novelty of this idea; but, as it would have been compromising her (Sowerberry) dignity to have said so, under existing circumstances, she (Sowerberry) merely inquired, with much sharpness, why such an obvious suggestion had not presented itself to her (Sowerberry) husband's mind before? Mr. Sowerberry rightly construed this, as an acquiescence in his (Sowerberry) proposition; it was speedily determined, therefore, that Oliver should be at once initiated into the mysteries of the trade; and, with this view, that he (Sowerberry) should accompany his (Sowerberry) master on the very next occasion of his (Sowerberry) services being required.

The occasion was not long in coming. Half an hour after breakfast next morning, Mr. Bumble entered the shop; and supporting his (Bumble) cane against the counter, drew forth his (Bumble) large leathern pocket-book: from which he (Bumble) selected a small scrap of paper, which he (Bumble) handed over to Sowerberry.

`Aha!' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker, glancing over it with a lively countenance;
`an order for a coffin, eh?' (the undertaker)

`For a coffin first, and a porochial funeral afterwards,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, fastening the strap of the leathern pocket-book: which, like himself, was very corpulent.

`Bayton,' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker, looking from the scrap of paper to Mr. Bumble.
`I never heard the name before.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Bumble shook his (Bumble) head, as he (Bumble) replied,

`Obstinate people, Mr. Sowerberry; very obstinate. Proud, too, I'm afraid, sir.' (he)

`Proud, eh?' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
exclaimed Mr. Sowerberry with a sneer.
`Come, that's too much.' (unknown)

`Oh, it's sickening,' (the beadle)
replied the beadle.
`Antimonial, Mr. Sowerberry!' (unknown)

`So it is,' (the undertaker)
acquiesced the undertaker.

`We only heard of the family the night before last,' (the beadle)
said the beadle; `and we shouldn't have known anything about them, then, only a woman who lodges in the same house made an application to the porochial committee for them to send the porochial surgeon to see a woman as was very bad. He (surgeon) had gone out to dinner; but his (surgeon)
`prentice -LRB-which is a very clever lad-RRB- sent 'em some medicine in a blacking-bottle, offhand.' (He)

`Ah, there's promptness,' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker.

`Promptness, indeed!' (the beadle)
replied the beadle.
`But what's the consequence; what's the ungrateful behaviour of these rebels, sir? Why, the husband sends back word that the medicine won't suit his (husband) wife's complaint, and so she (wife) shan't take it--says she (wife) shan't take it, sir! Good, strong, wholesome medicine, as was given with great success to two Irish labourers and a coal-heaver, only a week before--sent 'em for nothing, with a blackin' (he)
-bottle in,--and he (husband) sends back word that she (wife) shan't take it, sir!'

As the atrocity presented itself to Mr. Bumble's mind in full force, he (Bumble) struck the counter sharply with his (Bumble) cane, and became flushed with indignation.

`Well,' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker,
`I ne--ver--did--' (the undertaker)

`Never did, sir!' (the undertaker)
ejaculated the beadle.
`No, nor nobody never did; but now she (wife)'s dead, we've got to bury her (wife); and that's the direction; and the sooner it's done, the better.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Thus saying, Mr. Bumble put on his (Bumble) cocked hat wrong side first, in a fever of parochial excitement; and flounced out of the shop.

`Why, he (Bumble) was so angry, Oliver, that he (Oliver) forgot even to ask after you!' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Mr. Sowerberry, looking after the beadle as he (Sowerberry) strode down the street.

`Yes, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, who had carefully kept himself out of sight, during the interview; and who was shaking from head to foot at the mere recollection of the sound of Mr. Bumble's voice.

He (Bumble) needn't haven taken the trouble to shrink from Mr. Bumble's glance, however; for that functionary, on whom the prediction of the gentleman in the white waistcoat had made a very strong impression, thought that now the undertaker had got Oliver upon trial the subject was better avoided, until such time as he (Oliver) should be firmly bound for seven years, and all danger of his (Oliver) being returned upon the hands of the parish should be thus effectually and legally overcome.

`Well,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Mr. Sowerberry, taking up his (Sowerberry) hat,
`the sooner this job is done, the better. Noah, look after the shop. Oliver, put on your cap, and come with me.' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
Oliver obeyed, and followed his (Oliver) master on his (Oliver) professional mission.

They walked on, for some time, through the most crowded and densely inhabited part of the town; and then, striking down a narrow street more dirty and miserable than any they had yet passed through, paused to look for the house which was the object of their search. The houses on either side were high and large, but very old, and tenanted by people of the poorest class: as their neglected appearance would have sufficiently denoted, without the concurrent testimony afforded by the squalid looks of the few men and women who, with folded arms and bodies half doubled, occasionally skulked along. A great many of the tenements had shop-fronts; but these were fast closed, and mouldering away; only the upper rooms being inhabited. Some houses which had become insecure from age and decay, were prevented from falling into the street, by huge beams of wood reared against the walls, and firmly planted in the road; but even these crazy dens seemed to have been selected as the nightly haunts of some houseless wretches, for many of the rough boards which supplied the place of door and window, were wrenched from their positions, to afford an aperture wide enough for the passage of a human body. The kennel was stagnant and filthy. The very rats, which here and there lay putrefying in its rottenness, were hideous with famine.

There was neither knocker nor bell-handle at the open door where Oliver and his (Oliver) master stopped; so, groping his (Oliver) way cautiously through the dark passage, and bidding Oliver keep close to him (Oliver) and not be afraid the undertaker mounted to the top of the first flight of stairs. Stumbling against a door on the landing, he (Oliver) rapped at it with his (Oliver) knuckles.

It was opened by a young girl of thirteen or fourteen. The undertaker at once saw enough of what the room contained, to know it was the apartment to which he (undertaker) had been directed. He (undertaker) stepped in; Oliver followed him (Oliver).

There was no fire in the room; but a man was crouching, mechanically, over the empty stove. An old woman, too, had drawn a low stool to the cold hearth, and was sitting beside him (man). There were some ragged children in another corner; and in a small recess, opposite the door, there lay upon the ground, something covered with an old blanket. Oliver shuddered as he (Oliver) cast his (Oliver) eyes toward the place, and crept involuntarily closer to his (Oliver) master; for though it was covered up, the boy felt that it was a corpse.

The man's face was thin and very pale; his (man) hair and beard were grizzly; his (man) eyes were bloodshot. The old woman's face was wrinkled; her (woman) two remaining teeth protruded over her (woman) under lip; and her (woman) eyes were bright and piercing. Oliver was afraid to look at either her (woman) or the man. They seemed so like the rats he (Oliver) had seen outside.

`Nobody shall go near her (woman),' (the man)
said the man, starting fiercely up, as the undertaker approached the recess.
`Keep back! Damn you, keep back, if you've a life to lose!' (unknown)

`Nonsense, my good man,' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker, who was pretty well used to misery in all its shapes.
`Nonsense!' (unknown)

`I tell you,' (the man)
said the man: clenching his (man) hands, and stamping furiously on the floor,--'I tell you I won't have her (woman) put into the ground. She (woman) couldn't rest there. The worms would worry her (woman)--not eat her (woman)--she (woman) is so worn away.'

The undertaker offered no reply to this raving; but producing a tape from his (undertaker) pocket, knelt down for a moment by the side of the body.

`Ah!' (the man)
said the man: bursting into tears, and sinking on his (man) knees at the feet of the dead woman;
`kneel down, kneel down--kneel round her (woman), every one of you, and mark my words! I say she (woman) was starved to death. I never knew how bad she (woman) was, till the fever came upon her (woman); and then her (woman) bones were starting through the skin. There was neither fire nor candle; she (woman) died in the dark--in the dark! She (woman) couldn't even see her (woman) children's faces, though we heard her (woman) gasping out their names. I begged for her (woman) in the streets: and they sent me to prison. When I came back, she (woman) was dying; and all the blood in my heart has dried up, for they starved her (woman) to death. I swear it before the God that saw it! They starved her (woman)!' (the woman)
He (God) twined his (God) hands in his (God) hair; and, with a loud scream, rolled grovelling upon the floor: his (God) eyes fixed, and the foam covering his (God) lips.

The terrified children cried bitterly; but the old woman, who had hitherto remained as quiet as if she (woman) had been wholly deaf to all that passed, menaced them into silence. Having unloosened the cravat of the man who still remained extended on the ground, she (woman) tottered towards the undertaker.

`She (woman) was my daughter,' (the woman)
said the old woman, nodding her (woman) head in the direction of the corpse; and speaking with an idiotic leer, more ghastly than even the presence of death in such a place.
`Lord, Lord! Well, it _is_ strange that I who gave birth to her (woman), and was a woman then, should be alive and merry now, and she (woman) lying there: so cold and stiff! Lord, Lord!--to think of it; it's as good as a play--as good as a play!' (the creature)

As the wretched creature mumbled and chuckled in her (woman) hideous merriment, the undertaker turned to go away.

`Stop, stop!' (the woman)
said the old woman in a loud whisper.
`Will she (woman) be buried to-morrow, or next day, or to-night? I laid her (woman) out; and I must walk, you know. Send me a large cloak: a good warm one: for it is bitter cold. We should have cake and wine, too, before we go! Never mind; send some bread--only a loaf of bread and a cup of water. Shall we have some bread, dear?' (she)
she (woman) said eagerly: catching at the undertaker's coat, as he (undertaker) once more moved towards the door.

`Yes, yes,' (the undertaker)
said the undertaker,`of course. Anything you like!' He (undertaker) disengaged himself from the old woman's grasp; and, drawing Oliver after him (Oliver), hurried away.

The next day, -LRB-the family having been meanwhile relieved with a half-quartern loaf and a piece of cheese, left with them by Mr. Bumble himself,-RRB- Oliver and his (Oliver) master returned to the miserable abode; where Mr. Bumble had already arrived, accompanied by four men from the workhouse, who were to act as bearers. An old black cloak had been thrown over the rags of the old woman and the man; and the bare coffin having been screwed down, was hoisted on the shoulders of the bearers, and carried into the street.

`Now, you must put your best leg foremost, old lady!' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
whispered Sowerberry in the old woman's ear;
`we are rather late; and it won't do, to keep the clergyman waiting. Move on, my men,--as quick as you like!' (the woman)

Thus directed, the bearers trotted on under their light burden; and the two mourners kept as near them, as they could. Mr. Bumble and Sowerberry walked at a good smart pace in front; and Oliver, whose legs were not so long as his (Oliver) master's, ran by the side.

There was not so great a necessity for hurrying as Mr. Sowerberry had anticipated, however; for when they reached the obscure corner of the churchyard in which the nettles grew, and where the parish graves were made, the clergyman had not arrived; and the clerk, who was sitting by the vestry-room fire, seemed to think it by no means improbable that it might be an hour or so, before he (clergyman) came. So, they put the bier on the brink of the grave; and the two mourners waited patiently in the damp clay, with a cold rain drizzling down, while the ragged boys whom the spectacle had attracted into the churchyard played a noisy game at hide-and-seek among the tombstones, or varied their amusements by jumping backwards and forwards over the coffin. Mr. Sowerberry and Bumble, being personal friends of the clerk, sat by the fire with him (Sowerberry), and read the paper.

At length, after a lapse of something more than an hour, Mr. Bumble, and Sowerberry, and the clerk, were seen running towards the grave. Immediately afterwards, the clergyman appeared: putting on his (clergyman) surplice as he (clergyman) came along. Mr. Bumble then thrashed a boy or two, to keep up appearances; and the reverend gentleman, having read as much of the burial service as could be compressed into four minutes, gave his (gentleman) surplice to the clerk, and walked away again.

`Now, Bill!' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Sowerberry to the grave-digger.
`Fill up!' (unknown)

It was no very difficult task, for the grave was so full, that the uppermost coffin was within a few feet of the surface. The grave-digger shovelled in the earth; stamped it loosely down with his (Sowerberry) feet: shouldered his (Sowerberry) spade; and walked off, followed by the boys, who murmured very loud complaints at the fun being over so soon.

`Come, my good fellow!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Bumble, tapping the man on the back.
`They want to shut up the yard.' (The man)

The man who had never once moved, since he (man) had taken his (man) station by the grave side, started, raised his (man) head, stared at the person who had addressed him (man), walked forward for a few paces; and fell down in a swoon. The crazy old woman was too much occupied in bewailing the loss of her (woman) cloak -LRB-which the undertaker had taken off-RRB-, to pay him (undertaker) any attention; so they threw a can of cold water over him (undertaker); and when he (undertaker) came to, saw him (undertaker) safely out of the churchyard, locked the gate, and departed on their different ways.

`Well, Oliver,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Sowerberry, as they walked home,
`how do you like it?' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)

`Pretty well, thank you, sir' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, with considerable hesitation.
`Not very much, sir.' (unknown)

`Ah, you'll get used to it in time, Oliver,' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Sowerberry.
`Nothing when you _are_ used to it, my boy.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver wondered, in his (Oliver) own mind, whether it had taken a very long time to get Mr. Sowerberry used to it. But he (Sowerberry) thought it better not to ask the question; and walked back to the shop: thinking over all he (Sowerberry) had seen and heard.

CHAPTER VI

OLIVER, BEING GOADED BY THE TAUNTS OF NOAH, ROUSES INTO ACTION, AND RATHER ASTONISHES HIM

The month's trial over, Oliver was formally apprenticed. It was a nice sickly season just at this time. In commercial phrase, coffins were looking up; and, in the course of a few weeks, Oliver acquired a great deal of experience. The success of Mr. Sowerberry's ingenious speculation, exceeded even his (Sowerberry) most sanguine hopes. The oldest inhabitants recollected no period at which measles had been so prevalent, or so fatal to infant existence; and many were the mournful processions which little Oliver headed, in a hat-band reaching down to his (Oliver) knees, to the indescribable admiration and emotion of all the mothers in the town. As Oliver accompanied his (Oliver) master in most of his (Oliver) adult expeditions too, in order that he (Oliver) might acquire that equanimity of demeanour and full command of nerve which was essential to a finished undertaker, he (undertaker) had many opportunities of observing the beautiful resignation and fortitude with which some strong-minded people bear their trials and losses.

For instance; when Sowerberry had an order for the burial of some rich old lady or gentleman, who was surrounded by a great number of nephews and nieces, who had been perfectly inconsolable during the previous illness, and whose grief had been wholly irrepressible even on the most public occasions, they would be as happy among themselves as need be--quite cheerful and contented--conversing together with as much freedom and gaiety, as if nothing whatever had happened to disturb them. Husbands, too, bore the loss of their wives with the most heroic calmness. Wives, again, put on weeds for their husbands, as if, so far from grieving in the garb of sorrow, they had made up their minds to render it as becoming and attractive as possible. It was observable, too, that ladies and gentlemen who were in passions of anguish during the ceremony of interment, recovered almost as soon as they reached home, and became quite composed before the tea-drinking was over. All this was very pleasant and improving to see; and Oliver beheld it with great admiration.

That Oliver Twist was moved to resignation by the example of these good people, I cannot, although I am his (Oliver) biographer, undertake to affirm with any degree of confidence; but I can most distinctly say, that for many months he (Oliver) continued meekly to submit to the domination and ill-treatment of Noah Claypole: who used him (Claypole) far worse than before, now that his (Claypole) jealousy was roused by seeing the new boy promoted to the black stick and hatband, while he (Claypole), the old one, remained stationary in the muffin-cap and leathers. Charlotte treated him (Claypole) ill, because Noah did; and Mrs. Sowerberry was his (Noah) decided enemy, because Mr. Sowerberry was disposed to be his (Sowerberry) friend; so, between these three on one side, and a glut of funerals on the other, Oliver was not altogether as comfortable as the hungry pig was, when he (Oliver) was shut up, by mistake, in the grain department of a brewery.

And now, I come to a very important passage in Oliver's history; for I have to record an act, slight and unimportant perhaps in appearance, but which indirectly produced a material change in all his (Oliver) future prospects and proceedings.

One day, Oliver and Noah had descended into the kitchen at the usual dinner-hour, to banquet upon a small joint of mutton--a pound and a half of the worst end of the neck--when Charlotte being called out of the way, there ensued a brief interval of time, which Noah Claypole, being hungry and vicious, considered he (Claypole) could not possibly devote to a worthier purpose than aggravating and tantalising young Oliver Twist.

Intent upon this innocent amusement, Noah put his (Noah) feet on the table-cloth; and pulled Oliver's hair; and twitched his (Oliver) ears; and expressed his (Oliver) opinion that he (Oliver) was a

`sneak' (he)
; and furthermore announced his (Oliver) intention of coming to see him (Oliver) hanged, whenever that desirable event should take place; and entered upon various topics of petty annoyance, like a malicious and ill-conditioned charity-boy as he (Oliver) was. But, making Oliver cry, Noah attempted to be more facetious still; and in his (Noah) attempt, did what many sometimes do to this day, when they want to be funny. He (Noah) got rather personal.

`Work`us,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah,
`how's your mother?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`She (mother)'s dead,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver;
`don't you say anything about her (mother) to me!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver's colour rose as he (Oliver) said this; he (Oliver) breathed quickly; and there was a curious working of the mouth and nostrils, which Mr. Claypole thought must be the immediate precursor of a violent fit of crying. Under this impression he (Claypole) returned to the charge.

`What did she (mother) die of, Work`us?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.

`Of a broken heart, some of our old nurses told me,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver: more as if he (Oliver) were talking to himself, than answering Noah.
`I think I know what it must be to die of that!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`Tol de rol lol lol, right fol lairy, Work`us,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, as a tear rolled down Oliver's cheek.
`What's set you a snivelling now?' (unknown)

`Not _you_,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, sharply.
`There; that's enough. Don't say anything more to me about her (Noah); you'd better not!' (unknown)

`Better not!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
exclaimed Noah. `Well! Better not! Work`us, don't be impudent. _Your_ mother, too! She (mother) was a nice
`un she (mother) was. Oh, Lor!' (She)
And here, Noah nodded his (Noah) head expressively; and curled up as much of his (Noah) small red nose as muscular action could collect together, for the occasion.

`Yer know, Work`us,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
continued Noah, emboldened by Oliver's silence, and speaking in a jeering tone of affected pity: of all tones the most annoying: `Yer know, Work`us, it can't be helped now; and of course yer couldn't help it then; and I am very sorry for it; and I'm sure we all are, and pity yer very much. But yer must know, Work`us, yer mother was a regular right-down bad
`un.' (mother)

`What did you say?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver, looking up very quickly.

`A regular right-down bad

`un, Work`us,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah, coolly.
`And it's a great deal better, Work`us, that she (mother) died when she (mother) did, or else she (mother)'d have been hard labouring in Bridewell, or transported, or hung; which is more likely than either, isn't it?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Crimson with fury, Oliver started up; overthrew the chair and table; seized Noah by the throat; shook him (Noah), in the violence of his (Noah) rage, till his (Noah) teeth chattered in his (Noah) head; and collecting his (Noah) whole force into one heavy blow, felled him (Noah) to the ground.

A minute ago, the boy had looked the quiet child, mild, dejected creature that harsh treatment had made him (boy). But his (boy) spirit was roused at last; the cruel insult to his (boy) dead mother had set his (boy) blood on fire. His (boy) breast heaved; his (boy) attitude was erect; his (boy) eye bright and vivid; his (boy) whole person changed, as he (boy) stood glaring over the cowardly tormentor who now lay crouching at his (boy) feet; and defied him (boy) with an energy he (boy) had never known before.

`He (boy)'ll murder me!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
blubbered Noah.
`Charlotte! missis! Here's the new boy a murdering of me! Help! help! Oliver's gone mad! Char--lotte!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

Noah's shouts were responded to, by a loud scream from Charlotte, and a louder from Mrs. Sowerberry; the former of whom rushed into the kitchen by a side-door, while the latter paused on the staircase till she (Sowerberry) was quite certain that it was consistent with the preservation of human life, to come further down.

`Oh, you little wretch!' (Charlotte)
screamed Charlotte: seizing Oliver with her (Charlotte) utmost force, which was about equal to that of a moderately strong man in particularly good training.
`Oh, you little un-grate-ful, mur-de-rous, hor-rid villain!' (Charlotte)
And between every syllable, Charlotte gave Oliver a blow with all her (Charlotte) might: accompanying it with a scream, for the benefit of society.

Charlotte's fist was by no means a light one; but, lest it should not be effectual in calming Oliver's wrath, Mrs. Sowerberry plunged into the kitchen, and assisted to hold him (Oliver) with one hand, while she (Sowerberry) scratched his (Oliver) face with the other. In this favourable position of affairs, Noah rose from the ground, and pommelled him (Noah) behind.

This was rather too violent exercise to last long. When they were all wearied out, and could tear and beat no longer, they dragged Oliver, struggling and shouting, but nothing daunted, into the dust-cellar, and there locked him (Oliver) up. This being done, Mrs. Sowerberry sunk into a chair, and burst into tears.

`Bless her (Sowerberry), she (Sowerberry)'s going off!' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.
`A glass of water, Noah, dear. Make haste!' (Charlotte)

`Oh! Charlotte,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry: speaking as well as she (Sowerberry) could, through a deficiency of breath, and a sufficiency of cold water, which Noah had poured over her (Sowerberry) head and shoulders.
`Oh! Charlotte, what a mercy we have not all been murdered in our beds!' (unknown)

`Ah! mercy indeed, ma'am,' (I)
was the reply. I only hope this'll teach master not to have any more of these dreadful creatures, that are born to be murderers and robbers from their very cradle. Poor Noah! He (Noah) was all but killed, ma'am, when I come in.'

`Poor fellow!' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry: looking piteously on the charity-boy.

Noah, whose top waistcoat-button might have been somewhere on a level with the crown of Oliver's head, rubbed his (Oliver) eyes with the inside of his (Oliver) wrists while this commiseration was bestowed upon him (Oliver), and performed some affecting tears and sniffs.

`What's to be done!' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry.
`Your master's not at home; there's not a man in the house, and he (man)'ll kick that door down in ten minutes.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
Oliver's vigorous plunges against the bit of timber in question, rendered this occurance highly probable.

`Dear, dear! I don't know, ma'am,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte,
`unless we send for the police-officers.' (Charlotte)

`Or the millingtary,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
suggested Mr. Claypole.

`No, no,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry: bethinking herself of Oliver's old friend.
`Run to Mr. Bumble, Noah, and tell him (Noah) to come here directly, and not to lose a minute; never mind your cap! Make haste! You can hold a knife to that black eye, as you run along. It'll keep the swelling down.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

Noah stopped to make no reply, but started off at his (Noah) fullest speed; and very much it astonished the people who were out walking, to see a charity-boy tearing through the streets pell-mell, with no cap on his (Noah) head, and a clasp-knife at his (Noah) eye.

CHAPTER VII

OLIVER CONTINUES REFRACTORY

Noah Claypole ran along the streets at his (OLIVER) swiftest pace, and paused not once for breath, until he (OLIVER) reached the workhouse-gate. Having rested here, for a minute or so, to collect a good burst of sobs and an imposing show of tears and terror, he (OLIVER) knocked loudly at the wicket; and presented such a rueful face to the aged pauper who opened it, that even he (OLIVER), who saw nothing but rueful faces about him (OLIVER) at the best of times, started back in astonishment.

`Why, what's the matter with the boy!' (the pauper)
said the old pauper.

`Mr. Bumble! Mr. Bumble!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
cried Noah, with well-affected dismay: and in tones so loud and agitated, that they not only caught the ear of Mr. Bumble himself, who happened to be hard by, but alarmed him (Bumble) so much that he (Bumble) rushed into the yard without his (Bumble) cocked hat,--which is a very curious and remarkable circumstance: as showing that even a beadle, acted upon a sudden and powerful impulse, may be afflicted with a momentary visitation of loss of self-possession, and forgetfulness of personal dignity.

`Oh, Mr. Bumble, sir!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah:
`Oliver, sir,--Oliver has--' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`What? What?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
interposed Mr. Bumble: with a gleam of pleasure in his (Bumble) metallic eyes.
`Not run away; he (Bumble) hasn't run away, has he (Bumble), Noah?' (unknown)

`No, sir, no. Not run away, sir, but he (Noah)'s turned wicious,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`He (Noah) tried to murder me, sir; and then he (Noah) tried to murder Charlotte; and then missis. Oh! what dreadful pain it is!

Such agony, please, sir!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

And here, Noah writhed and twisted his (Noah) body into an extensive variety of eel-like positions; thereby giving Mr. Bumble to understand that, from the violent and sanguinary onset of Oliver Twist, he (Bumble) had sustained severe internal injury and damage, from which he (Bumble) was at that moment suffering the acutest torture.

When Noah saw that the intelligence he (Noah) communicated perfectly paralysed Mr. Bumble, he (Noah) imparted additional effect thereunto, by bewailing his (Noah) dreadful wounds ten times louder than before; and when he (Noah) observed a gentleman in a white waistcoat crossing the yard, he (Noah) was more tragic in his (Noah) lamentations than ever: rightly conceiving it highly expedient to attract the notice, and rouse the indignation, of the gentleman aforesaid.

The gentleman's notice was very soon attracted; for he (gentleman) had not walked three paces, when he (gentleman) turned angrily round, and inquired what that young cur was howling for, and why Mr. Bumble did not favour him (Bumble) with something which would render the series of vocular exclamations so designated, an involuntary process?

`It's a poor boy from the free-school, sir,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble,
`who has been nearly murdered--all but murdered, sir,--by young Twist.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`By Jove!' (the gentleman)
exclaimed the gentleman in the white waistcoat, stopping short.
`I knew it! I felt a strange presentiment from the very first, that that audacious young savage would come to be hung!' (the gentleman)

`He (gentleman) has likewise attempted, sir, to murder the female servant,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, with a face of ashy paleness.

`And his (Bumble) missis,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
interposed Mr. Claypole.

`And his (Bumble) master, too, I think you said, Noah?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
added Mr. Bumble.

`No! he (Bumble)'s out, or he (Bumble) would have murdered him (Bumble),' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`He (Noah) said he (Noah) wanted to.' (unknown)

`Ah! Said he (Said) wanted to, did he (Said), my boy?' (the gentleman)
inquired the gentleman in the white waistcoat.

`Yes, sir,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`And please, sir, missis wants to know whether Mr. Bumble can spare time to step up there, directly, and flog him (Bumble)--'cause master's out.' (unknown)

`Certainly, my boy; certainly,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman in the white waistcoat: smiling benignly, and patting Noah's head, which was about three inches higher than his (Noah) own.
`You're a good boy--a very good boy. Here's a penny for you. Bumble, just step up to Sowerberry's with your cane, and see what's best to be done. Don't spare him (Sowerberry), Bumble.' (unknown)

`No, I will not, sir,' (the beadle)
replied the beadle. And the cocked hat and cane having been, by this time, adjusted to their owner's satisfaction, Mr. Bumble and Noah Claypole betook themselves with all speed to the undertaker's shop.

Here the position of affairs had not at all improved. Sowerberry had not yet returned, and Oliver continued to kick, with undiminished vigour, at the cellar-door. The accounts of his (Oliver) ferocity as related by Mrs. Sowerberry and Charlotte, were of so startling a nature, that Mr. Bumble judged it prudent to parley, before opening the door. With this view he (Bumble) gave a kick at the outside, by way of prelude; and, then, applying his (Bumble) mouth to the keyhole, said, in a deep and impressive tone:

`Oliver!' (he)

`Come; you let me out!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, from the inside.

`Do you know this here voice, Oliver?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.

`Yes,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Ain't you afraid of it, sir? Ain't you a-trembling while I speak, sir?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.

`No!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, boldly.

An answer so different from the one he (Bumble) had expected to elicit, and was in the habit of receiving, staggered Mr. Bumble not a little. He (Bumble) stepped back from the keyhole; drew himself up to his (Bumble) full height; and looked from one to another of the three bystanders, in mute astonishment.

`Oh, you know, Mr. Bumble, he (Bumble) must be mad,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry.

`No boy in half his (boy) senses could venture to speak so to you.' (unknown)

`It's not Madness, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, after a few moments of deep meditation.
`It's Meat.' (unknown)

`What?' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
exclaimed Mrs. Sowerberry.

`Meat, ma'am, meat,' (unknown)
replied Bumble, with stern emphasis.
`You've over-fed him (Bumble), ma'am. You've raised a artificial soul and spirit in him (Bumble), ma'am unbecoming a person of his (Bumble) condition: as the board, Mrs. Sowerberry, who are practical philosophers, will tell you. What have paupers to do with soul or spirit? It's quite enough that we let 'em have live bodies. If you had kept the boy on gruel, ma'am, this would never have happened.' (unknown)

`Dear, dear!' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
ejaculated Mrs. Sowerberry, piously raising her (Sowerberry) eyes to the kitchen ceiling:
`this comes of being liberal!' (Mrs. Sowerberry)

The liberality of Mrs. Sowerberry to Oliver, had consisted of a profuse bestowal upon him (Oliver) of all the dirty odds and ends which nobody else would eat; so there was a great deal of meekness and self-devotion in her (Sowerberry) voluntarily remaining under Mr. Bumble's heavy accusation. Of which, to do her (Sowerberry) justice, she (Sowerberry) was wholly innocent, in thought, word, or deed.

`Ah!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, when the lady brought her (lady) eyes down to earth again;
`the only thing that can be done now, that I know of, is to leave him (Bumble) in the cellar for a day or so, till he (Bumble)'s a little starved down; and then to take him (Bumble) out, and keep him (Bumble) on gruel all through the apprenticeship. He (Bumble) comes of a bad family. Excitable natures, Mrs. Sowerberry! Both the nurse and doctor said, that that mother of his (doctor) made her (Sowerberry) way here, against difficulties and pain that would have killed any well-disposed woman, weeks before.' (the lady)

At this point of Mr. Bumble's discourse, Oliver, just hearing enough to know that some allusion was being made to his (Bumble) mother, recommenced kicking, with a violence that rendered every other sound inaudible. Sowerberry returned at this juncture. Oliver's offence having been explained to him (Sowerberry), with such exaggerations as the ladies thought best calculated to rouse his (Sowerberry) ire, he (Sowerberry) unlocked the cellar-door in a twinkling, and dragged his (Sowerberry) rebellious apprentice out, by the collar.

Oliver's clothes had been torn in the beating he (Oliver) had received; his (Oliver) face was bruised and scratched; and his (Oliver) hair scattered over his (Oliver) forehead. The angry flush had not disappeared, however; and when he (Oliver) was pulled out of his (Oliver) prison, he (Oliver) scowled boldly on Noah, and looked quite undismayed.

`Now, you are a nice young fellow, ain't you?' (Mr. Sowerberry/Sowerberry)
said Sowerberry; giving Oliver a shake, and a box on the ear.

`He (Sowerberry) called my mother names,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Well, and what if he (Oliver) did, you little ungrateful wretch?' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry.
`She (Sowerberry) deserved what he (Oliver) said, and worse.' (unknown)

`She (Sowerberry) didn't' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

`She (Sowerberry) did,' (Mrs. Sowerberry)
said Mrs. Sowerberry.

`It's a lie!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

Mrs. Sowerberry burst into a flood of tears.

This flood of tears left Mr. Sowerberry no alternative. If he (Sowerberry) had hesitated for one instant to punish Oliver most severely, it must be quite clear to every experienced reader that he (Oliver) would have been, according to all precedents in disputes of matrimony established, a brute, an unnatural husband, an insulting creature, a base imitation of a man, and various other agreeable characters too numerous for recital within the limits of this chapter. To do him (man) justice, he (man) was, as far as his (man) power went--it was not very extensive--kindly disposed towards the boy; perhaps, because it was his (man) interest to be so; perhaps, because his (man) wife disliked him (man). The flood of tears, however, left him (man) no resource; so he (man) at once gave him (man) a drubbing, which satisfied even Mrs. Sowerberry herself, and rendered Mr. Bumble's subsequent application of the parochial cane, rather unnecessary. For the rest of the day, he (Bumble) was shut up in the back kitchen, in company with a pump and a slice of bread; and at night, Mrs. Sowerberry, after making various remarks outside the door, by no means complimentary to the memory of his (Bumble) mother, looked into the room, and, amidst the jeers and pointings of Noah and Charlotte, ordered him (Noah) upstairs to his (Noah) dismal bed.

It was not until he (Noah) was left alone in the silence and stillness of the gloomy workshop of the undertaker, that Oliver gave way to the feelings which the day's treatment may be supposed likely to have awakened in a mere child. He (Oliver) had listened to their taunts with a look of contempt; he (Oliver) had borne the lash without a cry: for he (Oliver) felt that pride swelling in his (Oliver) heart which would have kept down a shriek to the last, though they had roasted him (Oliver) alive. But now, when there were none to see or hear him (Oliver), he (Oliver) fell upon his (Oliver) knees on the floor; and, hiding his (Oliver) face in his (Oliver) hands, wept such tears as, God send for the credit of our nature, few so young may ever have cause to pour out before him (God)!

For a long time, Oliver remained motionless in this attitude. The candle was burning low in the socket when he (Oliver) rose to his (Oliver) feet. Having gazed cautiously round him (Oliver), and listened intently, he (Oliver) gently undid the fastenings of the door, and looked abroad.

It was a cold, dark night. The stars seemed, to the boy's eyes, farther from the earth than he (boy) had ever seen them before; there was no wind; and the sombre shadows thrown by the trees upon the ground, looked sepulchral and death-like, from being so still. He (boy) softly reclosed the door. Having availed himself of the expiring light of the candle to tie up in a handkerchief the few articles of wearing apparel he (boy) had, sat himself down upon a bench, to wait for morning.

With the first ray of light that struggled through the crevices in the shutters, Oliver arose, and again unbarred the door. One timid look around--one moment's pause of hesitation--he (Oliver) had closed it behind him (Oliver), and was in the open street.

He (Oliver) looked to the right and to the left, uncertain whither to fly.

He (Oliver) remembered to have seen the waggons, as they went out, toiling up the hill. He (Oliver) took the same route; and arriving at a footpath across the fields: which he (Oliver) knew, after some distance, led out again into the road; struck into it, and walked quickly on.

Along this same footpath, Oliver well-remembered he (Oliver) had trotted beside Mr. Bumble, when he (Oliver) first carried him (Oliver) to the workhouse from the farm. His (Oliver) way lay directly in front of the cottage. His (Oliver) heart beat quickly when he (Oliver) bethought himself of this; and he (Oliver) half resolved to turn back. He (Oliver) had come a long way though, and should lose a great deal of time by doing so. Besides, it was so early that there was very little fear of his (Oliver) being seen; so he (Oliver) walked on.

He (Oliver) reached the house. There was no appearance of its inmates stirring at that early hour. Oliver stopped, and peeped into the garden. A child was weeding one of the little beds; as he (Oliver) stopped, he (Oliver) raised his (Oliver) pale face and disclosed the features of one of his (Oliver) former companions. Oliver felt glad to see him (Oliver), before he (Oliver) went; for, though younger than himself, he (Oliver) had been his (Oliver) little friend and playmate. They had been beaten, and starved, and shut up together, many and many a time.

`Hush, Dick!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, as the boy ran to the gate, and thrust his (Oliver) thin arm between the rails to greet him (Oliver).
`Is any one up?' (unknown)

`Nobody but me,' (the child)
replied the child.

`You musn't say you saw me, Dick,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`I am running away. They beat and ill-use me, Dick; and I am going to seek my fortune, some long way off. I don't know where. How pale you are!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`I heard the doctor tell them I was dying,' (the child)
replied the child with a faint smile.
`I am very glad to see you, dear; but don't stop, don't stop!' (the child)

`Yes, yes, I will, to say good-b`ye to you,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`I shall see you again, Dick. I know I shall! You will be well and happy!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`I hope so,' (the child)
replied the child.
`After I am dead, but not before. I know the doctor must be right, Oliver, because I dream so much of Heaven, and Angels, and kind faces that I never see when I am awake. Kiss me,' (the child)
said the child, climbing up the low gate, and flinging his (Oliver) little arms round Oliver's neck.
`Good-b`ye, dear! God bless you!' (a child)

The blessing was from a young child's lips, but it was the first that Oliver had ever heard invoked upon his (Oliver) head; and through the struggles and sufferings, and troubles and changes, of his (Oliver) after life, he (Oliver) never once forgot it.

CHAPTER VIII

OLIVER WALKS TO LONDON. HE (Oliver) ENCOUNTERS ON THE ROAD A STRANGE SORT OF YOUNG GENTLEMAN

Oliver reached the stile at which the by-path terminated; and once more gained the high-road. It was eight o'clock now. Though he (Oliver) was nearly five miles away from the town, he (Oliver) ran, and hid behind the hedges, by turns, till noon: fearing that he (Oliver) might be pursued and overtaken. Then he (Oliver) sat down to rest by the side of the milestone, and began to think, for the first time, where he (Oliver) had better go and try to live.

The stone by which he (Oliver) was seated, bore, in large characters, an intimation that it was just seventy miles from that spot to London. The name awakened a new train of ideas in the boy's mind.

London!--that great place!--nobody--not even Mr. Bumble--could ever find him (Bumble) there! He (Bumble) had often heard the old men in the workhouse, too, say that no lad of spirit need want in London; and that there were ways of living in that vast city, which those who had been bred up in country parts had no idea of. It was the very place for a homeless boy, who must die in the streets unless some one helped him (boy). As these things passed through his (boy) thoughts, he (boy) jumped upon his (boy) feet, and again walked forward.

He (boy) had diminished the distance between himself and London by full four miles more, before he (boy) recollected how much he (boy) must undergo ere he (boy) could hope to reach his (boy) place of destination. As this consideration forced itself upon him (boy), he (boy) slackened his (boy) pace a little, and meditated upon his (boy) means of getting there. He (boy) had a crust of bread, a coarse shirt, and two pairs of stockings, in his (boy) bundle. He (boy) had a penny too--a gift of Sowerberry's after some funeral in which he (Sowerberry) had acquitted himself more than ordinarily well--in his (Sowerberry) pocket.

`A clean shirt,' (he)
thought Oliver,
`is a very comfortable thing; and so are two pairs of darned stockings; and so is a penny; but they are small helps to a sixty-five miles' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
walk in winter time.' But Oliver's thoughts, like those of most other people, although they were extremely ready and active to point out his (Oliver) difficulties, were wholly at a loss to suggest any feasible mode of surmounting them; so, after a good deal of thinking to no particular purpose, he (Oliver) changed his (Oliver) little bundle over to the other shoulder, and trudged on.

Oliver walked twenty miles that day; and all that time tasted nothing but the crust of dry bread, and a few draughts of water, which he (Oliver) begged at the cottage-doors by the road-side. When the night came, he (Oliver) turned into a meadow; and, creeping close under a hay-rick, determined to lie there, till morning. He (Oliver) felt frightened at first, for the wind moaned dismally over the empty fields: and he (Oliver) was cold and hungry, and more alone than he (Oliver) had ever felt before. Being very tired with his (Oliver) walk, however, he (Oliver) soon fell asleep and forgot his (Oliver) troubles.

He (Oliver) felt cold and stiff, when he (Oliver) got up next morning, and so hungry that he (Oliver) was obliged to exchange the penny for a small loaf, in the very first village through which he (Oliver) passed. He (Oliver) had walked no more than twelve miles, when night closed in again. His (Oliver) feet were sore, and his (Oliver) legs so weak that they trembled beneath him (Oliver). Another night passed in the bleak damp air, made him (Oliver) worse; when he (Oliver) set forward on his (Oliver) journey next morning he (Oliver) could hardly crawl along.

He (Oliver) waited at the bottom of a steep hill till a stage-coach came up, and then begged of the outside passengers; but there were very few who took any notice of him (Oliver): and even those told him (Oliver) to wait till they got to the top of the hill, and then let them see how far he (Oliver) could run for a halfpenny. Poor Oliver tried to keep up with the coach a little way, but was unable to do it, by reason of his (Oliver) fatigue and sore feet. When the outsides saw this, they put their halfpence back into their pockets again, declaring that he (Oliver) was an idle young dog, and didn't deserve anything; and the coach rattled away and left only a cloud of dust behind.

In some villages, large painted boards were fixed up: warning all persons who begged within the district, that they would be sent to jail. This frightened Oliver very much, and made him (Oliver) glad to get out of those villages with all possible expedition. In others, he (Oliver) would stand about the inn-yards, and look mournfully at every one who passed: a proceeding which generally terminated in the landlady's ordering one of the post-boys who were lounging about, to drive that strange boy out of the place, for she (landlady) was sure he (boy) had come to steal something. If he (boy) begged at a farmer's house, ten to one but they threatened to set the dog on him (boy); and when he (boy) showed his (boy) nose in a shop, they talked about the beadle--which brought Oliver's heart into his (Oliver) mouth,--very often the only thing he (Oliver) had there, for many hours together.

In fact, if it had not been for a good-hearted turnpike-man, and a benevolent old lady, Oliver's troubles would have been shortened by the very same process which had put an end to his (Oliver) mother's; in other words, he (Oliver) would most assuredly have fallen dead upon the king's highway. But the turnpike-man gave him (Oliver) a meal of bread and cheese; and the old lady, who had a shipwrecked grandson wandering barefoot in some distant part of the earth, took pity upon the poor orphan, and gave him (grandson) what little she (lady) could afford--and more--with such kind and gentle words, and such tears of sympathy and compassion, that they sank deeper into Oliver's soul, than all the sufferings he (Oliver) had ever undergone.

Early on the seventh morning after he (Oliver) had left his (Oliver) native place, Oliver limped slowly into the little town of Barnet. The window-shutters were closed; the street was empty; not a soul had awakened to the business of the day. The sun was rising in all its splendid beauty; but the light only served to show the boy his (boy) own lonesomeness and desolation, as he (boy) sat, with bleeding feet and covered with dust, upon a door-step.

By degrees, the shutters were opened; the window-blinds were drawn up; and people began passing to and fro. Some few stopped to gaze at Oliver for a moment or two, or turned round to stare at him (Oliver) as they hurried by; but none relieved him (Oliver), or troubled themselves to inquire how he (Oliver) came there. He (Oliver) had no heart to beg. And there he (Oliver) sat.

He (Oliver) had been crouching on the step for some time: wondering at the great number of public-houses -LRB-every other house in Barnet was a tavern, large or small-RRB-, gazing listlessly at the coaches as they passed through, and thinking how strange it seemed that they could do, with ease, in a few hours, what it had taken him (Oliver) a whole week of courage and determination beyond his (Oliver) years to accomplish: when he (Oliver) was roused by observing that a boy, who had passed him (boy) carelessly some minutes before, had returned, and was now surveying him (boy) most earnestly from the opposite side of the way. He (boy) took little heed of this at first; but the boy remained in the same attitude of close observation so long, that Oliver raised his (Oliver) head, and returned his (Oliver) steady look. Upon this, the boy crossed over; and walking close up to Oliver, said,

`Hullo, my covey! What's the row?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The boy who addressed this inquiry to the young wayfarer, was about his (boy) own age: but one of the queerest looking boys that Oliver had even seen. He (Oliver) was a snub-nosed, flat-browed, common-faced boy enough; and as dirty a juvenile as one would wish to see; but he (boy) had about him (boy) all the airs and manners of a man. He (boy) was short of his (boy) age: with rather bow-legs, and little, sharp, ugly eyes. His (boy) hat was stuck on the top of his (boy) head so lightly, that it threatened to fall off every moment--and would have done so, very often, if the wearer had not had a knack of every now and then giving his (boy) head a sudden twitch, which brought it back to its old place again. He (boy) wore a man's coat, which reached nearly to his (boy) heels. He (boy) had turned the cuffs back, half-way up his (boy) arm, to get his (boy) hands out of the sleeves: apparently with the ultimate view of thrusting them into the pockets of his (boy) corduroy trousers; for there he (boy) kept them. He (boy) was, altogether, as roystering and swaggering a young gentleman as ever stood four feet six, or something less, in the bluchers.

`Hullo, my covey! What's the row?' (this gentleman)
said this strange young gentleman to Oliver.

`I am very hungry and tired,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver: the tears standing in his (Oliver) eyes as he (Oliver) spoke.
`I have walked a long way. I have been walking these seven days.' (he)

`Walking for sivin days!' (the gentleman)
said the young gentleman.
`Oh, I see. Beak's order, eh? But,' (he)
he (gentleman) added, noticing Oliver's look of surprise,
`I suppose you don't know what a beak is, my flash com-pan-i-on.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver mildly replied, that he (Oliver) had always heard a bird's mouth described by the term in question.

`My eyes, how green!' (the gentleman)
exclaimed the young gentleman.
`Why, a beak's a madgst`rate; and when you walk by a beak's order, it's not straight forerd, but always agoing up, and niver a coming down agin. Was you never on the mill?' (unknown)

`What mill?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver.

`What mill! Why, _the_ mill--the mill as takes up so little room that it'll work inside a Stone Jug; and always goes better when the wind's low with people, than when it's high; acos then they can't get workmen. But come,' (the gentleman)
said the young gentleman; `you want grub, and you shall have it. I'm at low-water-mark myself--only one bob and a magpie; but, as far as it goes, I'll fork out and stump. Up with you on your pins. There! Now then!
`Morrice!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Assisting Oliver to rise, the young gentleman took him (Oliver) to an adjacent chandler's shop, where he (Oliver) purchased a sufficiency of ready-dressed ham and a half-quartern loaf, or, as he (Oliver) himself expressed it,

`a fourpenny bran!' (he)
the ham being kept clean and preserved from dust, by the ingenious expedient of making a hole in the loaf by pulling out a portion of the crumb, and stuffing it therein. Taking the bread under his (ham) arm, the young gentlman turned into a small public-house, and led the way to a tap-room in the rear of the premises. Here, a pot of beer was brought in, by direction of the mysterious youth; and Oliver, falling to, at his (Oliver) new friend's bidding, made a long and hearty meal, during the progress of which the strange boy eyed him (boy) from time to time with great attention.

`Going to London?' (the boy)
said the strange boy, when Oliver had at length concluded.

`Yes.' (unknown)

`Got any lodgings?' (unknown)

`No.' (unknown)

`Money?' (unknown)

`No.' (The boy)

The strange boy whistled; and put his (boy) arms into his (boy) pockets, as far as the big coat-sleeves would let them go.

`Do you live in London?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver.

`Yes. I do, when I'm at home,' (the boy)
replied the boy.
`I suppose you want some place to sleep in to-night, don't you?' (the boy)

`I do, indeed,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
answered Oliver.
`I have not slept under a roof since I left the country.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Don't fret your eyelids on that score,' (the gentleman)
said the young gentleman. `I've got to be in London to-night; and I know a
`spectable old gentleman as lives there, wot'll give you lodgings for nothink, and never ask for the change--that is, if any genelman he (gentleman) knows interduces you. And don't he (gentleman) know me? Oh, no! Not in the least! By no means. Certainly not!' (I)

The young gentleman smiled, as if to intimate that the latter fragments of discourse were playfully ironical; and finished the beer as he (gentleman) did so.

This unexpected offer of shelter was too tempting to be resisted; especially as it was immediately followed up, by the assurance that the old gentleman referred to, would doubtless provide Oliver with a comfortable place, without loss of time. This led to a more friendly and confidential dialogue; from which Oliver discovered that his (Oliver) friend's name was Jack Dawkins, and that he (Oliver) was a peculiar pet and protege of the elderly gentleman before mentioned.

Mr. Dawkin's appearance did not say a vast deal in favour of the comforts which his (Mr.) patron's interest obtained for those whom he (Mr.) took under his (Mr.) protection; but, as he (Mr.) had a rather flightly and dissolute mode of conversing, and furthermore avowed that among his (Mr.) intimate friends he (Mr.) was better known by the sobriquet of

`The Artful Dodger,' (he)
Oliver concluded that, being of a dissipated and careless turn, the moral precepts of his (Oliver) benefactor had hitherto been thrown away upon him (Oliver). Under this impression, he (Oliver) secretly resolved to cultivate the good opinion of the old gentleman as quickly as possible; and, if he (gentleman) found the Dodger incorrigible, as he (gentleman) more than half suspected he (gentleman) should, to decline the honour of his (gentleman) farther acquaintance.

As John Dawkins objected to their entering London before nightfall, it was nearly eleven o'clock when they reached the turnpike at Islington. They crossed from the Angel into St. John's Road; struck down the small street which terminates at Sadler's Wells Theatre; through Exmouth Street and Coppice Row; down the little court by the side of the workhouse; across the classic ground which once bore the name of Hockley-in-the-Hole; thence into Little Saffron Hill; and so into Saffron Hill the Great: along which the Dodger scudded at a rapid pace, directing Oliver to follow close at his (Oliver) heels.

Although Oliver had enough to occupy his (Oliver) attention in keeping sight of his (Oliver) leader, he (Oliver) could not help bestowing a few hasty glances on either side of the way, as he (Oliver) passed along. A dirtier or more wretched place he (Oliver) had never seen. The street was very narrow and muddy, and the air was impregnated with filthy odours.

There were a good many small shops; but the only stock in trade appeared to be heaps of children, who, even at that time of night, were crawling in and out at the doors, or screaming from the inside. The sole places that seemed to prosper amid the general blight of the place, were the public-houses; and in them, the lowest orders of Irish were wrangling with might and main. Covered ways and yards, which here and there diverged from the main street, disclosed little knots of houses, where drunken men and women were positively wallowing in filth; and from several of the door-ways, great ill-looking fellows were cautiously emerging, bound, to all appearance, on no very well-disposed or harmless errands.

Oliver was just considering whether he (Oliver) hadn't better run away, when they reached the bottom of the hill. His (Oliver) conductor, catching him (Oliver) by the arm, pushed open the door of a house near Field Lane; and drawing him (Oliver) into the passage, closed it behind them.

`Now, then!' (the Dodger)
cried a voice from below, in reply to a whistle from the Dodger.

`Plummy and slam!' (unknown)
was the reply.

This seemed to be some watchword or signal that all was right; for the light of a feeble candle gleamed on the wall at the remote end of the passage; and a man's face peeped out, from where a balustrade of the old kitchen staircase had been broken away.

`There's two on you,' (the man)
said the man, thrusting the candle farther out, and shielding his (man) eyes with his (man) hand.
`Who's the t`other one?' (unknown)

`A new pal,' (Jack Dawkins/Jack)
replied Jack Dawkins, pulling Oliver forward.

`Where did he (Oliver) come from?' (unknown)

`Greenland. Is Fagin upstairs?' (unknown)

`Yes, he (Fagin)'s a sortin' (unknown)
the wipes. Up with you!' The candle was drawn back, and the face disappeared.

Oliver, groping his (Oliver) way with one hand, and having the other firmly grasped by his (Oliver) companion, ascended with much difficulty the dark and broken stairs: which his (Oliver) conductor mounted with an ease and expedition that showed he (Oliver) was well acquainted with them.

He (Oliver) threw open the door of a back-room, and drew Oliver in after him (Oliver).

The walls and ceiling of the room were perfectly black with age and dirt. There was a deal table before the fire: upon which were a candle, stuck in a ginger-beer bottle, two or three pewter pots, a loaf and butter, and a plate. In a frying-pan, which was on the fire, and which was secured to the mantelshelf by a string, some sausages were cooking; and standing over them, with a toasting-fork in his (Oliver) hand, was a very old shrivelled Jew, whose villainous-looking and repulsive face was obscured by a quantity of matted red hair. He (Oliver) was dressed in a greasy flannel gown, with his (Oliver) throat bare; and seemed to be dividing his (Oliver) attention between the frying-pan and the clothes-horse, over which a great number of silk handkerchiefs were hanging. Several rough beds made of old sacks, were huddled side by side on the floor. Seated round the table were four or five boys, none older than the Dodger, smoking long clay pipes, and drinking spirits with the air of middle-aged men. These all crowded about their associate as he (associate) whispered a few words to the Jew; and then turned round and grinned at Oliver. So did the Jew himself, toasting-fork in hand.

`This is him (Oliver), Fagin,' (Jack Dawkins/Jack)
said Jack Dawkins;`my friend Oliver Twist.'

The Jew grinned; and, making a low obeisance to Oliver, took him (Oliver) by the hand, and hoped he (Oliver) should have the honour of his (Oliver) intimate acquaintance. Upon this, the young gentleman with the pipes came round him (gentleman), and shook both his (gentleman) hands very hard--especially the one in which he (gentleman) held his (gentleman) little bundle. One young gentleman was very anxious to hang up his (gentleman) cap for him (gentleman); and another was so obliging as to put his (gentleman) hands in his (gentleman) pockets, in order that, as he (gentleman) was very tired, he (gentleman) might not have the trouble of emptying them, himself, when he (gentleman) went to bed. These civilities would probably be extended much farther, but for a liberal exercise of the Jew's toasting-fork on the heads and shoulders of the affectionate youths who offered them.

`We are very glad to see you, Oliver, very,' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`Dodger, take off the sausages; and draw a tub near the fire for Oliver. Ah, you're a-staring at the pocket-handkerchiefs! eh, my dear. There are a good many of 'em, ain't there? We've just looked 'em out, ready for the wash; that's all, Oliver; that's all. Ha! ha! ha!' (the pupils)

The latter part of this speech, was hailed by a boisterous shout from all the hopeful pupils of the merry old gentleman. In the midst of which they went to supper.

Oliver ate his (Oliver) share, and the Jew then mixed him (Oliver) a glass of hot gin-and-water: telling him (Oliver) he (Oliver) must drink it off directly, because another gentleman wanted the tumbler. Oliver did as he (Oliver) was desired. Immediately afterwards he (Oliver) felt himself gently lifted on to one of the sacks; and then he (Oliver) sunk into a deep sleep.

CHAPTER IX

CONTAINING FURTHER PARTICULARS CONCERNING THE PLEASANT OLD GENTLEMAN, AND HIS (GENTLEMAN) HOPEFUL PUPILS

It was late next morning when Oliver awoke, from a sound, long sleep. There was no other person in the room but the old Jew, who was boiling some coffee in a saucepan for breakfast, and whistling softly to himself as he (Jew) stirred it round and round, with an iron spoon. He (Jew) would stop every now and then to listen when there was the least noise below: and when he (Jew) had satisfied himself, he (Jew) would go on whistling and stirring again, as before.

Although Oliver had roused himself from sleep, he (Oliver) was not thoroughly awake. There is a drowsy state, between sleeping and waking, when you dream more in five minutes with your eyes half open, and yourself half conscious of everything that is passing around you, than you would in five nights with your eyes fast closed, and your senses wrapt in perfect unconsciousness. At such time, a mortal knows just enough of what his (Oliver) mind is doing, to form some glimmering conception of its mighty powers, its bounding from earth and spurning time and space, when freed from the restraint of its corporeal associate.

Oliver was precisely in this condition. He (Oliver) saw the Jew with his (Oliver) half-closed eyes; heard his (Oliver) low whistling; and recognised the sound of the spoon grating against the saucepan's sides: and yet the self-same senses were mentally engaged, at the same time, in busy action with almost everybody he (Oliver) had ever known.

When the coffee was done, the Jew drew the saucepan to the hob. Standing, then in an irresolute attitude for a few minutes, as if he (Jew) did not well know how to employ himself, he (Jew) turned round and looked at Oliver, and called him (Oliver) by his (Oliver) name. He (Oliver) did not answer, and was to all appearances asleep.

After satisfying himself upon this head, the Jew stepped gently to the door: which he (Jew) fastened. He (Jew) then drew forth: as it seemed to Oliver, from some trap in the floor: a small box, which he (Oliver) placed carefully on the table. His (Oliver) eyes glistened as he (Oliver) raised the lid, and looked in. Dragging an old chair to the table, he (Oliver) sat down; and took from it a magnificent gold watch, sparkling with jewels.

`Aha!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, shrugging up his (Jew) shoulders, and distorting every feature with a hideous grin.
`Clever dogs! Clever dogs! Staunch to the last! Never told the old parson where they were. Never poached upon old Fagin! And why should they? It wouldn't have loosened the knot, or kept the drop up, a minute longer. No, no, no! Fine fellows! Fine fellows!' (the Jew)

With these, and other muttered reflections of the like nature, the Jew once more deposited the watch in its place of safety. At least half a dozen more were severally drawn forth from the same box, and surveyed with equal pleasure; besides rings, brooches, bracelets, and other articles of jewellery, of such magnificent materials, and costly workmanship, that Oliver had no idea, even of their names.

Having replaced these trinkets, the Jew took out another: so small that it lay in the palm of his (Jew) hand. There seemed to be some very minute inscription on it; for the Jew laid it flat upon the table, and shading it with his (Jew) hand, pored over it, long and earnestly. At length he (Jew) put it down, as if despairing of success; and, leaning back in his (Jew) chair, muttered:

`What a fine thing capital punishment is! Dead men never repent; dead men never bring awkward stories to light. Ah, it's a fine thing for the trade! Five of 'em strung up in a row, and none left to play booty, or turn white-livered!' (he)

As the Jew uttered these words, his (Jew) bright dark eyes, which had been staring vacantly before him (Jew), fell on Oliver's face; the boy's eyes were fixed on his (Oliver) in mute curiousity; and although the recognition was only for an instant--for the briefest space of time that can possibly be conceived--it was enough to show the old man that he (man) had been observed.

He (man) closed the lid of the box with a loud crash; and, laying his (man) hand on a bread knife which was on the table, started furiously up. He (man) trembled very much though; for, even in his (man) terror, Oliver could see that the knife quivered in the air.

`What's that?' (the Jew)
said the Jew. `What do you watch me for? Why are you awake? What have you seen? Speak out, boy! Quick--quick! for your life.

`I wasn't able to sleep any longer, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, meekly.
`I am very sorry if I have disturbed you, sir.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`You were not awake an hour ago?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, scowling fiercely on the boy.

`No! No, indeed!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Are you sure?' (the Jew)
cried the Jew: with a still fiercer look than before: and a threatening attitude.

`Upon my word I was not, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, earnestly.
`I was not, indeed, sir.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Tush, tush, my dear!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, abruptly resuming his (Jew) old manner, and playing with the knife a little, before he (Jew) laid it down; as if to induce the belief that he (Jew) had caught it up, in mere sport.
`Of course I know that, my dear. I only tried to frighten you. You're a brave boy. Ha! ha! you're a brave boy, Oliver.' (The Jew)
The Jew rubbed his (Jew) hands with a chuckle, but glanced uneasily at the box, notwithstanding.

`Did you see any of these pretty things, my dear?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, laying his (Jew) hand upon it after a short pause.

`Yes, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Ah!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning rather pale.
`They--they're mine, Oliver; my little property. All I have to live upon, in my old age. The folks call me a miser, my dear. Only a miser; that's all.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver thought the old gentleman must be a decided miser to live in such a dirty place, with so many watches; but, thinking that perhaps his (Oliver) fondness for the Dodger and the other boys, cost him (Oliver) a good deal of money, he (Oliver) only cast a deferential look at the Jew, and asked if he (Jew) might get up.

`Certainly, my dear, certainly,' (the gentleman)
replied the old gentleman.
`Stay. There's a pitcher of water in the corner by the door. Bring it here; and I'll give you a basin to wash in, my dear.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver got up; walked across the room; and stooped for an instant to raise the pitcher. When he (Oliver) turned his (Oliver) head, the box was gone.

He (Oliver) had scarcely washed himself, and made everything tidy, by emptying the basin out of the window, agreeably to the Jew's directions, when the Dodger returned: accompanied by a very sprightly young friend, whom Oliver had seen smoking on the previous night, and who was now formally introduced to him (Oliver) as Charley Bates. The four sat down, to breakfast, on the coffee, and some hot rolls and ham which the Dodger had brought home in the crown of his (Dodger) hat.

`Well,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, glancing slyly at Oliver, and addressing himself to the Dodger,
`I hope you've been at work this morning, my dears?' (the Dodger)

`Hard,' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger.

`As nails,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
added Charley Bates.

`Good boys, good boys!' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`What have you got, Dodger?' (unknown)

`A couple of pocket-books,' (gentlman)
replied that young gentlman.

`Lined?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew, with eagerness.

`Pretty well,' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger, producing two pocket-books; one green, and the other red.

`Not so heavy as they might be,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, after looking at the insides carefully;
`but very neat and nicely made. Ingenious workman, ain't he (workman), Oliver?' (the Jew)

`Very indeed, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver. At which Mr. Charles Bates laughed uproariously; very much to the amazement of Oliver, who saw nothing to laugh at, in anything that had passed.

`And what have you got, my dear?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin to Charley Bates.

`Wipes,' (Master)
replied Master Bates; at the same time producing four pocket-handkerchiefs.

`Well,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, inspecting them closely;
`they're very good ones, very. You haven't marked them well, though, Charley; so the marks shall be picked out with a needle, and we'll teach Oliver how to do it. Shall us, Oliver, eh? Ha! ha! ha!' (the Jew)

`If you please, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

`You'd like to be able to make pocket-handkerchiefs as easy as Charley Bates, wouldn't you, my dear?' (the Jew)
said the Jew.

`Very much, indeed, if you'll teach me, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

Master Bates saw something so exquisitely ludicrous in this reply, that he (Oliver) burst into another laugh; which laugh, meeting the coffee he (Oliver) was drinking, and carrying it down some wrong channel, very nearly terminated in his (Oliver) premature suffocation.

`He (Oliver) is so jolly green!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley when he (Charley) recovered, as an apology to the company for his (Charley) unpolite behaviour.

The Dodger said nothing, but he (Dodger) smoothed Oliver's hair over his (Oliver) eyes, and said he (Oliver)'d know better, by and by; upon which the old gentleman, observing Oliver's colour mounting, changed the subject by asking whether there had been much of a crowd at the execution that morning? This made him (Oliver) wonder more and more; for it was plain from the replies of the two boys that they had both been there; and Oliver naturally wondered how they could possibly have found time to be so very industrious.

When the breakfast was cleared away; the merry old gentlman and the two boys played at a very curious and uncommon game, which was performed in this way. The merry old gentleman, placing a snuff-box in one pocket of his (gentleman) trousers, a note-case in the other, and a watch in his (gentleman) waistcoat pocket, with a guard-chain round his (gentleman) neck, and sticking a mock diamond pin in his (gentleman) shirt: buttoned his (gentleman) coat tight round him (gentleman), and putting his (gentleman) spectacle-case and handkerchief in his (gentleman) pockets, trotted up and down the room with a stick, in imitation of the manner in which old gentlemen walk about the streets any hour in the day. Sometimes he (gentleman) stopped at the fire-place, and sometimes at the door, making believe that he (gentleman) was staring with all his (gentleman) might into shop-windows. At such times, he (gentleman) would look constantly round him (gentleman), for fear of thieves, and would keep slapping all his (gentleman) pockets in turn, to see that he (gentleman) hadn't lost anything, in such a very funny and natural manner, that Oliver laughed till the tears ran down his (Oliver) face. All this time, the two boys followed him (Oliver) closely about: getting out of his (Oliver) sight, so nimbly, every time he (Oliver) turned round, that it was impossible to follow their motions. At last, the Dodger trod upon his (Dodger) toes, or ran upon his (Dodger) boot accidently, while Charley Bates stumbled up against him (Bates) behind; and in that one moment they took from him (Bates), with the most extraordinary rapidity, snuff-box, note-case, watch-guard, chain, shirt-pin, pocket-handkerchief, even the spectacle-case. If the old gentlman felt a hand in any one of his (Bates) pockets, he (Bates) cried out where it was; and then the game began all over again.
