When this game had been played a great many times, a couple of young ladies called to see the young gentleman; one of whom was named Bet, and the other Nancy. They wore a good deal of hair, not very neatly turned up behind, and were rather untidy about the shoes and stockings. They were not exactly pretty, perhaps; but they had a great deal of colour in their faces, and looked quite stout and hearty. Being remarkably free and agreeable in their manners, Oliver thought them very nice girls indeed. As there is no doubt they were.

The visitors stopped a long time. Spirits were produced, in consequence of one of the young ladies complaining of a coldness in her (they) inside; and the conversation took a very convivial and improving turn. At length, Charley Bates expressed his (Bates) opinion that it was time to pad the hoof. This, it occurred to Oliver, must be French for going out; for directly afterwards, the Dodger, and Charley, and the two young ladies, went away together, having been kindly furnished by the amiable old Jew with money to spend.

`There, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`That's a pleasant life, isn't it? They have gone out for the day.' (unknown)

`Have they done work, sir?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver.

`Yes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew;
`that is, unless they should unexpectedly come across any, when they are out; and they won't neglect it, if they do, my dear, depend upon it. Make 'em your models, my dear. Make 'em your models,' (the Jew)
tapping the fire-shovel on the hearth to add force to his (Jew) words;
`do everything they bid you, and take their advice in all matters--especially the Dodger's, my dear. He (Dodger)'ll be a great man himself, and will make you one too, if you take pattern by him (Dodger).--Is my handkerchief hanging out of my pocket, my dear?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, stopping short.

`Yes, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

`See if you can take it out, without my feeling it; as you saw them do, when we were at play this morning.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver held up the bottom of the pocket with one hand, as he (Oliver) had seen the Dodger hold it, and drew the handkerchief lightly out of it with the other.

`Is it gone?' (the Jew)
cried the Jew.

`Here it is, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, showing it in his (Oliver) hand.

`You're a clever boy, my dear,' (the gentleman)
said the playful old gentleman, patting Oliver on the head approvingly.
`I never saw a sharper lad. Here's a shilling for you. If you go on, in this way, you'll be the greatest man of the time. And now come here, and I'll show you how to take the marks out of the handkerchiefs.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver wondered what picking the old gentleman's pocket in play, had to do with his (Oliver) chances of being a great man. But, thinking that the Jew, being so much his (Jew) senior, must know best, he (Jew) followed him (Jew) quietly to the table, and was soon deeply involved in his (Jew) new study.

CHAPTER X

OLIVER BECOMES BETTER ACQUAINTED WITH THE CHARACTERS OF HIS (OLIVER) NEW ASSOCIATES; AND PURCHASES EXPERIENCE AT A HIGH PRICE. BEING A SHORT, BUT VERY IMPORTANT CHAPTER, IN THIS HISTORY

For many days, Oliver remained in the Jew's room, picking the marks out of the pocket-handkerchief, -LRB-of which a great number were brought home,-RRB- and sometimes taking part in the game already described: which the two boys and the Jew played, regularly, every morning. At length, he (Jew) began to languish for fresh air, and took many occasions of earnestly entreating the old gentleman to allow him (gentleman) to go out to work with his (gentleman) two companions.

Oliver was rendered the more anxious to be actively employed, by what he (Oliver) had seen of the stern morality of the old gentleman's character. Whenever the Dodger or Charley Bates came home at night, empty-handed, he (Dodger) would expatiate with great vehemence on the misery of idle and lazy habits; and would enforce upon them the necessity of an active life, by sending them supperless to bed. On one occasion, indeed, he (Dodger) even went so far as to knock them both down a flight of stairs; but this was carrying out his (Dodger) virtuous precepts to an unusual extent.

At length, one morning, Oliver obtained the permission he (Oliver) had so eagerly sought. There had been no handkerchiefs to work upon, for two or three days, and the dinners had been rather meagre. Perhaps these were reasons for the old gentleman's giving his (gentleman) assent; but, whether they were or no, he (gentleman) told Oliver he (Oliver) might go, and placed him (Oliver) under the joint guardianship of Charley Bates, and his (Bates) friend the Dodger.

The three boys sallied out; the Dodger with his (Dodger) coat-sleeves tucked up, and his (Dodger) hat cocked, as usual; Master Bates sauntering along with his (Bates) hands in his (Bates) pockets; and Oliver between them, wondering where they were going, and what branch of manufacture he (Oliver) would be instructed in, first.

The pace at which they went, was such a very lazy, ill-looking saunter, that Oliver soon began to think his (Oliver) companions were going to deceive the old gentleman, by not going to work at all. The Dodger had a vicious propensity, too, of pulling the caps from the heads of small boys and tossing them down areas; while Charley Bates exhibited some very loose notions concerning the rights of property, by pilfering divers apples and onions from the stalls at the kennel sides, and thrusting them into pockets which were so surprisingly capacious, that they seemed to undermine his (Bates) whole suit of clothes in every direction. These things looked so bad, that Oliver was on the point of declaring his (Oliver) intention of seeking his (Oliver) way back, in the best way he (Oliver) could; when his (Oliver) thoughts were suddenly directed into another channel, by a very mysterious change of behaviour on the part of the Dodger.

They were just emerging from a narrow court not far from the open square in Clerkenwell, which is yet called, by some strange perversion of terms,

`The Green' (the Dodger)
: when the Dodger made a sudden stop; and, laying his (Dodger) finger on his (Dodger) lip, drew his (Dodger) companions back again, with the greatest caution and circumspection.

`What's the matter?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
demanded Oliver.

`Hush!' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger.
`Do you see that old cove at the book-stall?' (unknown)

`The old gentleman over the way?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`Yes, I see him (Oliver).' (unknown)

`He (Oliver)'ll do,' (unknown)
said the Doger.

`A prime plant,' (Master)
observed Master Charley Bates.

Oliver looked from one to the other, with the greatest surprise; but he (Oliver) was not permitted to make any inquiries; for the two boys walked stealthily across the road, and slunk close behind the old gentleman towards whom his (gentleman) attention had been directed. Oliver walked a few paces after them; and, not knowing whether to advance or retire, stood looking on in silent amazement.

The old gentleman was a very respectable-looking personage, with a powdered head and gold spectacles. He (gentleman) was dressed in a bottle-green coat with a black velvet collar; wore white trousers; and carried a smart bamboo cane under his (gentleman) arm. He (gentleman) had taken up a book from the stall, and there he (gentleman) stood, reading away, as hard as if he (gentleman) were in his (gentleman) elbow-chair, in his (gentleman) own study. It is very possible that he (gentleman) fancied himself there, indeed; for it was plain, from his (gentleman) abstraction, that he (gentleman) saw not the book-stall, nor the street, nor the boys, nor, in short, anything but the book itself: which he (gentleman) was reading straight through: turning over the leaf when he (gentleman) got to the bottom of a page, beginning at the top line of the next one, and going regularly on, with the greatest interest and eagerness.

What was Oliver's horror and alarm as he (Oliver) stood a few paces off, looking on with his (Oliver) eyelids as wide open as they would possibly go, to see the Dodger plunge his (Dodger) hand into the old gentleman's pocket, and draw from thence a handkerchief! To see him (Dodger) hand the same to Charley Bates; and finally to behold them, both running away round the corner at full speed!

In an instant the whole mystery of the hankerchiefs, and the watches, and the jewels, and the Jew, rushed upon the boy's mind.

He (boy) stood, for a moment, with the blood so tingling through all his (boy) veins from terror, that he (boy) felt as if he (boy) were in a burning fire; then, confused and frightened, he (boy) took to his (boy) heels; and, not knowing what he (boy) did, made off as fast as he (boy) could lay his (boy) feet to the ground.

This was all done in a minute's space. In the very instant when Oliver began to run, the old gentleman, putting his (Oliver) hand to his (Oliver) pocket, and missing his (Oliver) handkerchief, turned sharp round. Seeing the boy scudding away at such a rapid pace, he (Oliver) very naturally concluded him (Oliver) to be the depredator; and shouting

`Stop thief!' (him)
with all his (Oliver) might, made off after him (Oliver), book in hand.

But the old gentleman was not the only person who raised the hue-and-cry. The Dodger and Master Bates, unwilling to attract public attention by running down the open street, had merely retired into the very first doorway round the corner. They no sooner heard the cry, and saw Oliver running, than, guessing exactly how the matter stood, they issued forth with great promptitude; and, shouting

`Stop thief!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
too, joined in the pursuit like good citizens.

Although Oliver had been brought up by philosophers, he (Oliver) was not theoretically acquainted with the beautiful axiom that self-preservation is the first law of nature. If he (Oliver) had been, perhaps he (Oliver) would have been prepared for this. Not being prepared, however, it alarmed him (Oliver) the more; so away he (Oliver) went like the wind, with the old gentleman and the two boys roaring and shouting behind him (gentleman).

`Stop thief! Stop thief!' (unknown)
There is a magic in the sound. The tradesman leaves his (tradesman) counter, and the car-man his (tradesman) waggon; the butcher throws down his (tradesman) tray; the baker his (tradesman) basket; the milkman his (tradesman) pail; the errand-boy his (tradesman) parcels; the school-boy his (tradesman) marbles; the paviour his (tradesman) pickaxe; the child his (tradesman) battledore. Away they run, pell-mell, helter-skelter, slap-dash: tearing, yelling, screaming, knocking down the passengers as they turn the corners, rousing up the dogs, and astonishing the fowls: and streets, squares, and courts, re-echo with the sound.

`Stop thief! Stop thief!' (unknown)
The cry is taken up by a hundred voices, and the crowd accumulate at every turning. Away they fly, splashing through the mud, and rattling along the pavements: up go the windows, out run the people, onward bear the mob, a whole audience desert Punch in the very thickest of the plot, and, joining the rushing throng, swell the shout, and lend fresh vigour to the cry,
`Stop thief! Stop thief!' (audience)

`Stop thief! Stop thief!' (unknown)
There is a passion FOR _hunting_ _something_ deeply implanted in the human breast. One wretched breathless child, panting with exhaustion; terror in his (thief) looks; agony in his (thief) eyes; large drops of perspiration streaming down his (thief) face; strains every nerve to make head upon his (thief) pursuers; and as they follow on his (thief) track, and gain upon him (thief) every instant, they hail his (thief) decreasing strength with joy.
`Stop thief!' (him)
Ay, stop him (thief) for God's sake, were it only in mercy!

Stopped at last! A clever blow. He (thief) is down upon the pavement; and the crowd eagerly gather round him (thief): each new comer, jostling and struggling with the others to catch a glimpse.

`Stand aside!' (unknown)
`Give him (thief) a little air!' (unknown)
`Nonsense! he (thief) don't deserve it.' (unknown)
`Where's the gentleman?' (unknown)
`Here his (gentleman) is, coming down the street.' (unknown)
`Make room there for the gentleman!' (unknown)
`Is this the boy, sir!' (unknown)
`Yes.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver lay, covered with mud and dust, and bleeding from the mouth, looking wildly round upon the heap of faces that surrounded him (Oliver), when the old gentleman was officiously dragged and pushed into the circle by the foremost of the pursuers.

`Yes,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman,
`I am afraid it is the boy.' (the gentleman)

`Afraid!' (unknown)
murmured the crowd. `That's a good
`un!' (unknown)

`Poor fellow!' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman,
`he (gentleman) has hurt himself.' (the gentleman)

`_I_ did that, sir,' (the gentleman)
said a great lubberly fellow, stepping forward;
`and preciously I cut my knuckle agin' (a fellow)
his (fellow) mouth. I stopped him (fellow), sir.'

The follow touched his (fellow) hat with a grin, expecting something for his (fellow) pains; but, the old gentleman, eyeing him (gentleman) with an expression of dislike, look anxiously round, as if he (gentleman) contemplated running away himself: which it is very possible he (gentleman) might have attempted to do, and thus have afforded another chase, had not a police officer -LRB-who is generally the last person to arrive in such cases-RRB- at that moment made his (officer) way through the crowd, and seized Oliver by the collar.

`Come, get up,' (the man)
said the man, roughly.

`It wasn't me indeed, sir. Indeed, indeed, it was two other boys,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, clasping his (Oliver) hands passionately, and looking round.
`They are here somewhere.' (unknown)

`Oh no, they ain't,' (the officer)
said the officer. He (officer) meant this to be ironical, but it was true besides; for the Dodger and Charley Bates had filed off down the first convenient court they came to.

`Come, get up!' (unknown)

`Don't hurt him (Dodger),' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, compassionately.

`Oh no, I won't hurt him (gentleman),' (the officer)
replied the officer, tearing his (officer) jacket half off his (officer) back, in proof thereof.
`Come, I know you; it won't do. Will you stand upon your legs, you young devil?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver, who could hardly stand, made a shift to raise himself on his (Oliver) feet, and was at once lugged along the streets by the jacket-collar, at a rapid pace. The gentleman walked on with them by the officer's side; and as many of the crowd as could achieve the feat, got a little ahead, and stared back at Oliver from time to time. The boys shouted in triumph; and on they went.

CHAPTER XI

TREATS OF MR. FANG THE POLICE MAGISTRATE; AND FURNISHES A SLIGHT SPECIMEN OF HIS (Oliver) MODE OF ADMINISTERING JUSTICE

The offence had been committed within the district, and indeed in the immediate neighborhood of, a very notorious metropolitan police office. The crowd had only the satisfaction of accompanying Oliver through two or three streets, and down a place called Mutton Hill, when he (Oliver) was led beneath a low archway, and up a dirty court, into this dispensary of summary justice, by the back way. It was a small paved yard into which they turned; and here they encountered a stout man with a bunch of whiskers on his (man) face, and a bunch of keys in his (man) hand.

`What's the matter now?' (the man)
said the man carelessly.

`A young fogle-hunter,' (the man)
replied the man who had Oliver in charge.

`Are you the party that's been robbed, sir?' (the man)
inquired the man with the keys.

`Yes, I am,' (the gentleman)
replied the old gentleman;
`but I am not sure that this boy actually took the handkerchief. I--I would rather not press the case.' (the gentleman)

`Must go before the magistrate now, sir,' (the man)
replied the man.
`His (man) worship will be disengaged in half a minute. Now, young gallows!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

This was an invitation for Oliver to enter through a door which he (Oliver) unlocked as he (Oliver) spoke, and which led into a stone cell. Here he (Oliver) was searched; and nothing being found upon him (Oliver), locked up.

This cell was in shape and size something like an area cellar, only not so light. It was most intolerably dirty; for it was Monday morning; and it had been tenanted by six drunken people, who had been locked up, elsewhere, since Saturday night. But this is little. In our station-houses, men and women are every night confined on the most trivial charges--the word is worth noting--in dungeons, compared with which, those in Newgate, occupied by the most atrocious felons, tried, found guilty, and under sentence of death, are palaces. Let any one who doubts this, compare the two.

The old gentleman looked almost as rueful as Oliver when the key grated in the lock. He (Oliver) turned with a sigh to the book, which had been the innocent cause of all this disturbance.

`There is something in that boy's face,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman to himself as he (gentleman) walked slowly away, tapping his (gentleman) chin with the cover of the book, in a thoughtful manner;
`something that touches and interests me. _Can_ he (gentleman) be innocent? He (gentleman) looked like--Bye the bye,' (he)
exclaimed the old gentleman, halting very abruptly, and staring up into the sky,
`Bless my soul!--where have I seen something like that look before?' (the gentleman)

After musing for some minutes, the old gentleman walked, with the same meditative face, into a back anteroom opening from the yard; and there, retiring into a corner, called up before his (gentleman) mind's eye a vast amphitheatre of faces over which a dusky curtain had hung for many years.

`No,' (the gentleman imagination)
said the old gentleman, shaking his (gentleman) head; `it must be imagination.

He (gentleman) wandered over them again. He (gentleman) had called them into view, and it was not easy to replace the shroud that had so long concealed them. There were the faces of friends, and foes, and of many that had been almost strangers peering intrusively from the crowd; there were the faces of young and blooming girls that were now old women; there were faces that the grave had changed and closed upon, but which the mind, superior to its power, still dressed in their old freshness and beauty, calling back the lustre of the eyes, the brightness of the smile, the beaming of the soul through its mask of clay, and whispering of beauty beyond the tomb, changed but to be heightened, and taken from earth only to be set up as a light, to shed a soft and gentle glow upon the path to Heaven.

But the old gentleman could recall no one countenance of which Oliver's features bore a trace. So, he (Oliver) heaved a sigh over the recollections he (Oliver) awakened; and being, happily for himself, an absent old gentleman, buried them again in the pages of the musty book.

He (gentleman) was roused by a touch on the shoulder, and a request from the man with the keys to follow him (man) into the office. He (man) closed his (man) book hastily; and was at once ushered into the imposing presence of the renowned Mr. Fang.

The office was a front parlour, with a panelled wall. Mr. Fang sat behind a bar, at the upper end; and on one side the door was a sort of wooden pen in which poor little Oliver was already deposited; trembling very much at the awfulness of the scene.

Mr. Fang was a lean, long-backed, stiff-necked, middle-sized man, with no great quantity of hair, and what he (Fang) had, growing on the back and sides of his (Fang) head. His (Fang) face was stern, and much flushed. If he (Fang) were really not in the habit of drinking rather more than was exactly good for him (Fang), he (Fang) might have brought action against his (Fang) countenance for libel, and have recovered heavy damages.

The old gentleman bowed respectfully; and advancing to the magistrate's desk, said, suiting the action to the word,

`That is my name and address, sir.' (the magistrate)
He (gentleman) then withdrew a pace or two; and, with another polite and gentlemanly inclination of the head, waited to be questioned.

Now, it so happened that Mr. Fang was at that moment perusing a leading article in a newspaper of the morning, adverting to some recent decision of his (Fang), and commending him (Fang), for the three hundred and fiftieth time, to the special and particular notice of the Secretary of State for the Home Department. He (Secretary) was out of temper; and he (Secretary) looked up with an angry scowl.

`Who are you?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang.

The old gentleman pointed, with some surprise, to his (gentleman) card.

`Officer!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang, tossing the card contemptuously away with the newspaper.
`Who is this fellow?' (unknown)

`My name, sir,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, speaking _like_ a gentleman,
`my name, sir, is Brownlow. Permit me to inquire the name of the magistrate who offers a gratuitous and unprovoked insult to a respectable person, under the protection of the bench.' (a gentleman)
Saying this, Mr. Brownlow looked around the office as if in search of some person who would afford him (Brownlow) the required information.

`Officer!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang, throwing the paper on one side,
`what's this fellow charged with?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)

`He (Fang)'s not charged at all, your worship,' (the officer)
replied the officer.
`He (officer) appears against this boy, your worship.' (unknown)

His (officer) worship knew this perfectly well; but it was a good annoyance, and a safe one.

`Appears against the boy, does he (boy)?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang, surveying Mr. Brownlow contemptuously from head to foot.
`Swear him (Fang)!' (unknown)

`Before I am sworn, I must beg to say one word,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`and that is, that I really never, without actual experience, could have believed--' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Hold your tongue, sir!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Fang, peremptorily.

`I will not, sir!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
replied the old gentleman.

`Hold your tongue this instant, or I'll have you turned out of the office!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang.
`You're an insolent impertinent fellow. How dare you bully a magistrate!' (unknown)

`What!' (the gentleman)
exclaimed the old gentleman, reddening.

`Swear this person!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Fang to the clerk.
`I'll not hear another word. Swear him (Fang).' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Mr. Brownlow's indignation was greatly roused; but reflecting perhaps, that he (Brownlow) might only injure the boy by giving vent to it, he (Brownlow) suppressed his (Brownlow) feelings and submitted to be sworn at once.

`Now,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Fang,
`what's the charge against this boy? What have you got to say, sir?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)

`I was standing at a bookstall--' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
Mr. Brownlow began.

`Hold your tongue, sir,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang.
`Policeman! Where's the policeman? Here, swear this policeman. Now, policeman, what is this?' (The policeman)

The policeman, with becoming humility, related how he (policeman) had taken the charge; how he (policeman) had searched Oliver, and found nothing on his (policeman) person; and how that was all he (policeman) knew about it.

`Are there any witnesses?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
inquired Mr. Fang.

`None, your worship,' (the policeman)
replied the policeman.

Mr. Fang sat silent for some minutes, and then, turning round to the prosecutor, said in a towering passion.

`Do you mean to state what your complaint against this boy is, man, or do you not? You have been sworn. Now, if you stand there, refusing to give evidence, I'll punish you for disrespect to the bench; I will, by--' (nobody)

By what, or by whom, nobody knows, for the clerk and jailor coughed very loud, just at the right moment; and the former dropped a heavy book upon the floor, thus preventing the word from being heard--accidently, of course.

With many interruptions, and repeated insults, Mr. Brownlow contrived to state his (Brownlow) case; observing that, in the surprise of the moment, he (Brownlow) had run after the boy because he (Brownlow) had saw him (Brownlow) running away; and expressing his (Brownlow) hope that, if the magistrate should believe him (Brownlow), although not actually the thief, to be connected with the thieves, he (thief) would deal as leniently with him (thief) as justice would allow.

`He (thief) has been hurt already,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman in conclusion.
`And I fear,' (he)
he (gentleman) added, with great energy, looking towards the bar,
`I really fear that he (gentleman) is ill.' (he)

`Oh! yes, I dare say!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang, with a sneer.
`Come, none of your tricks here, you young vagabond; they won't do. What's your name?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver tried to reply but his (Oliver) tongue failed him (Oliver). He (Oliver) was deadly pale; and the whole place seemed turning round and round.

`What's your name, you hardened scoundrel?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
demanded Mr. Fang.
`Officer, what's his (Fang) name?' (a bluff fellow)

This was addressed to a bluff old fellow, in a striped waistcoat, who was standing by the bar. He (Fang) bent over Oliver, and repeated the inquiry; but finding him (Oliver) really incapable of understanding the question; and knowing that his (Oliver) not replying would only infuriate the magistrate the more, and add to the severity of his (Oliver) sentence; he (Oliver) hazarded a guess.

`He (Oliver) says his (Oliver) name's Tom White, your worship,' (unknown)
said the kind-hearted thief-taker.

`Oh, he (White) won't speak out, won't he (White)?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Fang.
`Very well, very well. Where does he (Fang) live?' (unknown)

`Where he (Fang) can, your worship,' (the officer)
replied the officer; again pretending to receive Oliver's answer.

`Has he (Oliver) any parents?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
inquired Mr. Fang.

`He (Fang) says they died in his (Fang) infancy, your worship,' (the officer)
replied the officer: hazarding the usual reply.

At this point of the inquiry, Oliver raised his (Oliver) head; and, looking round with imploring eyes, murmured a feeble prayer for a draught of water.

`Stuff and nonsense!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Mr. Fang:
`don't try to make a fool of me.' (Mr. Fang/Fang)

`I think he (Fang) really is ill, your worship,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
remonstrated the officer.

`I know better,' (the officer)
said Mr. Fang.

`Take care of him (Fang), officer,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, raising his (gentleman) hands instinctively;
`he (gentleman)'ll fall down.' (the gentleman)

`Stand away, officer,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
cried Fang;
`let him (Fang), if he (Fang) likes.' (Mr. Fang/Fang)

Oliver availed himself of the kind permission, and fell to the floor in a fainting fit. The men in the office looked at each other, but no one dared to stir.

`I knew he (Oliver) was shamming,' (The men)
said Fang, as if this were incontestable proof of the fact.
`Let him (Fang) lie there; he (Fang)'ll soon be tired of that.' (unknown)

`How do you propose to deal with the case, sir?' (the clerk)
inquired the clerk in a low voice.

`Summarily,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
replied Mr. Fang.
`He (Fang) stands committed for three months--hard labour of course. Clear the office.' (a couple)

The door was opened for this purpose, and a couple of men were preparing to carry the insensible boy to his (boy) cell; when an elderly man of decent but poor appearance, clad in an old suit of black, rushed hastily into the office, and advanced towards the bench.

`Stop, stop! don't take him (boy) away! For Heaven's sake stop a moment!' (unknown)
cried the new comer, breathless with haste.

Although the presiding Genii in such an office as this, exercise a summary and arbitrary power over the liberties, the good name, the character, almost the lives, of Her (character) Majesty's subjects, expecially of the poorer class; and although, within such walls, enough fantastic tricks are daily played to make the angels blind with weeping; they are closed to the public, save through the medium of the daily press.-LSB-Footnote: Or were virtually, then.-RSB- Mr. Fang was consequently not a little indignant to see an unbidden guest enter in such irreverent disorder.

`What is this? Who is this? Turn this man out. Clear the office!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
cried Mr. Fang.

`I _will_ speak,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
cried the man;
`I will not be turned out. I saw it all. I keep the book-stall. I demand to be sworn. I will not be put down. Mr. Fang, you must hear me. You must not refuse, sir.' (the man)

The man was right. His (man) manner was determined; and the matter was growing rather too serious to be hushed up.

`Swear the man,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
growled Mr. Fang, with a very ill grace.
`Now, man, what have you got to say?' (unknown)

`This,' (the man)
said the man:
`I saw three boys: two others and the prisoner here: loitering on the opposite side of the way, when this gentleman was reading. The robbery was committed by another boy. I saw it done; and I saw that this boy was perfectly amazed and stupified by it.' (the man)
Having by this time recovered a little breath, the worthy book-stall keeper proceeded to relate, in a more coherent manner the exact circumstances of the robbery.

`Why didn't you come here before?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Fang, after a pause.

`I hadn't a soul to mind the shop,' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
replied the man.
`Everybody who could have helped me, had joined in the pursuit. I could get nobody till five minutes ago; and I've run here all the way.' (unknown)

`The prosecutor was reading, was he (prosecutor)?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
inquired Fang, after another pause.

`Yes,' (the man)
replied the man.
`The very book he (man) has in his (man) hand.' (unknown)

`Oh, that book, eh?' (Mr. Fang/Fang)
said Fang.
`Is it paid for?' (unknown)

`No, it is not,' (the man)
replied the man, with a smile.

`Dear me, I forgot all about it!' (the gentleman)
exclaimed the absent old gentleman, innocently.

`A nice person to prefer a charge against a poor boy!' (the gentleman)
said Fang, with a comical effort to look humane.
`I consider, sir, that you have obtained possession of that book, under very suspicious and disreputable circumstances; and you may think yourself very fortunate that the owner of the property declines to prosecute. Let this be a lesson to you, my man, or the law will overtake you yet. The boy is discharged. Clear the office!' (Mr. Fang/Fang)

'D--n me!' cried the old gentleman, bursting out with the rage he (gentleman) had kept down so long, 'd--n me! I'll--'

`Clear the office!' (I)
said the magistrate.
`Officers, do you hear? Clear the office!' (unknown)

The mandate was obeyed; and the indignant Mr. Brownlow was conveyed out, with the book in one hand, and the bamboo cane in the other: in a perfect phrenzy of rage and defiance. He (Brownlow) reached the yard; and his (Brownlow) passion vanished in a moment. Little Oliver Twist lay on his (Twist) back on the pavement, with his (Twist) shirt unbuttoned, and his (Twist) temples bathed with water; his (Twist) face a deadly white; and a cold tremble convulsing his (Twist) whole frame.

`Poor boy, poor boy!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, bending over him (Brownlow).
`Call a coach, somebody, pray. Directly!' (A coach)

A coach was obtained, and Oliver having been carefully laid on the seat, the old gentleman got in and sat himself on the other.

`May I accompany you?' (the book-stall keeper)
said the book-stall keeper, looking in.

`Bless me, yes, my dear sir,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow quickly.
`I forgot you. Dear, dear! I have this unhappy book still! Jump in. Poor fellow! There's no time to lose.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

The book-stall keeper got into the coach; and away they drove.

CHAPTER XII

IN WHICH OLIVER IS TAKEN BETTER CARE OF THAN HE (OLIVER) EVER WAS BEFORE. AND IN WHICH THE NARRATIVE REVERTS TO THE MERRY OLD GENTLEMAN AND HIS (GENTLEMAN) YOUTHFUL FRIENDS.

The coach rattled away, over nearly the same ground as that which Oliver had traversed when he (Oliver) first entered London in company with the Dodger; and, turning a different way when it reached the Angel at Islington, stopped at length before a neat house, in a quiet shady street near Pentonville. Here, a bed was prepared, without loss of time, in which Mr. Brownlow saw his (Brownlow) young charge carefully and comfortably deposited; and here, he (Brownlow) was tended with a kindness and solicitude that knew no bounds.

But, for many days, Oliver remained insensible to all the goodness of his (Oliver) new friends. The sun rose and sank, and rose and sank again, and many times after that; and still the boy lay stretched on his (boy) uneasy bed, dwindling away beneath the dry and wasting heat of fever. The worm does not work more surely on the dead body, than does this slow creeping fire upon the living frame.

Weak, and thin, and pallid, he (boy) awoke at last from what seemed to have been a long and troubled dream. Feebly raising himself in the bed, with his (boy) head resting on his (boy) trembling arm, he (boy) looked anxiously around.

`What room is this? Where have I been brought to?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`This is not the place I went to sleep in.' (He)

He (Oliver) uttered these words in a feeble voice, being very faint and weak; but they were overheard at once. The curtain at the bed's head was hastily drawn back, and a motherly old lady, very neatly and precisely dressed, rose as she (lady) undrew it, from an arm-chair close by, in which she (lady) had been sitting at needle-work.

`Hush, my dear,' (the lady)
said the old lady softly.
`You must be very quiet, or you will be ill again; and you have been very bad,--as bad as bad could be, pretty nigh. Lie down again; there's a dear!' (the lady)
With those words, the old lady very gently placed Oliver's head upon the pillow; and, smoothing back his (Oliver) hair from his (Oliver) forehead, looked so kindly and loving in his (Oliver) face, that he (Oliver) could not help placing his (Oliver) little withered hand in hers, and drawing it round his (Oliver) neck.

`Save us!' (the lady)
said the old lady, with tears in her (lady) eyes.
`What a grateful little dear it is. Pretty creetur! What would his (Oliver) mother feel if she (mother) had sat by him (Oliver) as I have, and could see him (Oliver) now!' (unknown)

`Perhaps she (mother) does see me,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
whispered Oliver, folding his (Oliver) hands together;
`perhaps she (mother) has sat by me. I almost feel as if she (mother) had.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`That was the fever, my dear,' (the lady)
said the old lady mildly.

`I suppose it was,' (the lady)
replied Oliver,
`because heaven is a long way off; and they are too happy there, to come down to the bedside of a poor boy. But if she (lady) knew I was ill, she (lady) must have pitied me, even there; for she (lady) was very ill herself before she (lady) died. She (lady) can't know anything about me though,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
added Oliver after a moment's silence.
`If she (lady) had seen me hurt, it would have made her (lady) sorrowful; and her (lady) face has always looked sweet and happy, when I have dreamed of her (lady).' (The lady)

The old lady made no reply to this; but wiping her (lady) eyes first, and her (lady) spectacles, which lay on the counterpane, afterwards, as if they were part and parcel of those features, brought some cool stuff for Oliver to drink; and then, patting him (Oliver) on the cheek, told him (Oliver) he (Oliver) must lie very quiet, or he (Oliver) would be ill again.

So, Oliver kept very still; partly because he (Oliver) was anxious to obey the kind old lady in all things; and partly, to tell the truth, because he (Oliver) was completely exhausted with what he (Oliver) had already said. He (Oliver) soon fell into a gentle doze, from which he (Oliver) was awakened by the light of a candle: which, being brought near the bed, showed him (Oliver) a gentleman with a very large and loud-ticking gold watch in his (Oliver) hand, who felt his (Oliver) pulse, and said he (Oliver) was a great deal better.

`You _are_ a great deal better, are you not, my dear?' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.

`Yes, thank you, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Yes, I know you are,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman:
`You're hungry too, an't you?' (the gentleman)

`No, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
answered Oliver.

`Hem!' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
`No, I know you're not. He (gentleman) is not hungry, Mrs. Bedwin,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman: looking very wise.

The old lady made a respectful inclination of the head, which seemed to say that she (lady) thought the doctor was a very clever man. The doctor appeared much of the same opinion himself.

`You feel sleepy, don't you, my dear?' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

`No, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`No,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, with a very shrewd and satisfied look.
`You're not sleepy. Nor thirsty. Are you?' (unknown)

`Yes, sir, rather thirsty,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
answered Oliver.

`Just as I expected, Mrs. Bedwin,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`It's very natural that he (doctor) should be thirsty. You may give him (doctor) a little tea, ma'am, and some dry toast without any butter. Don't keep him (doctor) too warm, ma'am; but be careful that you don't let him (doctor) be too cold; will you have the goodness?' (The lady)

The old lady dropped a curtsey. The doctor, after tasting the cool stuff, and expressing a qualified approval of it, hurried away: his (doctor) boots creaking in a very important and wealthy manner as he (doctor) went downstairs.

Oliver dozed off again, soon after this; when he (Oliver) awoke, it was nearly twelve o'clock. The old lady tenderly bade him (Oliver) good-night shortly afterwards, and left him (Oliver) in charge of a fat old woman who had just come: bringing with her (woman), in a little bundle, a small Prayer Book and a large nightcap. Putting the latter on her (woman) head and the former on the table, the old woman, after telling Oliver that she (woman) had come to sit up with him (Oliver), drew her (woman) chair close to the fire and went off into a series of short naps, chequered at frequent intervals with sundry tumblings forward, and divers moans and chokings. These, however, had no worse effect than causing her (woman) to rub her (woman) nose very hard, and then fall asleep again.

And thus the night crept slowly on. Oliver lay awake for some time, counting the little circles of light which the reflection of the rushlight-shade threw upon the ceiling; or tracing with his (Oliver) languid eyes the intricate pattern of the paper on the wall. The darkness and the deep stillness of the room were very solemn; as they brought into the boy's mind the thought that death had been hovering there, for many days and nights, and might yet fill it with the gloom and dread of his (boy) awful presence, he (boy) turned his (boy) face upon the pillow, and fervently prayed to Heaven.

Gradually, he (boy) fell into that deep tranquil sleep which ease from recent suffering alone imparts; that calm and peaceful rest which it is pain to wake from. Who, if this were death, would be roused again to all the struggles and turmoils of life; to all its cares for the present; its anxieties for the future; more than all, its weary recollections of the past!

It had been bright day, for hours, when Oliver opened his (Oliver) eyes; he (Oliver) felt cheerful and happy. The crisis of the disease was safely past. He (Oliver) belonged to the world again.

In three days' time he (Oliver) was able to sit in an easy-chair, well propped up with pillows; and, as he (Oliver) was still too weak to walk, Mrs. Bedwin had him (Oliver) carried downstairs into the little housekeeper's room, which belonged to her (Bedwin). Having him (Oliver) set, here, by the fire-side, the good old lady sat herself down too; and, being in a state of considerable delight at seeing him (Oliver) so much better, forthwith began to cry most violently.

`Never mind me, my dear,' (the lady)
said the old lady;
`I'm only having a regular good cry. There; it's all over now; and I'm quite comfortable.' (the lady)

`You're very, very kind to me, ma'am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

`Well, never you mind that, my dear,' (the lady)
said the old lady;
`that's got nothing to do with your broth; and it's full time you had it; for the doctor says Mr. Brownlow may come in to see you this morning; and we must get up our best looks, because the better we look, the more he (Brownlow)'ll be pleased.' (the lady)
And with this, the old lady applied herself to warming up, in a little saucepan, a basin full of broth: strong enough, Oliver thought, to furnish an ample dinner, when reduced to the regulation strength, for three hundred and fifty paupers, at the lowest computation.

`Are you fond of pictures, dear?' (the lady)
inquired the old lady, seeing that Oliver had fixed his (Oliver) eyes, most intently, on a portrait which hung against the wall; just opposite his (Oliver) chair.

`I don't quite know, ma'am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, without taking his (Oliver) eyes from the canvas;
`I have seen so few that I hardly know. What a beautiful, mild face that lady's is!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Ah!' (the lady)
said the old lady,
`painters always make ladies out prettier than they are, or they wouldn't get any custom, child. The man that invented the machine for taking likenesses might have known that would never succeed; it's a deal too honest. A deal,' (the lady)
said the old lady, laughing very heartily at her (lady) own acuteness.

`Is--is that a likeness, ma'am?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.

`Yes,' (the lady)
said the old lady, looking up for a moment from the broth;
`that's a portrait.' (the lady)

`Whose, ma'am?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver.

`Why, really, my dear, I don't know,' (the lady)
answered the old lady in a good-humoured manner.
`It's not a likeness of anybody that you or I know, I expect. It seems to strike your fancy, dear.' (unknown)

`It is so pretty,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Why, sure you're not afraid of it?' (the lady look)
said the old lady: observing in great surprise, the look of awe with which the child regarded the painting.

`Oh no, no,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
returned Oliver quickly;
`but the eyes look so sorrowful; and where I sit, they seem fixed upon me. It makes my heart beat,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
added Oliver in a low voice,
`as if it was alive, and wanted to speak to me, but couldn't.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Lord save us!' (the lady)
exclaimed the old lady, starting;
`don't talk in that way, child. You're weak and nervous after your illness. Let me wheel your chair round to the other side; and then you won't see it. There!' (the lady)
said the old lady, suiting the action to the word;
`you don't see it now, at all events.' (the lady)

Oliver _did_ see it in his (Oliver) mind's eye as distinctly as if he (Oliver) had not altered his (Oliver) position; but he (Oliver) thought it better not to worry the kind old lady; so he (Oliver) smiled gently when she (lady) looked at him (Oliver); and Mrs. Bedwin, satisfied that he (Oliver) felt more comfortable, salted and broke bits of toasted bread into the broth, with all the bustle befitting so solemn a preparation. Oliver got through it with extraordinary expedition. He (Oliver) had scarcely swallowed the last spoonful, when there came a soft rap at the door.

`Come in,' (the lady)
said the old lady; and in walked Mr. Brownlow.

Now, the old gentleman came in as brisk as need be; but, he (gentleman) had no sooner raised his (gentleman) spectacles on his (gentleman) forehead, and thrust his (gentleman) hands behind the skirts of his (gentleman) dressing-gown to take a good long look at Oliver, than his (Oliver) countenance underwent a very great variety of odd contortions. Oliver looked very worn and shadowy from sickness, and made an ineffectual attempt to stand up, out of respect to his (Oliver) benefactor, which terminated in his (Oliver) sinking back into the chair again; and the fact is, if the truth must be told, that Mr. Brownlow's heart, being large enough for any six ordinary old gentlemen of humane disposition, forced a supply of tears into his (Brownlow) eyes, by some hydraulic process which we are not sufficiently philosophical to be in a condition to explain.

`Poor boy, poor boy!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, clearing his (Brownlow) throat.
`I'm rather hoarse this morning, Mrs. Bedwin. I'm afraid I have caught cold.' (unknown)

`I hope not, sir,' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)
said Mrs. Bedwin.
`Everything you have had, has been well aired, sir.' (unknown)

`I don't know, Bedwin. I don't know,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`I rather think I had a damp napkin at dinner-time yesterday; but never mind that. How do you feel, my dear?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Very happy, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`And very grateful indeed, sir, for your goodness to me.' (unknown)

`Good by,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, stoutly.
`Have you given him (Brownlow) any nourishment, Bedwin? Any slops, eh?' (unknown)

`He (Brownlow) has just had a basin of beautiful strong broth, sir,' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)
replied Mrs. Bedwin: drawing herself up slightly, and laying strong emphasis on the last word: to intimate that between slops, and broth will compounded, there existed no affinity or connection whatsoever.

`Ugh!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, with a slight shudder;
`a couple of glasses of port wine would have done him (Brownlow) a great deal more good. Wouldn't they, Tom White, eh?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`My name is Oliver, sir,' (unknown)
replied the little invalid: with a look of great astonishment.

`Oliver,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`Oliver what? Oliver White, eh?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`No, sir, Twist, Oliver Twist.' (unknown)

`Queer name!' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
`What made you tell the magistrate your name was White?' (unknown)

`I never told him (White) so, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
returned Oliver in amazement.

This sounded so like a falsehood, that the old gentleman looked somewhat sternly in Oliver's face. It was impossible to doubt him (Oliver); there was truth in every one of its thin and sharpened lineaments.

`Some mistake,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow. But, although his (Brownlow) motive for looking steadily at Oliver no longer existed, the old idea of the resemblance between his (Oliver) features and some familiar face came upon him (Oliver) so strongly, that he (Oliver) could not withdraw his (Oliver) gaze.

`I hope you are not angry with me, sir?' (he)
said Oliver, raising his (Oliver) eyes beseechingly.

`No, no,' (the gentleman)
replied the old gentleman.
`Why! what's this? Bedwin, look there!' (he)

As he (Oliver) spoke, he (Oliver) pointed hastily to the picture over Oliver's head, and then to the boy's face. There was its living copy. The eyes, the head, the mouth; every feature was the same. The expression was, for the instant, so precisely alike, that the minutest line seemed copied with startling accuracy!

Oliver knew not the cause of this sudden exclamation; for, not being strong enough to bear the start it gave him (Oliver), he (Oliver) fainted away. A weakness on his (Oliver) part, which affords the narrative an opportunity of relieving the reader from suspense, in behalf of the two young pupils of the Merry Old Gentleman; and of recording--

That when the Dodger, and his (Dodger) accomplished friend Master Bates, joined in the hue-and-cry which was raised at Oliver's heels, in consequence of their executing an illegal conveyance of Mr. Brownlow's personal property, as has been already described, they were actuated by a very laudable and becoming regard for themselves; and forasmuch as the freedom of the subject and the liberty of the individual are among the first and proudest boasts of a true-hearted Englishman, so, I need hardly beg the reader to observe, that this action should tend to exalt them in the opinion of all public and patriotic men, in almost as great a degree as this strong proof of their anxiety for their own preservation and safety goes to corroborate and confirm the little code of laws which certain profound and sound-judging philosophers have laid down as the main-springs of all Nature's deeds and actions: the said philosophers very wisely reducing the good lady's proceedings to matters of maxim and theory: and, by a very neat and pretty compliment to her (lady) exalted wisdom and understanding, putting entirely out of sight any considerations of heart, or generous impulse and feeling. For, these are matters totally beneath a female who is acknowledged by universal admission to be far above the numerous little foibles and weaknesses of her (female) sex.

If I wanted any further proof of the strictly philosophical nature of the conduct of these young gentlemen in their very delicate predicament, I should at once find it in the fact -LRB-also recorded in a foregoing part of this narrative-RRB-, of their quitting the pursuit, when the general attention was fixed upon Oliver; and making immediately for their home by the shortest possible cut. Although I do not mean to assert that it is usually the practice of renowned and learned sages, to shorten the road to any great conclusion -LRB-their course indeed being rather to lengthen the distance, by various circumlocutions and discursive staggerings, like unto those in which drunken men under the pressure of a too mighty flow of ideas, are prone to indulge-RRB-; still, I do mean to say, and do say distinctly, that it is the invariable practice of many mighty philosophers, in carrying out their theories, to evince great wisdom and foresight in providing against every possible contingency which can be supposed at all likely to affect themselves. Thus, to do a great right, you may do a little wrong; and you may take any means which the end to be attained, will justify; the amount of the right, or the amount of the wrong, or indeed the distinction between the two, being left entirely to the philosopher concerned, to be settled and determined by his (philosopher) clear, comprehensive, and impartial view of his (philosopher) own particular case.

It was not until the two boys had scoured, with great rapidity, through a most intricate maze of narrow streets and courts, that they ventured to halt beneath a low and dark archway. Having remained silent here, just long enough to recover breath to speak, Master Bates uttered an exclamation of amusement and delight; and, bursting into an uncontrollable fit of laughter, flung himself upon a doorstep, and rolled thereon in a transport of mirth.

`What's the matter?' (the Dodger)
inquired the Dodger.

`Ha! ha! ha!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
roared Charley Bates.

`Hold your noise,' (the Dodger)
remonstrated the Dodger, looking cautiously round.
`Do you want to be grabbed, stupid?' (unknown)

`I can't help it,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley,
`I can't help it! To see him (Charley) splitting away at that pace, and cutting round the corners, and knocking up again' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
the posts, and starting on again as if he (Charley) was made of iron as well as them, and me with the wipe in my pocket, singing out arter him (Charley)--oh, my eye!' The vivid imagination of Master Bates presented the scene before him (Bates) in too strong colours. As he (Bates) arrived at this apostrophe, he (Bates) again rolled upon the door-step, and laughed louder than before.

`What'll Fagin say?' (the Dodger)
inquired the Dodger; taking advantage of the next interval of breathlessness on the part of his (Dodger) friend to propound the question.

`What?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
repeated Charley Bates.

`Ah, what?' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger.

`Why, what should he (Dodger) say?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
inquired Charley: stopping rather suddenly in his (Charley) merriment; for the Dodger's manner was impressive.
`What should he (Dodger) say?' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)

Mr. Dawkins whistled for a couple of minutes; then, taking off his (Dawkins) hat, scratched his (Dawkins) head, and nodded thrice.

`What do you mean?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley.

`Toor rul lol loo, gammon and spinnage, the frog he (Charley) wouldn't, and high cockolorum,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger: with a slight sneer on his (Dodger) intellectual countenance.

This was explanatory, but not satisfactory. Master Bates felt it so; and again said,

`What do you mean?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

The Dodger made no reply; but putting his (Dodger) hat on again, and gathering the skirts of his (Dodger) long-tailed coat under his (Dodger) arm, thrust his (Dodger) tongue into his (Dodger) cheek, slapped the bridge of his (Dodger) nose some half-dozen times in a familiar but expressive manner, and turning on his (Dodger) heel, slunk down the court. Master Bates followed, with a thoughtful countenance.

The noise of footsteps on the creaking stairs, a few minutes after the occurrence of this conversation, roused the merry old gentleman as he (gentleman) sat over the fire with a saveloy and a small loaf in his (gentleman) hand; a pocket-knife in his (gentleman) right; and a pewter pot on the trivet. There was a rascally smile on his (gentleman) white face as he (gentleman) turned round, and looking sharply out from under his (gentleman) thick red eyebrows, bent his (gentleman) ear towards the door, and listened.

`Why, how's this?' (the Jew)
muttered the Jew: changing countenance;
`only two of 'em? Where's the third? They can't have got into trouble. Hark!' (the Jew)

The footsteps approached nearer; they reached the landing. The door was slowly opened; and the Dodger and Charley Bates entered, closing it behind them.

CHAPTER XIII

SOME NEW ACQUAINTANCES ARE INTRODUCED TO THE INTELLIGENT READER, CONNECTED WITH WHOM VARIOUS PLEASANT MATTERS ARE RELATED, APPERTAINING TO THIS HISTORY

`Where's Oliver?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, rising with a menacing look.
`Where's the boy?' (The thieves)

The young thieves eyed their preceptor as if they were alarmed at his (boy) violence; and looked uneasily at each other. But they made no reply.

`What's become of the boy?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, seizing the Dodger tightly by the collar, and threatening him (Dodger) with horrid imprecations.
`Speak out, or I'll throttle you!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Mr. Fagin looked so very much in earnest, that Charley Bates, who deemed it prudent in all cases to be on the safe side, and who conceived it by no means improbable that it might be his (Bates) turn to be throttled second, dropped upon his (Bates) knees, and raised a loud, well-sustained, and continuous roar--something between a mad bull and a speaking trumpet.

`Will you speak?' (the Jew)
thundered the Jew: shaking the Dodger so much that his (Dodger) keeping in the big coat at all, seemed perfectly miraculous.

`Why, the traps have got him (Dodger), and that's all about it,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, sullenly.
`Come, let go o' (me)
me, will you!' And, swinging himself, at one jerk, clean out of the big coat, which he (jerk) left in the Jew's hands, the Dodger snatched up the toasting fork, and made a pass at the merry old gentleman's waistcoat; which, if it had taken effect, would have let a little more merriment out than could have been easily replaced.

The Jew stepped back in this emergency, with more agility than could have been anticipated in a man of his (man) apparent decrepitude; and, seizing up the pot, prepared to hurl it at his (man) assailant's head. But Charley Bates, at this moment, calling his (Bates) attention by a perfectly terrific howl, he (Bates) suddenly altered its destination, and flung it full at that young gentleman.

`Why, what the blazes is in the wind now!' (unknown)
growled a deep voice. `Who pitched that
`ere at me? It's well it's the beer, and not the pot, as hit me, or I'd have settled somebody. I might have know'd, as nobody but an infernal, rich, plundering, thundering old Jew could afford to throw away any drink but water--and not that, unless he (Jew) done the River Company every quarter. Wot's it all about, Fagin? D--me, if my neck-handkercher an't lined with beer! Come in, you sneaking warmint; wot are you stopping outside for, as if you was ashamed of your master! Come in!' (The man)

The man who growled out these words, was a stoutly-built fellow of about five-and-thirty, in a black velveteen coat, very soiled drab breeches, lace-up half boots, and grey cotton stockings which inclosed a bulky pair of legs, with large swelling calves;--the kind of legs, which in such costume, always look in an unfinished and incomplete state without a set of fetters to garnish them. He (fellow) had a brown hat on his (fellow) head, and a dirty belcher handkerchief round his (fellow) neck: with the long frayed ends of which he (fellow) smeared the beer from his (fellow) face as he (fellow) spoke. He (fellow) disclosed, when he (fellow) had done so, a broad heavy countenance with a beard of three days' growth, and two scowling eyes; one of which displayed various parti-coloured symptoms of having been recently damaged by a blow.

`Come in, d'ye hear?' (this ruffian)
growled this engaging ruffian.

A white shaggy dog, with his (fellow) face scratched and torn in twenty different places, skulked into the room.

`Why didn't you come in afore?' (the man)
said the man.
`You're getting too proud to own me afore company, are you? Lie down!' (unknown)

This command was accompanied with a kick, which sent the animal to the other end of the room. He (man) appeared well used to it, however; for he (man) coiled himself up in a corner very quietly, without uttering a sound, and winking his (man) very ill-looking eyes twenty times in a minute, appeared to occupy himself in taking a survey of the apartment.

`What are you up to? Ill-treating the boys, you covetous, avaricious, in-sa-ti-a-ble old fence?' (the man)
said the man, seating himself deliberately. `I wonder they don't murder you! I would if I was them. If I'd been your
`prentice, I'd have done it long ago, and--no, I couldn't have sold you afterwards, for you're fit for nothing but keeping as a curiousity of ugliness in a glass bottle, and I suppose they don't blow glass bottles large enough.' (I)

`Hush! hush! Mr. Sikes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, trembling;
`don't speak so loud!' (the Jew)

`None of your mistering,' (the ruffian)
replied the ruffian;
`you always mean mischief when you come that. You know my name: out with it! I shan't disgrace it when the time comes.' (the ruffian)

`Well, well, then--Bill Sikes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, with abject humility.
`You seem out of humour, Bill.' (unknown)

`Perhaps I am,' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)
replied Sikes;
`I should think you was rather out of sorts too, unless you mean as little harm when you throw pewter pots about, as you do when you blab and--' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)

`Are you mad?' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)
said the Jew, catching the man by the sleeve, and pointing towards the boys.

Mr. Sikes contented himself with tying an imaginary knot under his (Sikes) left ear, and jerking his (Sikes) head over on the right shoulder; a piece of dumb show which the Jew appeared to understand perfectly. He (Jew) then, in cant terms, with which his (Jew) whole conversation was plentifully besprinkled, but which would be quite unintelligible if they were recorded here, demanded a glass of liquor.

`And mind you don't poison it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, laying his (Sikes) hat upon the table.

This was said in jest; but if the speaker could have seen the evil leer with which the Jew bit his (Jew) pale lip as he (Jew) turned round to the cupboard, he (Jew) might have thought the caution not wholly unnecessary, or the wish -LRB-at all events-RRB- to improve upon the distiller's ingenuity not very far from the old gentleman's merry heart.

After swallowing two of three glasses of spirits, Mr. Sikes condescended to take some notice of the young gentlemen; which gracious act led to a conversation, in which the cause and manner of Oliver's capture were circumstantially detailed, with such alterations and improvements on the truth, as to the Dodger appeared most advisable under the circumstances.

`I'm afraid,' (the Jew)
said the Jew,
`that he (Jew) may say something which will get us into trouble.' (the Jew)

`That's very likely,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
returned Sikes with a malicious grin.
`You're blowed upon, Fagin.' (unknown)

`And I'm afraid, you see,' (the Jew)
added the Jew, speaking as if he (Jew) had not noticed the interruption; and regarding the other closely as he (Jew) did so,--`I'm afraid that, if the game was up with us, it might be up with a good many more, and that it would come out rather worse for you than it would for me, my dear.'

The man started, and turned round upon the Jew. But the old gentleman's shoulders were shrugged up to his (Jew) ears; and his (Jew) eyes were vacantly staring on the opposite wall.

There was a long pause. Every member of the respectable coterie appeared plunged in his (member) own reflections; not excepting the dog, who by a certain malicious licking of his (member) lips seemed to be meditating an attack upon the legs of the first gentleman or lady he (member) might encounter in the streets when he (member) went out.

`Somebody must find out wot's been done at the office,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes in a much lower tone than he (Sikes) had taken since he (Sikes) came in.

The Jew nodded assent.

`If he (Jew) hasn't peached, and is committed, there's no fear till he (Jew) comes out again,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes,
`and then he (Sikes) must be taken care on. You must get hold of him (Sikes) somehow.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Again the Jew nodded.

The prudence of this line of action, indeed, was obvious; but, unfortunately, there was one very strong objection to its being adopted. This was, that the Dodger, and Charley Bates, and Fagin, and Mr. William Sikes, happened, one and all, to entertain a violent and deeply-rooted antipathy to going near a police-office on any ground or pretext whatever.

How long they might have sat and looked at each other, in a state of uncertainty not the most pleasant of its kind, it is difficult to guess. It is not necessary to make any guesses on the subject, however; for the sudden entrance of the two young ladies whom Oliver had seen on a former occasion, caused the conversation to flow afresh.

`The very thing!' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`Bet will go; won't you, my dear?' (unknown)

`Wheres?' (the lady)
inquired the young lady.

`Only just up to the office, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew coaxingly.

It is due to the young lady to say that she (lady) did not positively affirm that she (lady) would not, but that she (lady) merely expressed an emphatic and earnest desire to be

`blessed' (she)
if she (lady) would; a polite and delicate evasion of the request, which shows the young lady to have been possessed of that natural good breeding which cannot bear to inflict upon a fellow-creature, the pain of a direct and pointed refusal.

The Jew's countenance fell. He (Jew) turned from this young lady, who was gaily, not to say gorgeously attired, in a red gown, green boots, and yellow curl-papers, to the other female.

`Nancy, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew in a soothing manner,
`what do YOU say?' (the Jew)

`That it won't do; so it's no use a-trying it on, Fagin,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy.

`What do you mean by that?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, looking up in a surly manner.

`What I say, Bill,' (the lady)
replied the lady collectedly.

`Why, you're just the very person for it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
reasoned Mr. Sikes:
`nobody about here knows anything of you.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`And as I don't want 'em to, neither,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy in the same composed manner,
`it's rather more no than yes with me, Bill.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`She (Nancy)'ll go, Fagin,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

`No, she (Nancy) won't, Fagin,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy.

`Yes, she (Nancy) will, Fagin,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

And Mr. Sikes was right. By dint of alternate threats, promises, and bribes, the lady in question was ultimately prevailed upon to undertake the commission. She (lady) was not, indeed, withheld by the same considerations as her (lady) agreeable friend; for, having recently removed into the neighborhood of Field Lane from the remote but genteel suburb of Ratcliffe, she (lady) was not under the same apprehension of being recognised by any of her (lady) numerous acquaintances.

Accordingly, with a clean white apron tied over her (lady) gown, and her (lady) curl-papers tucked up under a straw bonnet,--both articles of dress being provided from the Jew's inexhaustible stock,--Miss Nancy prepared to issue forth on her (Nancy) errand.

`Stop a minute, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, producing, a little covered basket.
`Carry that in one hand. It looks more respectable, my dear.' (unknown)

`Give her (Nancy) a door-key to carry in her (Nancy) t`other one, Fagin,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes;
`it looks real and genivine like.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Yes, yes, my dear, so it does,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, hanging a large street-door key on the forefinger of the young lady's right hand.

`There; very good! Very good indeed, my dear!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, rubbing his (Jew) hands.

`Oh, my brother! My poor, dear, sweet, innocent little brother!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
exclaimed Nancy, bursting into tears, and wringing the little basket and the street-door key in an agony of distress.
`What has become of him (brother)! Where have they taken him (brother) to! Oh, do have pity, and tell me what's been done with the dear boy, gentlemen; do, gentlemen, if you please, gentlemen!' (unknown)

Having uttered those words in a most lamentable and heart-broken tone: to the immeasurable delight of her (Nancy) hearers: Miss Nancy paused, winked to the company, nodded smilingly round, and disappeared.

`Ah, she (Nancy)'s a clever girl, my dears,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning round to his (Jew) young friends, and shaking his (Jew) head gravely, as if in mute admonition to them to follow the bright example they had just beheld.

`She (Nancy)'s a honour to her (Nancy) sex,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, filling his (Sikes) glass, and smiting the table with his (Sikes) enormous fist.
`Here's her (Nancy) health, and wishing they was all like her (Nancy)!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

While these, and many other encomiums, were being passed on the accomplished Nancy, that young lady made the best of her (lady) way to the police-office; whither, notwithstanding a little natural timidity consequent upon walking through the streets alone and unprotected, she (lady) arrived in perfect safety shortly afterwards.

Entering by the back way, she (lady) tapped softly with the key at one of the cell-doors, and listened. There was no sound within: so she (lady) coughed and listened again. Still there was no reply: so she (lady) spoke.

`Nolly, dear?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
murmured Nancy in a gentle voice;
`Nolly?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

There was nobody inside but a miserable shoeless criminal, who had been taken up for playing the flute, and who, the offence against society having been clearly proved, had been very properly committed by Mr. Fang to the House of Correction for one month; with the appropriate and amusing remark that since he (Fang) had so much breath to spare, it would be more wholesomely expended on the treadmill than in a musical instrument. He (Fang) made no answer: being occupied mentally bewailing the loss of the flute, which had been confiscated for the use of the county: so Nancy passed on to the next cell, and knocked there.

`Well!' (unknown)
cried a faint and feeble voice.

`Is there a little boy here?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
inquired Nancy, with a preliminary sob.

`No,' (unknown)
replied the voice;
`God forbid.' (unknown)

This was a vagrant of sixty-five, who was going to prison for _not_ playing the flute; or, in other words, for begging in the streets, and doing nothing for his (God) livelihood. In the next cell was another man, who was going to the same prison for hawking tin saucepans without license; thereby doing something for his (man) living, in defiance of the Stamp-office.

But, as neither of these criminals answered to the name of Oliver, or knew anything about him (Oliver), Nancy made straight up to the bluff officer in the striped waistcoat; and with the most piteous wailings and lamentations, rendered more piteous by a prompt and efficient use of the street-door key and the little basket, demanded her (Nancy) own dear brother.

`I haven't got him (brother), my dear,' (brother)
said the old man.

`Where is he (man)?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
screamed Nancy, in a distracted manner.

`Why, the gentleman's got him (gentleman),' (the officer)
replied the officer.

`What gentleman! Oh, gracious heavens! What gentleman?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
exclaimed Nancy.

In reply to this incoherent questioning, the old man informed the deeply affected sister that Oliver had been taken ill in the office, and discharged in consequence of a witness having proved the robbery to have been committed by another boy, not in custody; and that the prosecutor had carried him (prosecutor) away, in an insensible condition, to his (prosecutor) own residence: of and concerning which, all the informant knew was, that it was somewhere in Pentonville, he (informant) having heard that word mentioned in the directions to the coachman.

In a dreadful state of doubt and uncertainty, the agonised young woman staggered to the gate, and then, exchanging her (woman) faltering walk for a swift run, returned by the most devious and complicated route she (woman) could think of, to the domicile of the Jew.

Mr. Bill Sikes no sooner heard the account of the expedition delivered, than he (Sikes) very hastily called up the white dog, and, putting on his (Sikes) hat, expeditiously departed: without devoting any time to the formality of wishing the company good-morning.

`We must know where he (Sikes) is, my dears; he (Sikes) must be found,' (the Jew)
said the Jew greatly excited.
`Charley, do nothing but skulk about, till you bring home some news of him (Charley)! Nancy, my dear, I must have him (Charley) found. I trust to you, my dear,--to you and the Artful for everything! Stay, stay,' (the Jew)
added the Jew, unlocking a drawer with a shaking hand;
`there's money, my dears. I shall shut up this shop to-night. You'll know where to find me! Don't stop here a minute. Not an instant, my dears!' (the Jew)

With these words, he (Jew) pushed them from the room: and carefully double-locking and barring the door behind them, drew from its place of concealment the box which he (Jew) had unintentionally disclosed to Oliver. Then, he (Oliver) hastily proceeded to dispose the watches and jewellery beneath his (Oliver) clothing.

A rap at the door startled him (Oliver) in this occupation.

`Who's there?' (he)
he (Oliver) cried in a shrill tone.

`Me!' (the Dodger)
replied the voice of the Dodger, through the key-hole.

`What now?' (the Jew)
cried the Jew impatiently.

`Is he (Jew) to be kidnapped to the other ken, Nancy says?' (the Dodger)
inquired the Dodger.

`Yes,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew,
`wherever she (Nancy) lays hands on him (Jew). Find him (Jew), find him (Jew) out, that's all. I shall know what to do next; never fear.' (the Jew)

The boy murmured a reply of intelligence: and hurried downstairs after his (boy) companions.

`He (boy) has not peached so far,' (the Jew)
said the Jew as he (Jew) pursued his (Jew) occupation.
`If he (Jew) means to blab us among his (Jew) new friends, we may stop his (Jew) mouth yet.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

CHAPTER XIV

COMPRISING FURTHER PARTICULARS OF OLIVER'S STAY AT MR. BROWNLOW'S, WITH THE REMARKABLE PREDICTION WHICH ONE MR. GRIMWIG UTTERED CONCERNING HIM, WHEN HE (GRIMWIG) WENT OUT ON AN ERRAND

Oliver soon recovering from the fainting-fit into which Mr. Brownlow's abrupt exclamation had thrown him (Brownlow), the subject of the picture was carefully avoided, both by the old gentleman and Mrs. Bedwin, in the conversation that ensued: which indeed bore no reference to Oliver's history or prospects, but was confined to such topics as might amuse without exciting him (Oliver). He (Oliver) was still too weak to get up to breakfast; but, when he (Oliver) came down into the housekeeper's room next day, his (Oliver) first act was to cast an eager glance at the wall, in the hope of again looking on the face of the beautiful lady. His (Oliver) expectations were disappointed, however, for the picture had been removed.

`Ah!' (the housekeeper)
said the housekeeper, watching the direction of Oliver's eyes.
`It is gone, you see.' (unknown)

`I see it is ma'am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`Why have they taken it away?' (unknown)

`It has been taken down, child, because Mr. Brownlow said, that as it seemed to worry you, perhaps it might prevent your getting well, you know,' (the lady)
rejoined the old lady.

`Oh, no, indeed. It didn't worry me, ma'am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`I liked to see it. I quite loved it.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Well, well!' (the lady)
said the old lady, good-humouredly;
`you get well as fast as ever you can, dear, and it shall be hung up again. There! I promise you that! Now, let us talk about something else.' (the lady)

This was all the information Oliver could obtain about the picture at that time. As the old lady had been so kind to him (Oliver) in his (Oliver) illness, he (Oliver) endeavoured to think no more of the subject just then; so he (Oliver) listened attentively to a great many stories she (lady) told him (Oliver), about an amiable and handsome daughter of hers, who was married to an amiable and handsome man, and lived in the country; and about a son, who was clerk to a merchant in the West Indies; and who was, also, such a good young man, and wrote such dutiful letters home four times a-year, that it brought the tears into her (clerk) eyes to talk about them. When the old lady had expatiated, a long time, on the excellences of her (lady) children, and the merits of her (lady) kind good husband besides, who had been dead and gone, poor dear soul! just six-and-twenty years, it was time to have tea. After tea she (lady) began to teach Oliver cribbage: which he (Oliver) learnt as quickly as she (lady) could teach: and at which game they played, with great interest and gravity, until it was time for the invalid to have some warm wine and water, with a slice of dry toast, and then to go cosily to bed.

They were happy days, those of Oliver's recovery. Everything was so quiet, and neat, and orderly; everybody so kind and gentle; that after the noise and turbulence in the midst of which he (Oliver) had always lived, it seemed like Heaven itself. He (Oliver) was no sooner strong enough to put his (Oliver) clothes on, properly, than Mr. Brownlow caused a complete new suit, and a new cap, and a new pair of shoes, to be provided for him (Brownlow). As Oliver was told that he (Oliver) might do what he (Oliver) liked with the old clothes, he (Oliver) gave them to a servant who had been very kind to him (Oliver), and asked her (Oliver) to sell them to a Jew, and keep the money for herself. This she (Oliver) very readily did; and, as Oliver looked out of the parlour window, and saw the Jew roll them up in his (Oliver) bag and walk away, he (Oliver) felt quite delighted to think that they were safely gone, and that there was now no possible danger of his (Oliver) ever being able to wear them again. They were sad rags, to tell the truth; and Oliver had never had a new suit before.

One evening, about a week after the affair of the picture, as he (Oliver) was sitting talking to Mrs. Bedwin, there came a message down from Mr. Brownlow, that if Oliver Twist felt pretty well, he (Twist) should like to see him (Twist) in his (Twist) study, and talk to him (Twist) a little while.

`Bless us, and save us! Wash your hands, and let me part your hair nicely for you, child,' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)
said Mrs. Bedwin.
`Dear heart alive! If we had known he (Twist) would have asked for you, we would have put you a clean collar on, and made you as smart as sixpence!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver did as the old lady bade him (Oliver); and, although she (lady) lamented grievously, meanwhile, that there was not even time to crimp the little frill that bordered his (Oliver) shirt-collar; he (Oliver) looked so delicate and handsome, despite that important personal advantage, that she (lady) went so far as to say: looking at him (Oliver) with great complacency from head to foot, that she (lady) really didn't think it would have been possible, on the longest notice, to have made much difference in him (Oliver) for the better.

Thus encouraged, Oliver tapped at the study door. On Mr. Brownlow calling to him (Oliver) to come in, he (Oliver) found himself in a little back room, quite full of books, with a window, looking into some pleasant little gardens. There was a table drawn up before the window, at which Mr. Brownlow was seated reading. When he (Brownlow) saw Oliver, he (Oliver) pushed the book away from him (Oliver), and told him (Oliver) to come near the table, and sit down. Oliver complied; marvelling where the people could be found to read such a great number of books as seemed to be written to make the world wiser. Which is still a marvel to more experienced people than Oliver Twist, every day of their lives.

`There are a good many books, are there not, my boy?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, observing the curiosity with which Oliver surveyed the shelves that reached from the floor to the ceiling.

`A great number, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`I never saw so many.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`You shall read them, if you behave well,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman kindly;
`and you will like that, better than looking at the outsides,--that is, some cases; because there are books of which the backs and covers are by far the best parts.' (the gentleman)

`I suppose they are those heavy ones, sir,' (the gentleman)
