said Oliver, pointing to some large quartos, with a good deal of gilding about the binding.

`Not always those,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, patting Oliver on the head, and smiling as he (Oliver) did so;
`there are other equally heavy ones, though of a much smaller size. How should you like to grow up a clever man, and write books, eh?' (he)

`I think I would rather read them, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`What! wouldn't you like to be a book-writer?' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.

Oliver considered a little while; and at last said, he (Oliver) should think it would be a much better thing to be a book-seller; upon which the old gentleman laughed heartily, and declared he (gentleman) had said a very good thing. Which Oliver felt glad to have done, though he (Oliver) by no means knew what it was.

`Well, well,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, composing his (gentleman) features.
`Don't be afraid! We won't make an author of you, while there's an honest trade to be learnt, or brick-making to turn to.' (unknown)

`Thank you, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver. At the earnest manner of his (Oliver) reply, the old gentleman laughed again; and said something about a curious instinct, which Oliver, not understanding, paid no very great attention to.

`Now,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, speaking if possible in a kinder, but at the same time in a much more serious manner, than Oliver had ever known him (Oliver) assume yet,
`I want you to pay great attention, my boy, to what I am going to say. I shall talk to you without any reserve; because I am sure you are well able to understand me, as many older persons would be.' (him)

`Oh, don't tell you are going to send me away, sir, pray!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
exclaimed Oliver, alarmed at the serious tone of the old gentleman's commencement!
`Don't turn me out of doors to wander in the streets again. Let me stay here, and be a servant. Don't send me back to the wretched place I came from. Have mercy upon a poor boy, sir!' (unknown)

`My dear child,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, moved by the warmth of Oliver's sudden appeal;
`you need not be afraid of my deserting you, unless you give me cause.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`I never, never will, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
interposed Oliver.

`I hope not,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
rejoined the old gentleman.
`I do not think you ever will. I have been deceived, before, in the objects whom I have endeavoured to benefit; but I feel strongly disposed to trust you, nevertheless; and I am more interested in your behalf than I can well account for, even to myself. The persons on whom I have bestowed my dearest love, lie deep in their graves; but, although the happiness and delight of my life lie buried there too, I have not made a coffin of my heart, and sealed it up, forever, on my best affections. Deep affliction has but strengthened and refined them.' (the gentleman)

As the old gentleman said this in a low voice: more to himself than to his (gentleman) companion: and as he (gentleman) remained silent for a short time afterwards: Oliver sat quite still.

`Well, well!' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman at length, in a more cheerful tone,
`I only say this, because you have a young heart; and knowing that I have suffered great pain and sorrow, you will be more careful, perhaps, not to wound me again. You say you are an orphan, without a friend in the world; all the inquiries I have been able to make, confirm the statement. Let me hear your story; where you come from; who brought you up; and how you got into the company in which I found you. Speak the truth, and you shall not be friendless while I live.' (the gentleman)

Oliver's sobs checked his (Oliver) utterance for some minutes; when he (Oliver) was on the point of beginning to relate how he (Oliver) had been brought up at the farm, and carried to the workhouse by Mr. Bumble, a peculiarly impatient little double-knock was heard at the street-door: and the servant, running upstairs, announced Mr. Grimwig.

`Is he (Grimwig) coming up?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
inquired Mr. Brownlow.

`Yes, sir,' (the servant)
replied the servant.
`He (servant) asked if there were any muffins in the house; and, when I told him (servant) yes, he (servant) said he (servant) had come to tea.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Mr. Brownlow smiled; and, turning to Oliver, said that Mr. Grimwig was an old friend of his (Grimwig), and he (Grimwig) must not mind his (Grimwig) being a little rough in his (Grimwig) manners; for he (Grimwig) was a worthy creature at bottom, as he (Grimwig) had reason to know.

`Shall I go downstairs, sir?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver.

`No,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow,
`I would rather you remained here.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

At this moment, there walked into the room: supporting himself by a thick stick: a stout old gentleman, rather lame in one leg, who was dressed in a blue coat, striped waistcoat, nankeen breeches and gaiters, and a broad-brimmed white hat, with the sides turned up with green. A very small-plaited shirt frill stuck out from his (gentleman) waistcoat; and a very long steel watch-chain, with nothing but a key at the end, dangled loosely below it. The ends of his (gentleman) white neckerchief were twisted into a ball about the size of an orange; the variety of shapes into which his (gentleman) countenance was twisted, defy description. He (gentleman) had a manner of screwing his (gentleman) head on one side when he (gentleman) spoke; and of looking out of the corners of his (gentleman) eyes at the same time: which irresistibly reminded the beholder of a parrot. In this attitude, he (gentleman) fixed himself, the moment he (gentleman) made his (gentleman) appearance; and, holding out a small piece of orange-peel at arm's length, exclaimed, in a growling, discontented voice.

`Look here! do you see this! Isn't it a most wonderful and extraordinary thing that I can't call at a man's house but I find a piece of this poor surgeon's friend on the staircase? I've been lamed with orange-peel once, and I know orange-peel will be my death, or I'll be content to eat my own head, sir!' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)

This was the handsome offer with which Mr. Grimwig backed and confirmed nearly every assertion he (Grimwig) made; and it was the more singular in his (Grimwig) case, because, even admitting for the sake of argument, the possibility of scientific improvements being brought to that pass which will enable a gentleman to eat his (gentleman) own head in the event of his (gentleman) being so disposed, Mr. Grimwig's head was such a particularly large one, that the most sanguine man alive could hardly entertain a hope of being able to get through it at a sitting--to put entirely out of the question, a very thick coating of powder.

`I'll eat my head, sir,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
repeated Mr. Grimwig, striking his (Grimwig) stick upon the ground.
`Hallo! what's that!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
looking at Oliver, and retreating a pace or two.

`This is young Oliver Twist, whom we were speaking about,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.

Oliver bowed.

`You don't mean to say that's the boy who had the fever, I hope?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, recoiling a little more.
`Wait a minute! Don't speak! Stop--' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
continued Mr. Grimwig, abruptly, losing all dread of the fever in his (Grimwig) triumph at the discovery;
`that's the boy who had the orange! If that's not the boy, sir, who had the orange, and threw this bit of peel upon the staircase, I'll eat my head, and his (boy) too.' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)

`No, no, he (boy) has not had one,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, laughing.
`Come! Put down your hat; and speak to my young friend.' (unknown)

`I feel strongly on this subject, sir,' (the gentleman)
said the irritable old gentleman, drawing off his (gentleman) gloves.
`There's always more or less orange-peel on the pavement in our street; and I _know_ it's put there by the surgeon's boy at the corner. A young woman stumbled over a bit last night, and fell against my garden-railings; directly she (woman) got up I saw her (woman) look towards his (boy) infernal red lamp with the pantomime-light. ``Don't go to him (boy),'' I called out of the window, ``he (boy)'s an assassin! A man-trap!'' So he (boy) is. If he (boy) is not--' (the gentleman)
Here the irascible old gentleman gave a great knock on the ground with his (gentleman) stick; which was always understood, by his (gentleman) friends, to imply the customary offer, whenever it was not expressed in words. Then, still keeping his (gentleman) stick in his (gentleman) hand, he (gentleman) sat down; and, opening a double eye-glass, which he (gentleman) wore attached to a broad black riband, took a view of Oliver: who, seeing that he (Oliver) was the object of inspection, coloured, and bowed again.

`That's the boy, is it?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, at length.

`That's the boy,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow.

`How are you, boy?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig.

`A great deal better, thank you, sir,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
replied Oliver.

Mr. Brownlow, seeming to apprehend that his (Brownlow) singular friend was about to say something disagreeable, asked Oliver to step downstairs and tell Mrs. Bedwin they were ready for tea; which, as he (Oliver) did not half like the visitor's manner, he (Oliver) was very happy to do.

`He (Oliver) is a nice-looking boy, is he (boy) not?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
inquired Mr. Brownlow.

`I don't know,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Grimwig, pettishly.

`Don't know?' (unknown)

`No. I don't know. I never see any difference in boys. I only knew two sort of boys. Mealy boys, and beef-faced boys.' (unknown)

`And which is Oliver?' (unknown)

`Mealy. I know a friend who has a beef-faced boy; a fine boy, they call him (boy); with a round head, and red cheeks, and glaring eyes; a horrid boy; with a body and limbs that appear to be swelling out of the seams of his (boy) blue clothes; with the voice of a pilot, and the appetite of a wolf. I know him (wolf)! The wretch!' (unknown)

`Come,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow,
`these are not the characteristics of young Oliver Twist; so he (Brownlow) needn't excite your wrath.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`They are not,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
replied Mr. Grimwig.
`He (Grimwig) may have worse.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Here, Mr. Brownlow coughed impatiently; which appeared to afford Mr. Grimwig the most exquisite delight.

`He (Grimwig) may have worse, I say,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
repeated Mr. Grimwig.
`Where does he (Grimwig) come from! Who is he (Grimwig)? What is he (Grimwig)? He (Grimwig) has had a fever. What of that? Fevers are not peculiar to good people; are they? Bad people have fevers sometimes; haven't they, eh? I knew a man who was hung in Jamaica for murdering his (man) master. He (man) had had a fever six times; he (man) wasn't recommended to mercy on that account. Pooh! nonsense!' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)

Now, the fact was, that in the inmost recesses of his (man) own heart, Mr. Grimwig was strongly disposed to admit that Oliver's appearance and manner were unusually prepossessing; but he (Grimwig) had a strong appetite for contradiction, sharpened on this occasion by the finding of the orange-peel; and, inwardly determining that no man should dictate to him (man) whether a boy was well-looking or not, he (boy) had resolved, from the first, to oppose his (boy) friend. When Mr. Brownlow admitted that on no one point of inquiry could he (Brownlow) yet return a satisfactory answer; and that he (Brownlow) had postponed any investigation into Oliver's previous history until he (Oliver) thought the boy was strong enough to hear it; Mr. Grimwig chuckled maliciously. And he (Grimwig) demanded, with a sneer, whether the housekeeper was in the habit of counting the plate at night; because if she (housekeeper) didn't find a table-spoon or two missing some sunshiny morning, why, he (Grimwig) would be content to--and so forth.

All this, Mr. Brownlow, although himself somewhat of an impetuous gentleman: knowing his (Brownlow) friend's peculiarities, bore with great good humour; as Mr. Grimwig, at tea, was graciously pleased to express his (Grimwig) entire approval of the muffins, matters went on very smoothly; and Oliver, who made one of the party, began to feel more at his (Oliver) ease than he (Oliver) had yet done in the fierce old gentleman's presence.

`And when are you going to hear a full, true, and particular account of the life and adventures of Oliver Twist?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
asked Grimwig of Mr. Brownlow, at the conclusion of the meal; looking sideways at Oliver, as he (Oliver) resumed his (Oliver) subject.

`To-morrow morning,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow.
`I would rather he (Brownlow) was alone with me at the time. Come up to me to-morrow morning at ten o'clock, my dear.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Yes, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver. He (Oliver) answered with some hesitation, because he (Oliver) was confused by Mr. Grimwig's looking so hard at him (Grimwig).

`I'll tell you what,' (gentleman)
whispered that gentleman to Mr. Brownlow;
`he (Brownlow) won't come up to you to-morrow morning. I saw him (Brownlow) hesitate. He (Brownlow) is deceiving you, my good friend.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I'll swear he (Brownlow) is not,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow, warmly.

`If he (Brownlow) is not,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig,
`I'll--' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
and down went the stick.

`I'll answer for that boy's truth with my life!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, knocking the table.

`And I for his (Brownlow) falsehood with my head!' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
rejoined Mr. Grimwig, knocking the table also.

`We shall see,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, checking his (Brownlow) rising anger.

`We will,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
replied Mr. Grimwig, with a provoking smile;
`we will.' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)

As fate would have it, Mrs. Bedwin chanced to bring in, at this moment, a small parcel of books, which Mr. Brownlow had that morning purchased of the identical bookstall-keeper, who has already figured in this history; having laid them on the table, she (Bedwin) prepared to leave the room.

`Stop the boy, Mrs. Bedwin!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`there is something to go back.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`He (Brownlow) has gone, sir,' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)
replied Mrs. Bedwin.

`Call after him (Brownlow),' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`it's particular. He (Brownlow) is a poor man, and they are not paid for. There are some books to be taken back, too.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

The street-door was opened. Oliver ran one way; and the girl ran another; and Mrs. Bedwin stood on the step and screamed for the boy; but there was no boy in sight. Oliver and the girl returned, in a breathless state, to report that there were no tidings of him (Oliver).

`Dear me, I am very sorry for that,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
exclaimed Mr. Brownlow;
`I particularly wished those books to be returned to-night.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Send Oliver with them,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, with an ironical smile;
`he (Grimwig) will be sure to deliver them safely, you know.' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)

`Yes; do let me take them, if you please, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`I'll run all the way, sir.' (The gentleman)

The old gentleman was just going to say that Oliver should not go out on any account; when a most malicious cough from Mr. Grimwig determined him (Grimwig) that he (Grimwig) should; and that, by his (Grimwig) prompt discharge of the commission, he (Grimwig) should prove to him (Grimwig) the injustice of his (Grimwig) suspicions: on this head at least: at once.

`You _shall_ go, my dear,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
`The books are on a chair by my table. Fetch them down.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver, delighted to be of use, brought down the books under his (Oliver) arm in a great bustle; and waited, cap in hand, to hear what message he (Oliver) was to take.

`You are to say,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, glancing steadily at Grimwig;
`you are to say that you have brought those books back; and that you have come to pay the four pound ten I owe him (Brownlow). This is a five-pound note, so you will have to bring me back, ten shillings change.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I won't be ten minutes, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, eagerly. Having buttoned up the bank-note in his (Oliver) jacket pocket, and placed the books carefully under his (Oliver) arm, he (Oliver) made a respectful bow, and left the room. Mrs. Bedwin followed him (Oliver) to the street-door, giving him (Oliver) many directions about the nearest way, and the name of the bookseller, and the name of the street: all of which Oliver said he (Oliver) clearly understood. Having superadded many injunctions to be sure and not take cold, the old lady at length permitted him (Oliver) to depart.

`Bless his (Oliver) sweet face!' (the lady)
said the old lady, looking after him (Oliver).
`I can't bear, somehow, to let him (Oliver) go out of my sight.' (him)

At this moment, Oliver looked gaily round, and nodded before he (Oliver) turned the corner. The old lady smilingly returned his (Oliver) salutation, and, closing the door, went back to her (lady) own room.

`Let me see; he (Oliver)'ll be back in twenty minutes, at the longest,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, pulling out his (Brownlow) watch, and placing it on the table.
`It will be dark by that time.' (unknown)

`Oh! you really expect him (Brownlow) to come back, do you?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
inquired Mr. Grimwig.

`Don't you?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
asked Mr. Brownlow, smiling.

The spirit of contradiction was strong in Mr. Grimwig's breast, at the moment; and it was rendered stronger by his (Grimwig) friend's confident smile.

`No,' (he)
he (Grimwig) said, smiting the table with his (Grimwig) fist,
`I do not. The boy has a new suit of clothes on his (boy) back, a set of valuable books under his (boy) arm, and a five-pound note in his (boy) pocket. He (boy)'ll join his (boy) old friends the thieves, and laugh at you. If ever that boy returns to this house, sir, I'll eat my head.' (he)

With these words he (boy) drew his (boy) chair closer to the table; and there the two friends sat, in silent expectation, with the watch between them.

It is worthy of remark, as illustrating the importance we attach to our own judgments, and the pride with which we put forth our most rash and hasty conclusions, that, although Mr. Grimwig was not by any means a bad-hearted man, and though he (Grimwig) would have been unfeignedly sorry to see his (Grimwig) respected friend duped and deceived, he (Grimwig) really did most earnestly and strongly hope at that moment, that Oliver Twist might not come back.

It grew so dark, that the figures on the dial-plate were scarcely discernible; but there the two old gentlemen continued to sit, in silence, with the watch between them.

CHAPTER XV

SHOWING HOW VERY FOND OF OLIVER TWIST, THE MERRY OLD JEW AND MISS NANCY WERE

In the obscure parlour of a low public-house, in the filthiest part of Little Saffron Hill; a dark and gloomy den, where a flaring gas-light burnt all day in the winter-time; and where no ray of sun ever shone in the summer: there sat, brooding over a little pewter measure and a small glass, strongly impregnated with the smell of liquor, a man in a velveteen coat, drab shorts, half-boots and stockings, whom even by that dim light no experienced agent of the police would have hesitated to recognise as Mr. William Sikes. At his (Sikes) feet, sat a white-coated, red-eyed dog; who occupied himself, alternately, in winking at his (Sikes) master with both eyes at the same time; and in licking a large, fresh cut on one side of his (Sikes) mouth, which appeared to be the result of some recent conflict.

`Keep quiet, you warmint! Keep quiet!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, suddenly breaking silence. Whether his (Sikes) meditations were so intense as to be disturbed by the dog's winking, or whether his (Sikes) feelings were so wrought upon by his (Sikes) reflections that they required all the relief derivable from kicking an unoffending animal to allay them, is matter for argument and consideration. Whatever was the cause, the effect was a kick and a curse, bestowed upon the dog simultaneously.

Dogs are not generally apt to revenge injuries inflicted upon them by their masters; but Mr. Sikes's dog, having faults of temper in common with his (Sikes) owner, and labouring, perhaps, at this moment, under a powerful sense of injury, made no more ado but at once fixed his (Sikes) teeth in one of the half-boots. Having given in a hearty shake, he (Sikes) retired, growling, under a form; just escaping the pewter measure which Mr. Sikes levelled at his (Sikes) head.

`You would, would you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, seizing the poker in one hand, and deliberately opening with the other a large clasp-knife, which he (Sikes) drew from his (Sikes) pocket.
`Come here, you born devil! Come here! D'ye hear?' (The dog)

The dog no doubt heard; because Mr. Sikes spoke in the very harshest key of a very harsh voice; but, appearing to entertain some unaccountable objection to having his (Sikes) throat cut, he (Sikes) remained where he (Sikes) was, and growled more fiercely than before: at the same time grasping the end of the poker between his (Sikes) teeth, and biting at it like a wild beast.

This resistance only infuriated Mr. Sikes the more; who, dropping on his (Sikes) knees, began to assail the animal most furiously. The dog jumped from right to left, and from left to right; snapping, growling, and barking; the man thrust and swore, and struck and blasphemed; and the struggle was reaching a most critical point for one or other; when, the door suddenly opening, the dog darted out: leaving Bill Sikes with the poker and the clasp-knife in his (Sikes) hands.

There must always be two parties to a quarrel, says the old adage. Mr. Sikes, being disappointed of the dog's participation, at once transferred his (Sikes) share in the quarrel to the new comer.

`What the devil do you come in between me and my dog for?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, with a fierce gesture.

`I didn't know, my dear, I didn't know,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Fagin, humbly; for the Jew was the new comer.

`Didn't know, you white-livered thief!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes.
`Couldn't you hear the noise?' (unknown)

`Not a sound of it, as I'm a living man, Bill,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`Oh no! You hear nothing, you don't,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
retorted Sikes with a fierce sneer.
`Sneaking in and out, so as nobody hears how you come or go! I wish you had been the dog, Fagin, half a minute ago.' (unknown)

`Why?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew with a forced smile.

'Cause the government, as cares for the lives of such men as you, as haven't half the pluck of curs, lets a man kill a dog how he (man) likes,' replied Sikes, shutting up the knife with a very expressive look;

`that's why.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

The Jew rubbed his (Jew) hands; and, sitting down at the table, affected to laugh at the pleasantry of his (Jew) friend. He (Jew) was obviously very ill at ease, however.

`Grin away,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, replacing the poker, and surveying him (Sikes) with savage contempt;
`grin away. You'll never have the laugh at me, though, unless it's behind a nightcap. I've got the upper hand over you, Fagin; and, d--me, I'll keep it. There! If I go, you go; so take care of me.' (him)

`Well, well, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew,
`I know all that; we--we--have a mutual interest, Bill,--a mutual interest.' (the Jew)

`Humph,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, as if he (Sikes) thought the interest lay rather more on the Jew's side than on his (Sikes).
`Well, what have you got to say to me?' (unknown)

`It's all passed safe through the melting-pot,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin,
`and this is your share. It's rather more than it ought to be, my dear; but as I know you'll do me a good turn another time, and--' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Stow that gammon,' (the robber)
interposed the robber, impatiently.
`Where is it? Hand over!' (unknown)

`Yes, yes, Bill; give me time, give me time,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, soothingly.
`Here it is! All safe!' (he)
As he (Jew) spoke, he (Jew) drew forth an old cotton handkerchief from his (Jew) breast; and untying a large knot in one corner, produced a small brown-paper packet. Sikes, snatching it from him (Sikes), hastily opened it; and proceeded to count the sovereigns it contained.

`This is all, is it?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`All,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`You haven't opened the parcel and swallowed one or two as you come along, have you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes, suspiciously.
`Don't put on an injured look at the question; you've done it many a time. Jerk the tinkler.' (unknown)

These words, in plain English, conveyed an injunction to ring the bell. It was answered by another Jew: younger than Fagin, but nearly as vile and repulsive in appearance.

Bill Sikes merely pointed to the empty measure. The Jew, perfectly understanding the hint, retired to fill it: previously exchanging a remarkable look with Fagin, who raised his (Fagin) eyes for an instant, as if in expectation of it, and shook his (Fagin) head in reply; so slightly that the action would have been almost imperceptible to an observant third person. It was lost upon Sikes, who was stooping at the moment to tie the boot-lace which the dog had torn. Possibly, if he (Sikes) had observed the brief interchange of signals, he (Sikes) might have thought that it boded no good to him (Sikes).

`Is anybody here, Barney?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin; speaking, now that that Sikes was looking on, without raising his (Sikes) eyes from the ground.

`Dot a shoul,' (Barney)
replied Barney; whose words: whether they came from the heart or not: made their way through the nose.

`Nobody?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin, in a tone of surprise: which perhaps might mean that Barney was at liberty to tell the truth.

`Dobody but Biss Dadsy,' (Barney)
replied Barney.

`Nancy!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
exclaimed Sikes. `Where? Strike me blind, if I don't honour that
`ere girl, for her (girl) native talents.' (I)

`She (girl)'s bid havid a plate of boiled beef id the bar,' (Barney)
replied Barney.

`Send her (girl) here,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, pouring out a glass of liquor.
`Send her (girl) here.' (Barney)

Barney looked timidly at Fagin, as if for permission; the Jew remaining silent, and not lifting his (Barney) eyes from the ground, he (Barney) retired; and presently returned, ushering in Nancy; who was decorated with the bonnet, apron, basket, and street-door key, complete.

`You are on the scent, are you, Nancy?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes, proffering the glass.

`Yes, I am, Bill,' (the lady)
replied the young lady, disposing of its contents;
`and tired enough of it I am, too. The young brat's been ill and confined to the crib; and--' (the lady)

`Ah, Nancy, dear!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, looking up.

Now, whether a peculiar contraction of the Jew's red eye-brows, and a half closing of his (Fagin) deeply-set eyes, warned Miss Nancy that she (Nancy) was disposed to be too communicative, is not a matter of much importance. The fact is all we need care for here; and the fact is, that she (Nancy) suddenly checked herself, and with several gracious smiles upon Mr. Sikes, turned the conversation to other matters. In about ten minutes' time, Mr. Fagin was seized with a fit of coughing; upon which Nancy pulled her (Nancy) shawl over her (Nancy) shoulders, and declared it was time to go. Mr. Sikes, finding that he (Sikes) was walking a short part of her (Nancy) way himself, expressed his (Sikes) intention of accompanying her (Nancy); they went away together, followed, at a little distant, by the dog, who slunk out of a back-yard as soon as his (Sikes) master was out of sight.

The Jew thrust his (Jew) head out of the room door when Sikes had left it; looked after him (Sikes) as we walked up the dark passage; shook his (Sikes) clenched fist; muttered a deep curse; and then, with a horrible grin, reseated himself at the table; where he (Sikes) was soon deeply absorbed in the interesting pages of the Hue-and-Cry.

Meanwhile, Oliver Twist, little dreaming that he (Twist) was within so very short a distance of the merry old gentleman, was on his (Twist) way to the book-stall. When he (Twist) got into Clerkenwell, he (Twist) accidently turned down a by-street which was not exactly in his (Twist) way; but not discovering his (Twist) mistake until he (Twist) had got half-way down it, and knowing it must lead in the right direction, he (Twist) did not think it worth while to turn back; and so marched on, as quickly as he (Twist) could, with the books under his (Twist) arm.

He (Twist) was walking along, thinking how happy and contented he (Twist) ought to feel; and how much he (Twist) would give for only one look at poor little Dick, who, starved and beaten, might be weeping bitterly at that very moment; when he (Dick) was startled by a young woman screaming out very loud.

`Oh, my dear brother!' (he)
And he (brother) had hardly looked up, to see what the matter was, when he (brother) was stopped by having a pair of arms thrown tight round his (brother) neck.

`Don't,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver, struggling.
`Let go of me. Who is it? What are you stopping me for?' (the woman)

The only reply to this, was a great number of loud lamentations from the young woman who had embraced him (Oliver); and who had a little basket and a street-door key in her (woman) hand.

`Oh my gracious!' (the woman)
said the young woman,
`I have found him (Oliver)! Oh! Oliver! Oliver! Oh you naughty boy, to make me suffer such distress on your account! Come home, dear, come. Oh, I've found him (Oliver). Thank gracious goodness heavins, I've found him (Oliver)!' (the woman)
With these incoherent exclamations, the young woman burst into another fit of crying, and got so dreadfully hysterical, that a couple of women who came up at the moment asked a butcher's boy with a shiny head of hair anointed with suet, who was also looking on, whether he (boy) didn't think he (boy) had better run for the doctor. To which, the butcher's boy: who appeared of a lounging, not to say indolent disposition: replied, that he (boy) thought not.

`Oh, no, no, never mind,' (the woman)
said the young woman, grasping Oliver's hand;
`I'm better now. Come home directly, you cruel boy! Come!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Oh, ma'am,' (the woman)
replied the young woman,
`he (boy) ran away, near a month ago, from his (boy) parents, who are hard-working and respectable people; and went and joined a set of thieves and bad characters; and almost broke his (boy) mother's heart.' (the woman)

`Young wretch!' (woman)
said one woman.

`Go home, do, you little brute,' (unknown)
said the other.

`I am not,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, greatly alarmed.
`I don't know her (woman). I haven't any sister, or father and mother either. I'm an orphan; I live at Pentonville.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Only hear him (father), how he (father) braves it out!' (the woman)
cried the young woman.

`Why, it's Nancy!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
exclaimed Oliver; who now saw her (Nancy) face for the first time; and started back, in irrepressible astonishment.

`You see he (Oliver) knows me!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
cried Nancy, appealing to the bystanders.
`He (Oliver) can't help himself. Make him (Oliver) come home, there's good people, or he (Oliver)'ll kill his (Oliver) dear mother and father, and break my heart!' (unknown)

`What the devil's this?' (a man Oliver)
said a man, bursting out of a beer-shop, with a white dog at his (man) heels;
`young Oliver! Come home to your poor mother, you young dog! Come home directly.' (a dog)

`I don't belong to them. I don't know them. Help! help!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver, struggling in the man's powerful grasp.

`Help!' (the man)
repeated the man.
`Yes; I'll help you, you young rascal!

What books are these? You've been a stealing 'em, have you? Give 'em here.' (the man)

With these words, the man tore the volumes from his (man) grasp, and struck him (man) on the head.

`That's right!' (unknown)
cried a looker-on, from a garret-window.
`That's the only way of bringing him (man) to his (man) senses!' (unknown)

`To be sure!' (a carpenter)
cried a sleepy-faced carpenter, casting an approving look at the garret-window.

`It'll do him (man) good!' (the women)
said the two women.

`And he (man) shall have it, too!' (the man)
rejoined the man, administering another blow, and seizing Oliver by the collar.
`Come on, you young villain! Here, Bull's-eye, mind him (Oliver), boy! Mind him (Oliver)!' (unknown)

Weak with recent illness; stupified by the blows and the suddenness of the attack; terrified by the fierce growling of the dog, and the brutality of the man; overpowered by the conviction of the bystanders that he (man) really was the hardened little wretch he (man) was described to be; what could one poor child do! Darkness had set in; it was a low neighborhood; no help was near; resistance was useless. In another moment he (man) was dragged into a labyrinth of dark narrow courts, and was forced along them at a pace which rendered the few cries he (man) dared to give utterance to, unintelligible. It was of little moment, indeed, whether they were intelligible or no; for there was nobody to care for them, had they been ever so plain.

* * * * *

The gas-lamps were lighted; Mrs. Bedwin was waiting anxiously at the open door; the servant had run up the street twenty times to see if there were any traces of Oliver; and still the two old gentlemen sat, perseveringly, in the dark parlour, with the watch between them.

CHAPTER XVI

RELATES WHAT BECAME OF OLIVER TWIST, AFTER HE (Oliver) HAD BEEN CLAIMED BY NANCY

The narrow streets and courts, at length, terminated in a large open space; scattered about which, were pens for beasts, and other indications of a cattle-market. Sikes slackened his (Sikes) pace when they reached this spot: the girl being quite unable to support any longer, the rapid rate at which they had hitherto walked. Turning to Oliver, he (Oliver) roughly commanded him (Oliver) to take hold of Nancy's hand.

`Do you hear?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes, as Oliver hesitated, and looked round.

They were in a dark corner, quite out of the track of passengers.

Oliver saw, but too plainly, that resistance would be of no avail. He (Oliver) held out his (Oliver) hand, which Nancy clasped tight in hers.

`Give me the other,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, seizing Oliver's unoccupied hand.
`Here, Bull's-Eye!' (The dog)

The dog looked up, and growled.

`See here, boy!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, putting his (Sikes) other hand to Oliver's throat;
`if he (Oliver) speaks ever so soft a word, hold him (Oliver)! D'ye mind!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The dog growled again; and licking his (Oliver) lips, eyed Oliver as if he (Oliver) were anxious to attach himself to his (Oliver) windpipe without delay.

`He (Oliver)'s as willing as a Christian, strike me blind if he (Oliver) isn't!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, regarding the animal with a kind of grim and ferocious approval.
`Now, you know what you've got to expect, master, so call away as quick as you like; the dog will soon stop that game. Get on, young`un!' (Bull)

Bull's-eye wagged his (master) tail in acknowledgment of this unusually endearing form of speech; and, giving vent to another admonitory growl for the benefit of Oliver, led the way onward.

It was Smithfield that they were crossing, although it might have been Grosvenor Square, for anything Oliver knew to the contrary. The night was dark and foggy. The lights in the shops could scarecely struggle through the heavy mist, which thickened every moment and shrouded the streets and houses in gloom; rendering the strange place still stranger in Oliver's eyes; and making his (Oliver) uncertainty the more dismal and depressing.

They had hurried on a few paces, when a deep church-bell struck the hour. With its first stroke, his (Oliver) two conductors stopped, and turned their heads in the direction whence the sound proceeded.

`Eight o' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)
clock, Bill,' said Nancy, when the bell ceased.

`What's the good of telling me that; I can hear it, can't I!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.

`I wonder whether THEY can hear it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Nancy.

`Of course they can,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.
`It was Bartlemy time when I was shopped; and there warn't a penny trumpet in the fair, as I couldn't hear the squeaking on. Arter I was locked up for the night, the row and din outside made the thundering old jail so silent, that I could almost have beat my brains out against the iron plates of the door.' (unknown)

`Poor fellow!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy, who still had her (Nancy) face turned towards the quarter in which the bell had sounded.
`Oh, Bill, such fine young chaps as them!' (unknown)

`Yes; that's all you women think of,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
answered Sikes.
`Fine young chaps! Well, they're as good as dead, so it don't much matter.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

With this consolation, Mr. Sikes appeared to repress a rising tendency to jealousy, and, clasping Oliver's wrist more firmly, told him (Oliver) to step out again.

`Wait a minute!' (the girl)
said the girl:
`I wouldn't hurry by, if it was you that was coming out to be hung, the next time eight o'clock struck, Bill. I'd walk round and round the place till I dropped, if the snow was on the ground, and I hadn't a shawl to cover me.' (the girl)

`And what good would that do?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired the unsentimental Mr. Sikes.
`Unless you could pitch over a file and twenty yards of good stout rope, you might as well be walking fifty mile off, or not walking at all, for all the good it would do me. Come on, and don't stand preaching there.' (girl)

The girl burst into a laugh; drew her (girl) shawl more closely round her (girl); and they walked away. But Oliver felt her (girl) hand tremble, and, looking up in her (girl) face as they passed a gas-lamp, saw that it had turned a deadly white.

They walked on, by little-frequented and dirty ways, for a full half-hour: meeting very few people, and those appearing from their looks to hold much the same position in society as Mr. Sikes himself. At length they turned into a very filthy narrow street, nearly full of old-clothes shops; the dog running forward, as if conscious that there was no further occasion for his (Sikes) keeping on guard, stopped before the door of a shop that was closed and apparently untenanted; the house was in a ruinous condition, and on the door was nailed a board, intimating that it was to let: which looked as if it had hung there for many years.

`All right,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, glancing cautiously about.

Nancy stooped below the shutters, and Oliver heard the sound of a bell. They crossed to the opposite side of the street, and stood for a few moments under a lamp. A noise, as if a sash window were gently raised, was heard; and soon afterwards the door softly opened. Mr. Sikes then seized the terrified boy by the collar with very little ceremony; and all three were quickly inside the house.

The passage was perfectly dark. They waited, while the person who had let them in, chained and barred the door.

`Anybody here?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`No,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied a voice, which Oliver thought he (Oliver) had heard before.

`Is the old

`un here?' (the robber)
asked the robber.

`Yes,' (unknown)
replied the voice,
`and precious down in the mouth he (robber) has been. Won't he (robber) be glad to see you? Oh, no!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The style of this reply, as well as the voice which delivered it, seemed familiar to Oliver's ears: but it was impossible to distinguish even the form of the speaker in the darkness.

`Let's have a glim,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes,
`or we shall go breaking our necks, or treading on the dog. Look after your legs if you do!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Stand still a moment, and I'll get you one,' (unknown)
replied the voice. The receding footsteps of the speaker were heard; and, in another minute, the form of Mr. John Dawkins, otherwise the Artful Dodger, appeared. He (Dodger) bore in his (Dodger) right hand a tallow candle stuck in the end of a cleft stick.

The young gentleman did not stop to bestow any other mark of recognition upon Oliver than a humourous grin; but, turning away, beckoned the visitors to follow him (Oliver) down a flight of stairs. They crossed an empty kitchen; and, opening the door of a low earthy-smelling room, which seemed to have been built in a small back-yard, were received with a shout of laughter.

`Oh, my wig, my wig!' (Master)
cried Master Charles Bates, from whose lungs the laughter had proceeded:
`here he (Bates) is! oh, cry, here he (Bates) is! Oh, Fagin, look at him (Bates)! Fagin, do look at him (Fagin)! I can't bear it; it is such a jolly game, I cant' (Charles Bates)
bear it. Hold me, somebody, while I laugh it out.'

With this irrepressible ebullition of mirth, Master Bates laid himself flat on the floor: and kicked convulsively for five minutes, in an ectasy of facetious joy. Then jumping to his (Bates) feet, he (Bates) snatched the cleft stick from the Dodger; and, advancing to Oliver, viewed him (Oliver) round and round; while the Jew, taking off his (Jew) nightcap, made a great number of low bows to the bewildered boy. The Artful, meantime, who was of a rather saturnine disposition, and seldom gave way to merriment when it interfered with business, rifled Oliver's pockets with steady assiduity.

`Look at his (Oliver) togs, Fagin!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley, putting the light so close to his (Charley) new jacket as nearly to set him (Charley) on fire.
`Look at his (Charley) togs! Superfine cloth, and the heavy swell cut! Oh, my eye, what a game! And his (Charley) books, too! Nothing but a gentleman, Fagin!' (unknown)

`Delighted to see you looking so well, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, bowing with mock humility.
`The Artful shall give you another suit, my dear, for fear you should spoil that Sunday one. Why didn't you write, my dear, and say you were coming? We'd have got something warm for supper.' (Master)

At his (Jew), Master Bates roared again: so loud, that Fagin himself relaxed, and even the Dodger smiled; but as the Artful drew forth the five-pound note at that instant, it is doubtful whether the sally of the discovery awakened his (Dodger) merriment.

`Hallo, what's that?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes, stepping forward as the Jew seized the note.
`That's mine, Fagin.' (unknown)

`No, no, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`Mine, Bill, mine. You shall have the books.' (unknown)

`If that ain't mine!' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)
said Bill Sikes, putting on his (Sikes) hat with a determined air;
`mine and Nancy's that is; I'll take the boy back again.' (Bill/Bill Sikes/Sikes)

The Jew started. Oliver started too, though from a very different cause; for he (Oliver) hoped that the dispute might really end in his (Oliver) being taken back.

`Come! Hand over, will you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

`This is hardly fair, Bill; hardly fair, is it, Nancy?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew.

`Fair, or not fair,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
retorted Sikes,
`hand over, I tell you! Do you think Nancy and me has got nothing else to do with our precious time but to spend it in scouting arter, and kidnapping, every young boy as gets grabbed through you? Give it here, you avaricious old skeleton, give it here!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

With this gentle remonstrance, Mr. Sikes plucked the note from between the Jew's finger and thumb; and looking the old man coolly in the face, folded it up small, and tied it in his (Sikes) neckerchief.

`That's for our share of the trouble,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes;
`and not half enough, neither. You may keep the books, if you're fond of reading. If you ain't, sell 'em.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`They're very pretty,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley Bates: who, with sundry grimaces, had been affecting to read one of the volumes in question;
`beautiful writing, isn't is, Oliver?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
At sight of the dismayed look with which Oliver regarded his (Oliver) tormentors, Master Bates, who was blessed with a lively sense of the ludicrous, fell into another ectasy, more boisterous than the first.

`They belong to the old gentleman,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, wringing his (Oliver) hands;
`to the good, kind, old gentleman who took me into his (Oliver) house, and had me nursed, when I was near dying of the fever. Oh, pray send them back; send him (Oliver) back the books and money. Keep me here all my life long; but pray, pray send them back. He (Oliver)'ll think I stole them; the old lady: all of them who were so kind to me: will think I stole them. Oh, do have mercy upon me, and send them back!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

With these words, which were uttered with all the energy of passionate grief, Oliver fell upon his (Oliver) knees at the Jew's feet; and beat his (Oliver) hands together, in perfect desperation.

`The boy's right,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
remarked Fagin, looking covertly round, and knitting his (Fagin) shaggy eyebrows into a hard knot.
`You're right, Oliver, you're right; they WILL think you have stolen 'em. Ha! ha!' (the Jew)
chuckled the Jew, rubbing his (Jew) hands,
`it couldn't have happened better, if we had chosen our time!' (the Jew)

`Of course it couldn't,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes;
`I know'd that, directly I see him (Sikes) coming through Clerkenwell, with the books under his (Sikes) arm. It's all right enough. They're soft-hearted psalm-singers, or they wouldn't have taken him (Sikes) in at all; and they'll ask no questions after him (Sikes), fear they should be obliged to prosecute, and so get him (Sikes) lagged. He (Sikes)'s safe enough.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Oliver had looked from one to the other, while these words were being spoken, as if he (Oliver) were bewildered, and could scarecely understand what passed; but when Bill Sikes concluded, he (Sikes) jumped suddenly to his (Sikes) feet, and tore wildly from the room: uttering shrieks for help, which made the bare old house echo to the roof.

`Keep back the dog, Bill!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
cried Nancy, springing before the door, and closing it, as the Jew and his (Jew) two pupils darted out in pursuit.
`Keep back the dog; he (Jew)'ll tear the boy to pieces.' (unknown)

`Serve him (Jew) right!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, struggling to disengage himself from the girl's grasp.
`Stand off from me, or I'll split your head against the wall.' (unknown)

`I don't care for that, Bill, I don't care for that,' (the girl)
screamed the girl, struggling violently with the man,
`the child shan't be torn down by the dog, unless you kill me first.' (the man child)

`Shan't he (man)!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, setting his (Sikes) teeth.
`I'll soon do that, if you don't keep off.' (The housebreaker)

The housebreaker flung the girl from him (Sikes) to the further end of the room, just as the Jew and the two boys returned, dragging Oliver among them.

`What's the matter here!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, looking round.

`The girl's gone mad, I think,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, savagely.

`No, she (girl) hasn't,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy, pale and breathless from the scuffle;
`no, she (Nancy) hasn't, Fagin; don't think it.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`Then keep quiet, will you?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, with a threatening look.

`No, I won't do that, neither,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy, speaking very loud.
`Come! What do you think of that?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Mr. Fagin was sufficiently well acquainted with the manners and customs of that particular species of humanity to which Nancy belonged, to feel tolerably certain that it would be rather unsafe to prolong any conversation with her (Nancy), at present. With the view of diverting the attention of the company, he (Fagin) turned to Oliver.

`So you wanted to get away, my dear, did you?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, taking up a jagged and knotted club which law in a corner of the fireplace;
`eh?' (the Jew)

Oliver made no reply. But he (Oliver) watched the Jew's motions, and breathed quickly.

`Wanted to get assistance; called for the police; did you?' (the Jew)
sneered the Jew, catching the boy by the arm.
`We'll cure you of that, my young master.' (The Jew)

The Jew inflicted a smart blow on Oliver's shoulders with the club; and was raising it for a second, when the girl, rushing forward, wrested it from his (Oliver) hand. She (girl) flung it into the fire, with a force that brought some of the glowing coals whirling out into the room.

`I won't stand by and see it done, Fagin,' (She)
cried the girl.
`You've got the boy, and what more would you have?--Let him (Fagin) be--let him (Fagin) be--or I shall put that mark on some of you, that will bring me to the gallows before my time.' (The girl)

The girl stamped her (girl) foot violently on the floor as she (girl) vented this threat; and with her (girl) lips compressed, and her (girl) hands clenched, looked alternately at the Jew and the other robber: her (girl) face quite colourless from the passion of rage into which she (girl) had gradually worked herself.

`Why, Nancy!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, in a soothing tone; after a pause, during which he (Jew) and Mr. Sikes had stared at one another in a disconcerted manner;
`you,--you're more clever than ever to-night. Ha! ha! my dear, you are acting beautifully.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Am I!' (the girl)
said the girl.
`Take care I don't overdo it. You will be the worse for it, Fagin, if I do; and so I tell you in good time to keep clear of me.' (a woman)

There is something about a roused woman: especially if she (woman) add to all her (woman) other strong passions, the fierce impulses of recklessness and despair; which few men like to provoke. The Jew saw that it would be hopeless to affect any further mistake regarding the reality of Miss Nancy's rage; and, shrinking involuntarily back a few paces, cast a glance, half imploring and half cowardly, at Sikes: as if to hint that he (Sikes) was the fittest person to pursue the dialogue.

Mr. Sikes, thus mutely appealed to; and possibly feeling his (Sikes) personal pride and influence interested in the immediate reduction of Miss Nancy to reason; gave utterance to about a couple of score of curses and threats, the rapid production of which reflected great credit on the fertility of his (Sikes) invention. As they produced no visible effect on the object against whom they were discharged, however, he (Sikes) resorted to more tangible arguments.

`What do you mean by this?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes; backing the inquiry with a very common imprecation concerning the most beautiful of human features: which, if it were heard above, only once out of every fifty thousand times that it is uttered below, would render blindness as common a disorder as measles:
`what do you mean by it? Burn my body! Do you know who you are, and what you are?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Oh, yes, I know all about it,' (the girl)
replied the girl, laughing hysterically; and shaking her (girl) head from side to side, with a poor assumption of indifference.

`Well, then, keep quiet,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes, with a growl like that he (Sikes) was accustomed to use when addressing his (Sikes) dog,
`or I'll quiet you for a good long time to come.' (dog)

The girl laughed again: even less composedly than before; and, darting a hasty look at Sikes, turned her (girl) face aside, and bit her (girl) lip till the blood came.

`You're a nice one,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
added Sikes, as he (Sikes) surveyed her (girl) with a contemptuous air,
`to take up the humane and gen--teel side! A pretty subject for the child, as you call him (Sikes), to make a friend of!' (her)

`God Almighty help me, I am!' (the girl)
cried the girl passionately;
`and I wish I had been struck dead in the street, or had changed places with them we passed so near to-night, before I had lent a hand in bringing him (Almighty) here. He (Almighty)'s a thief, a liar, a devil, all that's bad, from this night forth. Isn't that enough for the old wretch, without blows?' (the girl)

`Come, come, Sikes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew appealing to him (Sikes) in a remonstratory tone, and motioning towards the boys, who were eagerly attentive to all that passed;
`we must have civil words; civil words, Bill.' (the boys)

`Civil words!' (the girl)
cried the girl, whose passion was frightful to see.
`Civil words, you villain! Yes, you deserve 'em from me. I thieved for you when I was a child not half as old as this!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
pointing to Oliver.
`I have been in the same trade, and in the same service, for twelve years since. Don't you know it? Speak out! Don't you know it?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Well, well,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, with an attempt at pacification;
`and, if you have, it's your living!' (the Jew)

`Aye, it is!' (the girl speaking)
returned the girl; not speaking, but pouring out the words in one continuous and vehement scream.
`It is my living; and the cold, wet, dirty streets are my home; and you're the wretch that drove me to them long ago, and that'll keep me there, day and night, day and night, till I die!' (unknown)

`I shall do you a mischief!' (the Jew)
interposed the Jew, goaded by these reproaches;
`a mischief worse than that, if you say much more!' (the Jew)

The girl said nothing more; but, tearing her (girl) hair and dress in a transport of passion, made such a rush at the Jew as would probably have left signal marks of her (girl) revenge upon him (Jew), had not her (girl) wrists been seized by Sikes at the right moment; upon which, she (girl) made a few ineffectual struggles, and fainted.

`She (girl)'s all right now,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, laying her (girl) down in a corner.
`She (girl)'s uncommon strong in the arms, when she (girl)'s up in this way.' (The Jew)

The Jew wiped his (Jew) forehead: and smiled, as if it were a relief to have the disturbance over; but neither he (Jew), nor Sikes, nor the dog, nor the boys, seemed to consider it in any other light than a common occurance incidental to business.

`It's the worst of having to do with women,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, replacing his (Jew) club;
`but they're clever, and we can't get on, in our line, without 'em. Charley, show Oliver to bed.' (the Jew)

`I suppose he (Charley)'d better not wear his (Charley) best clothes tomorrow, Fagin, had he (Fagin)?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
inquired Charley Bates.

`Certainly not,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, reciprocating the grin with which Charley put the question.

Master Bates, apparently much delighted with his (Bates) commission, took the cleft stick: and led Oliver into an adjacent kitchen, where there were two or three of the beds on which he (Oliver) had slept before; and here, with many uncontrollable bursts of laughter, he (Oliver) produced the identical old suit of clothes which Oliver had so much congratulated himself upon leaving off at Mr. Brownlow's; and the accidental display of which, to Fagin, by the Jew who purchased them, had been the very first clue received, of his (Jew) whereabout.

`Put off the smart ones,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley,
`and I'll give 'em to Fagin to take care of. What fun it is!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

Poor Oliver unwillingly complied. Master Bates rolling up the new clothes under his (Bates) arm, departed from the room, leaving Oliver in the dark, and locking the door behind him (Oliver).

The noise of Charley's laughter, and the voice of Miss Betsy, who opportunely arrived to throw water over her (Betsy) friend, and perform other feminine offices for the promotion of her (Betsy) recovery, might have kept many people awake under more happy circumstances than those in which Oliver was placed. But he (Oliver) was sick and weary; and he (Oliver) soon fell sound asleep.

CHAPTER XVII

OLIVER'S DESTINY CONTINUING UNPROPITIOUS, BRINGS A GREAT MAN TO LONDON TO INJURE HIS (OLIVER) REPUTATION

It is the custom on the stage, in all good murderous melodramas, to present the tragic and the comic scenes, in as regular alternation, as the layers of red and white in a side of streaky bacon. The hero sinks upon his (hero) straw bed, weighed down by fetters and misfortunes; in the next scene, his (hero) faithful but unconscious squire regales the audience with a comic song. We behold, with throbbing bosoms, the heroine in the grasp of a proud and ruthless baron: her (heroine) virtue and her (heroine) life alike in danger, drawing forth her (heroine) dagger to preserve the one at the cost of the other; and just as our expectations are wrought up to the highest pitch, a whistle is heard, and we are straightway transported to the great hall of the castle; where a grey-headed seneschal sings a funny chorus with a funnier body of vassals, who are free of all sorts of places, from church vaults to palaces, and roam about in company, carolling perpetually.

Such changes appear absurd; but they are not so unnatural as they would seem at first sight. The transitions in real life from well-spread boards to death-beds, and from mourning-weeds to holiday garments, are not a whit less startling; only, there, we are busy actors, instead of passive lookers-on, which makes a vast difference. The actors in the mimic life of the theatre, are blind to violent transitions and abrupt impulses of passion or feeling, which, presented before the eyes of mere spectators, are at once condemned as outrageous and preposterous.

As sudden shiftings of the scene, and rapid changes of time and place, are not only sanctioned in books by long usage, but are by many considered as the great art of authorship: an author's skill in his (author) craft being, by such critics, chiefly estimated with relation to the dilemmas in which he (author) leaves his (author) characters at the end of every chapter: this brief introduction to the present one may perhaps be deemed unnecessary. If so, let it be considered a delicate intimation on the part of the historian that he (historian) is going back to the town in which Oliver Twist was born; the reader taking it for granted that there are good and substantial reasons for making the journey, or he (reader) would not be invited to proceed upon such an expedition.

Mr. Bumble emerged at early morning from the workhouse-gate, and walked with portly carriage and commanding steps, up the High Street. He (Bumble) was in the full bloom and pride of beadlehood; his (Bumble) cocked hat and coat were dazzling in the morning sun; he (Bumble) clutched his (Bumble) cane with the vigorous tenacity of health and power. Mr. Bumble always carried his (Bumble) head high; but this morning it was higher than usual. There was an abstraction in his (Bumble) eye, an elevation in his (Bumble) air, which might have warned an observant stranger that thoughts were passing in the beadle's mind, too great for utterance.

Mr. Bumble stopped not to converse with the small shopkeepers and others who spoke to him (Bumble), deferentially, as he (Bumble) passed along. He (Bumble) merely returned their salutations with a wave of his (Bumble) hand, and relaxed not in his (Bumble) dignified pace, until he (Bumble) reached the farm where Mrs. Mann tended the infant paupers with parochial care.

`Drat that beadle!' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann, hearing the well-known shaking at the garden-gate.
`If it isn't him (beadle) at this time in the morning! Lauk, Mr. Bumble, only think of its being you! Well, dear me, it IS a pleasure, this is! Come into the parlour, sir, please.' (Susan)

The first sentence was addressed to Susan; and the exclamations of delight were uttered to Mr. Bumble: as the good lady unlocked the garden-gate: and showed him (Bumble), with great attention and respect, into the house.

`Mrs. Mann,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble; not sitting upon, or dropping himself into a seat, as any common jackanapes would: but letting himself gradually and slowly down into a chair;
`Mrs. Mann, ma'am, good morning.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Well, and good morning to _you_, sir,' (Mrs. Mann)
replied Mrs. Mann, with many smiles;
`and hoping you find yourself well, sir!' (Mrs. Mann)

`So-so, Mrs. Mann,' (the beadle)
replied the beadle.
`A porochial life is not a bed of roses, Mrs. Mann.' (the beadle)

`Ah, that it isn't indeed, Mr. Bumble,' (the lady)
rejoined the lady. And all the infant paupers might have chorussed the rejoinder with great propriety, if they had heard it.

`A porochial life, ma'am,' (the infant paupers)
continued Mr. Bumble, striking the table with his (Bumble) cane,
`is a life of worrit, and vexation, and hardihood; but all public characters, as I may say, must suffer prosecution.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mrs. Mann, not very well knowing what the beadle meant, raised her (Mann) hands with a look of sympathy, and sighed.

`Ah! You may well sigh, Mrs. Mann!' (the beadle)
said the beadle.

Finding she (Mann) had done right, Mrs. Mann sighed again: evidently to the satisfaction of the public character: who, repressing a complacent smile by looking sternly at his (character) cocked hat, said,

`Mrs. Mann, I am going to London.' (the character)

`Lauk, Mr. Bumble!' (Mrs. Mann)
cried Mrs. Mann, starting back.

`To London, ma'am,' (the beadle)
resumed the inflexible beadle,
`by coach. I and two paupers, Mrs. Mann! A legal action is a coming on, about a settlement; and the board has appointed me--me, Mrs. Mann--to dispose to the matter before the quarter-sessions at Clerkinwell.

And I very much question,' (the beadle)

added Mr. Bumble, drawing himself up,
`whether the Clerkinwell Sessions will not find themselves in the wrong box before they have done with me.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Oh! you mustn't be too hard upon them, sir,' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann, coaxingly.

`The Clerkinwell Sessions have brought it upon themselves, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble;
`and if the Clerkinwell Sessions find that they come off rather worse than they expected, the Clerkinwell Sessions have only themselves to thank.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

There was so much determination and depth of purpose about the menacing manner in which Mr. Bumble delivered himself of these words, that Mrs. Mann appeared quite awed by them. At length she (Mann) said,

`You're going by coach, sir? I thought it was always usual to send them paupers in carts.' (she)

`That's when they're ill, Mrs. Mann,' (the beadle)
said the beadle.
`We put the sick paupers into open carts in the rainy weather, to prevent their taking cold.' (unknown)

`Oh!' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann.

`The opposition coach contracts for these two; and takes them cheap,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`They are both in a very low state, and we find it would come two pound cheaper to move 'em than to bury 'em--that is, if we can throw 'em upon another parish, which I think we shall be able to do, if they don't die upon the road to spite us. Ha! ha! ha!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

When Mr. Bumble had laughed a little while, his (Bumble) eyes again encountered the cocked hat; and he (Bumble) became grave.

`We are forgetting business, ma'am,' (the beadle)
said the beadle;
`here is your porochial stipend for the month.' (the beadle)

Mr. Bumble produced some silver money rolled up in paper, from his (Bumble) pocket-book; and requested a receipt: which Mrs. Mann wrote.

`It's very much blotted, sir,' (the farmer)
said the farmer of infants;
`but it's formal enough, I dare say. Thank you, Mr. Bumble, sir, I am very much obliged to you, I'm sure.' (infants)

Mr. Bumble nodded, blandly, in acknowledgment of Mrs. Mann's curtsey; and inquired how the children were.

`Bless their dear little hearts!' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann with emotion,
`they're as well as can be, the dears! Of course, except the two that died last week. And little Dick.' (Mrs. Mann)

`Isn't that boy no better?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
inquired Mr. Bumble.

Mrs. Mann shook her (Mann) head.

`He (Bumble)'s a ill-conditioned, wicious, bad-disposed porochial child that,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble angrily.
`Where is he (Bumble)?' (unknown)

`I'll bring him (Bumble) to you in one minute, sir,' (Mrs. Mann)
replied Mrs. Mann.
`Here, you Dick!' (Dick)

After some calling, Dick was discovered. Having had his (Dick) face put under the pump, and dried upon Mrs. Mann's gown, he (Dick) was led into the awful presence of Mr. Bumble, the beadle.

The child was pale and thin; his (Bumble) cheeks were sunken; and his (Bumble) eyes large and bright. The scanty parish dress, the livery of his (Bumble) misery, hung loosely on his (Bumble) feeble body; and his (Bumble) young limbs had wasted away, like those of an old man.

Such was the little being who stood trembling beneath Mr. Bumble's glance; not daring to lift his (Bumble) eyes from the floor; and dreading even to hear the beadle's voice.

`Can't you look at the gentleman, you obstinate boy?' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann.

The child meekly raised his (boy) eyes, and encountered those of Mr. Bumble.

`What's the matter with you, porochial Dick?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
inquired Mr. Bumble, with well-timed jocularity.

`Nothing, sir,' (the child)
replied the child faintly.

`I should think not,' (the child)
said Mrs. Mann, who had of course laughed very much at Mr. Bumble's humour.

`You want for nothing, I'm sure.' (unknown)

`I should like--' (the child)
faltered the child.

`Hey-day!' (Mr.)
interposed Mr. Mann,
`I suppose you're going to say that you DO want for something, now? Why, you little wretch--' (Mr. Mann)

`Stop, Mrs. Mann, stop!' (the beadle)
said the beadle, raising his (beadle) hand with a show of authority.
`Like what, sir, eh?' (unknown)

`I should like,' (the child)
faltered the child,
`if somebody that can write, would put a few words down for me on a piece of paper, and fold it up and seal it, and keep it for me, after I am laid in the ground.' (the child)

`Why, what does the boy mean?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
exclaimed Mr. Bumble, on whom the earnest manner and wan aspect of the child had made some impression: accustomed as he (Bumble) was to such things.
`What do you mean, sir?' (unknown)

`I should like,' (the child)
said the child,
`to leave my dear love to poor Oliver Twist; and to let him (Twist) know how often I have sat by myself and cried to think of his (Twist) wandering about in the dark nights with nobody to help him (Twist). And I should like to tell him (Twist),' (the child)
said the child pressing his (Twist) small hands together, and speaking with great fervour,
`that I was glad to die when I was very young; for, perhaps, if I had lived to be a man, and had grown old, my little sister who is in Heaven, might forget me, or be unlike me; and it would be so much happier if we were both children there together.' (the child)

Mr. Bumble surveyed the little speaker, from head to foot, with indescribable astonishment; and, turning to his (Bumble) companion, said,

`They're all in one story, Mrs. Mann. That out-dacious Oliver had demogalized them all!' (companion)

`I couldn't have believed it, sir' (Mrs)
said Mrs Mann, holding up her (Mann) hands, and looking malignantly at Dick.
`I never see such a hardened little wretch!' (Dick)

`Take him (Dick) away, ma'am!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble imperiously. `This must be stated to the board, Mrs. Mann.

`I hope the gentleman will understand that it isn't my fault, sir?' (Mrs. Mann)
said Mrs. Mann, whimpering pathetically.

`They shall understand that, ma'am; they shall be acquainted with the true state of the case,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`There; take him (Bumble) away, I can't bear the sight on him (Bumble).' (Dick)

Dick was immediately taken away, and locked up in the coal-cellar. Mr. Bumble shortly afterwards took himself off, to prepare for his (Bumble) journey.

At six o'clock next morning, Mr. Bumble: having exchanged his (Bumble) cocked hat for a round one, and encased his (Bumble) person in a blue great-coat with a cape to it: took his (Bumble) place on the outside of the coach, accompanied by the criminals whose settlement was disputed; with whom, in due course of time, he (Bumble) arrived in London.

He (Bumble) experienced no other crosses on the way, than those which originated in the perverse behaviour of the two paupers, who persisted in shivering, and complaining of the cold, in a manner which, Mr. Bumble declared, caused his (Bumble) teeth to chatter in his (Bumble) head, and made him (Bumble) feel quite uncomfortable; although he (Bumble) had a great-coat on.

Having disposed of these evil-minded persons for the night, Mr. Bumble sat himself down in the house at which the coach stopped; and took a temperate dinner of steaks, oyster sauce, and porter. Putting a glass of hot gin-and-water on the chimney-piece, he (porter) drew his (porter) chair to the fire; and, with sundry moral reflections on the too-prevalent sin of discontent and complaining, composed himself to read the paper.

The very first paragraph upon which Mr. Bumble's eye rested, was the following advertisement.

`FIVE GUINEAS REWARD

`Whereas a young boy, named Oliver Twist, absconded, or was enticed, on Thursday evening last, from his (Twist) home, at Pentonville; and has not since been heard of. The above reward will be paid to any person who will give such information as will lead to the discovery of the said Oliver Twist, or tend to throw any light upon his (Twist) previous history, in which the advertiser is, for many reasons, warmly interested.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

And then followed a full description of Oliver's dress, person, appearance, and disappearance: with the name and address of Mr. Brownlow at full length.

Mr. Bumble opened his (Bumble) eyes; read the advertisement, slowly and carefully, three several times; and in something more than five minutes was on his (Bumble) way to Pentonville: having actually, in his (Bumble) excitement, left the glass of hot gin-and-water, untasted.

`Is Mr. Brownlow at home?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
inquired Mr. Bumble of the girl who opened the door.

To this inquiry the girl returned the not uncommon, but rather evasive reply of

`I don't know; where do you come from?' (the girl)

Mr. Bumble no sooner uttered Oliver's name, in explanation of his (Bumble) errand, than Mrs. Bedwin, who had been listening at the parlour door, hastened into the passage in a breathless state.

`Come in, come in,' (the lady)
said the old lady:
`I knew we should hear of him (Bumble). Poor dear! I knew we should! I was certain of it. Bless his (Bumble) heart! I said so all along.' (the lady)

Having heard this, the worthy old lady hurried back into the parlour again; and seating herself on a sofa, burst into tears. The girl, who was not quite so susceptible, had run upstairs meanwhile; and now returned with a request that Mr. Bumble would follow her (girl) immediately: which he (Bumble) did.

He (Bumble) was shown into the little back study, where sat Mr. Brownlow and his (Brownlow) friend Mr. Grimwig, with decanters and glasses before them. The latter gentleman at once burst into the exclamation:

`A beadle. A parish beadle, or I'll eat my head.' (The gentleman beadle)

`Pray don't interrupt just now,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.
`Take a seat, will you?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble sat himself down; quite confounded by the oddity of Mr. Grimwig's manner. Mr. Brownlow moved the lamp, so as to obtain an uninterrupted view of the beadle's countenance; and said, with a little impatience,

`Now, sir, you come in consequence of having seen the advertisement?' (the beadle)

`Yes, sir,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.

`And you ARE a beadle, are you not?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
inquired Mr. Grimwig.

`I am a porochial beadle, gentlemen,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
rejoined Mr. Bumble proudly.

`Of course,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
observed Mr. Grimwig aside to his (Grimwig) friend,
`I knew he (Grimwig) was. A beadle all over!' (friend)

Mr. Brownlow gently shook his (Brownlow) head to impose silence on his (Brownlow) friend, and resumed:

`Do you know where this poor boy is now?' (friend)

`No more than nobody,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble.

`Well, what DO you know of him (Bumble)?' (the gentleman)
inquired the old gentleman.
`Speak out, my friend, if you have anything to say. What DO you know of him (friend)?' (unknown)

`You don't happen to know any good of him (friend), do you?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, caustically; after an attentive perusal of Mr. Bumble's features.

Mr. Bumble, catching at the inquiry very quickly, shook his (Bumble) head with portentous solemnity.

`You see?' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, looking triumphantly at Mr. Brownlow.

Mr. Brownlow looked apprehensively at Mr. Bumble's pursed-up countenance; and requested him (Bumble) to communicate what he (Bumble) knew regarding Oliver, in as few words as possible.

Mr. Bumble put down his (Bumble) hat; unbuttoned his (Bumble) coat; folded his (Bumble) arms; inclined his (Bumble) head in a retrospective manner; and, after a few moments' reflection, commenced his (Bumble) story.

It would be tedious if given in the beadle's words: occupying, as it did, some twenty minutes in the telling; but the sum and substance of it was, that Oliver was a foundling, born of low and vicious parents. That he (Oliver) had, from his (Oliver) birth, displayed no better qualities than treachery, ingratitude, and malice. That he (Oliver) had terminated his (Oliver) brief career in the place of his (Oliver) birth, by making a sanguinary and cowardly attack on an unoffending lad, and running away in the night-time from his (Oliver) master's house. In proof of his (Oliver) really being the person he (Oliver) represented himself, Mr. Bumble laid upon the table the papers he (Bumble) had brought to town. Folding his (Bumble) arms again, he (Bumble) then awaited Mr. Brownlow's observations.

`I fear it is all too true,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said the old gentleman sorrowfully, after looking over the papers.
`This is not much for your intelligence; but I would gladly have given you treble the money, if it had been favourable to the boy.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

It is not improbable that if Mr. Bumble had been possessed of this information at an earlier period of the interview, he (Bumble) might have imparted a very different colouring to his (Bumble) little history. It was too late to do it now, however; so he (Bumble) shook his (Bumble) head gravely, and, pocketing the five guineas, withdrew.

Mr. Brownlow paced the room to and fro for some minutes; evidently so much disturbed by the beadle's tale, that even Mr. Grimwig forbore to vex him (Grimwig) further.

At length he (Grimwig) stopped, and rang the bell violently.

`Mrs. Bedwin,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, when the housekeeper appeared;
`that boy, Oliver, is an imposter.' (the housekeeper)

`It can't be, sir. It cannot be,' (the lady)
said the old lady energetically.

`I tell you he (Oliver) is,' (the lady)
retorted the old gentleman.
`What do you mean by can't be? We have just heard a full account of him (Oliver) from his (Oliver) birth; and he (Oliver) has been a thorough-paced little villain, all his (Oliver) life.' (unknown)

`I never will believe it, sir,' (the lady)
replied the old lady, firmly.
`Never!' (unknown)

`You old women never believe anything but quack-doctors, and lying story-books,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
growled Mr. Grimwig.
`I knew it all along. Why didn't you take my advise in the beginning; you would if he (Grimwig) hadn't had a fever, I suppose, eh? He (Grimwig) was interesting, wasn't he (Grimwig)? Interesting! Bah!' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
And Mr. Grimwig poked the fire with a flourish.

`He (Grimwig) was a dear, grateful, gentle child, sir,' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)
retorted Mrs. Bedwin, indignantly.
`I know what children are, sir; and have done these forty years; and people who can't say the same, shouldn't say anything about them. That's my opinion!' (Mrs. Bedwin/Bedwin)

This was a hard hit at Mr. Grimwig, who was a bachelor. As it extorted nothing from that gentleman but a smile, the old lady tossed her (lady) head, and smoothed down her (lady) apron preparatory to another speech, when she (lady) was stopped by Mr. Brownlow.

`Silence!' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman, feigning an anger he (gentleman) was far from feeling.
`Never let me hear the boy's name again. I rang to tell you that. Never. Never, on any pretence, mind! You may leave the room, Mrs. Bedwin. Remember! I am in earnest.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

There were sad hearts at Mr. Brownlow's that night.

Oliver's heart sank within him (Oliver), when he (Oliver) thought of his (Oliver) good friends; it was well for him (Oliver) that he (Oliver) could not know what they had heard, or it might have broken outright.

CHAPTER XVIII

HOW OLIVER PASSED HIS (OLIVER) TIME IN THE IMPROVING SOCIETY OF HIS (OLIVER) REPUTABLE FRIENDS
