About noon next day, when the Dodger and Master Bates had gone out to pursue their customary avocations, Mr. Fagin took the opportunity of reading Oliver a long lecture on the crying sin of ingratitude; of which he (Oliver) clearly demonstrated he (Oliver) had been guilty, to no ordinary extent, in wilfully absenting himself from the society of his (Oliver) anxious friends; and, still more, in endeavouring to escape from them after so much trouble and expense had been incurred in his (Oliver) recovery. Mr. Fagin laid great stress on the fact of his (Fagin) having taken Oliver in, and cherished him (Fagin), when, without his (Fagin) timely aid, he (Fagin) might have perished with hunger; and he (Fagin) related the dismal and affecting history of a young lad whom, in his (Fagin) philanthropy, he (Fagin) had succoured under parallel circumstances, but who, proving unworthy of his (Fagin) confidence and evincing a desire to communicate with the police, had unfortunately come to be hanged at the Old Bailey one morning. Mr. Fagin did not seek to conceal his (Fagin) share in the catastrophe, but lamented with tears in his (Fagin) eyes that the wrong-headed and treacherous behaviour of the young person in question, had rendered it necessary that he (Fagin) should become the victim of certain evidence for the crown: which, if it were not precisely true, was indispensably necessary for the safety of him (Fagin) -LRB-Mr. Fagin-RRB- and a few select friends. Mr. Fagin concluded by drawing a rather disagreeable picture of the discomforts of hanging; and, with great friendliness and politeness of manner, expressed his (Fagin) anxious hopes that he (Fagin) might never be obliged to submit Oliver Twist to that unpleasant operation.

Little Oliver's blood ran cold, as he (Oliver) listened to the Jew's words, and imperfectly comprehended the dark threats conveyed in them. That it was possible even for justice itself to confound the innocent with the guilty when they were in accidental companionship, he (Oliver) knew already; and that deeply-laid plans for the destruction of inconveniently knowing or over-communicative persons, had been really devised and carried out by the Jew on more occasions than one, he (Jew) thought by no means unlikely, when he (Jew) recollected the general nature of the altercations between that gentleman and Mr. Sikes: which seemed to bear reference to some foregone conspiracy of the kind. As he (Sikes) glanced timidly up, and met the Jew's searching look, he (Sikes) felt that his (Sikes) pale face and trembling limbs were neither unnoticed nor unrelished by that wary old gentleman.

The Jew, smiling hideously, patted Oliver on the head, and said, that if he (Oliver) kept himself quiet, and applied himself to business, he (Oliver) saw they would be very good friends yet. Then, taking his (Oliver) hat, and covering himself with an old patched great-coat, he (Oliver) went out, and locked the room-door behind him (Oliver).

And so Oliver remained all that day, and for the greater part of many subsequent days, seeing nobody, between early morning and midnight, and left during the long hours to commune with his (Oliver) own thoughts. Which, never failing to revert to his (Oliver) kind friends, and the opinion they must long ago have formed of him (Oliver), were sad indeed.

After the lapse of a week or so, the Jew left the room-door unlocked; and he (Jew) was at liberty to wander about the house.

It was a very dirty place. The rooms upstairs had great high wooden chimney-pieces and large doors, with panelled walls and cornices to the ceiling; which, although they were black with neglect and dust, were ornamented in various ways. From all of these tokens Oliver concluded that a long time ago, before the old Jew was born, it had belonged to better people, and had perhaps been quite gay and handsome: dismal and dreary as it looked now.

Spiders had built their webs in the angles of the walls and ceilings; and sometimes, when Oliver walked softly into a room, the mice would scamper across the floor, and run back terrified to their holes. With these exceptions, there was neither sight nor sound of any living thing; and often, when it grew dark, and he (Oliver) was tired of wandering from room to room, he (Oliver) would crouch in the corner of the passage by the street-door, to be as near living people as he (Oliver) could; and would remain there, listening and counting the hours, until the Jew or the boys returned.

In all the rooms, the mouldering shutters were fast closed: the bars which held them were screwed tight into the wood; the only light which was admitted, stealing its way through round holes at the top: which made the rooms more gloomy, and filled them with strange shadows. There was a back-garret window with rusty bars outside, which had no shutter; and out of this, Oliver often gazed with a melancholy face for hours together; but nothing was to be descried from it but a confused and crowded mass of housetops, blackened chimneys, and gable-ends. Sometimes, indeed, a grizzly head might be seen, peering over the parapet-wall of a distant house; but it was quickly withdrawn again; and as the window of Oliver's observatory was nailed down, and dimmed with the rain and smoke of years, it was as much as he (Oliver) could do to make out the forms of the different objects beyond, without making any attempt to be seen or heard,--which he (Oliver) had as much chance of being, as if he (Oliver) had lived inside the ball of St. Paul's Cathedral.

One afternoon, the Dodger and Master Bates being engaged out that evening, the first-named young gentleman took it into his (gentleman) head to evince some anxiety regarding the decoration of his (gentleman) person -LRB-to do him (gentleman) justice, this was by no means an habitual weakness with him (gentleman)-RRB-; and, with this end and aim, he (gentleman) condescendingly commanded Oliver to assist him (Oliver) in his (Oliver) toilet, straightway.

Oliver was but too glad to make himself useful; too happy to have some faces, however bad, to look upon; too desirous to conciliate those about him (Oliver) when he (Oliver) could honestly do so; to throw any objection in the way of this proposal. So he (Oliver) at once expressed his (Oliver) readiness; and, kneeling on the floor, while the Dodger sat upon the table so that he (Dodger) could take his (Dodger) foot in his (Dodger) laps, he (Dodger) applied himself to a process which Mr. Dawkins designated as

`japanning his (Dawkins) trotter-cases.' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)
The phrase, rendered into plain English, signifieth, cleaning his (Dawkins) boots.

Whether it was the sense of freedom and independence which a rational animal may be supposed to feel when he (Dawkins) sits on a table in an easy attitude smoking a pipe, swinging one leg carelessly to and fro, and having his (Dawkins) boots cleaned all the time, without even the past trouble of having taken them off, or the prospective misery of putting them on, to disturb his (Dawkins) reflections; or whether it was the goodness of the tobacco that soothed the feelings of the Dodger, or the mildness of the beer that mollified his (Dodger) thoughts; he (Dodger) was evidently tinctured, for the nonce, with a spice of romance and enthusiasm, foreign to his (Dodger) general nature. He (Dodger) looked down on Oliver, with a thoughtful countenance, for a brief space; and then, raising his (Oliver) head, and heaving a gentle sign, said, half in abstraction, and half to Master Bates:

`What a pity it is he (Bates) isn't a prig!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

`Ah!' (Master)
said Master Charles Bates;
`he (Bates) don't know what's good for him (Bates).' (Master Charles Bates)

The Dodger sighed again, and resumed his (Dodger) pipe: as did Charley Bates. They both smoked, for some seconds, in silence.

`I suppose you don't even know what a prig is?' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger mournfully.

`I think I know that,' (the Dodger)
replied Oliver, looking up.
`It's a the--; you're one, are you not?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver, checking himself.

`I am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied the Doger.
`I'd scorn to be anything else.' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)
Mr. Dawkins gave his (Dawkins) hat a ferocious cock, after delivering this sentiment, and looked at Master Bates, as if to denote that he (Bates) would feel obliged by his (Bates) saying anything to the contrary.

`I am,' (he)
repeated the Dodger.
`So's Charley. So's Fagin. So's Sikes. So's Nancy. So's Bet. So we all are, down to the dog. And he (Sikes)'s the downiest one of the lot!' (unknown)

`And the least given to peaching,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
added Charley Bates.

`He (Bates) wouldn't so much as bark in a witness-box, for fear of committing himself; no, not if you tied him (Bates) up in one, and left him (Bates) there without wittles for a fortnight,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger.

`Not a bit of it,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
observed Charley.

`He (Charley)'s a rum dog. Don't he (Charley) look fierce at any strange cove that laughs or sings when he (Charley)'s in company!' (the Dodger)
pursued the Dodger.
`Won't he (Dodger) growl at all, when he (Dodger) hears a fiddle playing! And don't he (Dodger) hate other dogs as ain't of his (Dodger) breed! Oh, no!' (unknown)

`He (Dodger)'s an out-and-out Christian,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley.

This was merely intended as a tribute to the animal's abilities, but it was an appropriate remark in another sense, if Master Bates had only known it; for there are a good many ladies and gentlemen, claiming to be out-and-out Christians, between whom, and Mr. Sikes' dog, there exist strong and singular points of resemblance.

`Well, well,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, recurring to the point from which they had strayed: with that mindfulness of his (Dodger) profession which influenced all his (Dodger) proceedings.
`This hasn't go anything to do with young Green here.' (unknown)

`No more it has,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley.
`Why don't you put yourself under Fagin, Oliver?' (unknown)

`And make your fortun' (unknown)
out of hand?' added the Dodger, with a grin.

`And so be able to retire on your property, and do the gen-teel: as I mean to, in the very next leap-year but four that ever comes, and the forty-second Tuesday in Trinity-week,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley Bates.

`I don't like it,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
rejoined Oliver, timidly;
`I wish they would let me go. I--I--would rather go.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`And Fagin would RATHER not!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
rejoined Charley.

Oliver knew this too well; but thinking it might be dangerous to express his (Oliver) feelings more openly, he (Oliver) only sighed, and went on with his (Oliver) boot-cleaning.

`Go!' (the Dodger)
exclaimed the Dodger.
`Why, where's your spirit?' (unknown)
Don't you take any pride out of yourself? Would you go and be dependent on your friends?'

`Oh, blow that!' (Master)
said Master Bates: drawing two or three silk handkerchiefs from his (Bates) pocket, and tossing them into a cupboard,
`that's too mean; that is.' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

`_I_ couldn't do it,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said the Dodger, with an air of haughty disgust.

`You can leave your friends, though,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver with a half smile;
`and let them be punished for what you did.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`That,' (the Dodger)
rejoined the Dodger, with a wave of his (Dodger) pipe,
`That was all out of consideration for Fagin, 'cause the traps know that we work together, and he (Fagin) might have got into trouble if we hadn't made our lucky; that was the move, wasn't it, Charley?' (the Dodger)

Master Bates nodded assent, and would have spoken, but the recollection of Oliver's flight came so suddenly upon him (Oliver), that the smoke he (Oliver) was inhaling got entangled with a laugh, and went up into his (Oliver) head, and down into his (Oliver) throat: and brought on a fit of coughing and stamping, about five minutes long.

`Look here!' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, drawing forth a handful of shillings and halfpence.
`Here's a jolly life! What's the odds where it comes from? Here, catch hold; there's plenty more where they were took from. You won't, won't you? Oh, you precious flat!' (unknown)

`It's naughty, ain't it, Oliver?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
inquired Charley Bates.
`He (Bates)'ll come to be scragged, won't he (Bates)?' (unknown)

`I don't know what that means,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Something in this way, old feller,' (Charly)
said Charly. As he (Oliver) said it, Master Bates caught up an end of his (Bates) neckerchief; and, holding it erect in the air, dropped his (Bates) head on his (Bates) shoulder, and jerked a curious sound through his (Bates) teeth; thereby indicating, by a lively pantomimic representation, that scragging and hanging were one and the same thing.

`That's what it means,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley. `Look how he (Charley) stares, Jack!

I never did see such prime company as that

`ere boy; he (boy)'ll be the death of me, I know he (boy) will.' (I)
Master Charley Bates, having laughed heartily again, resumed his (Bates) pipe with tears in his (Bates) eyes.

`You've been brought up bad,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, surveying his (Dodger) boots with much satisfaction when Oliver had polished them.
`Fagin will make something of you, though, or you'll be the first he (Fagin) ever had that turned out unprofitable. You'd better begin at once; for you'll come to the trade long before you think of it; and you're only losing time, Oliver.' (Master)

Master Bates backed this advice with sundry moral admonitions of his (Bates) own: which, being exhausted, he (Bates) and his (Bates) friend Mr. Dawkins launched into a glowing description of the numerous pleasures incidental to the life they led, interspersed with a variety of hints to Oliver that the best thing he (Oliver) could do, would be to secure Fagin's favour without more delay, by the means which they themselves had employed to gain it.

`And always put this in your pipe, Nolly,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, as the Jew was heard unlocking the door above,
`if you don't take fogels and tickers--' (the Jew)

`What's the good of talking in that way?' (the Jew)
interposed Master Bates;
`he (Bates) don't know what you mean.' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

`If you don't take pocket-handkechers and watches,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, reducing his (Dodger) conversation to the level of Oliver's capacity,
`some other cove will; so that the coves that lose 'em will be all the worse, and you'll be all the worse, too, and nobody half a ha`p`orth the better, except the chaps wot gets them--and you've just as good a right to them as they have.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`To be sure, to be sure!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, who had entered unseen by Oliver.
`It all lies in a nutshell my dear; in a nutshell, take the Dodger's word for it. Ha! ha! ha! He (Dodger) understands the catechism of his (Dodger) trade.' (The man)

The old man rubbed his (Dodger) hands gleefully together, as he (Dodger) corroborated the Dodger's reasoning in these terms; and chuckled with delight at his (Dodger) pupil's proficiency.

The conversation proceeded no farther at this time, for the Jew had returned home accompanied by Miss Betsy, and a gentleman whom Oliver had never seen before, but who was accosted by the Dodger as Tom Chitling; and who, having lingered on the stairs to exchange a few gallantries with the lady, now made his (Dodger) appearance.

Mr. Chitling was older in years than the Dodger: having perhaps numbered eighteen winters; but there was a degree of deference in his (Dodger) deportment towards that young gentleman which seemed to indicate that he (Dodger) felt himself conscious of a slight inferiority in point of genius and professional aquirements. He (Dodger) had small twinkling eyes, and a pock-marked face; wore a fur cap, a dark corduroy jacket, greasy fustian trousers, and an apron. His (Dodger) wardrobe was, in truth, rather out of repair; but he (Dodger) excused himself to the company by stating that his (Dodger)

`time' (he)
was only out an hour before; and that, in consequence of having worn the regimentals for six weeks past, he (Dodger) had not been able to bestow any attention on his (Dodger) private clothes. Mr. Chitling added, with strong marks of irritation, that the new way of fumigating clothes up yonder was infernal unconstitutional, for it burnt holes in them, and there was no remedy against the County. The same remark he (Chitling) considered to apply to the regulation mode of cutting the hair: which he (Chitling) held to be decidedly unlawful. Mr. Chitling wound up his (Chitling) observations by stating that he (Chitling) had not touched a drop of anything for forty-two moral long hard-working days; and that he (Chitling)
`wished he (Chitling) might be busted if he (Chitling) warn't as dry as a lime-basket.' (he)

`Where do you think the gentleman has come from, Oliver?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew, with a grin, as the other boys put a bottle of spirits on the table.

`I--I--don't know, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Who's that?' (Tom Chitling)
inquired Tom Chitling, casting a contemptuous look at Oliver.

`A young friend of mine, my dear,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied the Jew.

`He (Jew)'s in luck, then,' (the man)
said the young man, with a meaning look at Fagin. `Never mind where I came from, young
`un; you'll find your way there, soon enough, I'll bet a crown!' (I)

At this sally, the boys laughed. After some more jokes on the same subject, they exchanged a few short whispers with Fagin; and withdrew.

After some words apart between the last comer and Fagin, they drew their chairs towards the fire; and the Jew, telling Oliver to come and sit by him (Oliver), led the conversation to the topics most calculated to interest his (Oliver) hearers. These were, the great advantages of the trade, the proficiency of the Dodger, the amiability of Charley Bates, and the liberality of the Jew himself. At length these subjects displayed signs of being thoroughly exhausted; and Mr. Chitling did the same: for the house of correction becomes fatiguing after a week or two. Miss Betsy accordingly withdrew; and left the party to their repose.

From this day, Oliver was seldom left alone; but was placed in almost constant communication with the two boys, who played the old game with the Jew every day: whether for their own improvement or Oliver's, Mr. Fagin best knew. At other times the old man would tell them stories of robberies he (man) had committed in his (man) younger days: mixed up with so much that was droll and curious, that Oliver could not help laughing heartily, and showing that he (Oliver) was amused in spite of all his (Oliver) better feelings.

In short, the wily old Jew had the boy in his (Jew) toils. Having prepared his (Jew) mind, by solitude and gloom, to prefer any society to the companionship of his (Jew) own sad thoughts in such a dreary place, he (Jew) was now slowly instilling into his (Jew) soul the poison which he (Jew) hoped would blacken it, and change its hue for ever.

CHAPTER XIX

IN WHICH A NOTABLE PLAN IS DISCUSSED AND DETERMINED ON

It was a chill, damp, windy night, when the Jew: buttoning his (Jew) great-coat tight round his (Jew) shrivelled body, and pulling the collar up over his (Jew) ears so as completely to obscure the lower part of his (Jew) face: emerged from his (Jew) den. He (Jew) paused on the step as the door was locked and chained behind him (Jew); and having listened while the boys made all secure, and until their retreating footsteps were no longer audible, slunk down the street as quickly as he (Jew) could.

The house to which Oliver had been conveyed, was in the neighborhood of Whitechapel. The Jew stopped for an instant at the corner of the street; and, glancing suspiciously round, crossed the road, and struck off in the direction of the Spitalfields.

The mud lay thick upon the stones, and a black mist hung over the streets; the rain fell sluggishly down, and everything felt cold and clammy to the touch. It seemed just the night when it befitted such a being as the Jew to be abroad. As he (Jew) glided stealthily along, creeping beneath the shelter of the walls and doorways, the hideous old man seemed like some loathsome reptile, engendered in the slime and darkness through which he (man) moved: crawling forth, by night, in search of some rich offal for a meal.

He (man) kept on his (man) course, through many winding and narrow ways, until he (man) reached Bethnal Green; then, turning suddenly off to the left, he (man) soon became involved in a maze of the mean and dirty streets which abound in that close and densely-populated quarter.

The Jew was evidently too familiar with the ground he (Jew) traversed to be at all bewildered, either by the darkness of the night, or the intricacies of the way. He (Jew) hurried through several alleys and streets, and at length turned into one, lighted only by a single lamp at the farther end. At the door of a house in this street, he (Jew) knocked; having exchanged a few muttered words with the person who opened it, he (Jew) walked upstairs.

A dog growled as he (Jew) touched the handle of a room-door; and a man's voice demanded who was there.

`Only me, Bill; only me, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew looking in.

`Bring in your body then,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Lie down, you stupid brute! Don't you know the devil when he (devil)'s got a great-coat on?' (the dog)

Apparently, the dog had been somewhat deceived by Mr. Fagin's outer garment; for as the Jew unbuttoned it, and threw it over the back of a chair, he (Jew) retired to the corner from which he (Jew) had risen: wagging his (Jew) tail as he (Jew) went, to show that he (Jew) was as well satisfied as it was in his (Jew) nature to be.

`Well!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

`Well, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.--`Ah! Nancy.'

The latter recognition was uttered with just enough of embarrassment to imply a doubt of its reception; for Mr. Fagin and his (Fagin) young friend had not met, since she (Nancy) had interfered in behalf of Oliver. All doubts upon the subject, if he (Oliver) had any, were speedily removed by the young lady's behaviour. She (lady) took her (lady) feet off the fender, pushed back her (lady) chair, and bade Fagin draw up his (Fagin), without saying more about it: for it was a cold night, and no mistake.

`It is cold, Nancy dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, as he (Jew) warmed his (Jew) skinny hands over the fire.
`It seems to go right through one,' (the man)
added the old man, touching his (man) side.

`It must be a piercer, if it finds its way through your heart,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes.
`Give him (Sikes) something to drink, Nancy. Burn my body, make haste! It's enough to turn a man ill, to see his (man) lean old carcase shivering in that way, like a ugly ghost just rose from the grave.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

Nancy quickly brought a bottle from a cupboard, in which there were many: which, to judge from the diversity of their appearance, were filled with several kinds of liquids. Sikes pouring out a glass of brandy, bade the Jew drink it off.

`Quite enough, quite, thankye, Bill,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, putting down the glass after just setting his (Bill) lips to it.

`What! You're afraid of our getting the better of you, are you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes, fixing his (Sikes) eyes on the Jew.
`Ugh!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

With a hoarse grunt of contempt, Mr. Sikes seized the glass, and threw the remainder of its contents into the ashes: as a preparatory ceremony to filling it again for himself: which he (Sikes) did at once.

The Jew glanced round the room, as his (Jew) companion tossed down the second glassful; not in curiousity, for he (Jew) had seen it often before; but in a restless and suspicious manner habitual to him (Jew). It was a meanly furnished apartment, with nothing but the contents of the closet to induce the belief that its occupier was anything but a working man; and with no more suspicious articles displayed to view than two or three heavy bludgeons which stood in a corner, and a

`life-preserver' (a man)
that hung over the chimney-piece.

`There,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, smacking his (Sikes) lips.
`Now I'm ready.' (unknown)

`For business?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew.

`For business,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes;
`so say what you've got to say.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`About the crib at Chertsey, Bill?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, drawing his (Jew) chair forward, and speaking in a very low voice.

`Yes. Wot about it?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`Ah! you know what I mean, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`He (Jew) knows what I mean, Nancy; don't he (Jew)?' (unknown)

`No, he (Jew) don't,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
sneered Mr. Sikes.
`Or he (Sikes) won't, and that's the same thing. Speak out, and call things by their right names; don't sit there, winking and blinking, and talking to me in hints, as if you warn't the very first that thought about the robbery. Wot d'ye mean?' (unknown)

`Hush, Bill, hush!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, who had in vain attempted to stop this burst of indignation;
`somebody will hear us, my dear. Somebody will hear us.' (the Jew)

`Let 'em hear!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes;
`I don't care.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
But as Mr. Sikes DID care, on reflection, he (Sikes) dropped his (Sikes) voice as he (Sikes) said the words, and grew calmer.

`There, there,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, coaxingly.
`It was only my caution, nothing more. Now, my dear, about that crib at Chertsey; when is it to be done, Bill, eh? When is it to be done? Such plate, my dear, such plate!' (the Jew)
said the Jew: rubbing his (Jew) hands, and elevating his (Jew) eyebrows in a rapture of anticipation.

`Not at all,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes coldly.

`Not to be done at all!' (the Jew)
echoed the Jew, leaning back in his (Jew) chair.

`No, not at all,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes.
`At least it can't be a put-up job, as we expected.' (unknown)

`Then it hasn't been properly gone about,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning pale with anger.
`Don't tell me!' (unknown)

`But I will tell you,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
retorted Sikes.
`Who are you that's not to be told? I tell you that Toby Crackit has been hanging about the place for a fortnight, and he (Crackit) can't get one of the servants in line.' (unknown)

`Do you mean to tell me, Bill,' (the Jew)
said the Jew: softening as the other grew heated:
`that neither of the two men in the house can be got over?' (the Jew)

`Yes, I do mean to tell you so,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.
`The old lady has had 'em these twenty years; and if you were to give 'em five hundred pound, they wouldn't be in it.' (unknown)

`But do you mean to say, my dear,' (the Jew)
remonstrated the Jew,
`that the women can't be got over?' (the Jew)

`Not a bit of it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.

`Not by flash Toby Crackit?' (the Jew)
said the Jew incredulously.
`Think what women are, Bill,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`No; not even by flash Toby Crackit,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.
`He (Sikes) says he (Sikes)'s worn sham whiskers, and a canary waistcoat, the whole blessed time he (Sikes)'s been loitering down there, and it's all of no use.' (unknown)

`He (Sikes) should have tried mustachios and a pair of military trousers, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew.

`So he (Jew) did,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes,
`and they warn't of no more use than the other plant.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

The Jew looked blank at this information. After ruminating for some minutes with his (Jew) chin sunk on his (Jew) breast, he (Jew) raised his (Jew) head and said, with a deep sigh, that if flash Toby Crackit reported aright, he (Crackit) feared the game was up.

`And yet,' (the man)
said the old man, dropping his (man) hands on his (man) knees,
`it's a sad thing, my dear, to lose so much when we had set our hearts upon it.' (the man)

`So it is,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes.
`Worse luck!' (unknown)

A long silence ensued; during which the Jew was plunged in deep thought, with his (Jew) face wrinkled into an expression of villainy perfectly demoniacal. Sikes eyed him (Sikes) furtively from time to time. Nancy, apparently fearful of irritating the housebreaker, sat with her (Nancy) eyes fixed upon the fire, as if she (Nancy) had been deaf to all that passed.

`Fagin,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, abruptly breaking the stillness that prevailed;
`is it worth fifty shiners extra, if it's safely done from the outside?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Yes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, as suddenly rousing himself.

`Is it a bargain?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`Yes, my dear, yes,' (the Jew)
rejoined the Jew; his (Jew) eyes glistening, and every muscle in his (Jew) face working, with the excitement that the inquiry had awakened.

`Then,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, thrusting aside the Jew's hand, with some disdain,
`let it come off as soon as you like. Toby and me were over the garden-wall the night afore last, sounding the panels of the door and shutters. The crib's barred up at night like a jail; but there's one part we can crack, safe and softly.' (the Jew)

`Which is that, Bill?' (the Jew)
asked the Jew eagerly.

`Why,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
whispered Sikes,
`as you cross the lawn--' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Yes?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said the Jew, bending his (Jew) head forward, with his (Jew) eyes almost starting out of it.

`Umph!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, stopping short, as the girl, scarcely moving her (girl) head, looked suddenly round, and pointed for an instant to the Jew's face.
`Never mind which part it is. You can't do it without me, I know; but it's best to be on the safe side when one deals with you.' (unknown)

`As you like, my dear, as you like' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.
`Is there no help wanted, but yours and Toby's?' (unknown)

`None,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Cept a centre-bit and a boy. The first we've both got; the second you must find us.' (unknown)

`A boy!' (the Jew)
exclaimed the Jew.
`Oh! then it's a panel, eh?' (unknown)

`Never mind wot it is!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes. `I want a boy, and he (Sikes) musn't be a big
`un. Lord!' (he)
said Mr. Sikes, reflectively, `if I'd only got that young boy of Ned, the chimbley-sweeper's! He (Sikes) kept him (Sikes) small on purpose, and let him (Sikes) out by the job. But the father gets lagged; and then the Juvenile Delinquent Society comes, and takes the boy away from a trade where he (boy) was earning money, teaches him (boy) to read and write, and in time makes a
`prentice of him (prentice). And so they go on,' (him)
said Mr. Sikes, his (Sikes) wrath rising with the recollection of his (Sikes) wrongs,
`so they go on; and, if they'd got money enough -LRB-which it's a Providence they haven't,-RRB- we shouldn't have half a dozen boys left in the whole trade, in a year or two.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`No more we should,' (the Jew)
acquiesced the Jew, who had been considering during this speech, and had only caught the last sentence.
`Bill!' (unknown)

`What now?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

The Jew nodded his (Jew) head towards Nancy, who was still gazing at the fire; and intimated, by a sign, that he (Jew) would have her (Nancy) told to leave the room. Sikes shrugged his (Sikes) shoulders impatiently, as if he (Sikes) thought the precaution unnecessary; but complied, nevertheless, by requesting Miss Nancy to fetch him (Sikes) a jug of beer.

`You don't want any beer,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy, folding her (Nancy) arms, and retaining her (Nancy) seat very composedly.

`I tell you I do!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Sikes.

`Nonsense,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl coolly,
`Go on, Fagin. I know what he (Fagin)'s going to say, Bill; he (Bill) needn't mind me.' (the girl)

The Jew still hesitated. Sikes looked from one to the other in some surprise.

`Why, you don't mind the old girl, do you, Fagin?' (he)
he (Fagin) asked at length.
`You've known her (girl) long enough to trust her (girl), or the Devil's in it. She (girl) ain't one to blab. Are you Nancy?' (unknown)

`_I_ should think not!' (the lady)
replied the young lady: drawing her (lady) chair up to the table, and putting her (lady) elbows upon it.

`No, no, my dear, I know you're not,' (the Jew)
said the Jew;
`but--' (the Jew)
and again the old man paused.

`But wot?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`I didn't know whether she (lady) mightn't p`r`aps be out of sorts, you know, my dear, as she (lady) was the other night,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied the Jew.

At this confession, Miss Nancy burst into a loud laugh; and, swallowing a glass of brandy, shook her (Nancy) head with an air of defiance, and burst into sundry exclamations of

`Keep the game a-going!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
`Never say die!' (unknown)
and the like. These seemed to have the effect of re-assuring both gentlemen; for the Jew nodded his (Jew) head with a satisfied air, and resumed his (Jew) seat: as did Mr. Sikes likewise.

`Now, Fagin,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy with a laugh.
`Tell Bill at once, about Oliver!' (unknown)

`Ha! you're a clever one, my dear: the sharpest girl I ever saw!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, patting her (girl) on the neck.
`It WAS about Oliver I was going to speak, sure enough. Ha! ha! ha!' (unknown)

`What about him (Oliver)?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
demanded Sikes.

`He (Sikes)'s the boy for you, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew in a hoarse whisper; laying his (Jew) finger on the side of his (Jew) nose, and grinning frightfully.

`He (Jew)!' (unknown)
exclaimed. Sikes.

`Have him (Sikes), Bill!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy.
`I would, if I was in your place. He (Bill) mayn't be so much up, as any of the others; but that's not what you want, if he (Bill)'s only to open a door for you. Depend upon it he (Bill)'s a safe one, Bill.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`I know he (Bill) is,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Fagin.
`He (Fagin)'s been in good training these last few weeks, and it's time he (Fagin) began to work for his (Fagin) bread. Besides, the others are all too big.' (unknown)

`Well, he (Fagin) is just the size I want,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, ruminating.

`And will do everything you want, Bill, my dear,' (the Jew)
interposed the Jew;
`he (Bill) can't help himself. That is, if you frighten him (Bill) enough.' (the Jew)

`Frighten him (Bill)!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
echoed Sikes.
`It'll be no sham frightening, mind you. If there's anything queer about him (Sikes) when we once get into the work; in for a penny, in for a pound. You won't see him (Sikes) alive again, Fagin. Think of that, before you send him (Fagin). Mark my words!' (the robber)
said the robber, poising a crowbar, which he (robber) had drawn from under the bedstead.

`I've thought of it all,' (the Jew)
said the Jew with energy. `I've--I've had my eye upon him (Jew), my dears, close--close. Once let him (Jew) feel that he (Jew) is one of us; once fill his (Jew) mind with the idea that he (Jew) has been a thief; and he (Jew)'s ours! Ours for his (Jew) life. Oho! It couldn't have come about better! The old man crossed his (man) arms upon his (man) breast; and, drawing his (man) head and shoulders into a heap, literally hugged himself for joy.

`Ours!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Yours, you mean.' (unknown)

`Perhaps I do, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, with a shrill chuckle.
`Mine, if you like, Bill.' (unknown)

`And wot,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, scowling fiercely on his (Sikes) agreeable friend,
`wot makes you take so much pains about one chalk-faced kid, when you know there are fifty boys snoozing about Common Garden every night, as you might pick and choose from?' (friend wot)

`Because they're of no use to me, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, with some confusion,
`not worth the taking. Their looks convict 'em when they get into trouble, and I lose 'em all. With this boy, properly managed, my dears, I could do what I couldn't with twenty of them. Besides,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, recovering his (Jew) self-possession,
`he (Jew) has us now if he (Jew) could only give us leg-bail again; and he (Jew) must be in the same boat with us. Never mind how he (Jew) came there; it's quite enough for my power over him (Jew) that he (Jew) was in a robbery; that's all I want. Now, how much better this is, than being obliged to put the poor leetle boy out of the way--which would be dangerous, and we should lose by it besides.' (the Jew)

`When is it to be done?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
asked Nancy, stopping some turbulent exclamation on the part of Mr. Sikes, expressive of the disgust with which he (Sikes) received Fagin's affectation of humanity.

`Ah, to be sure,' (the Jew)
said the Jew;
`when is it to be done, Bill?' (the Jew)

`I planned with Toby, the night arter to-morrow,' (the Jew)
rejoined Sikes in a surly voice,
`if he (Sikes) heerd nothing from me to the contrairy.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Good,' (the Jew)
said the Jew;
`there's no moon.' (the Jew)

`No,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes.

`It's all arranged about bringing off the swag, is it?' (the Jew)
asked the Jew.

Sikes nodded.

`And about--' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Oh, ah, it's all planned,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes, interrupting him (Sikes).
`Never mind particulars. You'd better bring the boy here to-morrow night. I shall get off the stone an hour arter daybreak. Then you hold your tongue, and keep the melting-pot ready, and that's all you'll have to do.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

After some discussion, in which all three took an active part, it was decided that Nancy should repair to the Jew's next evening when the night had set in, and bring Oliver away with her (Nancy); Fagin craftily observing, that, if he (Fagin) evinced any disinclination to the task, he (Fagin) would be more willing to accompany the girl who had so recently interfered in his (Fagin) behalf, than anybody else. It was also solemnly arranged that poor Oliver should, for the purposes of the contemplated expedition, be unreservedly consigned to the care and custody of Mr. William Sikes; and further, that the said Sikes should deal with him (Sikes) as he (Sikes) thought fit; and should not be held responsible by the Jew for any mischance or evil that might be necessary to visit him (Jew): it being understood that, to render the compact in this respect binding, any representations made by Mr. Sikes on his (Sikes) return should be required to be confirmed and corroborated, in all important particulars, by the testimony of flash Toby Crackit.

These preliminaries adjusted, Mr. Sikes proceeded to drink brandy at a furious rate, and to flourish the crowbar in an alarming manner; yelling forth, at the same time, most unmusical snatches of song, mingled with wild execrations. At length, in a fit of professional enthusiasm, he (Sikes) insisted upon producing his (Sikes) box of housebreaking tools: which he (Sikes) had no sooner stumbled in with, and opened for the purpose of explaining the nature and properties of the various implements it contained, and the peculiar beauties of their construction, than he (Sikes) fell over the box upon the floor, and went to sleep where he (Sikes) fell.

`Good-night, Nancy,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, muffling himself up as before.

`Good-night.' (the Jew)

Their eyes met, and the Jew scrutinised her (Nancy), narrowly. There was no flinching about the girl. She (girl) was as true and earnest in the matter as Toby Crackit himself could be.

The Jew again bade her (girl) good-night, and, bestowing a sly kick upon the prostrate form of Mr. Sikes while her (girl) back was turned, groped downstairs.

`Always the way!' (the Jew)
muttered the Jew to himself as he (Jew) turned homeward.
`The worst of these women is, that a very little thing serves to call up some long-forgotten feeling; and, the best of them is, that it never lasts. Ha! ha! The man against the child, for a bag of gold!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Beguiling the time with these pleasant reflections, Mr. Fagin wended his (Fagin) way, through mud and mire, to his (Fagin) gloomy abode: where the Dodger was sitting up, impatiently awaiting his (Dodger) return.

`Is Oliver a-bed? I want to speak to him (Oliver),' (unknown)
was his (Oliver) first remark as they descended the stairs.

`Hours ago,' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger, throwing open a door.
`Here he (Dodger) is!' (The boy)

The boy was lying, fast asleep, on a rude bed upon the floor; so pale with anxiety, and sadness, and the closeness of his (boy) prison, that he (boy) looked like death; not death as it shows in shroud and coffin, but in the guise it wears when life has just departed; when a young and gentle spirit has, but an instant, fled to Heaven, and the gross air of the world has not had time to breathe upon the changing dust it hallowed.

`Not now,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning softly away.
`To-morrow. To-morrow.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

CHAPTER XX

WHEREIN OLIVER IS DELIVERED OVER TO MR. WILLIAM SIKES

When Oliver awoke in the morning, he (Oliver) was a good deal surprised to find that a new pair of shoes, with strong thick soles, had been placed at his (Oliver) bedside; and that his (Oliver) old shoes had been removed. At first, he (Oliver) was pleased with the discovery: hoping that it might be the forerunner of his (Oliver) release; but such thoughts were quickly dispelled, on his (Oliver) sitting down to breakfast along with the Jew, who told him (Jew), in a tone and manner which increased his (Jew) alarm, that he (Jew) was to be taken to the residence of Bill Sikes that night.

`To--to--stop there, sir?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver, anxiously.

`No, no, my dear. Not to stop there,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.
`We shouldn't like to lose you. Don't be afraid, Oliver, you shall come back to us again. Ha! ha! ha! We won't be so cruel as to send you away, my dear. Oh no, no!' (The man)

The old man, who was stooping over the fire toasting a piece of bread, looked round as he (man) bantered Oliver thus; and chuckled as if to show that he (Oliver) knew he (Oliver) would still be very glad to get away if he (Oliver) could.

`I suppose,' (he)
said the Jew, fixing his (Jew) eyes on Oliver,
`you want to know what you're going to Bill's for--eh, my dear?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver coloured, involuntarily, to find that the old thief had been reading his (Oliver) thoughts; but boldly said, Yes, he (Oliver) did want to know.

`Why, do you think?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin, parrying the question.

`Indeed I don't know, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Bah!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning away with a disappointed countenance from a close perusal of the boy's face.
`Wait till Bill tells you, then.' (The Jew)

The Jew seemed much vexed by Oliver's not expressing any greater curiosity on the subject; but the truth is, that, although Oliver felt very anxious, he (Oliver) was too much confused by the earnest cunning of Fagin's looks, and his (Oliver) own speculations, to make any further inquiries just then. He (Oliver) had no other opportunity: for the Jew remained very surly and silent till night: when he (Jew) prepared to go abroad.

`You may burn a candle,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, putting one upon the table.
`And here's a book for you to read, till they come to fetch you. Good-night!' (unknown)

`Good-night!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, softly.

The Jew walked to the door: looking over his (Jew) shoulder at the boy as he (Jew) went. Suddenly stopping, he (Jew) called him (Jew) by his (Jew) name.

Oliver looked up; the Jew, pointing to the candle, motioned him (Oliver) to light it. He (Oliver) did so; and, as he (Oliver) placed the candlestick upon the table, saw that the Jew was gazing fixedly at him (Jew), with lowering and contracted brows, from the dark end of the room.

`Take heed, Oliver! take heed!' (the man)
said the old man, shaking his (Oliver) right hand before him (Oliver) in a warning manner.
`He (Oliver)'s a rough man, and thinks nothing of blood when his (Oliver) own is up. Whatever falls out, say nothing; and do what he (Oliver) bids you. Mind!' (he)
Placing a strong emphasis on the last word, he (Oliver) suffered his (Oliver) features gradually to resolve themselves into a ghastly grin, and, nodding his (Oliver) head, left the room.

Oliver leaned his (Oliver) head upon his (Oliver) hand when the old man disappeared, and pondered, with a trembling heart, on the words he (Oliver) had just heard. The more he (Oliver) thought of the Jew's admonition, the more he (Jew) was at a loss to divine its real purpose and meaning.

He (Jew) could think of no bad object to be attained by sending him (Jew) to Sikes, which would not be equally well answered by his (Sikes) remaining with Fagin; and after meditating for a long time, concluded that he (Sikes) had been selected to perform some ordinary menial offices for the housebreaker, until another boy, better suited for his (boy) purpose could be engaged. He (boy) was too well accustomed to suffering, and had suffered too much where he (boy) was, to bewail the prospect of change very severely. He (boy) remained lost in thought for some minutes; and then, with a heavy sigh, snuffed the candle, and, taking up the book which the Jew had left with him (Jew), began to read.

He (Jew) turned over the leaves. Carelessly at first; but, lighting on a passage which attracted his (Jew) attention, he (Jew) soon became intent upon the volume. It was a history of the lives and trials of great criminals; and the pages were soiled and thumbed with use. Here, he (Jew) read of dreadful crimes that made the blood run cold; of secret murders that had been committed by the lonely wayside; of bodies hidden from the eye of man in deep pits and wells: which would not keep them down, deep as they were, but had yielded them up at last, after many years, and so maddened the murderers with the sight, that in their horror they had confessed their guilt, and yelled for the gibbet to end their agony. Here, too, he (man) read of men who, lying in their beds at dead of night, had been tempted -LRB-so they said-RRB- and led on, by their own bad thoughts, to such dreadful bloodshed as it made the flesh creep, and the limbs quail, to think of. The terrible descriptions were so real and vivid, that the sallow pages seemed to turn red with gore; and the words upon them, to be sounded in his (creep) ears, as if they were whispered, in hollow murmurs, by the spirits of the dead.

In a paroxysm of fear, the boy closed the book, and thrust it from him (boy). Then, falling upon his (boy) knees, he (boy) prayed Heaven to spare him (boy) from such deeds; and rather to will that he (boy) should die at once, than be reserved for crimes, so fearful and appalling. By degrees, he (boy) grew more calm, and besought, in a low and broken voice, that he (boy) might be rescued from his (boy) present dangers; and that if any aid were to be raised up for a poor outcast boy who had never known the love of friends or kindred, it might come to him (boy) now, when, desolate and deserted, he (boy) stood alone in the midst of wickedness and guilt.

He (boy) had concluded his (boy) prayer, but still remained with his (boy) head buried in his (boy) hands, when a rustling noise aroused him (boy).

`What's that!' (he)
he (boy) cried, starting up, and catching sight of a figure standing by the door.
`Who's there?' (unknown)

`Me. Only me,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied a tremulous voice.

Oliver raised the candle above his (Oliver) head: and looked towards the door. It was Nancy.

`Put down the light,' (the girl)
said the girl, turning away her (girl) head.
`It hurts my eyes.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver saw that she (girl) was very pale, and gently inquired if she (girl) were ill. The girl threw herself into a chair, with her (girl) back towards him (Oliver): and wrung her (girl) hands; but made no reply.

`God forgive me!' (she)
she (girl) cried after a while,
`I never thought of this.' (she)

`Has anything happened?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver.
`Can I help you? I will if I can. I will, indeed.' (She)

She (girl) rocked herself to and fro; caught her (girl) throat; and, uttering a gurgling sound, gasped for breath.

`Nancy!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver,
`What is it?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The girl beat her (girl) hands upon her (girl) knees, and her (girl) feet upon the ground; and, suddenly stopping, drew her (girl) shawl close round her (girl): and shivered with cold.

Oliver stirred the fire. Drawing her (girl) chair close to it, she (girl) sat there, for a little time, without speaking; but at length she (girl) raised her (girl) head, and looked round.

`I don't know what comes over me sometimes,' (she)
said she (girl), affecting to busy herself in arranging her (girl) dress;
`it's this damp dirty room, I think. Now, Nolly, dear, are you ready?' (she)

`Am I to go with you?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver.

`Yes. I have come from Bill,' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`You are to go with me.' (unknown)

`What for?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver, recoiling.

`What for?' (the girl)
echoed the girl, raising her (girl) eyes, and averting them again, the moment they encountered the boy's face.
`Oh! For no harm.' (unknown)

`I don't believe it,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver: who had watched her (girl) closely.

`Have it your own way,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl, affecting to laugh.
`For no good, then.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver could see that he (Oliver) had some power over the girl's better feelings, and, for an instant, thought of appealing to her (girl) compassion for his (Oliver) helpless state. But, then, the thought darted across his (Oliver) mind that it was barely eleven o'clock; and that many people were still in the streets: of whom surely some might be found to give credence to his (Oliver) tale. As the reflection occured to him (Oliver), he (Oliver) stepped forward: and said, somewhat hastily, that he (Oliver) was ready.

Neither his (Oliver) brief consideration, nor its purport, was lost on his (Oliver) companion. She (girl) eyed him (Oliver) narrowly, while he (Oliver) spoke; and cast upon him (Oliver) a look of intelligence which sufficiently showed that she (girl) guessed what had been passing in his (Oliver) thoughts.

`Hush!' (the girl)
said the girl, stooping over him (Oliver), and pointing to the door as she (girl) looked cautiously round.
`You can't help yourself. I have tried hard for you, but all to no purpose. You are hedged round and round. If ever you are to get loose from here, this is not the time.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Struck by the energy of her (girl) manner, Oliver looked up in her (girl) face with great surprise. She (girl) seemed to speak the truth; her (girl) countenance was white and agitated; and she (girl) trembled with very earnestness.

`I have saved you from being ill-used once, and I will again, and I do now,' (she)
continued the girl aloud;
`for those who would have fetched you, if I had not, would have been far more rough than me. I have promised for your being quiet and silent; if you are not, you will only do harm to yourself and me too, and perhaps be my death. See here! I have borne all this for you already, as true as God sees me show it.' (the girl)

She (girl) pointed, hastily, to some livid bruises on her (girl) neck and arms; and continued, with great rapidity:

`Remember this! And don't let me suffer more for you, just now. If I could help you, I would; but I have not the power. They don't mean to harm you; whatever they make you do, is no fault of yours. Hush! Every word from you is a blow for me. Give me your hand. Make haste! Your hand!' (She)

She (girl) caught the hand which Oliver instinctively placed in hers, and, blowing out the light, drew him (Oliver) after her (girl) up the stairs. The door was opened, quickly, by some one shrouded in the darkness, and was as quickly closed, when they had passed out. A hackney-cabriolet was in waiting; with the same vehemence which she (girl) had exhibited in addressing Oliver, the girl pulled him (Oliver) in with her (girl), and drew the curtains close. The driver wanted no directions, but lashed his (driver) horse into full speed, without the delay of an instant.

The girl still held Oliver fast by the hand, and continued to pour into his (Oliver) ear, the warnings and assurances she (girl) had already imparted. All was so quick and hurried, that he (Oliver) had scarcely time to recollect where he (Oliver) was, or how he (Oliver) came there, when the carriage stopped at the house to which the Jew's steps had been directed on the previous evening.

For one brief moment, Oliver cast a hurried glance along the empty street, and a cry for help hung upon his (Oliver) lips. But the girl's voice was in his (Oliver) ear, beseeching him (Oliver) in such tones of agony to remember her (girl), that he (Oliver) had not the heart to utter it. While he (Oliver) hesitated, the opportunity was gone; he (Oliver) was already in the house, and the door was shut.

`This way,' (the girl)
said the girl, releasing her (girl) hold for the first time.
`Bill!' (unknown)

`Hallo!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes: appearing at the head of the stairs, with a candle.
`Oh! That's the time of day. Come on!' (a person)

This was a very strong expression of approbation, an uncommonly hearty welcome, from a person of Mr. Sikes' temperament. Nancy, appearing much gratified thereby, saluted him (Sikes) cordially.

`Bull's-eye's gone home with Tom,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
observed Sikes, as he (Sikes) lighted them up.
`He (Sikes)'d have been in the way.' (unknown)

`That's right,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
rejoined Nancy.

`So you've got the kid,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes when they had all reached the room: closing the door as he (Sikes) spoke.

`Yes, here he (Sikes) is,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy.

`Did he (Sikes) come quiet?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`Like a lamb,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
rejoined Nancy.

`I'm glad to hear it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, looking grimly at Oliver; `for the sake of his (Sikes) young carcase: as would otherways have suffered for it. Come here, young
`un; and let me read you a lectur' (unknown)
, which is as well got over at once.'

Thus addressing his (Sikes) new pupil, Mr. Sikes pulled off Oliver's cap and threw it into a corner; and then, taking him (Sikes) by the shoulder, sat himself down by the table, and stood the boy in front of him (boy).

`Now, first: do you know wot this is?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes, taking up a pocket-pistol which lay on the table.

Oliver replied in the affirmative.

`Well, then, look here,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
continued Sikes. `This is powder; that
`ere's a bullet; and this is a little bit of a old hat for waddin' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
.'

Oliver murmured his (Oliver) comprehension of the different bodies referred to; and Mr. Sikes proceeded to load the pistol, with great nicety and deliberation.

`Now it's loaded,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes, when he (Sikes) had finished.

`Yes, I see it is, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`Well,' (the robber)
said the robber, grasping Oliver's wrist, and putting the barrel so close to his (Oliver) temple that they touched; at which moment the boy could not repress a start;
`if you speak a word when you're out o'doors with me, except when I speak to you, that loading will be in your head without notice. So, if you _do_ make up your mind to speak without leave, say your prayers first.' (the boy)

Having bestowed a scowl upon the object of this warning, to increase its effect, Mr. Sikes continued.

`As near as I know, there isn't anybody as would be asking very partickler arter you, if you _was_ disposed of; so I needn't take this devil-and-all of trouble to explain matters to you, if it warn't for your own good. D'ye hear me?' (unknown)

`The short and the long of what you mean,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy: speaking very emphatically, and slightly frowning at Oliver as if to bespeak his (Oliver) serious attention to her (Nancy) words:
`is, that if you're crossed by him (Oliver) in this job you have on hand, you'll prevent his (Oliver) ever telling tales afterwards, by shooting him (Oliver) through the head, and will take your chance of swinging for it, as you do for a great many other things in the way of business, every month of your life.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`That's it!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
observed Mr. Sikes, approvingly;
`women can always put things in fewest words.--Except when it's blowing up; and then they lengthens it out. And now that he (Sikes)'s thoroughly up to it, let's have some supper, and get a snooze before starting.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

In pursuance of this request, Nancy quickly laid the cloth; disappearing for a few minutes, she (Nancy) presently returned with a pot of porter and a dish of sheep's heads: which gave occasion to several pleasant witticisms on the part of Mr. Sikes, founded upon the singular coincidence of

`jemmies' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
being a can name, common to them, and also to an ingenious implement much used in his (Sikes) profession. Indeed, the worthy gentleman, stimulated perhaps by the immediate prospect of being on active service, was in great spirits and good humour; in proof whereof, it may be here remarked, that he (gentleman) humourously drank all the beer at a draught, and did not utter, on a rough calculation, more than four-score oaths during the whole progress of the meal.

Supper being ended--it may be easily conceived that Oliver had no great appetite for it--Mr. Sikes disposed of a couple of glasses of spirits and water, and threw himself on the bed; ordering Nancy, with many imprecations in case of failure, to call him (Sikes) at five precisely. Oliver stretched himself in his (Oliver) clothes, by command of the same authority, on a mattress upon the floor; and the girl, mending the fire, sat before it, in readiness to rouse them at the appointed time.

For a long time Oliver lay awake, thinking it not impossible that Nancy might seek that opportunity of whispering some further advice; but the girl sat brooding over the fire, without moving, save now and then to trim the light. Weary with watching and anxiety, he (Oliver) at length fell asleep.

When he (Oliver) awoke, the table was covered with tea-things, and Sikes was thrusting various articles into the pockets of his (Sikes) great-coat, which hung over the back of a chair. Nancy was busily engaged in preparing breakfast. It was not yet daylight; for the candle was still burning, and it was quite dark outside. A sharp rain, too, was beating against the window-panes; and the sky looked black and cloudy.

`Now, then!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes, as Oliver started up;
`half-past five! Look sharp, or you'll get no breakfast; for it's late as it is.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver was not long in making his (Oliver) toilet; having taken some breakfast, he (Oliver) replied to a surly inquiry from Sikes, by saying that he (Sikes) was quite ready.

Nancy, scarcely looking at the boy, threw him (Sikes) a handkerchief to tie round his (Sikes) throat; Sikes gave him (Sikes) a large rough cape to button over his (Sikes) shoulders. Thus attired, he (Sikes) gave his (Sikes) hand to the robber, who, merely pausing to show him (Sikes) with a menacing gesture that he (Sikes) had that same pistol in a side-pocket of his (Sikes) great-coat, clasped it firmly in his (Sikes), and, exchanging a farewell with Nancy, led him (Sikes) away.

Oliver turned, for an instant, when they reached the door, in the hope of meeting a look from the girl. But she (girl) had resumed her (girl) old seat in front of the fire, and sat, perfectly motionless before it.

CHAPTER XXI

THE EXPEDITION

It was a cheerless morning when they got into the street; blowing and raining hard; and the clouds looking dull and stormy. The night had been very wet: large pools of water had collected in the road: and the kennels were overflowing. There was a faint glimmering of the coming day in the sky; but it rather aggravated than relieved the gloom of the scene: the sombre light only serving to pale that which the street lamps afforded, without shedding any warmer or brighter tints upon the wet house-tops, and dreary streets. There appeared to be nobody stirring in that quarter of the town; the windows of the houses were all closely shut; and the streets through which they passed, were noiseless and empty.

By the time they had turned into the Bethnal Green Road, the day had fairly begun to break. Many of the lamps were already extinguished; a few country waggons were slowly toiling on, towards London; now and then, a stage-coach, covered with mud, rattled briskly by: the driver bestowing, as he (driver) passed, an admonitory lash upon the heavy waggoner who, by keeping on the wrong side of the road, had endangered his (driver) arriving at the office, a quarter of a minute after his (driver) time. The public-houses, with gas-lights burning inside, were already open. By degrees, other shops began to be unclosed, and a few scattered people were met with. Then, came straggling groups of labourers going to their work; then, men and women with fish-baskets on their heads; donkey-carts laden with vegetables; chaise-carts filled with live-stock or whole carcasses of meat; milk-women with pails; an unbroken concourse of people, trudging out with various supplies to the eastern suburbs of the town. As they approached the City, the noise and traffic gradually increased; when they threaded the streets between Shoreditch and Smithfield, it had swelled into a roar of sound and bustle. It was as light as it was likely to be, till night came on again, and the busy morning of half the London population had begun.

Turning down Sun Street and Crown Street, and crossing Finsbury square, Mr. Sikes struck, by way of Chiswell Street, into Barbican: thence into Long Lane, and so into Smithfield; from which latter place arose a tumult of discordant sounds that filled Oliver Twist with amazement.

It was market-morning. The ground was covered, nearly ankle-deep, with filth and mire; a thick steam, perpetually rising from the reeking bodies of the cattle, and mingling with the fog, which seemed to rest upon the chimney-tops, hung heavily above. All the pens in the centre of the large area, and as many temporary pens as could be crowded into the vacant space, were filled with sheep; tied up to posts by the gutter side were long lines of beasts and oxen, three or four deep. Countrymen, butchers, drovers, hawkers, boys, thieves, idlers, and vagabonds of every low grade, were mingled together in a mass; the whistling of drovers, the barking dogs, the bellowing and plunging of the oxen, the bleating of sheep, the grunting and squeaking of pigs, the cries of hawkers, the shouts, oaths, and quarrelling on all sides; the ringing of bells and roar of voices, that issued from every public-house; the crowding, pushing, driving, beating, whooping and yelling; the hideous and discordant dim that resounded from every corner of the market; and the unwashed, unshaven, squalid, and dirty figures constantly running to and fro, and bursting in and out of the throng; rendered it a stunning and bewildering scene, which quite confounded the senses.

Mr. Sikes, dragging Oliver after him (Sikes), elbowed his (Sikes) way through the thickest of the crowd, and bestowed very little attention on the numerous sights and sounds, which so astonished the boy. He (boy) nodded, twice or thrice, to a passing friend; and, resisting as many invitations to take a morning dram, pressed steadily onward, until they were clear of the turmoil, and had made their way through Hosier Lane into Holborn.

`Now, young

`un!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, looking up at the clock of St. Andrew's Church,
`hard upon seven! you must step out. Come, don't lag behind already, Lazy-legs!' (St. Andrew)

Mr. Sikes accompanied this speech with a jerk at his (Sikes) little companion's wrist; Oliver, quickening his (Oliver) pace into a kind of trot between a fast walk and a run, kept up with the rapid strides of the house-breaker as well as he (Oliver) could.

They held their course at this rate, until they had passed Hyde Park corner, and were on their way to Kensington: when Sikes relaxed his (Sikes) pace, until an empty cart which was at some little distance behind, came up. Seeing

`Hounslow' (he)
written on it, he (Sikes) asked the driver with as much civility as he (Sikes) could assume, if he (Sikes) would give them a lift as far as Isleworth.

`Jump up,' (the man)
said the man.
`Is that your boy?' (unknown)

`Yes; he (boy)'s my boy,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, looking hard at Oliver, and putting his (Oliver) hand abstractedly into the pocket where the pistol was.

`Your father walks rather too quick for you, don't he (father), my man?' (the driver)
inquired the driver: seeing that Oliver was out of breath.

`Not a bit of it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, interposing.
`He (Sikes)'s used to it.

Here, take hold of my hand, Ned. In with you!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Thus addressing Oliver, he (Oliver) helped him (Oliver) into the cart; and the driver, pointing to a heap of sacks, told him (driver) to lie down there, and rest himself.

As they passed the different mile-stones, Oliver wondered, more and more, where his (Oliver) companion meant to take him (Oliver). Kensington, Hammersmith, Chiswick, Kew Bridge, Brentford, were all passed; and yet they went on as steadily as if they had only just begun their journey. At length, they came to a public-house called the Coach and Horses; a little way beyond which, another road appeared to run off. And here, the cart stopped.

Sikes dismounted with great precipitation, holding Oliver by the hand all the while; and lifting him (Sikes) down directly, bestowed a furious look upon him (Sikes), and rapped the side-pocket with his (Sikes) fist, in a significant manner.

`Good-bye, boy,' (the man)
said the man.

`He (man)'s sulky,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, giving him (Sikes) a shake;
`he (Sikes)'s sulky. A young dog! Don't mind him (Sikes).' (him)

`Not I!' (unknown)
rejoined the other, getting into his (Sikes) cart.
`It's a fine day, after all.' (he)
And he (Sikes) drove away.

Sikes waited until he (Sikes) had fairly gone; and then, telling Oliver he (Oliver) might look about him (Oliver) if he (Oliver) wanted, once again led him (Oliver) onward on his (Oliver) journey.

They turned round to the left, a short way past the public-house; and then, taking a right-hand road, walked on for a long time: passing many large gardens and gentlemen's houses on both sides of the way, and stopping for nothing but a little beer, until they reached a town. Here against the wall of a house, Oliver saw written up in pretty large letters,

`Hampton.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
They lingered about, in the fields, for some hours. At length they came back into the town; and, turning into an old public-house with a defaced sign-board, ordered some dinner by the kitchen fire.

The kitchen was an old, low-roofed room; with a great beam across the middle of the ceiling, and benches, with high backs to them, by the fire; on which were seated several rough men in smock-frocks, drinking and smoking. They took no notice of Oliver; and very little of Sikes; and, as Sikes took very little notice of them, he (Sikes) and his (Sikes) young comrade sat in a corner by themselves, without being much troubled by their company.

They had some cold meat for dinner, and sat so long after it, while Mr. Sikes indulged himself with three or four pipes, that Oliver began to feel quite certain they were not going any further. Being much tired with the walk, and getting up so early, he (Oliver) dozed a little at first; then, quite overpowered by fatigue and the fumes of the tobacco, fell asleep.

It was quite dark when he (Oliver) was awakened by a push from Sikes. Rousing himself sufficiently to sit up and look about him (Sikes), he (Sikes) found that worthy in close fellowship and communication with a labouring man, over a pint of ale.

`So, you're going on to Lower Halliford, are you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
inquired Sikes.

`Yes, I am,' (the man)
replied the man, who seemed a little the worse--or better, as the case might be--for drinking;
`and not slow about it neither. My horse hasn't got a load behind him (Sikes) going back, as he (Sikes) had coming up in the mornin' (the man)
; and he (Sikes) won't be long a-doing of it. Here's luck to him (Sikes). Ecod! he (Sikes)'s a good
`un!' (he)

`Could you give my boy and me a lift as far as there?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
demanded Sikes, pushing the ale towards his (Sikes) new friend.

`If you're going directly, I can,' (the man)
replied the man, looking out of the pot.
`Are you going to Halliford?' (unknown)

`Going on to Shepperton,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.

`I'm your man, as far as I go,' (unknown)
replied the other.
`Is all paid, Becky?' (unknown)

`Yes, the other gentleman's paid,' (the girl)
replied the girl.

`I say!' (the girl)
said the man, with tipsy gravity;
`that won't do, you know.' (the man)

`Why not?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Sikes.
`You're a-going to accommodate us, and wot's to prevent my standing treat for a pint or so, in return?' (The stranger fellow)

The stranger reflected upon this argument, with a very profound face; having done so, he (stranger) seized Sikes by the hand: and declared he (Sikes) was a real good fellow. To which Mr. Sikes replied, he (Sikes) was joking; as, if he (Sikes) had been sober, there would have been strong reason to suppose he (Sikes) was.

After the exchange of a few more compliments, they bade the company good-night, and went out; the girl gathering up the pots and glasses as they did so, and lounging out to the door, with her (girl) hands full, to see the party start.

The horse, whose health had been drunk in his (Sikes) absence, was standing outside: ready harnessed to the cart. Oliver and Sikes got in without any further ceremony; and the man to whom he (man) belonged, having lingered for a minute or two

`to bear him (man) up,' (he)
and to defy the hostler and the world to produce his (man) equal, mounted also. Then, the hostler was told to give the horse his (man) head; and, his (man) head being given him (man), he (man) made a very unpleasant use of it: tossing it into the air with great disdain, and running into the parlour windows over the way; after performing those feats, and supporting himself for a short time on his (man) hind-legs, he (man) started off at great speed, and rattled out of the town right gallantly.

The night was very dark. A damp mist rose from the river, and the marshy ground about; and spread itself over the dreary fields. It was piercing cold, too; all was gloomy and black. Not a word was spoken; for the driver had grown sleepy; and Sikes was in no mood to lead him (Sikes) into conversation. Oliver sat huddled together, in a corner of the cart; bewildered with alarm and apprehension; and figuring strange objects in the gaunt trees, whose branches waved grimly to and fro, as if in some fantastic joy at the desolation of the scene.

As they passed Sunbury Church, the clock struck seven. There was a light in the ferry-house window opposite: which streamed across the road, and threw into more sombre shadow a dark yew-tree with graves beneath it. There was a dull sound of falling water not far off; and the leaves of the old tree stirred gently in the night wind. It seemed like quiet music for the repose of the dead.

Sunbury was passed through, and they came again into the lonely road. Two or three miles more, and the cart stopped. Sikes alighted, took Oliver by the hand, and they once again walked on.

They turned into no house at Shepperton, as the weary boy had expected; but still kept walking on, in mud and darkness, through gloomy lanes and over cold open wastes, until they came within sight of the lights of a town at no great distance. On looking intently forward, Oliver saw that the water was just below them, and that they were coming to the foot of a bridge.

Sikes kept straight on, until they were close upon the bridge; then turned suddenly down a bank upon the left.

`The water!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
thought Oliver, turning sick with fear.
`He (Oliver) has brought me to this lonely place to murder me!' (He)

He (Oliver) was about to throw himself on the ground, and make one struggle for his (Oliver) young life, when he (Oliver) saw that they stood before a solitary house: all ruinous and decayed. There was a window on each side of the dilapidated entrance; and one story above; but no light was visible. The house was dark, dismantled: and the all appearance, uninhabited.

Sikes, with Oliver's hand still in his (Oliver), softly approached the low porch, and raised the latch. The door yielded to the pressure, and they passed in together.

CHAPTER XXII

THE BURGLARY

`Hallo!' (unknown)
cried a loud, hoarse voice, as soon as they set foot in the passage.

`Don't make such a row,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, bolting the door.
`Show a glim, Toby.' (unknown)

`Aha! my pal!' (unknown)
cried the same voice.
`A glim, Barney, a glim! Show the gentleman in, Barney; wake up first, if convenient.' (The speaker)

The speaker appeared to throw a boot-jack, or some such article, at the person he (speaker) addressed, to rouse him (speaker) from his (speaker) slumbers: for the noise of a wooden body, falling violently, was heard; and then an indistinct muttering, as of a man between sleep and awake.

`Do you hear?' (unknown)
cried the same voice.
`There's Bill Sikes in the passage with nobody to do the civil to him (Sikes); and you sleeping there, as if you took laudanum with your meals, and nothing stronger. Are you any fresher now, or do you want the iron candlestick to wake you thoroughly?' (unknown)

A pair of slipshod feet shuffled, hastily, across the bare floor of the room, as this interrogatory was put; and there issued, from a door on the right hand; first, a feeble candle: and next, the form of the same individual who has been heretofore described as labouring under the infirmity of speaking through his (individual) nose, and officiating as waiter at the public-house on Saffron Hill.

`Bister Sikes!' (Barney)
exclaimed Barney, with real or counterfeit joy;
`cub id, sir; cub id.' (Barney)

`Here! you get on first,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, putting Oliver in front of him (Sikes).
`Quicker! or I shall tread upon your heels.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Muttering a curse upon his (Sikes) tardiness, Sikes pushed Oliver before him (Sikes); and they entered a low dark room with a smoky fire, two or three broken chairs, a table, and a very old couch: on which, with his (Sikes) legs much higher than his (Sikes) head, a man was reposing at full length, smoking a long clay pipe. He (Sikes) was dressed in a smartly-cut snuff-coloured coat, with large brass buttons; an orange neckerchief; a coarse, staring, shawl-pattern waistcoat; and drab breeches. Mr. Crackit -LRB-for he (Crackit) it was-RRB- had no very great quantity of hair, either upon his (Crackit) head or face; but what he (Crackit) had, was of a reddish dye, and tortured into long corkscrew curls, through which he (Crackit) occasionally thrust some very dirty fingers, ornamented with large common rings. He (Crackit) was a trifle above the middle size, and apparently rather weak in the legs; but this circumstance by no means detracted from his (Crackit) own admiration of his (Crackit) top-boots, which he (Crackit) contemplated, in their elevated situation, with lively satisfaction.

`Bill, my boy!' (unknown)
said this figure, turning his (Bill) head towards the door,
`I'm glad to see you. I was almost afraid you'd given it up: in which case I should have made a personal wentur. Hallo!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Uttering this exclamation in a tone of great surprise, as his (Bill) eyes rested on Oliver, Mr. Toby Crackit brought himself into a sitting posture, and demanded who that was.

`The boy. Only the boy!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, drawing a chair towards the fire.

`Wud of Bister Fagid's lads,' (Barney)
exclaimed Barney, with a grin.

`Fagin's, eh!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
exclaimed Toby, looking at Oliver.
`Wot an inwalable boy that'll make, for the old ladies' (unknown)
pockets in chapels! His (Oliver) mug is a fortin' to him (Oliver).'

`There--there's enough of that,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
interposed Sikes, impatiently; and stooping over his (Sikes) recumbant friend, he (Sikes) whispered a few words in his (Sikes) ear: at which Mr. Crackit laughed immensely, and honoured Oliver with a long stare of astonishment.

`Now,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, as he (Sikes) resumed his (Sikes) seat,
`if you'll give us something to eat and drink while we're waiting, you'll put some heart in us; or in me, at all events. Sit down by the fire, younker, and rest yourself; for you'll have to go out with us again to-night, though not very far off.' (he)

Oliver looked at Sikes, in mute and timid wonder; and drawing a stool to the fire, sat with his (Oliver) aching head upon his (Oliver) hands, scarecely knowing where he (Oliver) was, or what was passing around him (Oliver).

`Here,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby, as the young Jew placed some fragments of food, and a bottle upon the table,
`Success to the crack!' (the Jew)
He (Toby) rose to honour the toast; and, carefully depositing his (Toby) empty pipe in a corner, advanced to the table, filled a glass with spirits, and drank off its contents. Mr. Sikes did the same.

`A drain for the boy,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Toby, half-filling a wine-glass.
`Down with it, innocence.' (unknown)

`Indeed,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
