said Oliver, looking piteously up into the man's face;
`indeed, I--' (the man)

`Down with it!' (the man)
echoed Toby.
`Do you think I don't know what's good for you? Tell him (Toby) to drink it, Bill.' (unknown)

`He (Bill) had better!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes clapping his (Sikes) hand upon his (Sikes) pocket.
`Burn my body, if he (Sikes) isn't more trouble than a whole family of Dodgers. Drink it, you perwerse imp; drink it!' (the men)

Frightened by the menacing gestures of the two men, Oliver hastily swallowed the contents of the glass, and immediately fell into a violent fit of coughing: which delighted Toby Crackit and Barney, and even drew a smile from the surly Mr. Sikes.

This done, and Sikes having satisfied his (Sikes) appetite -LRB-Oliver could eat nothing but a small crust of bread which they made him (Oliver) swallow-RRB-, the two men laid themselves down on chairs for a short nap. Oliver retained his (Oliver) stool by the fire; Barney wrapped in a blanket, stretched himself on the floor: close outside the fender.

They slept, or appeared to sleep, for some time; nobody stirring but Barney, who rose once or twice to throw coals on the fire. Oliver fell into a heavy doze: imagining himself straying along the gloomy lanes, or wandering about the dark churchyard, or retracing some one or other of the scenes of the past day: when he (Oliver) was roused by Toby Crackit jumping up and declaring it was half-past one.

In an instant, the other two were on their legs, and all were actively engaged in busy preparation. Sikes and his (Sikes) companion enveloped their necks and chins in large dark shawls, and drew on their great-coats; Barney, opening a cupboard, brought forth several articles, which he (Barney) hastily crammed into the pockets.

`Barkers for me, Barney,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby Crackit.

`Here they are,' (Barney)
replied Barney, producing a pair of pistols.
`You loaded them yourself.' (unknown)

`All right!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
replied Toby, stowing them away.
`The persuaders?' (unknown)

`I've got 'em,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.

`Crape, keys, centre-bits, darkies--nothing forgotten?' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
inquired Toby: fastening a small crowbar to a loop inside the skirt of his (Toby) coat.

`All right,' (companion)
rejoined his (Toby) companion.
`Bring them bits of timber, Barney. That's the time of day.' (he)

With these words, he (Barney) took a thick stick from Barney's hands, who, having delivered another to Toby, busied himself in fastening on Oliver's cape.

`Now then!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, holding out his (Sikes) hand.

Oliver: who was completely stupified by the unwonted exercise, and the air, and the drink which had been forced upon him (Oliver): put his (Oliver) hand mechanically into that which Sikes extended for the purpose.

`Take his (Sikes) other hand, Toby,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Look out, Barney.' (The man)

The man went to the door, and returned to announce that all was quiet. The two robbers issued forth with Oliver between them. Barney, having made all fast, rolled himself up as before, and was soon asleep again.

It was now intensely dark. The fog was much heavier than it had been in the early part of the night; and the atmosphere was so damp, that, although no rain fell, Oliver's hair and eyebrows, within a few minutes after leaving the house, had become stiff with the half-frozen moisture that was floating about. They crossed the bridge, and kept on towards the lights which he (Oliver) had seen before. They were at no great distance off; and, as they walked pretty briskly, they soon arrived at Chertsey.

`Slap through the town,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
whispered Sikes;
`there'll be nobody in the way, to-night, to see us.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Toby acquiesced; and they hurried through the main street of the little town, which at that late hour was wholly deserted. A dim light shone at intervals from some bed-room window; and the hoarse barking of dogs occasionally broke the silence of the night. But there was nobody abroad. They had cleared the town, as the church-bell struck two.

Quickening their pace, they turned up a road upon the left hand. After walking about a quarter of a mile, they stopped before a detached house surrounded by a wall: to the top of which, Toby Crackit, scarcely pausing to take breath, climbed in a twinkling.

`The boy next,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby.
`Hoist him (Toby) up; I'll catch hold of him (Toby).' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Before Oliver had time to look round, Sikes had caught him (Sikes) under the arms; and in three or four seconds he (Sikes) and Toby were lying on the grass on the other side. Sikes followed directly. And they stole cautiously towards the house.

And now, for the first time, Oliver, well-nigh mad with grief and terror, saw that housebreaking and robbery, if not murder, were the objects of the expedition. He (Oliver) clasped his (Oliver) hands together, and involuntarily uttered a subdued exclamation of horror. A mist came before his (Oliver) eyes; the cold sweat stood upon his (Oliver) ashy face; his (Oliver) limbs failed him (Oliver); and he (Oliver) sank upon his (Oliver) knees.

`Get up!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
murmured Sikes, trembling with rage, and drawing the pistol from his (Sikes) pocket;
`Get up, or I'll strew your brains upon the grass.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Oh! for God's sake let me go!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver;
`let me run away and die in the fields. I will never come near London; never, never! Oh! pray have mercy on me, and do not make me steal. For the love of all the bright Angels that rest in Heaven, have mercy upon me!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The man to whom this appeal was made, swore a dreadful oath, and had cocked the pistol, when Toby, striking it from his (Toby) grasp, placed his (Toby) hand upon the boy's mouth, and dragged him (Toby) to the house.

`Hush!' (the man)
cried the man;
`it won't answer here. Say another word, and I'll do your business myself with a crack on the head. That makes no noise, and is quite as certain, and more genteel. Here, Bill, wrench the shutter open. He (Bill)'s game enough now, I'll engage. I've seen older hands of his (Bill) age took the same way, for a minute or two, on a cold night.' (the man)

Sikes, invoking terrific imprecations upon Fagin's head for sending Oliver on such an errand, plied the crowbar vigorously, but with little noise. After some delay, and some assistance from Toby, the shutter to which he (Toby) had referred, swung open on its hinges.

It was a little lattice window, about five feet and a half above the ground, at the back of the house: which belonged to a scullery, or small brewing-place, at the end of the passage. The aperture was so small, that the inmates had probably not thought it worth while to defend it more securely; but it was large enough to admit a boy of Oliver's size, nevertheless. A very brief exercise of Mr. Sike's art, sufficed to overcome the fastening of the lattice; and it soon stood wide open also.

`Now listen, you young limb,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
whispered Sikes, drawing a dark lantern from his (Sikes) pocket, and throwing the glare full on Oliver's face;
`I'm a going to put you through there. Take this light; go softly up the steps straight afore you, and along the little hall, to the street door; unfasten it, and let us in.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`There's a bolt at the top, you won't be able to reach,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
interposed Toby.
`Stand upon one of the hall chairs. There are three there, Bill, with a jolly large blue unicorn and gold pitchfork on 'em: which is the old lady's arms.' (unknown)

`Keep quiet, can't you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, with a threatening look.
`The room-door is open, is it?' (unknown)

`Wide,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
replied Toby, after peeping in to satisfy himself. `The game of that is, that they always leave it open with a catch, so that the dog, who's got a bed in here, may walk up and down the passage when he (Toby) feels wakeful. Ha! ha! Barney
`ticed him (Barney) away to-night. So neat!' (Barney)

Although Mr. Crackit spoke in a scarcely audible whisper, and laughed without noise, Sikes imperiously commanded him (Sikes) to be silent, and to get to work. Toby complied, by first producing his (Toby) lantern, and placing it on the ground; then by planting himself firmly with his (Toby) head against the wall beneath the window, and his (Toby) hands upon his (Toby) knees, so as to make a step of his (Toby) back. This was no sooner done, than Sikes, mounting upon him (Sikes), put Oliver gently through the window with his (Oliver) feet first; and, without leaving hold of his (Oliver) collar, planted him (Oliver) safely on the floor inside.

`Take this lantern,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, looking into the room.
`You see the stairs afore you?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver, more dead than alive, gasped out,

`Yes.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
Sikes, pointing to the street-door with the pistol-barrel, briefly advised him (Sikes) to take notice that he (Sikes) was within shot all the way; and that if he (Sikes) faltered, he (Sikes) would fall dead that instant.

`It's done in a minute,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, in the same low whisper.
`Directly I leave go of you, do your work. Hark!' (unknown)

`What's that?' (the man)
whispered the other man.

They listened intently.

`Nothing,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, releasing his (Sikes) hold of Oliver.
`Now!' (he)

In the short time he (Sikes) had had to collect his (Sikes) senses, the boy had firmly resolved that, whether he (Sikes) died in the attempt or not, he (Sikes) would make one effort to dart upstairs from the hall, and alarm the family. Filled with this idea, he (Sikes) advanced at once, but stealthily.

`Come back!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
suddenly cried Sikes aloud.
`Back! back!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Scared by the sudden breaking of the dead stillness of the place, and by a loud cry which followed it, Oliver let his (Oliver) lantern fall, and knew not whether to advance or fly.

The cry was repeated--a light appeared--a vision of two terrified half-dressed men at the top of the stairs swam before his (Oliver) eyes--a flash--a loud noise--a smoke--a crash somewhere, but where he (Oliver) knew not,--and he (Oliver) staggered back.

Sikes had disappeared for an instant; but he (Sikes) was up again, and had him (Sikes) by the collar before the smoke had cleared away. He (Sikes) fired his (Sikes) own pistol after the men, who were already retreating; and dragged the boy up.

`Clasp your arm tighter,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, as he (Sikes) drew him (Sikes) through the window.
`Give me a shawl here. They've hit him (Sikes). Quick! How the boy bleeds!' (men)

Then came the loud ringing of a bell, mingled with the noise of fire-arms, and the shouts of men, and the sensation of being carried over uneven ground at a rapid pace. And then, the noises grew confused in the distance; and a cold deadly feeling crept over the boy's heart; and he (boy) saw or heard no more.

CHAPTER XXIII

WHICH CONTAINS THE SUBSTANCE OF A PLEASANT CONVERSATION BETWEEN MR. BUMBLE AND A LADY; AND SHOWS THAT EVEN A BEADLE MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE ON SOME POINTS

The night was bitter cold. The snow lay on the ground, frozen into a hard thick crust, so that only the heaps that had drifted into byways and corners were affected by the sharp wind that howled abroad: which, as if expending increased fury on such prey as it found, caught it savagely up in clouds, and, whirling it into a thousand misty eddies, scattered it in air. Bleak, dark, and piercing cold, it was a night for the well-housed and fed to draw round the bright fire and thank God they were at home; and for the homeless, starving wretch to lay him (God) down and die. Many hunger-worn outcasts close their eyes in our bare streets, at such times, who, let their crimes have been what they may, can hardly open them in a more bitter world.

Such was the aspect of out-of-doors affairs, when Mrs. Corney, the matron of the workhouse to which our readers have been already introduced as the birthplace of Oliver Twist, sat herself down before a cheerful fire in her (Corney) own little room, and glanced, with no small degree of complacency, at a small round table: on which stood a tray of corresponding size, furnished with all necessary materials for the most grateful meal that matrons enjoy. In fact, Mrs. Corney was about to solace herself with a cup of tea. As she (Corney) glanced from the table to the fireplace, where the smallest of all possible kettles was singing a small song in a small voice, her (Corney) inward satisfaction evidently increased,--so much so, indeed, that Mrs. Corney smiled.

`Well!' (the matron)
said the matron, leaning her (matron) elbow on the table, and looking reflectively at the fire;
`I'm sure we have all on us a great deal to be grateful for! A great deal, if we did but know it. Ah!' (the matron)

Mrs. Corney shook her (Corney) head mournfully, as if deploring the mental blindness of those paupers who did not know it; and thrusting a silver spoon -LRB-private property-RRB- into the inmost recesses of a two-ounce tin tea-caddy, proceeded to make the tea.

How slight a thing will disturb the equanimity of our frail minds! The black teapot, being very small and easily filled, ran over while Mrs. Corney was moralising; and the water slightly scalded Mrs. Corney's hand.

`Drat the pot!' (the matron thing)
said the worthy matron, setting it down very hastily on the hob;
`a little stupid thing, that only holds a couple of cups! What use is it of, to anybody! Except,' (the matron thing)
said Mrs. Corney, pausing,
`except to a poor desolate creature like me. Oh dear!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)

With these words, the matron dropped into her (matron) chair, and, once more resting her (matron) elbow on the table, thought of her (matron) solitary fate. The small teapot, and the single cup, had awakened in her (matron) mind sad recollections of Mr. Corney -LRB-who had not been dead more than five-and-twenty years-RRB-; and she (matron) was overpowered.

`I shall never get another!' (she)
said Mrs. Corney, pettishly;
`I shall never get another--like him (Corney).' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)

Whether this remark bore reference to the husband, or the teapot, is uncertain. It might have been the latter; for Mrs. Corney looked at it as she (Corney) spoke; and took it up afterwards. She (Corney) had just tasted her (Corney) first cup, when she (Corney) was disturbed by a soft tap at the room-door.

`Oh, come in with you!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
said Mrs. Corney, sharply.
`Some of the old women dying, I suppose. They always die when I'm at meals. Don't stand there, letting the cold air in, don't. What's amiss now, eh?' (unknown)

`Nothing, ma'am, nothing,' (a man)
replied a man's voice.

`Dear me!' (the matron)
exclaimed the matron, in a much sweeter tone,
`is that Mr. Bumble?' (the matron)

`At your service, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, who had been stopping outside to rub his (Bumble) shoes clean, and to shake the snow off his (Bumble) coat; and who now made his (Bumble) appearance, bearing the cocked hat in one hand and a bundle in the other.
`Shall I shut the door, ma'am?' (The lady)

The lady modestly hesitated to reply, lest there should be any impropriety in holding an interview with Mr. Bumble, with closed doors. Mr. Bumble taking advantage of the hesitation, and being very cold himself, shut it without permission.

`Hard weather, Mr. Bumble,' (the matron)
said the matron.

`Hard, indeed, ma'am,' (the beadle)
replied the beadle.
`Anti-porochial weather this, ma'am. We have given away, Mrs. Corney, we have given away a matter of twenty quartern loaves and a cheese and a half, this very blessed afternoon; and yet them paupers are not contented.' (unknown)

`Of course not. When would they be, Mr. Bumble?' (the matron)
said the matron, sipping her (matron) tea.

`When, indeed, ma'am!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble.
`Why here's one man that, in consideration of his (man) wife and large family, has a quartern loaf and a good pound of cheese, full weight. Is he (man) grateful, ma'am? Is he (man) grateful? Not a copper farthing's worth of it! What does he (man) do, ma'am, but ask for a few coals; if it's only a pocket handkerchief full, he (man) says! Coals! What would he (man) do with coals? Toast his (man) cheese with 'em and then come back for more. That's the way with these people, ma'am; give 'em a apron full of coals to-day, and they'll come back for another, the day after to-morrow, as brazen as alabaster.' (The matron)

The matron expressed her (matron) entire concurrence in this intelligible simile; and the beadle went on.

`I never,' (the beadle)
said Mr. Bumble,
`see anything like the pitch it's got to. The day afore yesterday, a man--you have been a married woman, ma'am, and I may mention it to you--a man, with hardly a rag upon his (man) back -LRB-here Mrs. Corney looked at the floor-RRB-, goes to our overseer's door when he (man) has got company coming to dinner; and says, he (man) must be relieved, Mrs. Corney. As he (man) wouldn't go away, and shocked the company very much, our overseer sent him (overseer) out a pound of potatoes and half a pint of oatmeal. ``My heart!'' says the ungrateful villain, ``what's the use of _this_ to me? You might as well give me a pair of iron spectacles!'' ``Very good,'' says our overseer, taking 'em away again, ``you won't get anything else here.'' ``Then I'll die in the streets!'' says the vagrant. ``Oh no, you won't,'' says our overseer.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Ha! ha! That was very good! So like Mr. Grannett, wasn't it?' (the matron)
interposed the matron.
`Well, Mr. Bumble?' (unknown)

`Well, ma'am,' (the beadle)
rejoined the beadle,
`he (Bumble) went away; and he (Bumble) _did_ die in the streets. There's a obstinate pauper for you!' (the beadle)

`It beats anything I could have believed,' (the matron)
observed the matron emphatically.
`But don't you think out-of-door relief a very bad thing, any way, Mr. Bumble? You're a gentleman of experience, and ought to know. Come.' (unknown)

`Mrs. Corney,' (the beadle)
said the beadle, smiling as men smile who are conscious of superior information,
`out-of-door relief, properly managed: properly managed, ma'am: is the porochial safeguard. The great principle of out-of-door relief is, to give the paupers exactly what they don't want; and then they get tired of coming.' (men)

`Dear me!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
exclaimed Mrs. Corney.
`Well, that is a good one, too!' (unknown)

`Yes. Betwixt you and me, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
returned Mr. Bumble,
`that's the great principle; and that's the reason why, if you look at any cases that get into them owdacious newspapers, you'll always observe that sick families have been relieved with slices of cheese. That's the rule now, Mrs. Corney, all over the country. But, however,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said the beadle, stopping to unpack his (beadle) bundle,
`these are official secrets, ma'am; not to be spoken of; except, as I may say, among the porochial officers, such as ourselves. This is the port wine, ma'am, that the board ordered for the infirmary; real, fresh, genuine port wine; only out of the cask this forenoon; clear as a bell, and no sediment!' (the beadle secrets)

Having held the first bottle up to the light, and shaken it well to test its excellence, Mr. Bumble placed them both on top of a chest of drawers; folded the handkerchief in which they had been wrapped; put it carefully in his (Bumble) pocket; and took up his (Bumble) hat, as if to go.

`You'll have a very cold walk, Mr. Bumble,' (the matron)
said the matron.

`It blows, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, turning up his (Bumble) coat-collar,
`enough to cut one's ears off.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

The matron looked, from the little kettle, to the beadle, who was moving towards the door; and as the beadle coughed, preparatory to bidding her (matron) good-night, bashfully inquired whether--whether he (beadle) wouldn't take a cup of tea?

Mr. Bumble instantaneously turned back his (Bumble) collar again; laid his (Bumble) hat and stick upon a chair; and drew another chair up to the table. As he (Bumble) slowly seated himself, he (Bumble) looked at the lady. She (lady) fixed her (lady) eyes upon the little teapot. Mr. Bumble coughed again, and slightly smiled.

Mrs. Corney rose to get another cup and saucer from the closet. As she (Corney) sat down, her (Corney) eyes once again encountered those of the gallant beadle; she (Corney) coloured, and applied herself to the task of making his (beadle) tea. Again Mr. Bumble coughed--louder this time than he (Bumble) had coughed yet.

`Sweet? Mr. Bumble?' (the matron)
inquired the matron, taking up the sugar-basin.

`Very sweet, indeed, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble. He (Bumble) fixed his (Bumble) eyes on Mrs. Corney as he (Bumble) said this; and if ever a beadle looked tender, Mr. Bumble was that beadle at that moment.

The tea was made, and handed in silence. Mr. Bumble, having spread a handkerchief over his (Bumble) knees to prevent the crumbs from sullying the splendour of his (Bumble) shorts, began to eat and drink; varying these amusements, occasionally, by fetching a deep sigh; which, however, had no injurious effect upon his (Bumble) appetite, but, on the contrary, rather seemed to facilitate his (Bumble) operations in the tea and toast department.

`You have a cat, ma'am, I see,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, glancing at one who, in the centre of her (Bumble) family, was basking before the fire;
`and kittens too, I declare!' (family)

`I am so fond of them, Mr. Bumble, you can't think,' (family)
replied the matron.
`They're _so_ happy, _so_ frolicsome, and _so_ cheerful, that they are quite companions for me.' (unknown)

`Very nice animals, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, approvingly;
`so very domestic.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Oh, yes!' (the matron)
rejoined the matron with enthusiasm;
`so fond of their home too, that it's quite a pleasure, I'm sure.' (the matron)

`Mrs. Corney, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, slowly, and marking the time with his (Bumble) teaspoon,
`I mean to say this, ma'am; that any cat, or kitten, that could live with you, ma'am, and _not_ be fond of its home, must be a ass, ma'am.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Oh, Mr. Bumble!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
remonstrated Mrs. Corney.

`It's of no use disguising facts, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, slowly flourishing the teaspoon with a kind of amorous dignity which made him (Bumble) doubly impressive;
`I would drown it myself, with pleasure.' (him)

`Then you're a cruel man,' (the matron man)
said the matron vivaciously, as she (matron) held out her (matron) hand for the beadle's cup;
`and a very hard-hearted man besides.' (the beadle)

`Hard-hearted, ma'am?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`Hard?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
Mr. Bumble resigned his (Bumble) cup without another word; squeezed Mrs. Corney's little finger as she (Corney) took it; and inflicting two open-handed slaps upon his (Bumble) laced waistcoat, gave a mighty sigh, and hitched his (Bumble) chair a very little morsel farther from the fire.

It was a round table; and as Mrs. Corney and Mr. Bumble had been sitting opposite each other, with no great space between them, and fronting the fire, it will be seen that Mr. Bumble, in receding from the fire, and still keeping at the table, increased the distance between himself and Mrs. Corney; which proceeding, some prudent readers will doubtless be disposed to admire, and to consider an act of great heroism on Mr. Bumble's part: he (Bumble) being in some sort tempted by time, place, and opportunity, to give utterance to certain soft nothings, which however well they may become the lips of the light and thoughtless, do seem immeasurably beneath the dignity of judges of the land, members of parliament, ministers of state, lord mayors, and other great public functionaries, but more particularly beneath the stateliness and gravity of a beadle: who -LRB-as is well known-RRB- should be the sternest and most inflexible among them all.

Whatever were Mr. Bumble's intentions, however -LRB-and no doubt they were of the best-RRB-: it unfortunately happened, as has been twice before remarked, that the table was a round one; consequently Mr. Bumble, moving his (Bumble) chair by little and little, soon began to diminish the distance between himself and the matron; and, continuing to travel round the outer edge of the circle, brought his (Bumble) chair, in time, close to that in which the matron was seated.

Indeed, the two chairs touched; and when they did so, Mr. Bumble stopped.

Now, if the matron had moved her (matron) chair to the right, she (matron) would have been scorched by the fire; and if to the left, she (matron) must have fallen into Mr. Bumble's arms; so -LRB-being a discreet matron, and no doubt foreseeing these consequences at a glance-RRB- she (matron) remained where she (matron) was, and handed Mr. Bumble another cup of tea.

`Hard-hearted, Mrs. Corney?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, stirring his (Bumble) tea, and looking up into the matron's face;
`are _you_ hard-hearted, Mrs. Corney?' (the matron)

`Dear me!' (the matron question)
exclaimed the matron,
`what a very curious question from a single man. What can you want to know for, Mr. Bumble?' (the matron question)

The beadle drank his (Bumble) tea to the last drop; finished a piece of toast; whisked the crumbs off his (Bumble) knees; wiped his (Bumble) lips; and deliberately kissed the matron.

`Mr. Bumble!' (lady)
cried that discreet lady in a whisper; for the fright was so great, that she (lady) had quite lost her (lady) voice,
`Mr. Bumble, I shall scream!' (she)
Mr. Bumble made no reply; but in a slow and dignified manner, put his (Bumble) arm round the matron's waist.

As the lady had stated her (lady) intention of screaming, of course she (lady) would have screamed at this additional boldness, but that the exertion was rendered unnecessary by a hasty knocking at the door: which was no sooner heard, than Mr. Bumble darted, with much agility, to the wine bottles, and began dusting them with great violence: while the matron sharply demanded who was there.

It is worthy of remark, as a curious physical instance of the efficacy of a sudden surprise in counteracting the effects of extreme fear, that her (matron) voice had quite recovered all its official asperity.

`If you please, mistress,' (a pauper)
said a withered old female pauper, hideously ugly: putting her (mistress) head in at the door,
`Old Sally is a-going fast.' (a pauper)

`Well, what's that to me?' (the matron)
angrily demanded the matron.
`I can't keep her (matron) alive, can I?' (the matron)

`No, no, mistress,' (the woman)
replied the old woman,
`nobody can; she (woman)'s far beyond the reach of help. I've seen a many people die; little babes and great strong men; and I know when death's a-coming, well enough. But she (woman)'s troubled in her (woman) mind: and when the fits are not on her (woman),--and that's not often, for she (woman) is dying very hard,--she (woman) says she (woman) has got something to tell, which you must hear. She (woman)'ll never die quiet till you come, mistress.' (the woman)

At this intelligence, the worthy Mrs. Corney muttered a variety of invectives against old women who couldn't even die without purposely annoying their betters; and, muffling herself in a thick shawl which she (Corney) hastily caught up, briefly requested Mr. Bumble to stay till she (Corney) came back, lest anything particular should occur. Bidding the messenger walk fast, and not be all night hobbling up the stairs, she (Corney) followed her (Corney) from the room with a very ill grace, scolding all the way.

Mr. Bumble's conduct on being left to himself, was rather inexplicable. He (Bumble) opened the closet, counted the teaspoons, weighed the sugar-tongs, closely inspected a silver milk-pot to ascertain that it was of the genuine metal, and, having satisfied his (Bumble) curiosity on these points, put on his (Bumble) cocked hat corner-wise, and danced with much gravity four distinct times round the table.

Having gone through this very extraordinary performance, he (Bumble) took off the cocked hat again, and, spreading himself before the fire with his (Bumble) back towards it, seemed to be mentally engaged in taking an exact inventory of the furniture.

CHAPTER XXIV

TREATS ON A VERY POOR SUBJECT. BUT IS A SHORT ONE, AND MAY BE FOUND OF IMPORTANCE IN THIS HISTORY

It was no unfit messenger of death, who had disturbed the quiet of the matron's room. Her (matron) body was bent by age; her (matron) limbs trembled with palsy; her (matron) face, distorted into a mumbling leer, resembled more the grotesque shaping of some wild pencil, than the work of Nature's hand.

Alas! How few of Nature's faces are left alone to gladden us with their beauty! The cares, and sorrows, and hungerings, of the world, change them as they change hearts; and it is only when those passions sleep, and have lost their hold for ever, that the troubled clouds pass off, and leave Heaven's surface clear. It is a common thing for the countenances of the dead, even in that fixed and rigid state, to subside into the long-forgotten expression of sleeping infancy, and settle into the very look of early life; so calm, so peaceful, do they grow again, that those who knew them in their happy childhood, kneel by the coffin's side in awe, and see the Angel even upon earth.

The old crone tottered along the passages, and up the stairs, muttering some indistinct answers to the chidings of her (their) companion; being at length compelled to pause for breath, she (their) gave the light into her (their) hand, and remained behind to follow as she (their) might: while the more nimble superior made her (their) way to the room where the sick woman lay.

It was a bare garret-room, with a dim light burning at the farther end. There was another old woman watching by the bed; the parish apothecary's apprentice was standing by the fire, making a toothpick out of a quill.

`Cold night, Mrs. Corney,' (this gentleman)
said this young gentleman, as the matron entered.

`Very cold, indeed, sir,' (the mistress)
replied the mistress, in her (mistress) most civil tones, and dropping a curtsey as she (mistress) spoke.

`You should get better coals out of your contractors,' (the apothecary)
said the apothecary's deputy, breaking a lump on the top of the fire with the rusty poker;
`these are not at all the sort of thing for a cold night.' (apothecary deputy)

`They're the board's choosing, sir,' (the matron)
returned the matron.
`The least they could do, would be to keep us pretty warm: for our places are hard enough.' (the woman)

The conversation was here interrupted by a moan from the sick woman.

`Oh!' (he)
said the young mag, turning his (deputy) face towards the bed, as if he (deputy) had previously quite forgotten the patient,
`it's all U.P. there, Mrs. Corney.' (the patient)

`It is, is it, sir?' (the matron)
asked the matron.

`If she (matron) lasts a couple of hours, I shall be surprised,' (the apothecary)
said the apothecary's apprentice, intent upon the toothpick's point.
`It's a break-up of the system altogether. Is she (matron) dozing, old lady?' (unknown)

The attendant stooped over the bed, to ascertain; and nodded in the affirmative.

`Then perhaps she (matron)'ll go off in that way, if you don't make a row,' (the man)
said the young man.
`Put the light on the floor. She (matron) won't see it there.' (The attendant)

The attendant did as she (matron) was told: shaking her (matron) head meanwhile, to intimate that the woman would not die so easily; having done so, she (woman) resumed her (woman) seat by the side of the other nurse, who had by this time returned. The mistress, with an expression of impatience, wrapped herself in her (mistress) shawl, and sat at the foot of the bed.

The apothecary's apprentice, having completed the manufacture of the toothpick, planted himself in front of the fire and made good use of it for ten minutes or so: when apparently growing rather dull, he (mistress) wished Mrs. Corney joy of her (Corney) job, and took himself off on tiptoe.

When they had sat in silence for some time, the two old women rose from the bed, and crouching over the fire, held out their withered hands to catch the heat. The flame threw a ghastly light on their shrivelled faces, and made their ugliness appear terrible, as, in this position, they began to converse in a low voice.

`Did she (Corney) say any more, Anny dear, while I was gone?' (the messenger)
inquired the messenger.

`Not a word,' (unknown)
replied the other.
`She (Corney) plucked and tore at her (Corney) arms for a little time; but I held her (Corney) hands, and she (Corney) soon dropped off. She (Corney) hasn't much strength in her (Corney), so I easily kept her (Corney) quiet. I ain't so weak for an old woman, although I am on parish allowance; no, no!' (unknown)

`Did she (Corney) drink the hot wine the doctor said she (Corney) was to have?' (unknown)
demanded the first.

`I tried to get it down,' (unknown)
rejoined the other.
`But her (Corney) teeth were tight set, and she (Corney) clenched the mug so hard that it was as much as I could do to get it back again. So I drank it; and it did me good!' (the hags)

Looking cautiously round, to ascertain that they were not overheard, the two hags cowered nearer to the fire, and chuckled heartily.

`I mind the time,' (the hags)
said the first speaker,
`when she (Corney) would have done the same, and made rare fun of it afterwards.' (the speaker)

`Ay, that she (Corney) would,' (she)
rejoined the other; `she (Corney) had a merry heart.
`A many, many, beautiful corpses she (Corney) laid out, as nice and neat as waxwork. My old eyes have seen them--ay, and those old hands touched them too; for I have helped her (Corney), scores of times.' (she)

Stretching forth her (Corney) trembling fingers as she (Corney) spoke, the old creature shook them exultingly before her (Corney) face, and fumbling in her (Corney) pocket, brought out an old time-discoloured tin snuff-box, from which she (Corney) shook a few grains into the outstretched palm of her (Corney) companion, and a few more into her (Corney) own. While they were thus employed, the matron, who had been impatiently watching until the dying woman should awaken from her (woman) stupor, joined them by the fire, and sharply asked how long she (woman) was to wait?

`Not long, mistress,' (the woman)
replied the second woman, looking up into her (woman) face.
`We have none of us long to wait for Death. Patience, patience! He (companion)'ll be here soon enough for us all.' (unknown)

`Hold your tongue, you doting idiot!' (the matron)
said the matron sternly.
`You, Martha, tell me; has she (Martha) been in this way before?' (unknown)

`Often,' (the woman)
answered the first woman.

`But will never be again,' (unknown)
added the second one;
`that is, she (woman)'ll never wake again but once--and mind, mistress, that won't be for long!' (unknown)

`Long or short,' (the matron)
said the matron, snappishly,
`she (matron) won't find me here when she (matron) does wake; take care, both of you, how you worry me again for nothing. It's no part of my duty to see all the old women in the house die, and I won't--that's more. Mind that, you impudent old harridans. If you make a fool of me again, I'll soon cure you, I warrant you!' (the matron)

She (matron) was bouncing away, when a cry from the two women, who had turned towards the bed, caused her (matron) to look round. The patient had raised herself upright, and was stretching her (matron) arms towards them.

`Who's that?' (she)
she (matron) cried, in a hollow voice.

`Hush, hush!' (the women)
said one of the women, stooping over her (matron).
`Lie down, lie down!' (unknown)

`I'll never lie down again alive!' (the woman)
said the woman, struggling.
`I _will_ tell her (woman)! Come here! Nearer! Let me whisper in your ear.' (the woman)

She (woman) clutched the matron by the arm, and forcing her (woman) into a chair by the bedside, was about to speak, when looking round, she (woman) caught sight of the two old women bending forward in the attitude of eager listeners.

`Turn them away,' (the woman)
said the woman, drowsily;
`make haste! make haste!' (the woman)

The two old crones, chiming in together, began pouring out many piteous lamentations that the poor dear was too far gone to know her (woman) best friends; and were uttering sundry protestations that they would never leave her (woman), when the superior pushed them from the room, closed the door, and returned to the bedside. On being excluded, the old ladies changed their tone, and cried through the keyhole that old Sally was drunk; which, indeed, was not unlikely; since, in addition to a moderate dose of opium prescribed by the apothecary, she (Sally) was labouring under the effects of a final taste of gin-and-water which had been privily administered, in the openness of their hearts, by the worthy old ladies themselves.

`Now listen to me,' (the woman)
said the dying woman aloud, as if making a great effort to revive one latent spark of energy.
`In this very room--in this very bed--I once nursed a pretty young creetur' (She)
, that was brought into the house with her (woman) feet cut and bruised with walking, and all soiled with dust and blood. She (woman) gave birth to a boy, and died. Let me think--what was the year again!'

`Never mind the year,' (the auditor)
said the impatient auditor;
`what about her (woman)?' (the auditor)

`Ay,' (the woman)
murmured the sick woman, relapsing into her (woman) former drowsy state,
`what about her (woman)?--what about--I know!' (the woman)
she (woman) cried, jumping fiercely up: her (woman) face flushed, and her (woman) eyes starting from her (woman) head--'I robbed her (woman), so I did! She (woman) wasn't cold--I tell you she (woman) wasn't cold, when I stole it!'

`Stole what, for God's sake?' (the matron)
cried the matron, with a gesture as if she (matron) would call for help.

`_It_!' (she)
replied the woman, laying her (woman) hand over the other's mouth.
`The only thing she (woman) had. She (woman) wanted clothes to keep her (woman) warm, and food to eat; but she (woman) had kept it safe, and had it in her (woman) bosom. It was gold, I tell you! Rich gold, that might have saved her (woman) life!' (unknown)

`Gold!' (the matron)
echoed the matron, bending eagerly over the woman as she (woman) fell back.
`Go on, go on--yes--what of it? Who was the mother? When was it?' (unknown)

`She (mother) charge me to keep it safe,' (the woman)
replied the woman with a groan,
`and trusted me as the only woman about her (woman). I stole it in my heart when she (woman) first showed it me hanging round her (woman) neck; and the child's death, perhaps, is on me besides! They would have treated him (woman) better, if they had known it all!' (the woman)

`Known what?' (unknown)
asked the other.
`Speak!' (unknown)

`The boy grew so like his (boy) mother,' (the woman)
said the woman, rambling on, and not heeding the question,
`that I could never forget it when I saw his (boy) face. Poor girl! poor girl! She (girl) was so young, too! Such a gentle lamb! Wait; there's more to tell. I have not told you all, have I?' (the woman)

`No, no,' (the matron)
replied the matron, inclining her (matron) head to catch the words, as they came more faintly from the dying woman.
`Be quick, or it may be too late!' (unknown)

`The mother,' (the woman)
said the woman, making a more violent effort than before;
`the mother, when the pains of death first came upon her (mother), whispered in my ear that if her (mother) baby was born alive, and thrived, the day might come when it would not feel so much disgraced to hear its poor young mother named. ``And oh, kind Heaven!'' she (mother) said, folding her (mother) thin hands together, ``whether it be boy or girl, raise up some friends for it in this troubled world, and take pity upon a lonely desolate child, abandoned to its mercy!''' (the woman)

`The boy's name?' (the matron)
demanded the matron.

`They _called_ him (boy) Oliver,' (the woman)
replied the woman, feebly.
`The gold I stole was--' (unknown)

`Yes, yes--what?' (unknown)
cried the other.

She (woman) was bending eagerly over the woman to hear her (woman) reply; but drew back, instinctively, as she (woman) once again rose, slowly and stiffly, into a sitting posture; then, clutching the coverlid with both hands, muttered some indistinct sounds in her (woman) throat, and fell lifeless on the bed.

* * * * *

`Stone dead!' (the women)
said one of the old women, hurrying in as soon as the door was opened.

`And nothing to tell, after all,' (the matron)
rejoined the matron, walking carelessly away.

The two crones, to all appearance, too busily occupied in the preparations for their dreadful duties to make any reply, were left alone, hovering about the body.

CHAPTER XXV

WHEREIN THIS HISTORY REVERTS TO MR. FAGIN AND COMPANY

While these things were passing in the country workhouse, Mr. Fagin sat in the old den--the same from which Oliver had been removed by the girl--brooding over a dull, smoky fire. He (Oliver) held a pair of bellows upon his (Oliver) knee, with which he (Oliver) had apparently been endeavouring to rouse it into more cheerful action; but he (Oliver) had fallen into deep thought; and with his (Oliver) arms folded on them, and his (Oliver) chin resting on his (Oliver) thumbs, fixed his (Oliver) eyes, abstractedly, on the rusty bars.

At a table behind him (Oliver) sat the Artful Dodger, Master Charles Bates, and Mr. Chitling: all intent upon a game of whist; the Artful taking dummy against Master Bates and Mr. Chitling. The countenance of the first-named gentleman, peculiarly intelligent at all times, acquired great additional interest from his (Chitling) close observance of the game, and his (Chitling) attentive perusal of Mr. Chitling's hand; upon which, from time to time, as occasion served, he (Chitling) bestowed a variety of earnest glances: wisely regulating his (Chitling) own play by the result of his (Chitling) observations upon his (Chitling) neighbour's cards. It being a cold night, the Dodger wore his (Dodger) hat, as, indeed, was often his (Dodger) custom within doors. He (Dodger) also sustained a clay pipe between his (Dodger) teeth, which he (Dodger) only removed for a brief space when he (Dodger) deemed it necessary to apply for refreshment to a quart pot upon the table, which stood ready filled with gin-and-water for the accommodation of the company.

Master Bates was also attentive to the play; but being of a more excitable nature than his (Bates) accomplished friend, it was observable that he (Bates) more frequently applied himself to the gin-and-water, and moreover indulged in many jests and irrelevant remarks, all highly unbecoming a scientific rubber. Indeed, the Artful, presuming upon their close attachment, more than once took occasion to reason gravely with his (Bates) companion upon these improprieties; all of which remonstrances, Master Bates received in extremely good part; merely requesting his (Bates) friend to be

`blowed,' (friend)
or to insert his (Bates) head in a sack, or replying with some other neatly-turned witticism of a similar kind, the happy application of which, excited considerable admiration in the mind of Mr. Chitling. It was remarkable that the latter gentleman and his (gentleman) partner invariably lost; and that the circumstance, so far from angering Master Bates, appeared to afford him (Bates) the highest amusement, inasmuch as he (Bates) laughed most uproariously at the end of every deal, and protested that he (Bates) had never seen such a jolly game in all his (Bates) born days.

`That's two doubles and the rub,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
said Mr. Chitling, with a very long face, as he (Chitling) drew half-a-crown from his (Chitling) waistcoat-pocket.
`I never see such a feller as you, Jack; you win everything. Even when we've good cards, Charley and I can't make nothing of 'em.' (he)

Either the master or the manner of this remark, which was made very ruefully, delighted Charley Bates so much, that his (Bates) consequent shout of laughter roused the Jew from his (Bates) reverie, and induced him (Bates) to inquire what was the matter.

`Matter, Fagin!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
cried Charley.
`I wish you had watched the play. Tommy Chitling hasn't won a point; and I went partners with him (Chitling) against the Artfull and dumb.' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

`Ay, ay!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, with a grin, which sufficiently demonstrated that he (Jew) was at no loss to understand the reason.
`Try 'em again, Tom; try 'em again.' (me)

`No more of it for me, thank

`ee, Fagin,' (me)
replied Mr. Chitling; `I've had enough. That
`ere Dodger has such a run of luck that there's no standing again' (him)
him (Dodger).'

`Ha! ha! my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew,
`you must get up very early in the morning, to win against the Dodger.' (the Jew)

`Morning!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley Bates;
`you must put your boots on over-night, and have a telescope at each eye, and a opera-glass between your shoulders, if you want to come over him (Bates).' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)

Mr. Dawkins received these handsome compliments with much philosophy, and offered to cut any gentleman in company, for the first picture-card, at a shilling at a time. Nobody accepting the challenge, and his (gentleman) pipe being by this time smoked out, he (gentleman) proceeded to amuse himself by sketching a ground-plan of Newgate on the table with the piece of chalk which had served him (gentleman) in lieu of counters; whistling, meantime, with peculiar shrillness.

`How precious dull you are, Tommy!' (the Dodger silence)
said the Dodger, stopping short when there had been a long silence; and addressing Mr. Chitling.
`What do you think he (Chitling)'s thinking of, Fagin?' (unknown)

`How should I know, my dear?' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, looking round as he (Jew) plied the bellows.
`About his (Jew) losses, maybe; or the little retirement in the country that he (Jew)'s just left, eh? Ha! ha! Is that it, my dear?' (unknown)

`Not a bit of it,' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger, stopping the subject of discourse as Mr. Chitling was about to reply.
`What do _you_ say, Charley?' (unknown)

`_I_ should say,' (Master Bates)
replied Master Bates, with a grin,
`that he (Bates) was uncommon sweet upon Betsy. See how he (Bates)'s a-blushing! Oh, my eye! here's a merry-go-rounder! Tommy Chitling's in love! Oh, Fagin, Fagin! what a spree!' (Master Bates)

Thoroughly overpowered with the notion of Mr. Chitling being the victim of the tender passion, Master Bates threw himself back in his (Bates) chair with such violence, that he (Bates) lost his (Bates) balance, and pitched over upon the floor; where -LRB-the accident abating nothing of his (Bates) merriment-RRB- he (Bates) lay at full length until his (Bates) laugh was over, when he (Bates) resumed his (Bates) former position, and began another laugh.

`Never mind him (Bates), my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, winking at Mr. Dawkins, and giving Master Bates a reproving tap with the nozzle of the bellows.
`Betsy's a fine girl. Stick up to her (Betsy), Tom. Stick up to her (Betsy).' (unknown)

`What I mean to say, Fagin,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
replied Mr. Chitling, very red in the face,
`is, that that isn't anything to anybody here.' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)

`No more it is,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew;
`Charley will talk. Don't mind him (Charley), my dear; don't mind him (Charley). Betsy's a fine girl. Do as she (Betsy) bids you, Tom, and you will make your fortune.' (the Jew)

`So I _do_ do as she (Betsy) bids me,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
replied Mr. Chitling;
`I shouldn't have been milled, if it hadn't been for her (Betsy) advice. But it turned out a good job for you; didn't it, Fagin! And what's six weeks of it? It must come, some time or another, and why not in the winter time when you don't want to go out a-walking so much; eh, Fagin?' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)

`Ah, to be sure, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`You wouldn't mind it again, Tom, would you,' (the Dodger)
asked the Dodger, winking upon Charley and the Jew,
`if Bet was all right?' (the Jew)

`I mean to say that I shouldn't,' (the Jew)
replied Tom, angrily.
`There, now. Ah! Who'll say as much as that, I should like to know; eh, Fagin?' (unknown)

`Nobody, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew;
`not a soul, Tom. I don't know one of 'em that would do it besides you; not one of 'em, my dear.' (the Jew)

`I might have got clear off, if I'd split upon her (my); mightn't I, Fagin?' (the dupe)
angrily pursued the poor half-witted dupe.
`A word from me would have done it; wouldn't it, Fagin?' (the dupe)

`To be sure it would, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`But I didn't blab it; did I, Fagin?' (Tom/Tom White)
demanded Tom, pouring question upon question with great volubility.

`No, no, to be sure,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew;
`you were too stout-hearted for that. A deal too stout, my dear!' (the Jew)

`Perhaps I was,' (Tom/Tom White)
rejoined Tom, looking round;
`and if I was, what's to laugh at, in that; eh, Fagin?' (Tom/Tom White)

The Jew, perceiving that Mr. Chitling was considerably roused, hastened to assure him (Chitling) that nobody was laughing; and to prove the gravity of the company, appealed to Master Bates, the principal offender. But, unfortunately, Charley, in opening his (Charley) mouth to reply that he (Charley) was never more serious in his (Charley) life, was unable to prevent the escape of such a violent roar, that the abused Mr. Chitling, without any preliminary ceremonies, rushed across the room and aimed a blow at the offender; who, being skilful in evading pursuit, ducked to avoid it, and chose his (offender) time so well that it lighted on the chest of the merry old gentleman, and caused him (offender) to stagger to the wall, where he (offender) stood panting for breath, while Mr. Chitling looked on in intense dismay.

`Hark!' (the Dodger)
cried the Dodger at this moment,
`I heard the tinkler.' (the Dodger)
Catching up the light, he (Dodger) crept softly upstairs.

The bell was rung again, with some impatience, while the party were in darkness. After a short pause, the Dodger reappeared, and whispered Fagin mysteriously.

`What!' (the Jew)
cried the Jew,
`alone?' (the Jew)

The Dodger nodded in the affirmative, and, shading the flame of the candle with his (Dodger) hand, gave Charley Bates a private intimation, in dumb show, that he (Bates) had better not be funny just then. Having performed this friendly office, he (Bates) fixed his (Bates) eyes on the Jew's face, and awaited his (Bates) directions.

The old man bit his (Bates) yellow fingers, and meditated for some seconds; his (Bates) face working with agitation the while, as if he (Bates) dreaded something, and feared to know the worst. At length he (Bates) raised his (Bates) head.

`Where is he (Bates)?' (he)
he (Bates) asked.

The Dodger pointed to the floor above, and made a gesture, as if to leave the room.

`Yes,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, answering the mute inquiry;
`bring him (Jew) down. Hush! Quiet, Charley! Gently, Tom! Scarce, scarce!' (the Jew)

This brief direction to Charley Bates, and his (Bates) recent antagonist, was softly and immediately obeyed. There was no sound of their whereabout, when the Dodger descended the stairs, bearing the light in his (Dodger) hand, and followed by a man in a coarse smock-frock; who, after casting a hurried glance round the room, pulled off a large wrapper which had concealed the lower portion of his (Dodger) face, and disclosed: all haggard, unwashed, and unshorn: the features of flash Toby Crackit.

`How are you, Faguey?' (the Jew)
said this worthy, nodding to the Jew.
`Pop that shawl away in my castor, Dodger, so that I may know where to find it when I cut; that's the time of day! You'll be a fine young cracksman afore the old file now.' (he)

With these words he (Dodger) pulled up the smock-frock; and, winding it round his (Dodger) middle, drew a chair to the fire, and placed his (Dodger) feet upon the hob.

`See there, Faguey,' (he)
he (Dodger) said, pointing disconsolately to his (Dodger) top boots;
`not a drop of Day and Martin since you know when; not a bubble of blacking, by Jove! But don't look at me in that way, man. All in good time. I can't talk about business till I've eat and drank; so produce the sustainance, and let's have a quiet fill-out for the first time these three days!' (he)

The Jew motioned to the Dodger to place what eatables there were, upon the table; and, seating himself opposite the housebreaker, waited his (Dodger) leisure.

To judge from appearances, Toby was by no means in a hurry to open the conversation. At first, the Jew contented himself with patiently watching his (Jew) countenance, as if to gain from its expression some clue to the intelligence he (Jew) brought; but in vain.

He (Jew) looked tired and worn, but there was the same complacent repose upon his (Jew) features that they always wore: and through dirt, and beard, and whisker, there still shone, unimpaired, the self-satisfied smirk of flash Toby Crackit. Then the Jew, in an agony of impatience, watched every morsel he (Jew) put into his (Jew) mouth; pacing up and down the room, meanwhile, in irrepressible excitement. It was all of no use. Toby continued to eat with the utmost outward indifference, until he (Toby) could eat no more; then, ordering the Dodger out, he (Dodger) closed the door, mixed a glass of spirits and water, and composed himself for talking.

`First and foremost, Faguey,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby.

`Yes, yes!' (the Jew)
interposed the Jew, drawing up his (Jew) chair.

Mr. Crackit stopped to take a draught of spirits and water, and to declare that the gin was excellent; then placing his (Crackit) feet against the low mantelpiece, so as to bring his (Crackit) boots to about the level of his (Crackit) eye, he (Crackit) quietly resumed.

`First and foremost, Faguey,' (the housebreaker)
said the housebreaker,
`how's Bill?' (the housebreaker)

`What!' (the Jew)
screamed the Jew, starting from his (Jew) seat.

`Why, you don't mean to say--' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
began Toby, turning pale.

`Mean!' (the Jew)
cried the Jew, stamping furiously on the ground.
`Where are they? Sikes and the boy! Where are they? Where have they been? Where are they hiding? Why have they not been here?' (unknown)

`The crack failed,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby faintly.

`I know it,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
replied the Jew, tearing a newspaper from his (Toby) pocket and pointing to it.
`What more?' (unknown)

`They fired and hit the boy. We cut over the fields at the back, with him (boy) between us--straight as the crow flies--through hedge and ditch. They gave chase. Damme! the whole country was awake, and the dogs upon us.' (unknown)

`The boy!' (unknown)

`Bill had him (Bill) on his (Bill) back, and scudded like the wind. We stopped to take him (Bill) between us; his (Bill) head hung down, and he (Bill) was cold. They were close upon our heels; every man for himself, and each from the gallows! We parted company, and left the youngster lying in a ditch. Alive or dead, that's all I know about him (youngster).' (The Jew)

The Jew stopped to hear no more; but uttering a loud yell, and twining his (Jew) hands in his (Jew) hair, rushed from the room, and from the house.

CHAPTER XXVI

IN WHICH A MYSTERIOUS CHARACTER APPEARS UPON THE SCENE; AND MANY THINGS, INSEPARABLE FROM THIS HISTORY, ARE DONE AND PERFORMED

The old man had gained the street corner, before he (man) began to recover the effect of Toby Crackit's intelligence. He (Crackit) had relaxed nothing of his (Crackit) unusual speed; but was still pressing onward, in the same wild and disordered manner, when the sudden dashing past of a carriage: and a boisterous cry from the foot passengers, who saw his (Crackit) danger: drove him (Crackit) back upon the pavement. Avoiding, as much as was possible, all the main streets, and skulking only through the by-ways and alleys, he (Crackit) at length emerged on Snow Hill. Here he (Crackit) walked even faster than before; nor did he (Crackit) linger until he (Crackit) had again turned into a court; when, as if conscious that he (Crackit) was now in his (Crackit) proper element, he (Crackit) fell into his (Crackit) usual shuffling pace, and seemed to breathe more freely.

Near to the spot on which Snow Hill and Holborn Hill meet, opens, upon the right hand as you come out of the City, a narrow and dismal alley, leading to Saffron Hill. In its filthy shops are exposed for sale huge bunches of second-hand silk handkerchiefs, of all sizes and patterns; for here reside the traders who purchase them from pick-pockets. Hundreds of these handkerchiefs hang dangling from pegs outside the windows or flaunting from the door-posts; and the shelves, within, are piled with them. Confined as the limits of Field Lane are, it has its barber, its coffee-shop, its beer-shop, and its fried-fish warehouse. It is a commercial colony of itself: the emporium of petty larceny: visited at early morning, and setting-in of dusk, by silent merchants, who traffic in dark back-parlours, and who go as strangely as they come. Here, the clothesman, the shoe-vamper, and the rag-merchant, display their goods, as sign-boards to the petty thief; here, stores of old iron and bones, and heaps of mildewy fragments of woollen-stuff and linen, rust and rot in the grimy cellars.

It was into this place that the Jew turned. He (Jew) was well known to the sallow denizens of the lane; for such of them as were on the look-out to buy or sell, nodded, familiarly, as he (Jew) passed along. He (Jew) replied to their salutations in the same way; but bestowed no closer recognition until he (Jew) reached the further end of the alley; when he (Jew) stopped, to address a salesman of small stature, who had squeezed as much of his (Jew) person into a child's chair as the chair would hold, and was smoking a pipe at his (Jew) warehouse door.

`Why, the sight of you, Mr. Fagin, would cure the hoptalmy!' (this trader)
said this respectable trader, in acknowledgment of the Jew's inquiry after his (trader) health.

`The neighbourhood was a little too hot, Lively,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, elevating his (Fagin) eyebrows, and crossing his (Fagin) hands upon his (Fagin) shoulders.

`Well, I've heerd that complaint of it, once or twice before,' (the trader)
replied the trader;
`but it soon cools down again; don't you find it so?' (the trader)

Fagin nodded in the affirmative. Pointing in the direction of Saffron Hill, he (Fagin) inquired whether any one was up yonder to-night.

`At the Cripples?' (the man)
inquired the man.

The Jew nodded.

`Let me see,' (the merchant)
pursued the merchant, reflecting.

`Yes, there's some half-dozen of 'em gone in, that I knows. I don't think your friend's there.' (unknown)

`Sikes is not, I suppose?' (the Jew)
inquired the Jew, with a disappointed countenance.

`_Non istwentus_, as the lawyers say,' (the Jew)
replied the little man, shaking his (man) head, and looking amazingly sly.
`Have you got anything in my line to-night?' (unknown)

`Nothing to-night,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning away.

`Are you going up to the Cripples, Fagin?' (the man)
cried the little man, calling after him (Fagin).
`Stop! I don't mind if I have a drop there with you!' (the Jew)

But as the Jew, looking back, waved his (Jew) hand to intimate that he (Jew) preferred being alone; and, moreover, as the little man could not very easily disengage himself from the chair; the sign of the Cripples was, for a time, bereft of the advantage of Mr. Lively's presence. By the time he (Mr.) had got upon his (Mr.) legs, the Jew had disappeared; so Mr. Lively, after ineffectually standing on tiptoe, in the hope of catching sight of him (Mr.), again forced himself into the little chair, and, exchanging a shake of the head with a lady in the opposite shop, in which doubt and mistrust were plainly mingled, resumed his (Mr.) pipe with a grave demeanour.

The Three Cripples, or rather the Cripples; which was the sign by which the establishment was familiarly known to its patrons: was the public-house in which Mr. Sikes and his (Sikes) dog have already figured. Merely making a sign to a man at the bar, Fagin walked straight upstairs, and opening the door of a room, and softly insinuating himself into the chamber, looked anxiously about: shading his (Fagin) eyes with his (Fagin) hand, as if in search of some particular person.

The room was illuminated by two gas-lights; the glare of which was prevented by the barred shutters, and closely-drawn curtains of faded red, from being visible outside. The ceiling was blackened, to prevent its colour from being injured by the flaring of the lamps; and the place was so full of dense tobacco smoke, that at first it was scarcely possible to discern anything more. By degrees, however, as some of it cleared away through the open door, an assemblage of heads, as confused as the noises that greeted the ear, might be made out; and as the eye grew more accustomed to the scene, the spectator gradually became aware of the presence of a numerous company, male and female, crowded round a long table: at the upper end of which, sat a chairman with a hammer of office in his (chairman) hand; while a professional gentleman with a bluish nose, and his (chairman) face tied up for the benefit of a toothache, presided at a jingling piano in a remote corner.

As Fagin stepped softly in, the professional gentleman, running over the keys by way of prelude, occasioned a general cry of order for a song; which having subsided, a young lady proceeded to entertain the company with a ballad in four verses, between each of which the accompanyist played the melody all through, as loud as he (Fagin) could. When this was over, the chairman gave a sentiment, after which, the professional gentleman on the chairman's right and left volunteered a duet, and sang it, with great applause.

It was curious to observe some faces which stood out prominently from among the group. There was the chairman himself, -LRB-the landlord of the house,-RRB- a coarse, rough, heavy built fellow, who, while the songs were proceeding, rolled his (fellow) eyes hither and thither, and, seeming to give himself up to joviality, had an eye for everything that was done, and an ear for everything that was said--and sharp ones, too. Near him (fellow) were the singers: receiving, with professional indifference, the compliments of the company, and applying themselves, in turn, to a dozen proffered glasses of spirits and water, tendered by their more boisterous admirers; whose countenances, expressive of almost every vice in almost every grade, irresistibly attracted the attention, by their very repulsiveness. Cunning, ferocity, and drunkeness in all its stages, were there, in their strongest aspect; and women: some with the last lingering tinge of their early freshness almost fading as you looked: others with every mark and stamp of their sex utterly beaten out, and presenting but one loathsome blank of profligacy and crime; some mere girls, others but young women, and none past the prime of life; formed the darkest and saddest portion of this dreary picture.

Fagin, troubled by no grave emotions, looked eagerly from face to face while these proceedings were in progress; but apparently without meeting that of which he (Fagin) was in search. Succeeding, at length, in catching the eye of the man who occupied the chair, he (man) beckoned to him (man) slightly, and left the room, as quietly as he (man) had entered it.

`What can I do for you, Mr. Fagin?' (the man)
inquired the man, as he (Fagin) followed him (Fagin) out to the landing.
`Won't you join us? They'll be delighted, every one of 'em.' (The Jew)

The Jew shook his (Jew) head impatiently, and said in a whisper,

`Is _he (Jew)_ here?' (The Jew)

`No,' (the man)
replied the man.

`And no news of Barney?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin.

`None,' (he)
replied the landlord of the Cripples; for it was he (Fagin).
`He (Fagin) won't stir till it's all safe. Depend on it, they're on the scent down there; and that if he (Fagin) moved, he (Fagin)'d blow upon the thing at once. He (Fagin)'s all right enough, Barney is, else I should have heard of him (Barney). I'll pound it, that Barney's managing properly. Let him (Barney) alone for that.' (unknown)

`Will _he (Barney)_ be here to-night?' (the Jew)
asked the Jew, laying the same emphasis on the pronoun as before.

`Monks, do you mean?' (unknown)
inquired the landlord, hesitating.

`Hush!' (the Jew)
said the Jew.
`Yes.' (unknown)

`Certain,' (the man)
replied the man, drawing a gold watch from his (man) fob;
`I expected him (man) here before now. If you'll wait ten minutes, he (man)'ll be--' (the man)

`No, no,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, hastily; as though, however desirous he (Jew) might be to see the person in question, he (Jew) was nevertheless relieved by his (Jew) absence.
`Tell him (Jew) I came here to see him (Jew); and that he (Jew) must come to me to-night. No, say to-morrow. As he (Jew) is not here, to-morrow will be time enough.' (unknown)

`Good!' (the man)
said the man.
`Nothing more?' (unknown)

`Not a word now,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, descending the stairs.

`I say,' (the Jew)
said the other, looking over the rails, and speaking in a hoarse whisper;
`what a time this would be for a sell! I've got Phil Barker here: so drunk, that a boy might take him (boy)!' (unknown)

`Ah! But it's not Phil Barker's time,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, looking up.

`Phil has something more to do, before we can afford to part with him (Phil); so go back to the company, my dear, and tell them to lead merry lives--_while they last_. Ha! ha! ha!' (the man)

The landlord reciprocated the old man's laugh; and returned to his (man) guests. The Jew was no sooner alone, than his (man) countenance resumed its former expression of anxiety and thought. After a brief reflection, he (man) called a hack-cabriolet, and bade the man drive towards Bethnal Green. He (Green) dismissed him (Green) within some quarter of a mile of Mr. Sikes's residence, and performed the short remainder of the distance, on foot.

`Now,' (the Jew)
muttered the Jew, as he (Jew) knocked at the door,
`if there is any deep play here, I shall have it out of you, my girl, cunning as you are.' (he)

She (girl) was in her (girl) room, the woman said. Fagin crept softly upstairs, and entered it without any previous ceremony. The girl was alone; lying with her (girl) head upon the table, and her (girl) hair straggling over it.

`She (girl) has been drinking,' (the Jew)
thought the Jew, cooly,
`or perhaps she (girl) is only miserable.' (the Jew)

The old man turned to close the door, as he (man) made this reflection; the noise thus occasioned, roused the girl. She (girl) eyed his (man) crafty face narrowly, as she (girl) inquired to his (man) recital of Toby Crackit's story. When it was concluded, she (girl) sank into her (girl) former attitude, but spoke not a word. She (girl) pushed the candle impatiently away; and once or twice as she (girl) feverishly changed her (girl) position, shuffled her (girl) feet upon the ground; but this was all.

During the silence, the Jew looked restlessly about the room, as if to assure himself that there were no appearances of Sikes having covertly returned. Apparently satisfied with his (Sikes) inspection, he (Sikes) coughed twice or thrice, and made as many efforts to open a conversation; but the girl heeded him (Sikes) no more than if he (Sikes) had been made of stone. At length he (Sikes) made another attempt; and rubbing his (Sikes) hands together, said, in his (Sikes) most conciliatory tone,

`And where should you think Bill was now, my dear?' (he)

The girl moaned out some half intelligible reply, that she (girl) could not tell; and seemed, from the smothered noise that escaped her (girl), to be crying.

`And the boy, too,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, straining his (Jew) eyes to catch a glimpse of her (girl) face.
`Poor leetle child! Left in a ditch, Nance; only think!' (unknown)

`The child,' (the girl)
said the girl, suddenly looking up,
`is better where he (Nance) is, than among us; and if no harm comes to Bill from it, I hope he (Bill) lies dead in the ditch and that his (Bill) young bones may rot there.' (the girl)

`What!' (the Jew)
cried the Jew, in amazement.

`Ay, I do,' (the girl)
returned the girl, meeting his (Jew) gaze.
`I shall be glad to have him (Jew) away from my eyes, and to know that the worst is over. I can't bear to have him (Jew) about me. The sight of him (Jew) turns me against myself, and all of you.' (the girl)

`Pooh!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, scornfully.
`You're drunk.' (unknown)

`Am I?' (the girl)
cried the girl bitterly.
`It's no fault of yours, if I am not! You'd never have me anything else, if you had your will, except now;--the humour doesn't suit you, doesn't it?' (unknown)

`No!' (the Jew)
rejoined the Jew, furiously.
`It does not.' (unknown)

`Change it, then!' (the girl)
responded the girl, with a laugh.

`Change it!' (the Jew)
exclaimed the Jew, exasperated beyond all bounds by his (Jew) companion's unexpected obstinacy, and the vexation of the night,
`I _will_ change it! Listen to me, you drab. Listen to me, who with six words, can strangle Sikes as surely as if I had his (Sikes) bull's throat between my fingers now. If he (Sikes) comes back, and leaves the boy behind him (Sikes); if he (Sikes) gets off free, and dead or alive, fails to restore him (Sikes) to me; murder him (Sikes) yourself if you would have him (Sikes) escape Jack Ketch. And do it the moment he (Sikes) sets foot in this room, or mind me, it will be too late!' (companion)

`What is all this?' (the girl)
cried the girl involuntarily.

`What is it?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
pursued Fagin, mad with rage.
`When the boy's worth hundreds of pounds to me, am I to lose what chance threw me in the way of getting safely, through the whims of a drunken gang that I could whistle away the lives of! And me bound, too, to a born devil that only wants the will, and has the power to, to--' (the man)

Panting for breath, the old man stammered for a word; and in that instant checked the torrent of his (man) wrath, and changed his (man) whole demeanour. A moment before, his (man) clenched hands had grasped the air; his (man) eyes had dilated; and his (man) face grown livid with passion; but now, he (man) shrunk into a chair, and, cowering together, trembled with the apprehension of having himself disclosed some hidden villainy. After a short silence, he (man) ventured to look round at his (man) companion. He (man) appeared somewhat reassured, on beholding her (man) in the same listless attitude from which he (man) had first roused her (man).

`Nancy, dear!' (the Jew)
croaked the Jew, in his (Jew) usual voice.
`Did you mind me, dear?' (unknown)

`Don't worry me now, Fagin!' (the girl)
replied the girl, raising her (girl) head languidly.
`If Bill has not done it this time, he (Bill) will another. He (Bill) has done many a good job for you, and will do many more when he (Bill) can; and when he (Bill) can't he (Bill) won't; so no more about that.' (unknown)

`Regarding this boy, my dear?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, rubbing the palms of his (Jew) hands nervously together.

`The boy must take his (boy) chance with the rest,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
interrupted Nancy, hastily;
`and I say again, I hope he (boy) is dead, and out of harm's way, and out of yours,--that is, if Bill comes to no harm. And if Toby got clear off, Bill's pretty sure to be safe; for Bill's worth two of Toby any time.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`And about what I was saying, my dear?' (the Jew)
observed the Jew, keeping his (Jew) glistening eye steadily upon her (Nancy).

`Your must say it all over again, if it's anything you want me to do,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
rejoined Nancy;
`and if it is, you had better wait till to-morrow. You put me up for a minute; but now I'm stupid again.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

Fagin put several other questions: all with the same drift of ascertaining whether the girl had profited by his (Fagin) unguarded hints; but, she (girl) answered them so readily, and was withal so utterly unmoved by his (Fagin) searching looks, that his (Fagin) original impression of her (girl) being more than a trifle in liquor, was confirmed. Nancy, indeed, was not exempt from a failing which was very common among the Jew's female pupils; and in which, in their tenderer years, they were rather encouraged than checked. Her (Nancy) disordered appearance, and a wholesale perfume of Geneva which pervaded the apartment, afforded strong confirmatory evidence of the justice of the Jew's supposition; and when, after indulging in the temporary display of violence above described, she (Nancy) subsided, first into dullness, and afterwards into a compound of feelings: under the influence of which she (Nancy) shed tears one minute, and in the next gave utterance to various exclamations of

`Never say die!' (she)
and divers calculations as to what might be the amount of the odds so long as a lady or gentleman was happy, Mr. Fagin, who had had considerable experience of such matters in his (Fagin) time, saw, with great satisfaction, that she (lady) was very far gone indeed.

Having eased his (Fagin) mind by this discovery; and having accomplished his (Fagin) twofold object of imparting to the girl what he (Fagin) had, that night, heard, and of ascertaining, with his (Fagin) own eyes, that Sikes had not returned, Mr. Fagin again turned his (Fagin) face homeward: leaving his (Fagin) young friend asleep, with her (girl) head upon the table.

It was within an hour of midnight. The weather being dark, and piercing cold, he (Fagin) had no great temptation to loiter. The sharp wind that scoured the streets, seemed to have cleared them of passengers, as of dust and mud, for few people were abroad, and they were to all appearance hastening fast home. It blew from the right quarter for the Jew, however, and straight before it he (Jew) went: trembling, and shivering, as every fresh gust drove him (Jew) rudely on his (Jew) way.

He (Jew) had reached the corner of his (Jew) own street, and was already fumbling in his (Jew) pocket for the door-key, when a dark figure emerged from a projecting entrance which lay in deep shadow, and, crossing the road, glided up to him (Jew) unperceived.

`Fagin!' (unknown)
whispered a voice close to his (Fagin) ear.

`Ah!' (the Jew)
said the Jew, turning quickly round,
`is that--' (the Jew)

`Yes!' (the Jew)
interrupted the stranger.
`I have been lingering here these two hours. Where the devil have you been?' (the stranger)

`On your business, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, glancing uneasily at his (Jew) companion, and slackening his (Jew) pace as he (Jew) spoke.
`On your business all night.' (unknown)

`Oh, of course!' (the stranger)
said the stranger, with a sneer.
`Well; and what's come of it?' (unknown)

`Nothing good,' (the Jew)
said the Jew.

`Nothing bad, I hope?' (the stranger)
said the stranger, stopping short, and turning a startled look on his (stranger) companion.

The Jew shook his (Jew) head, and was about to reply, when the stranger, interrupting him (stranger), motioned to the house, before which they had by this time arrived: remarking, that he (stranger) had better say what he (stranger) had got to say, under cover: for his (stranger) blood was chilled with standing about so long, and the wind blew through him (stranger).

Fagin looked as if he (Fagin) could have willingly excused himself from taking home a visitor at that unseasonable hour; and, indeed, muttered something about having no fire; but his (Fagin) companion repeating his (Fagin) request in a peremptory manner, he (Fagin) unlocked the door, and requested him (Fagin) to close it softly, while he (Fagin) got a light.

`It's as dark as the grave,' (the man)
said the man, groping forward a few steps.
`Make haste!' (unknown)

`Shut the door,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
whispered Fagin from the end of the passage. As he (Fagin) spoke, it closed with a loud noise.

`That wasn't my doing,' (the man)
said the other man, feeling his (man) way.
`The wind blew it to, or it shut of its own accord: one or the other. Look sharp with the light, or I shall knock my brains out against something in this confounded hole.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin stealthily descended the kitchen stairs. After a short absence, he (Fagin) returned with a lighted candle, and the intelligence that Toby Crackit was asleep in the back room below, and that the boys were in the front one. Beckoning the man to follow him (man), he (man) led the way upstairs.

`We can say the few words we've got to say in here, my dear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, throwing open a door on the first floor;
`and as there are holes in the shutters, and we never show lights to our neighbours, we'll set the candle on the stairs. There!' (the Jew)

With those words, the Jew, stooping down, placed the candle on an upper flight of stairs, exactly opposite to the room door. This done, he (Jew) led the way into the apartment; which was destitute of all movables save a broken arm-chair, and an old couch or sofa without covering, which stood behind the door. Upon this piece of furniture, the stranger sat himself with the air of a weary man; and the Jew, drawing up the arm-chair opposite, they sat face to face. It was not quite dark; the door was partially open; and the candle outside, threw a feeble reflection on the opposite wall.

They conversed for some time in whispers. Though nothing of the conversation was distinguishable beyond a few disjointed words here and there, a listener might easily have perceived that Fagin appeared to be defending himself against some remarks of the stranger; and that the latter was in a state of considerable irritation. They might have been talking, thus, for a quarter of an hour or more, when Monks--by which name the Jew had designated the strange man several times in the course of their colloquy--said, raising his (Jew) voice a little,

`I tell you again, it was badly planned. Why not have kept him (Jew) here among the rest, and made a sneaking, snivelling pickpocket of him (pickpocket) at once?' (the man times)

`Only hear him (pickpocket)!' (the Jew)
exclaimed the Jew, shrugging his (Jew) shoulders.

`Why, do you mean to say you couldn't have done it, if you had chosen?' (Monks)
demanded Monks, sternly.
`Haven't you done it, with other boys, scores of times? If you had had patience for a twelvemonth, at most, couldn't you have got him (Jew) convicted, and sent safely out of the kingdom; perhaps for life?' (unknown)

`Whose turn would that have served, my dear?' (the Jew)
