inquired the Jew humbly.

`Mine,' (Monks)
replied Monks.

`But not mine,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, submissively.
`He (Jew) might have become of use to me. When there are two parties to a bargain, it is only reasonable that the interests of both should be consulted; is it, my good friend?' (unknown)

`What then?' (Monks)
demanded Monks.

`I saw it was not easy to train him (friend) to the business,' (Monks)
replied the Jew;
`he (Jew) was not like other boys in the same circumstances.' (the Jew)

`Curse him (Jew), no!' (the man thief)
muttered the man,
`or he (man) would have been a thief, long ago.' (the man thief)

`I had no hold upon him (man) to make him (man) worse,' (the man thief)
pursued the Jew, anxiously watching the countenance of his (Jew) companion.
`His (Jew) hand was not in. I had nothing to frighten him (Jew) with; which we always must have in the beginning, or we labour in vain. What could I do? Send him (Jew) out with the Dodger and Charley? We had enough of that, at first, my dear; I trembled for us all.' (unknown)

`_That_ was not my doing,' (Monks)
observed Monks.

`No, no, my dear!' (the Jew)
renewed the Jew.
`And I don't quarrel with it now; because, if it had never happened, you might never have clapped eyes on the boy to notice him (boy), and so led to the discovery that it was him (boy) you were looking for. Well! I got him (boy) back for you by means of the girl; and then _she (girl)_ begins to favour him (boy).' (unknown)

`Throttle the girl!' (Monks)
said Monks, impatiently.

`Why, we can't afford to do that just now, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, smiling;
`and, besides, that sort of thing is not in our way; or, one of these days, I might be glad to have it done. I know what these girls are, Monks, well. As soon as the boy begins to harden, she (girl)'ll care no more for him (boy), than for a block of wood. You want him (boy) made a thief. If he (boy) is alive, I can make him (boy) one from this time; and, if--if--' (the Jew)
said the Jew, drawing nearer to the other,--`it's not likely, mind,--but if the worst comes to the worst, and he (Jew) is dead--'

`It's no fault of mine if he (Jew) is!' (he)
interposed the other man, with a look of terror, and clasping the Jew's arm with trembling hands.
`Mind that. Fagin! I had no hand in it. Anything but his (Fagin) death, I told you from the first. I won't shed blood; it's always found out, and haunts a man besides. If they shot him (man) dead, I was not the cause; do you hear me? Fire this infernal den! What's that?' (unknown)

`What!' (the Jew)
cried the Jew, grasping the coward round the body, with both arms, as he (Jew) sprung to his (Jew) feet.
`Where?' (unknown)

`Yonder! replied the man, glaring at the opposite wall.

`The shadow! I saw the shadow of a woman, in a cloak and bonnet, pass along the wainscot like a breath!' (The Jew)

The Jew released his (Jew) hold, and they rushed tumultuously from the room. The candle, wasted by the draught, was standing where it had been placed. It showed them only the empty staircase, and their own white faces. They listened intently: a profound silence reigned throughout the house.

`It's your fancy,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, taking up the light and turning to his (Jew) companion.

`I'll swear I saw it!' (Monks)
replied Monks, trembling.
`It was bending forward when I saw it first; and when I spoke, it darted away.' (The Jew)

The Jew glanced contemptuously at the pale face of his (Jew) associate, and, telling him (Jew) he (Jew) could follow, if he (Jew) pleased, ascended the stairs. They looked into all the rooms; they were cold, bare, and empty. They descended into the passage, and thence into the cellars below. The green damp hung upon the low walls; the tracks of the snail and slug glistened in the light of the candle; but all was still as death.

`What do you think now?' (the Jew)
said the Jew, when they had regained the passage.
`Besides ourselves, there's not a creature in the house except Toby and the boys; and they're safe enough. See here!' (the Jew)

As a proof of the fact, the Jew drew forth two keys from his (Jew) pocket; and explained, that when he (Jew) first went downstairs, he (Jew) had locked them in, to prevent any intrusion on the conference.

This accumulated testimony effectually staggered Mr. Monks. His (Monks) protestations had gradually become less and less vehement as they proceeded in their search without making any discovery; and, now, he (Monks) gave vent to several very grim laughs, and confessed it could only have been his (Monks) excited imagination. He (Monks) declined any renewal of the conversation, however, for that night: suddenly remembering that it was past one o'clock. And so the amiable couple parted.

CHAPTER XXVII

ATONES FOR THE UNPOLITENESS OF A FORMER CHAPTER; WHICH DESERTED A LADY, MOST UNCEREMONIOUSLY

As it would be, by no means, seemly in a humble author to keep so mighty a personage as a beadle waiting, with his (beadle) back to the fire, and the skirts of his (beadle) coat gathered up under his (beadle) arms, until such time as it might suit his (beadle) pleasure to relieve him (beadle); and as it would still less become his (beadle) station, or his (beadle) gallantry to involve in the same neglect a lady on whom that beadle had looked with an eye of tenderness and affection, and in whose ear he (beadle) had whispered sweet words, which, coming from such a quarter, might well thrill the bosom of maid or matron of whatsoever degree; the historian whose pen traces these words--trusting that he (historian) knows his (historian) place, and that he (historian) entertains a becoming reverence for those upon earth to whom high and important authority is delegated--hastens to pay them that respect which their position demands, and to treat them with all that duteous ceremony which their exalted rank, and -LRB-by consequence-RRB- great virtues, imperatively claim at his (historian) hands. Towards this end, indeed, he (historian) had purposed to introduce, in this place, a dissertation touching the divine right of beadles, and elucidative of the position, that a beadle can do no wrong: which could not fail to have been both pleasurable and profitable to the right-minded reader but which he (reader) is unfortunately compelled, by want of time and space, to postpone to some more convenient and fitting opportunity; on the arrival of which, he (reader) will be prepared to show, that a beadle properly constituted: that is to say, a parochial beadle, attached to a parochial workhouse, and attending in his (beadle) official capacity the parochial church: is, in right and virtue of his (beadle) office, possessed of all the excellences and best qualities of humanity; and that to none of those excellences, can mere companies' beadles, or court-of-law beadles, or even chapel-of-ease beadles -LRB-save the last, and they in a very lowly and inferior degree-RRB-, lay the remotest sustainable claim.

Mr. Bumble had re-counted the teaspoons, re-weighed the sugar-tongs, made a closer inspection of the milk-pot, and ascertained to a nicety the exact condition of the furniture, down to the very horse-hair seats of the chairs; and had repeated each process full half a dozen times; before he (Bumble) began to think that it was time for Mrs. Corney to return. Thinking begets thinking; as there were no sounds of Mrs. Corney's approach, it occured to Mr. Bumble that it would be an innocent and virtuous way of spending the time, if he (Bumble) were further to allay his (Bumble) curiousity by a cursory glance at the interior of Mrs. Corney's chest of drawers.

Having listened at the keyhole, to assure himself that nobody was approaching the chamber, Mr. Bumble, beginning at the bottom, proceeded to make himself acquainted with the contents of the three long drawers: which, being filled with various garments of good fashion and texture, carefully preserved between two layers of old newspapers, speckled with dried lavender: seemed to yield him (Bumble) exceeding satisfaction. Arriving, in course of time, at the right-hand corner drawer -LRB-in which was the key-RRB-, and beholding therein a small padlocked box, which, being shaken, gave forth a pleasant sound, as of the chinking of coin, Mr. Bumble returned with a stately walk to the fireplace; and, resuming his (Bumble) old attitude, said, with a grave and determined air,

`I'll do it!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
He (Bumble) followed up this remarkable declaration, by shaking his (Bumble) head in a waggish manner for ten minutes, as though he (Bumble) were remonstrating with himself for being such a pleasant dog; and then, he (Bumble) took a view of his (Bumble) legs in profile, with much seeming pleasure and interest.

He (Bumble) was still placidly engaged in this latter survey, when Mrs. Corney, hurrying into the room, threw herself, in a breathless state, on a chair by the fireside, and covering her (Corney) eyes with one hand, placed the other over her (Corney) heart, and gasped for breath.

`Mrs. Corney,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, stooping over the matron,
`what is this, ma'am? Has anything happened, ma'am? Pray answer me: I'm on--on--' (the matron this)
Mr. Bumble, in his (Bumble) alarm, could not immediately think of the word
`tenterhooks,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
so he (Bumble) said
`broken bottles.' (he)

`Oh, Mr. Bumble!' (the lady)
cried the lady,
`I have been so dreadfully put out!' (the lady)

`Put out, ma'am!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
exclaimed Mr. Bumble;
`who has dared to--? I know!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, checking himself, with native majesty,
`this is them wicious paupers!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`It's dreadful to think of!' (the lady)
said the lady, shuddering.

`Then _don't_ think of it, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble.

`I can't help it,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
whimpered the lady.

`Then take something, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble soothingly.
`A little of the wine?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Not for the world!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
replied Mrs. Corney.
`I couldn't,--oh! The top shelf in the right-hand corner--oh!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
Uttering these words, the good lady pointed, distractedly, to the cupboard, and underwent a convulsion from internal spasms. Mr. Bumble rushed to the closet; and, snatching a pint green-glass bottle from the shelf thus incoherently indicated, filled a tea-cup with its contents, and held it to the lady's lips.

`I'm better now,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
said Mrs. Corney, falling back, after drinking half of it.

Mr. Bumble raised his (Bumble) eyes piously to the ceiling in thankfulness; and, bringing them down again to the brim of the cup, lifted it to his (Bumble) nose.

`Peppermint,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
exclaimed Mrs. Corney, in a faint voice, smiling gently on the beadle as she (Corney) spoke.
`Try it! There's a little--a little something else in it.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble tasted the medicine with a doubtful look; smacked his (Bumble) lips; took another taste; and put the cup down empty.

`It's very comforting,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
said Mrs. Corney.

`Very much so indeed, ma'am,' (the beadle)
said the beadle. As he (beadle) spoke, he (beadle) drew a chair beside the matron, and tenderly inquired what had happened to distress her (matron).

`Nothing,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
replied Mrs. Corney.
`I am a foolish, excitable, weak creetur.' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)

`Not weak, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
retorted Mr. Bumble, drawing his (Bumble) chair a little closer.
`Are you a weak creetur, Mrs. Corney?' (unknown)

`We are all weak creeturs,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
said Mrs. Corney, laying down a general principle.

`So we are,' (the beadle)
said the beadle.

Nothing was said on either side, for a minute or two afterwards. By the expiration of that time, Mr. Bumble had illustrated the position by removing his (Bumble) left arm from the back of Mrs. Corney's chair, where it had previously rested, to Mrs. Corney's apron-string, round which it gradually became entwined.

`We are all weak creeturs,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.

Mrs. Corney sighed.

`Don't sigh, Mrs. Corney,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.

`I can't help it,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mrs. Corney. And she (Corney) sighed again.

`This is a very comfortable room, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble looking round.
`Another room, and this, ma'am, would be a complete thing.' (unknown)

`It would be too much for one,' (the lady)
murmured the lady.

`But not for two, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble, in soft accents.
`Eh, Mrs. Corney?' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)

Mrs. Corney drooped her (Corney) head, when the beadle said this; the beadle drooped his (beadle), to get a view of Mrs. Corney's face. Mrs. Corney, with great propriety, turned her (Corney) head away, and released her (Corney) hand to get at her (Corney) pocket-handkerchief; but insensibly replaced it in that of Mr. Bumble.

`The board allows you coals, don't they, Mrs. Corney?' (the beadle)
inquired the beadle, affectionately pressing her (Corney) hand.

`And candles,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
replied Mrs. Corney, slightly returning the pressure.

`Coals, candles, and house-rent free,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`Oh, Mrs. Corney, what an Angel you are!' (The lady)

The lady was not proof against this burst of feeling. She (Corney) sank into Mr. Bumble's arms; and that gentleman in his (Bumble) agitation, imprinted a passionate kiss upon her (Corney) chaste nose.

`Such porochial perfection!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
exclaimed Mr. Bumble, rapturously.
`You know that Mr. Slout is worse to-night, my fascinator?' (unknown)

`Yes,' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)
replied Mrs. Corney, bashfully.

`He (Mr.) can't live a week, the doctor says,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
pursued Mr. Bumble.
`He (Bumble) is the master of this establishment; his (Bumble) death will cause a wacancy; that wacancy must be filled up. Oh, Mrs. Corney, what a prospect this opens! What a opportunity for a jining of hearts and housekeepings!' (Mrs. Corney/Corney)

Mrs. Corney sobbed.

`The little word?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, bending over the bashful beauty.
`The one little, little, little word, my blessed Corney?' (unknown)

`Ye--ye--yes!' (the matron)
sighed out the matron.

`One more,' (the beadle)
pursued the beadle;
`compose your darling feelings for only one more. When is it to come off?' (the beadle)

Mrs. Corney twice essayed to speak: and twice failed. At length summoning up courage, she (Corney) threw her (Corney) arms around Mr. Bumble's neck, and said, it might be as soon as ever he (Bumble) pleased, and that he (Bumble) was

`a irresistible duck.' (he)

Matters being thus amicably and satisfactorily arranged, the contract was solemnly ratified in another teacupful of the peppermint mixture; which was rendered the more necessary, by the flutter and agitation of the lady's spirits. While it was being disposed of, she (lady) acquainted Mr. Bumble with the old woman's decease.

`Very good,' (gentleman)
said that gentleman, sipping his (Bumble) peppermint;
`I'll call at Sowerberry's as I go home, and tell him (Sowerberry) to send to-morrow morning. Was it that as frightened you, love?' (gentleman)

`It wasn't anything particular, dear,' (the lady)
said the lady evasively.

`It must have been something, love,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
urged Mr. Bumble.
`Won't you tell your own B.?' (unknown)

`Not now,' (the lady)
rejoined the lady;
`one of these days. After we're married, dear.' (the lady)

`After we're married!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
exclaimed Mr. Bumble.
`It wasn't any impudence from any of them male paupers as--' (unknown)

`No, no, love!' (the lady)
interposed the lady, hastily.

`If I thought it was,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
continued Mr. Bumble;
`if I thought as any one of 'em had dared to lift his (Bumble) wulgar eyes to that lovely countenance--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`They wouldn't have dared to do it, love,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
responded the lady.

`They had better not!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, clenching his (Bumble) fist.
`Let me see any man, porochial or extra-porochial, as would presume to do it; and I can tell him (Bumble) that he (Bumble) wouldn't do it a second time!' (the lady)

Unembellished by any violence of gesticulation, this might have seemed no very high compliment to the lady's charms; but, as Mr. Bumble accompanied the threat with many warlike gestures, she (lady) was much touched with this proof of his (Bumble) devotion, and protested, with great admiration, that he (Bumble) was indeed a dove.

The dove then turned up his (Bumble) coat-collar, and put on his (Bumble) cocked hat; and, having exchanged a long and affectionate embrace with his (Bumble) future partner, once again braved the cold wind of the night: merely pausing, for a few minutes, in the male paupers' ward, to abuse them a little, with the view of satisfying himself that he (Bumble) could fill the office of workhouse-master with needful acerbity. Assured of his (Bumble) qualifications, Mr. Bumble left the building with a light heart, and bright visions of his (Bumble) future promotion: which served to occupy his (Bumble) mind until he (Bumble) reached the shop of the undertaker.

Now, Mr. and Mrs. Sowerberry having gone out to tea and supper: and Noah Claypole not being at any time disposed to take upon himself a greater amount of physical exertion than is necessary to a convenient performance of the two functions of eating and drinking, the shop was not closed, although it was past the usual hour of shutting-up. Mr. Bumble tapped with his (Bumble) cane on the counter several times; but, attracting no attention, and beholding a light shining through the glass-window of the little parlour at the back of the shop, he (Bumble) made bold to peep in and see what was going forward; and when he (Bumble) saw what was going forward, he (Bumble) was not a little surprised.

The cloth was laid for supper; the table was covered with bread and butter, plates and glasses; a porter-pot and a wine-bottle. At the upper end of the table, Mr. Noah Claypole lolled negligently in an easy-chair, with his (Claypole) legs thrown over one of the arms: an open clasp-knife in one hand, and a mass of buttered bread in the other. Close beside him (Claypole) stood Charlotte, opening oysters from a barrel: which Mr. Claypole condescended to swallow, with remarkable avidity. A more than ordinary redness in the region of the young gentleman's nose, and a kind of fixed wink in his (gentleman) right eye, denoted that he (gentleman) was in a slight degree intoxicated; these symptoms were confirmed by the intense relish with which he (gentleman) took his (gentleman) oysters, for which nothing but a strong appreciation of their cooling properties, in cases of internal fever, could have sufficiently accounted.

`Here's a delicious fat one, Noah, dear!' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte;
`try him (Noah), do; only this one.' (Charlotte)

`What a delicious thing is a oyster!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
remarked Mr. Claypole, after he (Claypole) had swallowed it.
`What a pity it is, a number of 'em should ever make you feel uncomfortable; isn't it, Charlotte?' (unknown)

`It's quite a cruelty,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.

`So it is,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
acquiesced Mr. Claypole.
`An't yer fond of oysters?' (unknown)

`Not overmuch,' (Charlotte)
replied Charlotte.
`I like to see you eat 'em, Noah dear, better than eating 'em myself.' (Charlotte)

`Lor!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, reflectively;
`how queer!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`Have another,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.
`Here's one with such a beautiful, delicate beard!' (unknown)

`I can't manage any more,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.
`I'm very sorry. Come here, Charlotte, and I'll kiss yer.' (unknown)

`What!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, bursting into the room.
`Say that again, sir.' (Charlotte)

Charlotte uttered a scream, and hid her (Charlotte) face in her (Charlotte) apron. Mr. Claypole, without making any further change in his (Claypole) position than suffering his (Claypole) legs to reach the ground, gazed at the beadle in drunken terror.

`Say it again, you wile, owdacious fellow!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`How dare you mention such a thing, sir? And how dare you encourage him (Bumble), you insolent minx? Kiss her (Charlotte)!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
exclaimed Mr. Bumble, in strong indignation.
`Faugh!' (unknown)

`I didn't mean to do it!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, blubbering.
`She (Charlotte)'s always a-kissing of me, whether I like it, or not.' (unknown)

`Oh, Noah,' (Charlotte)
cried Charlotte, reproachfully.

`Yer are; yer know yer are!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
retorted Noah.
`She (Charlotte)'s always a-doin' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
of it, Mr. Bumble, sir; she (Charlotte) chucks me under the chin, please, sir; and makes all manner of love!'

`Silence!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
cried Mr. Bumble, sternly.
`Take yourself downstairs, ma'am. Noah, you shut up the shop; say another word till your master comes home, at your peril; and, when he (Noah) does come home, tell him (Noah) that Mr. Bumble said he (Bumble) was to send a old woman's shell after breakfast to-morrow morning. Do you hear sir? Kissing!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
cried Mr. Bumble, holding up his (Bumble) hands.
`The sin and wickedness of the lower orders in this porochial district is frightful! If Parliament don't take their abominable courses under consideration, this country's ruined, and the character of the peasantry gone for ever!' (the beadle)
With these words, the beadle strode, with a lofty and gloomy air, from the undertaker's premises.

And now that we have accompanied him (undertaker) so far on his (undertaker) road home, and have made all necessary preparations for the old woman's funeral, let us set on foot a few inquires after young Oliver Twist, and ascertain whether he (Twist) be still lying in the ditch where Toby Crackit left him (Crackit).

CHAPTER XXVIII

LOOKS AFTER OLIVER, AND PROCEEDS WITH HIS (OLIVER) ADVENTURES

`Wolves tear your throats!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
muttered Sikes, grinding his (Sikes) teeth.
`I wish I was among some of you; you'd howl the hoarser for it.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

As Sikes growled forth this imprecation, with the most desperate ferocity that his (Sikes) desperate nature was capable of, he (Sikes) rested the body of the wounded boy across his (Sikes) bended knee; and turned his (Sikes) head, for an instant, to look back at his (Sikes) pursuers.

There was little to be made out, in the mist and darkness; but the loud shouting of men vibrated through the air, and the barking of the neighbouring dogs, roused by the sound of the alarm bell, resounded in every direction.

`Stop, you white-livered hound!' (the robber)
cried the robber, shouting after Toby Crackit, who, making the best use of his (Crackit) long legs, was already ahead.
`Stop!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

The repetition of the word, brought Toby to a dead stand-still. For he (Toby) was not quite satisfied that he (Toby) was beyond the range of pistol-shot; and Sikes was in no mood to be played with.

`Bear a hand with the boy,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, beckoning furiously to his (Sikes) confederate.
`Come back!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

Toby made a show of returning; but ventured, in a low voice, broken for want of breath, to intimate considerable reluctance as he (Toby) came slowly along.

`Quicker!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, laying the boy in a dry ditch at his (Sikes) feet, and drawing a pistol from his (Sikes) pocket.
`Don't play booty with me.' (unknown)

At this moment the noise grew louder. Sikes, again looking round, could discern that the men who had given chase were already climbing the gate of the field in which he (Sikes) stood; and that a couple of dogs were some paces in advance of them.

`It's all up, Bill!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
cried Toby;
`drop the kid, and show 'em your heels.' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
With this parting advice, Mr. Crackit, preferring the chance of being shot by his (Crackit) friend, to the certainty of being taken by his (Crackit) enemies, fairly turned tail, and darted off at full speed. Sikes clenched his (Sikes) teeth; took one look around; threw over the prostrate form of Oliver, the cape in which he (Oliver) had been hurriedly muffled; ran along the front of the hedge, as if to distract the attention of those behind, from the spot where the boy lay; paused, for a second, before another hedge which met it at right angles; and whirling his (boy) pistol high into the air, cleared it at a bound, and was gone.

`Ho, ho, there!' (unknown)
cried a tremulous voice in the rear.
`Pincher! Neptune! Come here, come here!' (masters)

The dogs, who, in common with their masters, seemed to have no particular relish for the sport in which they were engaged, readily answered to the command. Three men, who had by this time advanced some distance into the field, stopped to take counsel together.

`My advice, or, leastways, I should say, my _orders_, is,' (the man)
said the fattest man of the party, `that we
`mediately go home again.' (the party)

`I am agreeable to anything which is agreeable to Mr. Giles,' (the party)
said a shorter man; who was by no means of a slim figure, and who was very pale in the face, and very polite: as frightened men frequently are.

`I shouldn't wish to appear ill-mannered, gentlemen,' (men)
said the third, who had called the dogs back,
`Mr. Giles ought to know.' (unknown)

`Certainly,' (the man)
replied the shorter man;
`and whatever Mr. Giles says, it isn't our place to contradict him (Giles). No, no, I know my sitiwation! Thank my stars, I know my sitiwation.' (the man)
To tell the truth, the little man _did_ seem to know his (man) situation, and to know perfectly well that it was by no means a desirable one; for his (man) teeth chattered in his (man) head as he (man) spoke.

`You are afraid, Brittles,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles.

`I an't,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Brittles.

`You are,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Giles.

`You're a falsehood, Mr. Giles,' (unknown)
said Brittles.

`You're a lie, Brittles,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles.

Now, these four retorts arose from Mr. Giles's taunt; and Mr. Giles's taunt had arisen from his (Giles) indignation at having the responsibility of going home again, imposed upon himself under cover of a compliment. The third man brought the dispute to a close, most philosophically.

`I'll tell you what it is, gentlemen,' (he)
said he (man),
`we're all afraid.' (he)

`Speak for yourself, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, who was the palest of the party.

`So I do,' (the man)
replied the man.
`It's natural and proper to be afraid, under such circumstances. I am.' (unknown)

`So am I,' (unknown)
said Brittles;
`only there's no call to tell a man he (man) is, so bounceably.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

These frank admissions softened Mr. Giles, who at once owned that _he (Giles)_ was afraid; upon which, they all three faced about, and ran back again with the completest unanimity, until Mr. Giles -LRB-who had the shortest wind of the party, as was encumbered with a pitchfork-RRB- most handsomely insisted on stopping, to make an apology for his (Giles) hastiness of speech.

`But it's wonderful,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, when he (Giles) had explained,
`what a man will do, when his (Giles) blood is up. I should have committed murder--I know I should--if we'd caught one of them rascals.' (he)

As the other two were impressed with a similar presentiment; and as their blood, like his (Giles), had all gone down again; some speculation ensued upon the cause of this sudden change in their temperament.

`I know what it was,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles;
`it was the gate.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`I shouldn't wonder if it was,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
exclaimed Brittles, catching at the idea.

`You may depend upon it,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Giles,
`that that gate stopped the flow of the excitement. I felt all mine suddenly going away, as I was climbing over it.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

By a remarkable coincidence, the other two had been visited with the same unpleasant sensation at that precise moment. It was quite obvious, therefore, that it was the gate; especially as there was no doubt regarding the time at which the change had taken place, because all three remembered that they had come in sight of the robbers at the instant of its occurance.

This dialogue was held between the two men who had surprised the burglars, and a travelling tinker who had been sleeping in an outhouse, and who had been roused, together with his (its) two mongrel curs, to join in the pursuit. Mr. Giles acted in the double capacity of butler and steward to the old lady of the mansion; Brittles was a lad of all-work: who, having entered her (lady) service a mere child, was treated as a promising young boy still, though he (boy) was something past thirty.

Encouraging each other with such converse as this; but, keeping very close together, notwithstanding, and looking apprehensively round, whenever a fresh gust rattled through the boughs; the three men hurried back to a tree, behind which they had left their lantern, lest its light should inform the thieves in what direction to fire. Catching up the light, they made the best of their way home, at a good round trot; and long after their dusky forms had ceased to be discernible, the light might have been seen twinkling and dancing in the distance, like some exhalation of the damp and gloomy atmosphere through which it was swiftly borne.

The air grew colder, as day came slowly on; and the mist rolled along the ground like a dense cloud of smoke. The grass was wet; the pathways, and low places, were all mire and water; the damp breath of an unwholesome wind went languidly by, with a hollow moaning. Still, Oliver lay motionless and insensible on the spot where Sikes had left him (Sikes).

Morning drew on apace. The air become more sharp and piercing, as its first dull hue--the death of night, rather than the birth of day--glimmered faintly in the sky. The objects which had looked dim and terrible in the darkness, grew more and more defined, and gradually resolved into their familiar shapes. The rain came down, thick and fast, and pattered noisily among the leafless bushes. But, Oliver felt it not, as it beat against him (Oliver); for he (Oliver) still lay stretched, helpless and unconscious, on his (Oliver) bed of clay.

At length, a low cry of pain broke the stillness that prevailed; and uttering it, the boy awoke. His (boy) left arm, rudely bandaged in a shawl, hung heavy and useless at his (boy) side; the bandage was saturated with blood. He (boy) was so weak, that he (boy) could scarcely raise himself into a sitting posture; when he (boy) had done so, he (boy) looked feebly round for help, and groaned with pain. Trembling in every joint, from cold and exhaustion, he (boy) made an effort to stand upright; but, shuddering from head to foot, fell prostrate on the ground.

After a short return of the stupor in which he (boy) had been so long plunged, Oliver: urged by a creeping sickness at his (Oliver) heart, which seemed to warn him (Oliver) that if he (Oliver) lay there, he (Oliver) must surely die: got upon his (Oliver) feet, and essayed to walk. His (Oliver) head was dizzy, and he (Oliver) staggered to and fro like a drunken man. But he (Oliver) kept up, nevertheless, and, with his (Oliver) head drooping languidly on his (Oliver) breast, went stumbling onward, he (Oliver) knew not whither.

And now, hosts of bewildering and confused ideas came crowding on his (Oliver) mind. He (Oliver) seemed to be still walking between Sikes and Crackit, who were angrily disputing--for the very words they said, sounded in his (Crackit) ears; and when he (Crackit) caught his (Crackit) own attention, as it were, by making some violent effort to save himself from falling, he (Crackit) found that he (Crackit) was talking to them. Then, he (Crackit) was alone with Sikes, plodding on as on the previous day; and as shadowy people passed them, he (Sikes) felt the robber's grasp upon his (Sikes) wrist. Suddenly, he (Sikes) started back at the report of firearms; there rose into the air, loud cries and shouts; lights gleamed before his (Sikes) eyes; all was noise and tumult, as some unseen hand bore him (Sikes) hurriedly away. Through all these rapid visions, there ran an undefined, uneasy consciousness of pain, which wearied and tormented him (Sikes) incessantly.

Thus he (Sikes) staggered on, creeping, almost mechanically, between the bars of gates, or through hedge-gaps as they came in his (Sikes) way, until he (Sikes) reached a road. Here the rain began to fall so heavily, that it roused him (Sikes).

He (Sikes) looked about, and saw that at no great distance there was a house, which perhaps he (Sikes) could reach. Pitying his (Sikes) condition, they might have compassion on him (Sikes); and if they did not, it would be better, he (Sikes) thought, to die near human beings, than in the lonely open fields. He (Sikes) summoned up all his (Sikes) strength for one last trial, and bent his (Sikes) faltering steps towards it.

As he (Sikes) drew nearer to this house, a feeling come over him (Sikes) that he (Sikes) had seen it before. He (Sikes) remembered nothing of its details; but the shape and aspect of the building seemed familiar to him (Sikes).

That garden wall! On the grass inside, he (Sikes) had fallen on his (Sikes) knees last night, and prayed the two men's mercy. It was the very house they had attempted to rob.

Oliver felt such fear come over him (Oliver) when he (Oliver) recognised the place, that, for the instant, he (Oliver) forgot the agony of his (Oliver) wound, and thought only of flight. Flight! He (Oliver) could scarcely stand: and if he (Oliver) were in full possession of all the best powers of his (Oliver) slight and youthful frame, whither could he (Oliver) fly? He (Oliver) pushed against the garden-gate; it was unlocked, and swung open on its hinges. He (Oliver) tottered across the lawn; climbed the steps; knocked faintly at the door; and, his (Oliver) whole strength failing him (Oliver), sunk down against one of the pillars of the little portico.

It happened that about this time, Mr. Giles, Brittles, and the tinker, were recruiting themselves, after the fatigues and terrors of the night, with tea and sundries, in the kitchen. Not that it was Mr. Giles's habit to admit to too great familiarity the humbler servants: towards whom it was rather his (Giles) wont to deport himself with a lofty affability, which, while it gratified, could not fail to remind them of his (Giles) superior position in society. But, death, fires, and burglary, make all men equals; so Mr. Giles sat with his (Giles) legs stretched out before the kitchen fender, leaning his (Giles) left arm on the table, while, with his (Giles) right, he (Giles) illustrated a circumstantial and minute account of the robbery, to which his (Giles) bearers -LRB-but especially the cook and housemaid, who were of the party-RRB- listened with breathless interest.

`It was about half-past two,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles,
`or I wouldn't swear that it mightn't have been a little nearer three, when I woke up, and, turning round in my bed, as it might be so, -LRB-here Mr. Giles turned round in his (Giles) chair, and pulled the corner of the table-cloth over him (Giles) to imitate bed-clothes,-RRB- I fancied I heerd a noise.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

At this point of the narrative the cook turned pale, and asked the housemaid to shut the door: who asked Brittles, who asked the tinker, who pretended not to hear.

`--Heerd a noise,' (the housemaid)
continued Mr. Giles.
`I says, at first, ``This is illusion''; and was composing myself off to sleep, when I heerd the noise again, distinct.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`What sort of a noise?' (the cook)
asked the cook.

`A kind of a busting noise,' (the cook)
replied Mr. Giles, looking round him (Giles).

`More like the noise of powdering a iron bar on a nutmeg-grater,' (unknown)
suggested Brittles.

`It was, when _you_ heerd it, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
rejoined Mr. Giles;
`but, at this time, it had a busting sound. I turned down the clothes' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
; continued Giles, rolling back the table-cloth,
`sat up in bed; and listened.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

The cook and housemaid simultaneously ejaculated

`Lor!' (housemaid)
and drew their chairs closer together.

`I heerd it now, quite apparent,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
resumed Mr. Giles.
```Somebody,'' I says, ``is forcing of a door, or window; what's to be done? I'll call up that poor lad, Brittles, and save him (lad) from being murdered in his (lad) bed; or his (lad) throat,'' I says, ``may be cut from his (lad) right ear to his (lad) left, without his (lad) ever knowing it.''' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

Here, all eyes were turned upon Brittles, who fixed his (lad) upon the speaker, and stared at him (lad), with his (lad) mouth wide open, and his (lad) face expressive of the most unmitigated horror.

`I tossed off the clothes,' (him)
said Giles, throwing away the table-cloth, and looking very hard at the cook and housemaid,
`got softly out of bed; drew on a pair of--' (housemaid)

`Ladies present, Mr. Giles,' (housemaid)
murmured the tinker.

`--Of _shoes_, sir,' (housemaid)
said Giles, turning upon him (Giles), and laying great emphasis on the word;
`seized the loaded pistol that always goes upstairs with the plate-basket; and walked on tiptoes to his (Giles) room. ``Brittles,'' I says, when I had woke him (Giles), ``don't be frightened!''' (him)

`So you did,' (unknown)
observed Brittles, in a low voice.

```We're dead men, I think, Brittles,'' I says,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
continued Giles;
```but don't be frightened.''' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`_Was_ he (Giles) frightened?' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
asked the cook.

`Not a bit of it,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Mr. Giles.
`He (Giles) was as firm--ah! pretty near as firm as I was.' (unknown)

`I should have died at once, I'm sure, if it had been me,' (the housemaid)
observed the housemaid.

`You're a woman,' (unknown)
retorted Brittles, plucking up a little.

`Brittles is right,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, nodding his (Giles) head, approvingly;
`from a woman, nothing else was to be expected. We, being men, took a dark lantern that was standing on Brittle's hob, and groped our way downstairs in the pitch dark,--as it might be so.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

Mr. Giles had risen from his (Giles) seat, and taken two steps with his (Giles) eyes shut, to accompany his (Giles) description with appropriate action, when he (Giles) started violently, in common with the rest of the company, and hurried back to his (Giles) chair. The cook and housemaid screamed.

`It was a knock,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, assuming perfect serenity.
`Open the door, somebody.' (Nobody)

Nobody moved.

`It seems a strange sort of a thing, a knock coming at such a time in the morning,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, surveying the pale faces which surrounded him (Giles), and looking very blank himself;
`but the door must be opened. Do you hear, somebody?' (him)

Mr. Giles, as he (Giles) spoke, looked at Brittles; but that young man, being naturally modest, probably considered himself nobody, and so held that the inquiry could not have any application to him (Giles); at all events, he (Giles) tendered no reply. Mr. Giles directed an appealing glance at the tinker; but he (Giles) had suddenly fallen asleep. The women were out of the question.

`If Brittles would rather open the door, in the presence of witnesses,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, after a short silence,
`I am ready to make one.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`So am I,' (he)
said the tinker, waking up, as suddenly as he (Giles) had fallen asleep.

Brittles capitulated on these terms; and the party being somewhat re-assured by the discovery -LRB-made on throwing open the shutters-RRB- that it was now broad day, took their way upstairs; with the dogs in front. The two women, who were afraid to stay below, brought up the rear. By the advice of Mr. Giles, they all talked very loud, to warn any evil-disposed person outside, that they were strong in numbers; and by a master-stoke of policy, originating in the brain of the same ingenious gentleman, the dogs' tails were well pinched, in the hall, to make them bark savagely.

These precautions having been taken, Mr. Giles held on fast by the tinker's arm -LRB-to prevent his (Giles) running away, as he (Giles) pleasantly said-RRB-, and gave the word of command to open the door. Brittles obeyed; the group, peeping timorously over each other's shoulders, beheld no more formidable object than poor little Oliver Twist, speechless and exhausted, who raised his (Twist) heavy eyes, and mutely solicited their compassion.

`A boy!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
exclaimed Mr. Giles, valiantly, pushing the tinker into the background.
`What's the matter with the--eh?--Why--Brittles--look here--don't you know?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Brittles, who had got behind the door to open it, no sooner saw Oliver, than he (Oliver) uttered a loud cry. Mr. Giles, seizing the boy by one leg and one arm -LRB-fortunately not the broken limb-RRB- lugged him (Giles) straight into the hall, and deposited him (Giles) at full length on the floor thereof.

`Here he (Giles) is!' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
bawled Giles, calling in a state of great excitement, up the staircase;
`here's one of the thieves, ma'am! Here's a thief, miss! Wounded, miss! I shot him (thief), miss; and Brittles held the light.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`--In a lantern, miss,' (unknown)
cried Brittles, applying one hand to the side of his (thief) mouth, so that his (thief) voice might travel the better.

The two women-servants ran upstairs to carry the intelligence that Mr. Giles had captured a robber; and the tinker busied himself in endeavouring to restore Oliver, lest he (Oliver) should die before he (Oliver) could be hanged. In the midst of all this noise and commotion, there was heard a sweet female voice, which quelled it in an instant.

`Giles!' (unknown)
whispered the voice from the stair-head.

`I'm here, miss,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Mr. Giles.
`Don't be frightened, miss; I ain't much injured. He (Giles) didn't make a very desperate resistance, miss! I was soon too many for him (Giles).' (unknown)

`Hush!' (the lady)
replied the young lady;
`you frighten my aunt as much as the thieves did. Is the poor creature much hurt?' (the lady)

`Wounded desperate, miss,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Giles, with indescribable complacency.

`He (Giles) looks as if he (Giles) was a-going, miss,' (unknown)
bawled Brittles, in the same manner as before.
`Wouldn't you like to come and look at him (Giles), miss, in case he (Giles) should?' (unknown)

`Hush, pray; there's a good man!' (the lady)
rejoined the lady.
`Wait quietly only one instant, while I speak to aunt.' (the speaker)

With a footstep as soft and gentle as the voice, the speaker tripped away. She (aunt) soon returned, with the direction that the wounded person was to be carried, carefully, upstairs to Mr. Giles's room; and that Brittles was to saddle the pony and betake himself instantly to Chertsey: from which place, he (Giles) was to despatch, with all speed, a constable and doctor.

`But won't you take one look at him (Giles), first, miss?' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
asked Mr. Giles, with as much pride as if Oliver were some bird of rare plumage, that he (Oliver) had skilfully brought down.
`Not one little peep, miss?' (unknown)

`Not now, for the world,' (the lady)
replied the young lady.
`Poor fellow! Oh! treat him (fellow) kindly, Giles for my sake!' (The servant)

The old servant looked up at the speaker, as she (lady) turned away, with a glance as proud and admiring as if she (lady) had been his (Giles) own child. Then, bending over Oliver, he (Oliver) helped to carry him (Oliver) upstairs, with the care and solicitude of a woman.

CHAPTER XXIX

HAS AN INTRODUCTORY ACCOUNT OF THE INMATES OF THE HOUSE, TO WHICH OLIVER RESORTED

In a handsome room: though its furniture had rather the air of old-fashioned comfort, than of modern elegance: there sat two ladies at a well-spread breakfast-table. Mr. Giles, dressed with scrupulous care in a full suit of black, was in attendance upon them. He (Giles) had taken his (Giles) station some half-way between the side-board and the breakfast-table; and, with his (Giles) body drawn up to its full height, his (Giles) head thrown back, and inclined the merest trifle on one side, his (Giles) left leg advanced, and his (Giles) right hand thrust into his (Giles) waist-coat, while his (Giles) left hung down by his (Giles) side, grasping a waiter, looked like one who laboured under a very agreeable sense of his (Giles) own merits and importance.

Of the two ladies, one was well advanced in years; but the high-backed oaken chair in which she (Giles) sat, was not more upright than she (Giles). Dressed with the utmost nicety and precision, in a quaint mixture of by-gone costume, with some slight concessions to the prevailing taste, which rather served to point the old style pleasantly than to impair its effect, she (Giles) sat, in a stately manner, with her (Giles) hands folded on the table before her (Giles). Her (Giles) eyes -LRB-and age had dimmed but little of their brightness-RRB- were attentively upon her (Giles) young companion.

The younger lady was in the lovely bloom and spring-time of womanhood; at that age, when, if ever angels be for God's good purposes enthroned in mortal forms, they may be, without impiety, supposed to abide in such as hers.

She (lady) was not past seventeen. Cast in so slight and exquisite a mould; so mild and gentle; so pure and beautiful; that earth seemed not her (lady) element, nor its rough creatures her (lady) fit companions. The very intelligence that shone in her (lady) deep blue eye, and was stamped upon her (lady) noble head, seemed scarcely of her (lady) age, or of the world; and yet the changing expression of sweetness and good humour, the thousand lights that played about the face, and left no shadow there; above all, the smile, the cheerful, happy smile, were made for Home, and fireside peace and happiness.

She (lady) was busily engaged in the little offices of the table. Chancing to raise her (lady) eyes as the elder lady was regarding her (lady), she (lady) playfully put back her (lady) hair, which was simply braided on her (lady) forehead; and threw into her (lady) beaming look, such an expression of affection and artless loveliness, that blessed spirits might have smiled to look upon her (lady).

`And Brittles has been gone upwards of an hour, has he (lady)?' (the lady)
asked the old lady, after a pause.

`An hour and twelve minutes, ma'am,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Mr. Giles, referring to a silver watch, which he (Giles) drew forth by a black ribbon.

`He (Giles) is always slow,' (the lady)
remarked the old lady.

`Brittles always was a slow boy, ma'am,' (the attendant)
replied the attendant. And seeing, by the bye, that Brittles had been a slow boy for upwards of thirty years, there appeared no great probability of his (boy) ever being a fast one.

`He (boy) gets worse instead of better, I think,' (the lady)
said the elder lady.

`It is very inexcusable in him (boy) if he (boy) stops to play with any other boys,' (the lady)
said the young lady, smiling.

Mr. Giles was apparently considering the propriety of indulging in a respectful smile himself, when a gig drove up to the garden-gate: out of which there jumped a fat gentleman, who ran straight up to the door: and who, getting quickly into the house by some mysterious process, burst into the room, and nearly overturned Mr. Giles and the breakfast-table together.

`I never heard of such a thing!' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
exclaimed the fat gentleman.
`My dear Mrs. Maylie--bless my soul--in the silence of the night, too--I _never_ heard of such a thing!' (the gentleman)

With these expressions of condolence, the fat gentleman shook hands with both ladies, and drawing up a chair, inquired how they found themselves.

`You ought to be dead; positively dead with the fright,' (the gentleman)
said the fat gentleman.
`Why didn't you send? Bless me, my man should have come in a minute; and so would I; and my assistant would have been delighted; or anybody, I'm sure, under such circumstances. Dear, dear! So unexpected! In the silence of the night, too!' (The doctor)

The doctor seemed expecially troubled by the fact of the robbery having been unexpected, and attempted in the night-time; as if it were the established custom of gentlemen in the housebreaking way to transact business at noon, and to make an appointment, by post, a day or two previous.

`And you, Miss Rose,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, turning to the young lady,
`I--' (the lady)

`Oh! very much so, indeed,' (the lady)
said Rose, interrupting him (doctor);
`but there is a poor creature upstairs, whom aunt wishes you to see.' (him)

`Ah! to be sure,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor,
`so there is. That was your handiwork, Giles, I understand.' (the doctor)

Mr. Giles, who had been feverishly putting the tea-cups to rights, blushed very red, and said that he (Giles) had had that honour.

`Honour, eh?' (the doctor)
said the doctor;
`well, I don't know; perhaps it's as honourable to hit a thief in a back kitchen, as to hit your man at twelve paces. Fancy that he (man) fired in the air, and you've fought a duel, Giles.' (the doctor)

Mr. Giles, who thought this light treatment of the matter an unjust attempt at diminishing his (Giles) glory, answered respectfully, that it was not for the like of him (Giles) to judge about that; but he (Giles) rather thought it was no joke to the opposite party.

`Gad, that's true!' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`Where is he (doctor)? Show me the way. I'll look in again, as I come down, Mrs. Maylie. That's the little window that he (doctor) got in at, eh? Well, I couldn't have believed it!' (he)

Talking all the way, he (doctor) followed Mr. Giles upstairs; and while he (Giles) is going upstairs, the reader may be informed, that Mr. Losberne, a surgeon in the neighbourhood, known through a circuit of ten miles round as

`the doctor,' (a surgeon)
had grown fat, more from good-humour than from good living: and was as kind and hearty, and withal as eccentric an old bachelor, as will be found in five times that space, by any explorer alive.

The doctor was absent, much longer than either he (doctor) or the ladies had anticipated. A large flat box was fetched out of the gig; and a bedroom bell was rung very often; and the servants ran up and down stairs perpetually; from which tokens it was justly concluded that something important was going on above. At length he (doctor) returned; and in reply to an anxious inquiry after his (doctor) patient; looked very mysterious, and closed the door, carefully.

`This is a very extraordinary thing, Mrs. Maylie,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, standing with his (doctor) back to the door, as if to keep it shut.

`He (doctor) is not in danger, I hope?' (the lady)
said the old lady.

`Why, that would _not_ be an extraordinary thing, under the circumstances,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor;
`though I don't think he (doctor) is. Have you seen the thief?' (the doctor)

`No,' (the lady)
rejoined the old lady.

`Nor heard anything about him (doctor)?' (unknown)

`No.' (I)

`I beg your pardon, ma'am, interposed Mr. Giles;

`but I was going to tell you about him (Giles) when Doctor Losberne came in.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

The fact was, that Mr. Giles had not, at first, been able to bring his (Giles) mind to the avowal, that he (Giles) had only shot a boy. Such commendations had been bestowed upon his (Giles) bravery, that he (Giles) could not, for the life of him (Giles), help postponing the explanation for a few delicious minutes; during which he (Giles) had flourished, in the very zenith of a brief reputation for undaunted courage.

`Rose wished to see the man,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie,
`but I wouldn't hear of it.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`Humph!' (the doctor)
rejoined the doctor.
`There is nothing very alarming in his (doctor) appearance. Have you any objection to see him (doctor) in my presence?' (unknown)

`If it be necessary,' (the lady)
replied the old lady,
`certainly not.' (the lady)

`Then I think it is necessary,' (the doctor)
said the doctor;
`at all events, I am quite sure that you would deeply regret not having done so, if you postponed it. He (doctor) is perfectly quiet and comfortable now. Allow me--Miss Rose, will you permit me? Not the slightest fear, I pledge you my honour!' (the doctor)

CHAPTER XXX

RELATES WHAT OLIVER'S NEW VISITORS THOUGHT OF HIM

With many loquacious assurances that they would be agreeably surprised in the aspect of the criminal, the doctor drew the young lady's arm through one of his (doctor); and offering his (doctor) disengaged hand to Mrs. Maylie, led them, with much ceremony and stateliness, upstairs.

`Now,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, in a whisper, as he (doctor) softly turned the handle of a bedroom-door,
`let us hear what you think of him (doctor). He (doctor) has not been shaved very recently, but he (doctor) don't look at all ferocious notwithstanding. Stop, though! Let me first see that he (doctor) is in visiting order.' (he)

Stepping before them, he (doctor) looked into the room. Motioning them to advance, he (doctor) closed the door when they had entered; and gently drew back the curtains of the bed. Upon it, in lieu of the dogged, black-visaged ruffian they had expected to behold, there lay a mere child: worn with pain and exhaustion, and sunk into a deep sleep. His (doctor) wounded arm, bound and splintered up, was crossed upon his (doctor) breast; his (doctor) head reclined upon the other arm, which was half hidden by his (doctor) long hair, as it streamed over the pillow.

The honest gentleman held the curtain in his (gentleman) hand, and looked on, for a minute or so, in silence. Whilst he (gentleman) was watching the patient thus, the younger lady glided softly past, and seating herself in a chair by the bedside, gathered Oliver's hair from his (Oliver) face. As she (lady) stooped over him (Oliver), her (lady) tears fell upon his (Oliver) forehead.

The boy stirred, and smiled in his (Oliver) sleep, as though these marks of pity and compassion had awakened some pleasant dream of a love and affection he (Oliver) had never known. Thus, a strain of gentle music, or the rippling of water in a silent place, or the odour of a flower, or the mention of a familiar word, will sometimes call up sudden dim remembrances of scenes that never were, in this life; which vanish like a breath; which some brief memory of a happier existence, long gone by, would seem to have awakened; which no voluntary exertion of the mind can ever recall.

`What can this mean?' (the lady)
exclaimed the elder lady.
`This poor child can never have been the pupil of robbers!' (unknown)

`Vice,' (the surgeon)
said the surgeon, replacing the curtain,
`takes up her (lady) abode in many temples; and who can say that a fair outside shell not enshrine her (lady)?' (the surgeon)

`But at so early an age!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
urged Rose.

`My dear young lady,' (the surgeon)
rejoined the surgeon, mournfully shaking his (surgeon) head;
`crime, like death, is not confined to the old and withered alone. The youngest and fairest are too often its chosen victims.' (the surgeon)

`But, can you--oh! can you really believe that this delicate boy has been the voluntary associate of the worst outcasts of society?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.

The surgeon shook his (surgeon) head, in a manner which intimated that he (surgeon) feared it was very possible; and observing that they might disturb the patient, led the way into an adjoining apartment.

`But even if he (patient) has been wicked,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
pursued Rose,
`think how young he (patient) is; think that he (patient) may never have known a mother's love, or the comfort of a home; that ill-usage and blows, or the want of bread, may have driven him (patient) to herd with men who have forced him (patient) to guilt. Aunt, dear aunt, for mercy's sake, think of this, before you let them drag this sick child to a prison, which in any case must be the grave of all his (patient) chances of amendment. Oh! as you love me, and know that I have never felt the want of parents in your goodness and affection, but that I might have done so, and might have been equally helpless and unprotected with this poor child, have pity upon him (patient) before it is too late!' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`My dear love,' (the lady)
said the elder lady, as she (lady) folded the weeping girl to her (lady) bosom,
`do you think I would harm a hair of his (patient) head?' (the girl)

`Oh, no!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose, eagerly.

`No, surely,' (the lady)
said the old lady;
`my days are drawing to their close: and may mercy be shown to me as I show it to others! What can I do to save him (patient), sir?' (the lady)

`Let me think, ma'am,' (the doctor)
said the doctor;
`let me think.' (the doctor)

Mr. Losberne thrust his (Losberne) hands into his (Losberne) pockets, and took several turns up and down the room; often stopping, and balancing himself on his (Losberne) toes, and frowning frightfully. After various exclamations of

`I've got it now' (he)
and
`no, I haven't,' (he)
and as many renewals of the walking and frowning, he (Losberne) at length made a dead halt, and spoke as follows:

`I think if you give me a full and unlimited commission to bully Giles, and that little boy, Brittles, I can manage it. Giles is a faithful fellow and an old servant, I know; but you can make it up to him (Giles) in a thousand ways, and reward him (Giles) for being such a good shot besides. You don't object to that?' (he)

`Unless there is some other way of preserving the child,' (Mrs. Maylie)
replied Mrs. Maylie.

`There is no other,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`No other, take my word for it.' (unknown)

`Then my aunt invests you with full power,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, smiling through her (Rose) tears;
`but pray don't be harder upon the poor fellows than is indispensably necessary.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`You seem to think,' (the doctor)
retorted the doctor,
`that everybody is disposed to be hard-hearted to-day, except yourself, Miss Rose. I only hope, for the sake of the rising male sex generally, that you may be found in as vulnerable and soft-hearted a mood by the first eligible young fellow who appeals to your compassion; and I wish I were a young fellow, that I might avail myself, on the spot, of such a favourable opportunity for doing so, as the present.' (the doctor)

`You are as great a boy as poor Brittles himself,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
returned Rose, blushing.

`Well,' (the doctor matter)
said the doctor, laughing heartily,
`that is no very difficult matter. But to return to this boy. The great point of our agreement is yet to come. He (boy) will wake in an hour or so, I dare say; and although I have told that thick-headed constable-fellow downstairs that he (boy) musn't be moved or spoken to, on peril of his (boy) life, I think we may converse with him (boy) without danger. Now I make this stipulation--that I shall examine him (boy) in your presence, and that, if, from what he (boy) says, we judge, and I can show to the satisfaction of your cool reason, that he (boy) is a real and thorough bad one -LRB-which is more than possible-RRB-, he (boy) shall be left to his (boy) fate, without any farther interference on my part, at all events.' (the doctor matter)

`Oh no, aunt!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
entreated Rose.

`Oh yes, aunt!' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`Is is a bargain?' (unknown)

`He (doctor) cannot be hardened in vice,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose;
`It is impossible.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`Very good,' (the doctor)
retorted the doctor;
`then so much the more reason for acceding to my proposition.' (the doctor)

Finally the treaty was entered into; and the parties thereunto sat down to wait, with some impatience, until Oliver should awake.

The patience of the two ladies was destined to undergo a longer trial than Mr. Losberne had led them to expect; for hour after hour passed on, and still Oliver slumbered heavily. It was evening, indeed, before the kind-hearted doctor brought them the intelligence, that he (doctor) was at length sufficiently restored to be spoken to. The boy was very ill, he (boy) said, and weak from the loss of blood; but his (boy) mind was so troubled with anxiety to disclose something, that he (boy) deemed it better to give him (boy) the opportunity, than to insist upon his (boy) remaining quiet until next morning: which he (boy) should otherwise have done.

The conference was a long one. Oliver told them all his (Oliver) simple history, and was often compelled to stop, by pain and want of strength. It was a solemn thing, to hear, in the darkened room, the feeble voice of the sick child recounting a weary catalogue of evils and calamities which hard men had brought upon him (Oliver). Oh! if when we oppress and grind our fellow-creatures, we bestowed but one thought on the dark evidences of human error, which, like dense and heavy clouds, are rising, slowly it is true, but not less surely, to Heaven, to pour their after-vengeance on our heads; if we heard but one instant, in imagination, the deep testimony of dead men's voices, which no power can stifle, and no pride shut out; where would be the injury and injustice, the suffering, misery, cruelty, and wrong, that each day's life brings with it!

Oliver's pillow was smoothed by gentle hands that night; and loveliness and virtue watched him (Oliver) as he (Oliver) slept. He (Oliver) felt calm and happy, and could have died without a murmur.

The momentous interview was no sooner concluded, and Oliver composed to rest again, than the doctor, after wiping his (Oliver) eyes, and condemning them for being weak all at once, betook himself downstairs to open upon Mr. Giles. And finding nobody about the parlours, it occurred to him (Giles), that he (Giles) could perhaps originate the proceedings with better effect in the kitchen; so into the kitchen he (Giles) went.

There were assembled, in that lower house of the domestic parliament, the women-servants, Mr. Brittles, Mr. Giles, the tinker -LRB-who had received a special invitation to regale himself for the remainder of the day, in consideration of his (Brittles) services-RRB-, and the constable. The latter gentleman had a large staff, a large head, large features, and large half-boots; and he (gentleman) looked as if he (gentleman) had been taking a proportionate allowance of ale--as indeed he (gentleman) had.

The adventures of the previous night were still under discussion; for Mr. Giles was expatiating upon his (Giles) presence of mind, when the doctor entered; Mr. Brittles, with a mug of ale in his (Brittles) hand, was corroborating everything, before his (Brittles) superior said it.

`Sit still!' (the doctor)
said the doctor, waving his (doctor) hand.

`Thank you, sir, said Mr. Giles.

`Misses wished some ale to be given out, sir; and as I felt no ways inclined for my own little room, sir, and was disposed for company, I am taking mine among 'em here.' (the ladies gentlemen)

Brittles headed a low murmur, by which the ladies and gentlemen generally were understood to express the gratification they derived from Mr. Giles's condescension. Mr. Giles looked round with a patronising air, as much as to say that so long as they behaved properly, he (Giles) would never desert them.

`How is the patient to-night, sir?' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
asked Giles.

`So-so' (the doctor)
; returned the doctor.
`I am afraid you have got yourself into a scrape there, Mr. Giles.' (the doctor)

`I hope you don't mean to say, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, trembling,
`that he (Giles)'s going to die. If I thought it, I should never be happy again. I wouldn't cut a boy off: no, not even Brittles here; not for all the plate in the county, sir.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`That's not the point,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, mysteriously.
`Mr. Giles, are you a Protestant?' (unknown)

`Yes, sir, I hope so,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
faltered Mr. Giles, who had turned very pale.

`And what are _you_, boy?' (the doctor)
said the doctor, turning sharply upon Brittles.

`Lord bless me, sir!' (unknown)
replied Brittles, starting violently;
`I'm the same as Mr. Giles, sir.' (unknown)

`Then tell me this,' (the doctor)
said the doctor,
`both of you, both of you! Are you going to take upon yourselves to swear, that that boy upstairs is the boy that was put through the little window last night? Out with it! Come! We are prepared for you!' (the doctor)

The doctor, who was universally considered one of the best-tempered creatures on earth, made this demand in such a dreadful tone of anger, that Giles and Brittles, who were considerably muddled by ale and excitement, stared at each other in a state of stupefaction.

`Pay attention to the reply, constable, will you?' (the doctor)
said the doctor, shaking his (doctor) forefinger with great solemnity of manner, and tapping the bridge of his (doctor) nose with it, to bespeak the exercise of that worthy's utmost acuteness.
`Something may come of this before long.' (he)

The constable looked as wise as he (doctor) could, and took up his (doctor) staff of office: which had been reclining indolently in the chimney-corner.

`It's a simple question of identity, you will observe,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

`That's what it is, sir,' (the constable)
replied the constable, coughing with great violence; for he (constable) had finished his (constable) ale in a hurry, and some of it had gone the wrong way.

`Here's the house broken into,' (the doctor couple)
said the doctor,
`and a couple of men catch one moment's glimpse of a boy, in the midst of gunpowder smoke, and in all the distraction of alarm and darkness. Here's a boy comes to that very same house, next morning, and because he (boy) happens to have his (boy) arm tied up, these men lay violent hands upon him (boy)--by doing which, they place his (boy) life in great danger--and swear he (boy) is the thief. Now, the question is, whether these men are justified by the fact; if not, in what situation do they place themselves?' (the doctor couple)

The constable nodded profoundly. He (boy) said, if that wasn't law, he (boy) would be glad to know what was.

`I ask you again,' (he)
thundered the doctor,
`are you, on your solemn oaths, able to identify that boy?' (the doctor)

Brittles looked doubtfully at Mr. Giles; Mr. Giles looked doubtfully at Brittles; the constable put his (Giles) hand behind his (Giles) ear, to catch the reply; the two women and the tinker leaned forward to listen; the doctor glanced keenly round; when a ring was heard at the gate, and at the same moment, the sound of wheels.

`It's the runners!' (unknown)
cried Brittles, to all appearance much relieved.

`The what?' (the doctor)
exclaimed the doctor, aghast in his (doctor) turn.

`The Bow Street officers, sir,' (unknown)
replied Brittles, taking up a candle;
`me and Mr. Giles sent for 'em this morning.' (unknown)

`What?' (the doctor)
cried the doctor.

`Yes,' (unknown)
replied Brittles;
`I sent a message up by the coachman, and I only wonder they weren't here before, sir.' (unknown)

`You did, did you? Then confound your--slow coaches down here; that's all,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, walking away.

CHAPTER XXXI

INVOLVES A CRITICAL POSITION

`Who's that?' (unknown)
inquired Brittles, opening the door a little way, with the chain up, and peeping out, shading the candle with his (doctor) hand.

`Open the door,' (a man)
replied a man outside;
`it's the officers from Bow Street, as was sent to to-day.' (a man)

Much comforted by this assurance, Brittles opened the door to its full width, and confronted a portly man in a great-coat; who walked in, without saying anything more, and wiped his (man) shoes on the mat, as coolly as if he (man) lived there.

`Just send somebody out to relieve my mate, will you, young man?' (the officer)
said the officer; `he (officer)'s in the gig, a-minding the prad. Have you got a coach
`us here, that you could put it up in, for five or ten minutes?' (a coach)

Brittles replying in the affirmative, and pointing out the building, the portly man stepped back to the garden-gate, and helped his (man) companion to put up the gig: while Brittles lighted them, in a state of great admiration. This done, they returned to the house, and, being shown into a parlour, took off their great-coats and hats, and showed like what they were.

The man who had knocked at the door, was a stout personage of middle height, aged about fifty: with shiny black hair, cropped pretty close; half-whiskers, a round face, and sharp eyes. The other was a red-headed, bony man, in top-boots; with a rather ill-favoured countenance, and a turned-up sinister-looking nose.

`Tell your governor that Blathers and Duff is here, will you?' (the man)
said the stouter man, smoothing down his (man) hair, and laying a pair of handcuffs on the table.
`Oh! Good-evening, master. Can I have a word or two with you in private, if you please?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

This was addressed to Mr. Losberne, who now made his (Losberne) appearance; that gentleman, motioning Brittles to retire, brought in the two ladies, and shut the door.

`This is the lady of the house,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, motioning towards Mrs. Maylie.

Mr. Blathers made a bow. Being desired to sit down, he (Blathers) put his (Blathers) hat on the floor, and taking a chair, motioned to Duff to do the same. The latter gentleman, who did not appear quite so much accustomed to good society, or quite so much at his (gentleman) ease in it--one of the two--seated himself, after undergoing several muscular affections of the limbs, and the head of his (gentleman) stick into his (gentleman) mouth, with some embarrassment.

`Now, with regard to this here robbery, master,' (unknown)
said Blathers.
`What are the circumstances?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

Mr. Losberne, who appeared desirous of gaining time, recounted them at great length, and with much circumlocution. Messrs. Blathers and Duff looked very knowing meanwhile, and occasionally exchanged a nod.

`I can't say, for certain, till I see the work, of course,' (Duff)
said Blathers;
`but my opinion at once is,--I don't mind committing myself to that extent,--that this wasn't done by a yokel; eh, Duff?' (unknown)

`Certainly not,' (Duff)
replied Duff.

`And, translating the word yokel for the benefit of the ladies, I apprehend your meaning to be, that this attempt was not made by a countryman?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, with a smile.

`That's it, master,' (unknown)
replied Blathers.
`This is all about the robbery, is it?' (unknown)

`All,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor.

`Now, what is this, about this here boy that the servants are a-talking on?' (unknown)
said Blathers.

`Nothing at all,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor.
`One of the frightened servants chose to take it into his (doctor) head, that he (doctor) had something to do with this attempt to break into the house; but it's nonsense: sheer absurdity.' (unknown)

`Wery easy disposed of, if it is,' (Duff)
remarked Duff.

`What he (Duff) says is quite correct,' (unknown)
observed Blathers, nodding his (Duff) head in a confirmatory way, and playing carelessly with the handcuffs, as if they were a pair of castanets.
`Who is the boy? What account does he (boy) give of himself? Where did he (boy) come from? He (boy) didn't drop out of the clouds, did he (boy), master?' (unknown)

`Of course not,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor, with a nervous glance at the two ladies.
`I know his (doctor) whole history: but we can talk about that presently. You would like, first, to see the place where the thieves made their attempt, I suppose?' (the ladies)

`Certainly,' (Mr. Blathers)
rejoined Mr. Blathers.
`We had better inspect the premises first, and examine the servants afterwards. That's the usual way of doing business.' (unknown)

Lights were then procured; and Messrs. Blathers and Duff, attended by the native constable, Brittles, Giles, and everybody else in short, went into the little room at the end of the passage and looked out at the window; and afterwards went round by way of the lawn, and looked in at the window; and after that, had a candle handed out to inspect the shutter with; and after that, a lantern to trace the footsteps with; and after that, a pitchfork to poke the bushes with. This done, amidst the breathless interest of all beholders, they came in again; and Mr. Giles and Brittles were put through a melodramatic representation of their share in the previous night's adventures: which they performed some six times over: contradicting each other, in not more than one important respect, the first time, and in not more than a dozen the last. This consummation being arrived at, Blathers and Duff cleared the room, and held a long council together, compared with which, for secrecy and solemnity, a consultation of great doctors on the knottiest point in medicine, would be mere child's play.

Meanwhile, the doctor walked up and down the next room in a very uneasy state; and Mrs. Maylie and Rose looked on, with anxious faces.

`Upon my word,' (he)
he (doctor) said, making a halt, after a great number of very rapid turns,
`I hardly know what to do.' (he)

`Surely,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose,
`the poor child's story, faithfully repeated to these men, will be sufficient to exonerate him (doctor).' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`I doubt it, my dear young lady,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said the doctor, shaking his (doctor) head.
`I don't think it would exonerate him (doctor), either with them, or with legal functionaries of a higher grade. What is he (doctor), after all, they would say? A runaway. Judged by mere worldly considerations and probabilities, his (doctor) story is a very doubtful one.' (the doctor)

`You believe it, surely?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
interrupted Rose.

`_I_ believe it, strange as it is; and perhaps I may be an old fool for doing so,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
rejoined the doctor;
`but I don't think it is exactly the tale for a practical police-officer, nevertheless.' (the doctor)

`Why not?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
demanded Rose.

`Because, my pretty cross-examiner,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor:
`because, viewed with their eyes, there are many ugly points about it; he (doctor) can only prove the parts that look ill, and none of those that look well. Confound the fellows, they _will_ have the why and the wherefore, and will take nothing for granted. On his (doctor) own showing, you see, he (doctor) has been the companion of thieves for some time past; he (doctor) has been carried to a police-officer, on a charge of picking a gentleman's pocket; he (doctor) has been taken away, forcibly, from that gentleman's house, to a place which he (doctor) cannot describe or point out, and of the situation of which he (doctor) has not the remotest idea. He (doctor) is brought down to Chertsey, by men who seem to have taken a violent fancy to him (doctor), whether he (doctor) will or no; and is put through a window to rob a house; and then, just at the very moment when he (doctor) is going to alarm the inmates, and so do the very thing that would set him (doctor) all to rights, there rushes into the way, a blundering dog of a half-bred butler, and shoots him (butler)! As if on purpose to prevent his (butler) doing any good for himself! Don't you see all this?' (the doctor)

`I see it, of course,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose, smiling at the doctor's impetuosity;
`but still I do not see anything in it, to criminate the poor child.' (the doctor)

`No,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor;
`of course not! Bless the bright eyes of your sex! They never see, whether for good or bad, more than one side of any question; and that is, always, the one which first presents itself to them.' (the doctor)

Having given vent to this result of experience, the doctor put his (doctor) hands into his (doctor) pockets, and walked up and down the room with even greater rapidity than before.

`The more I think of it,' (the doctor)
said the doctor,
`the more I see that it will occasion endless trouble and difficulty if we put these men in possession of the boy's real story. I am certain it will not be believed; and even if they can do nothing to him (boy) in the end, still the dragging it forward, and giving publicity to all the doubts that will be cast upon it, must interfere, materially, with your benevolent plan of rescuing him (boy) from misery.' (the doctor)

`Oh! what is to be done?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
cried Rose.
`Dear, dear! why did they send for these people?' (unknown)

`Why, indeed!' (Mrs. Maylie)
exclaimed Mrs. Maylie.
`I would not have had them here, for the world.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`All I know is,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, at last: sitting down with a kind of desperate calmness,
`that we must try and carry it off with a bold face. The object is a good one, and that must be our excuse. The boy has strong symptoms of fever upon him (boy), and is in no condition to be talked to any more; that's one comfort. We must make the best of it; and if bad be the best, it is no fault of ours. Come in!' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

`Well, master,' (colleague)
said Blathers, entering the room followed by his (master) colleague, and making the door fast, before he (master) said any more.
`This warn't a put-up thing.' (unknown)

`And what the devil's a put-up thing?' (the doctor)
demanded the doctor, impatiently.

`We call it a put-up robbery, ladies,' (he)
said Blathers, turning to them, as if he (doctor) pitied their ignorance, but had a contempt for the doctor's,
`when the servants is in it.' (the doctor)

`Nobody suspected them, in this case,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie.

`Wery likely not, ma'am,' (unknown)
replied Blathers;
`but they might have been in it, for all that.' (unknown)

`More likely on that wery account,' (Duff)
said Duff.

`We find it was a town hand,' (unknown)
said Blathers, continuing his (Duff) report;
`for the style of work is first-rate.' (unknown)

`Wery pretty indeed it is,' (Duff)
remarked Duff, in an undertone.

`There was two of 'em in it,' (unknown)
continued Blathers;
`and they had a boy with 'em; that's plain from the size of the window. That's all to be said at present. We'll see this lad that you've got upstairs at once, if you please.' (unknown)

`Perhaps they will take something to drink first, Mrs. Maylie?' (the doctor face)
said the doctor: his (doctor) face brightening, as if some new thought had occurred to him (doctor).

`Oh! to be sure!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
exclaimed Rose, eagerly.
`You shall have it immediately, if you will.' (unknown)

`Why, thank you, miss!' (unknown)
said Blathers, drawing his (doctor) coat-sleeve across his (doctor) mouth;
`it's dry work, this sort of duty. Anythink that's handy, miss; don't put yourself out of the way, on our accounts.' (unknown)

`What shall it be?' (the doctor)
asked the doctor, following the young lady to the sideboard.

`A little drop of spirits, master, if it's all the same,' (the lady)
replied Blathers.
