`It's a cold ride from London, ma'am; and I always find that spirits comes home warmer to the feelings.' (Mrs. Maylie)

This interesting communication was addressed to Mrs. Maylie, who received it very graciously. While it was being conveyed to her (Maylie), the doctor slipped out of the room.

`Ah!' (Mr. Blathers)
said Mr. Blathers: not holding his (Blathers) wine-glass by the stem, but grasping the bottom between the thumb and forefinger of his (Blathers) left hand: and placing it in front of his (Blathers) chest;
`I have seen a good many pieces of business like this, in my time, ladies.' (Mr. Blathers)

`That crack down in the back lane at Edmonton, Blathers,' (Mr.)
said Mr. Duff, assisting his (Duff) colleague's memory.

`That was something in this way, warn't it?' (Mr. Blathers)
rejoined Mr. Blathers;
`that was done by Conkey Chickweed, that was.' (Mr. Blathers)

`You always gave that to him (Blathers)' (Duff)
replied Duff.
`It was the Family Pet, I tell you. Conkey hadn't any more to do with it than I had.' (unknown)

`Get out!' (Mr. Blathers)
retorted Mr. Blathers;
`I know better. Do you mind that time when Conkey was robbed of his (Blathers) money, though? What a start that was! Better than any novel-book _I_ ever see!' (Mr. Blathers)

`What was that?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
inquired Rose: anxious to encourage any symptoms of good-humour in the unwelcome visitors.

`It was a robbery, miss, that hardly anybody would have been down upon,' (unknown)
said Blathers.
`This here Conkey Chickweed--' (Duff)

`Conkey means Nosey, ma'am,' (Duff)
interposed Duff.

`Of course the lady knows that, don't she (lady)?' (Mr. Blathers)
demanded Mr. Blathers.
`Always interrupting, you are, partner! This here Conkey Chickweed, miss, kept a public-house over Battlebridge way, and he (Blathers) had a cellar, where a good many young lords went to see cock-fighting, and badger-drawing, and that; and a wery intellectual manner the sports was conducted in, for I've seen 'em off`en. He (Blathers) warn't one of the family, at that time; and one night he (Blathers) was robbed of three hundred and twenty-seven guineas in a canvas bag, that was stole out of his (Blathers) bedroom in the dead of night, by a tall man with a black patch over his (Blathers) eye, who had concealed himself under the bed, and after committing the robbery, jumped slap out of window: which was only a story high. He (Blathers) was wery quick about it. But Conkey was quick, too; for he (Blathers) fired a blunderbuss arter him (Blathers), and roused the neighbourhood. They set up a hue-and-cry, directly, and when they came to look about 'em, found that Conkey had hit the robber; for there was traces of blood, all the way to some palings a good distance off; and there they lost 'em. However, he (robber) had made off with the blunt; and, consequently, the name of Mr. Chickweed, licensed witler, appeared in the Gazette among the other bankrupts; and all manner of benefits and subscriptions, and I don't know what all, was got up for the poor man, who was in a wery low state of mind about his (man) loss, and went up and down the streets, for three or four days, a pulling his (man) hair off in such a desperate manner that many people was afraid he (man) might be going to make away with himself. One day he (man) came up to the office, all in a hurry, and had a private interview with the magistrate, who, after a deal of talk, rings the bell, and orders Jem Spyers in -LRB-Jem was a active officer-RRB-, and tells him (officer) to go and assist Mr. Chickweed in apprehending the man as robbed his (Chickweed) house. ``I see him (Chickweed), Spyers,'' said Chickweed, ``pass my house yesterday morning,'' ``Why didn't you up, and collar him (Chickweed)!'' says Spyers. ``I was so struck all of a heap, that you might have fractured my skull with a toothpick,'' says the poor man; ``but we're sure to have him (man); for between ten and eleven o'clock at night he (man) passed again.'' Spyers no sooner heard this, than he (man) put some clean linen and a comb, in his (man) pocket, in case he (man) should have to stop a day or two; and away he (man) goes, and sets himself down at one of the public-house windows behind the little red curtain, with his (man) hat on, all ready to bolt out, at a moment's notice. He (man) was smoking his (man) pipe here, late at night, when all of a sudden Chickweed roars out, ``Here he (man) is! Stop thief! Murder!'' Jem Spyers dashes out; and there he (man) sees Chickweed, a-tearing down the street full cry. Away goes Spyers; on goes Chickweed; round turns the people; everybody roars out, ``Thieves!'' and Chickweed himself keeps on shouting, all the time, like mad. Spyers loses sight of him (man) a minute as he (man) turns a corner; shoots round; sees a little crowd; dives in; ``Which is the man?'' ``D--me!'' says Chickweed, ``I've lost him (man) again!'' It was a remarkable occurrence, but he (man) warn't to be seen nowhere, so they went back to the public-house. Next morning, Spyers took his (man) old place, and looked out, from behind the curtain, for a tall man with a black patch over his (man) eye, till his (man) own two eyes ached again. At last, he (man) couldn't help shutting 'em, to ease 'em a minute; and the very moment he (man) did so, he (man) hears Chickweed a-roaring out, ``Here he (man) is!'' Off he (man) starts once more, with Chickweed half-way down the street ahead of him (man); and after twice as long a run as the yesterday's one, the man's lost again! This was done, once or twice more, till one-half the neighbours gave out that Mr. Chickweed had been robbed by the devil, who was playing tricks with him (Chickweed) arterwards; and the other half, that poor Mr. Chickweed had gone mad with grief.' (unknown)

`What did Jem Spyers say?' (the doctor)
inquired the doctor; who had returned to the room shortly after the commencement of the story.

`Jem Spyers,' (the officer)
resumed the officer,
`for a long time said nothing at all, and listened to everything without seeming to, which showed he (officer) understood his (officer) business. But, one morning, he (officer) walked into the bar, and taking out his (officer) snuffbox, says ``Chickweed, I've found out who done this here robbery.'' ``Have you?'' said Chickweed. ``Oh, my dear Spyers, only let me have wengeance, and I shall die contented! Oh, my dear Spyers, where is the villain!'' ``Come!'' said Spyers, offering him (villain) a pinch of snuff, ``none of that gammon! You did it yourself.'' So he (villain) had; and a good bit of money he (villain) had made by it, too; and nobody would never have found it out, if he (villain) hadn't been so precious anxious to keep up appearances!' (the officer)
said Mr. Blathers, putting down his (Blathers) wine-glass, and clinking the handcuffs together.

`Very curious, indeed,' (the doctor)
observed the doctor.
`Now, if you please, you can walk upstairs.' (unknown)

`If _you_ please, sir,' (Mr. Blathers)
returned Mr. Blathers. Closely following Mr. Losberne, the two officers ascended to Oliver's bedroom; Mr. Giles preceding the party, with a lighted candle.

Oliver had been dozing; but looked worse, and was more feverish than he (Oliver) had appeared yet. Being assisted by the doctor, he (doctor) managed to sit up in bed for a minute or so; and looked at the strangers without at all understanding what was going forward--in fact, without seeming to recollect where he (doctor) was, or what had been passing.

`This,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, speaking softly, but with great vehemence notwithstanding,
`this is the lad, who, being accidently wounded by a spring-gun in some boyish trespass on Mr. What-d' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
ye-call-him's grounds, at the back here, comes to the house for assistance this morning, and is immediately laid hold of and maltreated, by that ingenious gentleman with the candle in his (gentleman) hand: who has placed his (gentleman) life in considerable danger, as I can professionally certify.'

Messrs. Blathers and Duff looked at Mr. Giles, as he (Giles) was thus recommended to their notice. The bewildered butler gazed from them towards Oliver, and from Oliver towards Mr. Losberne, with a most ludicrous mixture of fear and perplexity.

`You don't mean to deny that, I suppose?' (the doctor)
said the doctor, laying Oliver gently down again.

`It was all done for the--for the best, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
answered Giles.
`I am sure I thought it was the boy, or I wouldn't have meddled with him (boy). I am not of an inhuman disposition, sir.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`Thought it was what boy?' (the officer)
inquired the senior officer.

`The housebreaker's boy, sir!' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Giles.
`They--they certainly had a boy.' (unknown)

`Well? Do you think so now?' (unknown)
inquired Blathers.

`Think what, now?' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Giles, looking vacantly at his (Giles) questioner.

`Think it's the same boy, Stupid-head?' (unknown)
rejoined Blathers, impatiently.

`I don't know; I really don't know,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Giles, with a rueful countenance.
`I couldn't swear to him (Giles).' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`What do you think?' (Mr. Blathers)
asked Mr. Blathers.

`I don't know what to think,' (Mr. Blathers)
replied poor Giles.
`I don't think it is the boy; indeed, I'm almost certain that it isn't. You know it can't be.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`Has this man been a-drinking, sir?' (the doctor)
inquired Blathers, turning to the doctor.

`What a precious muddle-headed chap you are!' (Duff)
said Duff, addressing Mr. Giles, with supreme contempt.

Mr. Losberne had been feeling the patient's pulse during this short dialogue; but he (Losberne) now rose from the chair by the bedside, and remarked, that if the officers had any doubts upon the subject, they would perhaps like to step into the next room, and have Brittles before them.

Acting upon this suggestion, they adjourned to a neighbouring apartment, where Mr. Brittles, being called in, involved himself and his (Brittles) respected superior in such a wonderful maze of fresh contradictions and impossibilities, as tended to throw no particular light on anything, but the fact of his (Brittles) own strong mystification; except, indeed, his (Brittles) declarations that he (Brittles) shouldn't know the real boy, if he (boy) were put before him (boy) that instant; that he (boy) had only taken Oliver to be he (Oliver), because Mr. Giles had said he (Giles) was; and that Mr. Giles had, five minutes previously, admitted in the kitchen, that he (Giles) began to be very much afraid he (Giles) had been a little too hasty.

Among other ingenious surmises, the question was then raised, whether Mr. Giles had really hit anybody; and upon examination of the fellow pistol to that which he (Giles) had fired, it turned out to have no more destructive loading than gunpowder and brown paper: a discovery which made a considerable impression on everybody but the doctor, who had drawn the ball about ten minutes before. Upon no one, however, did it make a greater impression than on Mr. Giles himself; who, after labouring, for some hours, under the fear of having mortally wounded a fellow-creature, eagerly caught at this new idea, and favoured it to the utmost. Finally, the officers, without troubling themselves very much about Oliver, left the Chertsey constable in the house, and took up their rest for that night in the town; promising to return the next morning.

With the next morning, there came a rumour, that two men and a boy were in the cage at Kingston, who had been apprehended over night under suspicious circumstances; and to Kingston Messrs. Blathers and Duff journeyed accordingly. The suspicious circumstances, however, resolving themselves, on investigation, into the one fact, that they had been discovered sleeping under a haystack; which, although a great crime, is only punishable by imprisonment, and is, in the merciful eye of the English law, and its comprehensive love of all the King's subjects, held to be no satisfactory proof, in the absence of all other evidence, that the sleeper, or sleepers, have committed burglary accompanied with violence, and have therefore rendered themselves liable to the punishment of death; Messrs. Blathers and Duff came back again, as wise as they went.

In short, after some more examination, and a great deal more conversation, a neighbouring magistrate was readily induced to take the joint bail of Mrs. Maylie and Mr. Losberne for Oliver's appearance if he (Oliver) should ever be called upon; and Blathers and Duff, being rewarded with a couple of guineas, returned to town with divided opinions on the subject of their expedition: the latter gentleman on a mature consideration of all the circumstances, inclining to the belief that the burglarious attempt had originated with the Family Pet; and the former being equally disposed to concede the full merit of it to the great Mr. Conkey Chickweed.

Meanwhile, Oliver gradually throve and prospered under the united care of Mrs. Maylie, Rose, and the kind-hearted Mr. Losberne. If fervent prayers, gushing from hearts overcharged with gratitude, be heard in heaven--and if they be not, what prayers are!--the blessings which the orphan child called down upon them, sunk into their souls, diffusing peace and happiness.

CHAPTER XXXII

OF THE HAPPY LIFE OLIVER BEGAN TO LEAD WITH HIS (OLIVER) KIND FRIENDS

Oliver's ailings were neither slight nor few. In addition to the pain and delay attendant on a broken limb, his (attendant) exposure to the wet and cold had brought on fever and ague: which hung about him (attendant) for many weeks, and reduced him (attendant) sadly. But, at length, he (attendant) began, by slow degrees, to get better, and to be able to say sometimes, in a few tearful words, how deeply he (attendant) felt the goodness of the two sweet ladies, and how ardently he (attendant) hoped that when he (attendant) grew strong and well again, he (attendant) could do something to show his (attendant) gratitude; only something, which would let them see the love and duty with which his (attendant) breast was full; something, however slight, which would prove to them that their gentle kindness had not been cast away; but that the poor boy whom their charity had rescued from misery, or death, was eager to serve them with his (boy) whole heart and soul.

`Poor fellow!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, when Oliver had been one day feebly endeavouring to utter the words of thankfulness that rose to his (Oliver) pale lips;
`you shall have many opportunities of serving us, if you will. We are going into the country, and my aunt intends that you shall accompany us. The quiet place, the pure air, and all the pleasure and beauties of spring, will restore you in a few days. We will employ you in a hundred ways, when you can bear the trouble.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`The trouble!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver.
`Oh! dear lady, if I could but work for you; if I could only give you pleasure by watering your flowers, or watching your birds, or running up and down the whole day long, to make you happy; what would I give to do it!' (unknown)

`You shall give nothing at all,' (Miss Maylie)
said Miss Maylie, smiling;
`for, as I told you before, we shall employ you in a hundred ways; and if you only take half the trouble to please us, that you promise now, you will make me very happy indeed.' (Miss Maylie)

`Happy, ma'am!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver;
`how kind of you to say so!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`You will make me happier than I can tell you,' (the lady)
replied the young lady.
`To think that my dear good aunt should have been the means of rescuing any one from such sad misery as you have described to us, would be an unspeakable pleasure to me; but to know that the object of her (aunt) goodness and compassion was sincerely grateful and attached, in consequence, would delight me, more than you can well imagine. Do you understand me?' (she)
she (aunt) inquired, watching Oliver's thoughtful face.

`Oh yes, ma'am, yes!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver eagerly;
`but I was thinking that I am ungrateful now.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`To whom?' (the lady)
inquired the young lady.

`To the kind gentleman, and the dear old nurse, who took so much care of me before,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
rejoined Oliver.
`If they knew how happy I am, they would be pleased, I am sure.' (unknown)

`I am sure they would,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
rejoined Oliver's benefactress;
`and Mr. Losberne has already been kind enough to promise that when you are well enough to bear the journey, he (Losberne) will carry you to see them.' (Oliver benefactress)

`Has he (Losberne), ma'am?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver, his (Oliver) face brightening with pleasure.
`I don't know what I shall do for joy when I see their kind faces once again!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

In a short time Oliver was sufficiently recovered to undergo the fatigue of this expedition. One morning he (Oliver) and Mr. Losberne set out, accordingly, in a little carriage which belonged to Mrs. Maylie. When they came to Chertsey Bridge, Oliver turned very pale, and uttered a loud exclamation.

`What's the matter with the boy?' (the doctor)
cried the doctor, as usual, all in a bustle.
`Do you see anything--hear anything--feel anything--eh?' (unknown)

`That, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver, pointing out of the carriage window.
`That house!' (unknown)

`Yes; well, what of it? Stop coachman. Pull up here,' (the doctor)
cried the doctor.
`What of the house, my man; eh?' (unknown)

`The thieves--the house they took me to!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
whispered Oliver.

`The devil it is!' (the doctor)
cried the doctor.
`Hallo, there! let me out!' (the coachman)

But, before the coachman could dismount from his (Oliver) box, he (Oliver) had tumbled out of the coach, by some means or other; and, running down to the deserted tenement, began kicking at the door like a madman.

`Halloa?' (a man)
said a little ugly hump-backed man: opening the door so suddenly, that the doctor, from the very impetus of his (doctor) last kick, nearly fell forward into the passage.
`What's the matter here?' (unknown)

`Matter!' (him)
exclaimed the other, collaring him (doctor), without a moment's reflection.
`A good deal. Robbery is the matter.' (him)

`There'll be Murder the matter, too,' (the man)
replied the hump-backed man, coolly,
`if you don't take your hands off. Do you hear me?' (the man)

`I hear you,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, giving his (doctor) captive a hearty shake.

`Where's--confound the fellow, what's his (doctor) rascally name--Sikes; that's it. Where's Sikes, you thief?' (The man)

The hump-backed man stared, as if in excess of amazement and indignation; then, twisting himself, dexterously, from the doctor's grasp, growled forth a volley of horrid oaths, and retired into the house. Before he (doctor) could shut the door, however, the doctor had passed into the parlour, without a word of parley.

He (doctor) looked anxiously round; not an article of furniture; not a vestige of anything, animate or inanimate; not even the position of the cupboards; answered Oliver's description!

`Now!' (the man)
said the hump-backed man, who had watched him (man) keenly,
`what do you mean by coming into my house, in this violent way? Do you want to rob me, or to murder me? Which is it?' (him)

`Did you ever know a man come out to do either, in a chariot and pair, you ridiculous old vampire?' (the doctor)
said the irritable doctor.

`What do you want, then?' (the hunchback)
demanded the hunchback.
`Will you take yourself off, before I do you a mischief? Curse you!' (unknown)

`As soon as I think proper,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, looking into the other parlour; which, like the first, bore no resemblance whatever to Oliver's account of it.
`I shall find you out, some day, my friend.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Will you?' (the cripple)
sneered the ill-favoured cripple.
`If you ever want me, I'm here. I haven't lived here mad and all alone, for five-and-twenty years, to be scared by you. You shall pay for this; you shall pay for this.' (the demon)
And so saying, the mis-shapen little demon set up a yell, and danced upon the ground, as if wild with rage.

`Stupid enough, this,' (the doctor)
muttered the doctor to himself;
`the boy must have made a mistake. Here! Put that in your pocket, and shut yourself up again.' (the doctor)
With these words he (boy) flung the hunchback a piece of money, and returned to the carriage.

The man followed to the chariot door, uttering the wildest imprecations and curses all the way; but as Mr. Losberne turned to speak to the driver, he (Losberne) looked into the carriage, and eyed Oliver for an instant with a glance so sharp and fierce and at the same time so furious and vindictive, that, waking or sleeping, he (Oliver) could not forget it for months afterwards. He (Oliver) continued to utter the most fearful imprecations, until the driver had resumed his (driver) seat; and when they were once more on their way, they could see him (driver) some distance behind: beating his (driver) feet upon the ground, and tearing his (driver) hair, in transports of real or pretended rage.

`I am an ass!' (him)
said the doctor, after a long silence.
`Did you know that before, Oliver?' (unknown)

`No, sir.' (unknown)

`Then don't forget it another time.' (unknown)

`An ass,' (the doctor)
said the doctor again, after a further silence of some minutes.
`Even if it had been the right place, and the right fellows had been there, what could I have done, single-handed? And if I had had assistance, I see no good that I should have done, except leading to my own exposure, and an unavoidable statement of the manner in which I have hushed up this business. That would have served me right, though. I am always involving myself in some scrape or other, by acting on impulse. It might have done me good.' (the doctor)

Now, the fact was that the excellent doctor had never acted upon anything but impulse all through his (doctor) life, and it was no bad compliment to the nature of the impulses which governed him (doctor), that so far from being involved in any peculiar troubles or misfortunes, he (doctor) had the warmest respect and esteem of all who knew him (doctor). If the truth must be told, he (doctor) was a little out of temper, for a minute or two, at being disappointed in procuring corroborative evidence of Oliver's story on the very first occasion on which he (Oliver) had a chance of obtaining any. He (Oliver) soon came round again, however; and finding that Oliver's replies to his (Oliver) questions, were still as straightforward and consistent, and still delivered with as much apparent sincerity and truth, as they had ever been, he (Oliver) made up his (Oliver) mind to attach full credence to them, from that time forth.

As Oliver knew the name of the street in which Mr. Brownlow resided, they were enabled to drive straight thither. When the coach turned into it, his (coach) heart beat so violently, that he (coach) could scarcely draw his (coach) breath.

`Now, my boy, which house is it?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
inquired Mr. Losberne.

`That! That!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, pointing eagerly out of the window.
`The white house. Oh! make haste! Pray make haste! I feel as if I should die: it makes me tremble so.' (unknown)

`Come, come!' (the doctor)
said the good doctor, patting him (doctor) on the shoulder.
`You will see them directly, and they will be overjoyed to find you safe and well.' (unknown)

`Oh! I hope so!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver.
`They were so good to me; so very, very good to me.' (The coach)

The coach rolled on. It stopped. No; that was the wrong house; the next door. It went on a few paces, and stopped again. Oliver looked up at the windows, with tears of happy expectation coursing down his (Oliver) face.

Alas! the white house was empty, and there was a bill in the window.

`To Let.' (unknown)

`Knock at the next door,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
cried Mr. Losberne, taking Oliver's arm in his (Oliver).
`What has become of Mr. Brownlow, who used to live in the adjoining house, do you know?' (The servant)

The servant did not know; but would go and inquire. She (Oliver) presently returned, and said, that Mr. Brownlow had sold off his (Brownlow) goods, and gone to the West Indies, six weeks before. Oliver clasped his (Oliver) hands, and sank feebly backward.

`Has his (Oliver) housekeeper gone too?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
inquired Mr. Losberne, after a moment's pause.

`Yes, sir' (the servant)
; replied the servant.
`The old gentleman, the housekeeper, and a gentleman who was a friend of Mr. Brownlow's, all went together.' (unknown)

`Then turn towards home again,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne to the driver;
`and don't stop to bait the horses, till you get out of this confounded London!' (the driver)

`The book-stall keeper, sir?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`I know the way there. See him (Oliver), pray, sir! Do see him (Oliver)!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`My poor boy, this is disappointment enough for one day,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`Quite enough for both of us. If we go to the book-stall keeper's, we shall certainly find that he (keeper) is dead, or has set his (keeper) house on fire, or run away. No; home again straight!' (the doctor)
And in obedience to the doctor's impulse, home they went.

This bitter disappointment caused Oliver much sorrow and grief, even in the midst of his (Oliver) happiness; for he (Oliver) had pleased himself, many times during his (Oliver) illness, with thinking of all that Mr. Brownlow and Mrs. Bedwin would say to him (Brownlow): and what delight it would be to tell them how many long days and nights he (Brownlow) had passed in reflecting on what they had done for him (Brownlow), and in bewailing his (Brownlow) cruel separation from them. The hope of eventually clearing himself with them, too, and explaining how he (Brownlow) had been forced away, had buoyed him (Brownlow) up, and sustained him (Brownlow), under many of his (Brownlow) recent trials; and now, the idea that they should have gone so far, and carried with them the belief that he (Brownlow) was an impostor and a robber--a belief which might remain uncontradicted to his (Brownlow) dying day--was almost more than he (Brownlow) could bear.

The circumstance occasioned no alteration, however, in the behaviour of his (Brownlow) benefactors. After another fortnight, when the fine warm weather had fairly begun, and every tree and flower was putting forth its young leaves and rich blossoms, they made preparations for quitting the house at Chertsey, for some months.

Sending the plate, which had so excited Fagin's cupidity, to the banker's; and leaving Giles and another servant in care of the house, they departed to a cottage at some distance in the country, and took Oliver with them.

Who can describe the pleasure and delight, the peace of mind and soft tranquillity, the sickly boy felt in the balmy air, and among the green hills and rich woods, of an inland village! Who can tell how scenes of peace and quietude sink into the minds of pain-worn dwellers in close and noisy places, and carry their own freshness, deep into their jaded hearts! Men who have lived in crowded, pent-up streets, through lives of toil, and who have never wished for change; men, to whom custom has indeed been second nature, and who have come almost to love each brick and stone that formed the narrow boundaries of their daily walks; even they, with the hand of death upon them, have been known to yearn at last for one short glimpse of Nature's face; and, carried far from the scenes of their old pains and pleasures, have seemed to pass at once into a new state of being. Crawling forth, from day to day, to some green sunny spot, they have had such memories wakened up within them by the sight of the sky, and hill and plain, and glistening water, that a foretaste of heaven itself has soothed their quick decline, and they have sunk into their tombs, as peacefully as the sun whose setting they watched from their lonely chamber window but a few hours before, faded from their dim and feeble sight! The memories which peaceful country scenes call up, are not of this world, nor of its thoughts and hopes. Their gentle influence may teach us how to weave fresh garlands for the graves of those we loved: may purify our thoughts, and bear down before it old enmity and hatred; but beneath all this, there lingers, in the least reflective mind, a vague and half-formed consciousness of having held such feelings long before, in some remote and distant time, which calls up solemn thoughts of distant times to come, and bends down pride and worldliness beneath it.

It was a lovely spot to which they repaired. Oliver, whose days had been spent among squalid crowds, and in the midst of noise and brawling, seemed to enter on a new existence there. The rose and honeysuckle clung to the cottage walls; the ivy crept round the trunks of the trees; and the garden-flowers perfumed the air with delicious odours. Hard by, was a little churchyard; not crowded with tall unsightly gravestones, but full of humble mounds, covered with fresh turf and moss: beneath which, the old people of the village lay at rest. Oliver often wandered here; and, thinking of the wretched grave in which his (Oliver) mother lay, would sometimes sit him (Oliver) down and sob unseen; but, when he (Oliver) raised his (Oliver) eyes to the deep sky overhead, he (Oliver) would cease to think of her (mother) as lying in the ground, and would weep for her (mother), sadly, but without pain.

It was a happy time. The days were peaceful and serene; the nights brought with them neither fear nor care; no languishing in a wretched prison, or associating with wretched men; nothing but pleasant and happy thoughts. Every morning he (Oliver) went to a white-headed old gentleman, who lived near the little church: who taught him (Oliver) to read better, and to write: and who spoke so kindly, and took such pains, that Oliver could never try enough to please him (Oliver). Then, he (Oliver) would walk with Mrs. Maylie and Rose, and hear them talk of books; or perhaps sit near them, in some shady place, and listen whilst the young lady read: which he (Oliver) could have done, until it grew too dark to see the letters. Then, he (Oliver) had his (Oliver) own lesson for the next day to prepare; and at this, he (Oliver) would work hard, in a little room which looked into the garden, till evening came slowly on, when the ladies would walk out again, and he (Oliver) with them: listening with such pleasure to all they said: and so happy if they wanted a flower that he (Oliver) could climb to reach, or had forgotten anything he (Oliver) could run to fetch: that he (Oliver) could never be quick enough about it. When it became quite dark, and they returned home, the young lady would sit down to the piano, and play some pleasant air, or sing, in a low and gentle voice, some old song which it pleased her (lady) aunt to hear. There would be no candles lighted at such times as these; and Oliver would sit by one of the windows, listening to the sweet music, in a perfect rapture.

And when Sunday came, how differently the day was spent, from any way in which he (Oliver) had ever spent it yet! and how happily too; like all the other days in that most happy time! There was the little church, in the morning, with the green leaves fluttering at the windows: the birds singing without: and the sweet-smelling air stealing in at the low porch, and filling the homely building with its fragrance. The poor people were so neat and clean, and knelt so reverently in prayer, that it seemed a pleasure, not a tedious duty, their assembling there together; and though the singing might be rude, it was real, and sounded more musical -LRB-to Oliver's ears at least-RRB- than any he (Oliver) had ever heard in church before. Then, there were the walks as usual, and many calls at the clean houses of the labouring men; and at night, Oliver read a chapter or two from the Bible, which he (Oliver) had been studying all the week, and in the performance of which duty he (Oliver) felt more proud and pleased, than if he (Oliver) had been the clergyman himself.

In the morning, Oliver would be a-foot by six o'clock, roaming the fields, and plundering the hedges, far and wide, for nosegays of wild flowers, with which he (Oliver) would return laden, home; and which it took great care and consideration to arrange, to the best advantage, for the embellishment of the breakfast-table. There was fresh groundsel, too, for Miss Maylie's birds, with which Oliver, who had been studying the subject under the able tuition of the village clerk, would decorate the cages, in the most approved taste. When the birds were made all spruce and smart for the day, there was usually some little commission of charity to execute in the village; or, failing that, there was rare cricket-playing, sometimes, on the green; or, failing that, there was always something to do in the garden, or about the plants, to which Oliver -LRB-who had studied this science also, under the same master, who was a gardener by trade,-RRB- applied himself with hearty good-will, until Miss Rose made her (Rose) appearance: when there were a thousand commendations to be bestowed on all he (gardener) had done.

So three months glided away; three months which, in the life of the most blessed and favoured of mortals, might have been unmingled happiness, and which, in Oliver's were true felicity. With the purest and most amiable generosity on one side; and the truest, warmest, soul-felt gratitude on the other; it is no wonder that, by the end of that short time, Oliver Twist had become completely domesticated with the old lady and her (lady) niece, and that the fervent attachment of his (Twist) young and sensitive heart, was repaid by their pride in, and attachment to, himself.

CHAPTER XXXIII

WHEREIN THE HAPPINESS OF OLIVER AND HIS (OLIVER) FRIENDS, EXPERIENCES A SUDDEN CHECK

Spring flew swiftly by, and summer came. If the village had been beautiful at first it was now in the full glow and luxuriance of its richness. The great trees, which had looked shrunken and bare in the earlier months, had now burst into strong life and health; and stretching forth their green arms over the thirsty ground, converted open and naked spots into choice nooks, where was a deep and pleasant shade from which to look upon the wide prospect, steeped in sunshine, which lay stretched beyond. The earth had donned her (it) mantle of brightest green; and shed her (it) richest perfumes abroad. It was the prime and vigour of the year; all things were glad and flourishing.

Still, the same quiet life went on at the little cottage, and the same cheerful serenity prevailed among its inmates. Oliver had long since grown stout and healthy; but health or sickness made no difference in his (Oliver) warm feelings of a great many people. He (Oliver) was still the same gentle, attached, affectionate creature that he (Oliver) had been when pain and suffering had wasted his (Oliver) strength, and when he (Oliver) was dependent for every slight attention, and comfort on those who tended him (Oliver).

One beautiful night, when they had taken a longer walk than was customary with them: for the day had been unusually warm, and there was a brilliant moon, and a light wind had sprung up, which was unusually refreshing. Rose had been in high spirits, too, and they had walked on, in merry conversation, until they had far exceeded their ordinary bounds. Mrs. Maylie being fatigued, they returned more slowly home. The young lady merely throwing off her (lady) simple bonnet, sat down to the piano as usual. After running abstractedly over the keys for a few minutes, she (lady) fell into a low and very solemn air; and as she (lady) played it, they heard a sound as if she (lady) were weeping.

`Rose, my dear!' (the lady)
said the elder lady.

Rose made no reply, but played a little quicker, as though the words had roused her (Rose) from some painful thoughts.

`Rose, my love!' (Mrs. Maylie)
cried Mrs. Maylie, rising hastily, and bending over her (Maylie).
`What is this? In tears! My dear child, what distresses you?' (unknown)

`Nothing, aunt; nothing,' (the lady)
replied the young lady.
`I don't know what it is; I can't describe it; but I feel--' (the lady)

`Not ill, my love?' (Mrs. Maylie)
interposed Mrs. Maylie.

`No, no! Oh, not ill!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose: shuddering as though some deadly chillness were passing over her (Rose), while she (Rose) spoke;
`I shall be better presently. Close the window, pray!' (she)

Oliver hastened to comply with her (Rose) request. The young lady, making an effort to recover her (lady) cheerfulness, strove to play some livelier tune; but her (lady) fingers dropped powerless over the keys. Covering her (lady) face with her (lady) hands, she (lady) sank upon a sofa, and gave vent to the tears which she (lady) was now unable to repress.

`My child!' (the lady arms)
said the elderly lady, folding her (lady) arms about her (lady),
`I never saw you so before.' (her)

`I would not alarm you if I could avoid it,' (her)
rejoined Rose;
`but indeed I have tried very hard, and cannot help this. I fear I _am_ ill, aunt.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

She (aunt) was, indeed; for, when candles were brought, they saw that in the very short time which had elapsed since their return home, the hue of her (aunt) countenance had changed to a marble whiteness. Its expression had lost nothing of its beauty; but it was changed; and there was an anxious haggard look about the gentle face, which it had never worn before. Another minute, and it was suffused with a crimson flush: and a heavy wildness came over the soft blue eye. Again this disappeared, like the shadow thrown by a passing cloud; and she (aunt) was once more deadly pale.

Oliver, who watched the old lady anxiously, observed that she (lady) was alarmed by these appearances; and so in truth, was he (Oliver); but seeing that she (lady) affected to make light of them, he (Oliver) endeavoured to do the same, and they so far succeeded, that when Rose was persuaded by her (Rose) aunt to retire for the night, she (Rose) was in better spirits; and appeared even in better health: assuring them that she (Rose) felt certain she (Rose) should rise in the morning, quite well.

`I hope,' (she)
said Oliver, when Mrs. Maylie returned,
`that nothing is the matter? She (Maylie) don't look well to-night, but--' (Mrs. Maylie)

The old lady motioned to him (Oliver) not to speak; and sitting herself down in a dark corner of the room, remained silent for some time. At length, she (lady) said, in a trembling voice:

`I hope not, Oliver. I have been very happy with her (lady) for some years: too happy, perhaps. It may be time that I should meet with some misfortune; but I hope it is not this.' (she)

`What?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver.

`The heavy blow,' (the lady)
said the old lady,
`of losing the dear girl who has so long been my comfort and happiness.' (the lady)

`Oh! God forbid!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
exclaimed Oliver, hastily.

`Amen to that, my child!' (the lady)
said the old lady, wringing her (lady) hands.

`Surely there is no danger of anything so dreadful?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`Two hours ago, she (lady) was quite well.' (unknown)

`She (lady) is very ill now,' (unknown)
rejoined Mrs. Maylies;
`and will be worse, I am sure. My dear, dear Rose! Oh, what shall I do without her (Rose)!' (She)

She (Rose) gave way to such great grief, that Oliver, suppressing his (Oliver) own emotion, ventured to remonstrate with her (Rose); and to beg, earnestly, that, for the sake of the dear young lady herself, she (lady) would be more calm.

`And consider, ma'am,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, as the tears forced themselves into his (Oliver) eyes, despite of his (Oliver) efforts to the contrary.
`Oh! consider how young and good she (lady) is, and what pleasure and comfort she (lady) gives to all about her (lady). I am sure--certain--quite certain--that, for your sake, who are so good yourself; and for her (lady) own; and for the sake of all she (lady) makes so happy; she (lady) will not die. Heaven will never let her (lady) die so young.' (unknown)

`Hush!' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie, laying her (Maylie) hand on Oliver's head.
`You think like a child, poor boy. But you teach me my duty, notwithstanding. I had forgotten it for a moment, Oliver, but I hope I may be pardoned, for I am old, and have seen enough of illness and death to know the agony of separation from the objects of our love. I have seen enough, too, to know that it is not always the youngest and best who are spared to those that love them; but this should give us comfort in our sorrow; for Heaven is just; and such things teach us, impressively, that there is a brighter world than this; and that the passage to it is speedy. God's will be done! I love her (our); and He (God) knows how well!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver was surprised to see that as Mrs. Maylie said these words, she (Maylie) checked her (Maylie) lamentations as though by one effort; and drawing herself up as she (Maylie) spoke, became composed and firm. He (Oliver) was still more astonished to find that this firmness lasted; and that, under all the care and watching which ensued, Mrs. Maylie was every ready and collected: performing all the duties which had devolved upon her (Maylie), steadily, and, to all external appearances, even cheerfully. But he (Oliver) was young, and did not know what strong minds are capable of, under trying circumstances. How should he (Oliver), when their possessors so seldom know themselves?

An anxious night ensued. When morning came, Mrs. Maylie's predictions were but too well verified. Rose was in the first stage of a high and dangerous fever.

`We must be active, Oliver, and not give way to useless grief,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie, laying her (Maylie) finger on her (Maylie) lip, as she (Maylie) looked steadily into his (lip) face;
`this letter must be sent, with all possible expedition, to Mr. Losberne. It must be carried to the market-town: which is not more than four miles off, by the footpath across the field: and thence dispatched, by an express on horseback, straight to Chertsey. The people at the inn will undertake to do this: and I can trust to you to see it done, I know.' (she)

Oliver could make no reply, but looked his (Oliver) anxiety to be gone at once.

`Here is another letter,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie, pausing to reflect;
`but whether to send it now, or wait until I see how Rose goes on, I scarcely know. I would not forward it, unless I feared the worst.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`Is it for Chertsey, too, ma'am?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
inquired Oliver; impatient to execute his (Oliver) commission, and holding out his (Oliver) trembling hand for the letter.

`No,' (the lady)
replied the old lady, giving it to him (Oliver) mechanically. Oliver glanced at it, and saw that it was directed to Harry Maylie, Esquire, at some great lord's house in the country; where, he (Maylie) could not make out.

`Shall it go, ma'am?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
asked Oliver, looking up, impatiently.

`I think not,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Mrs. Maylie, taking it back.
`I will wait until to-morrow.' (Mrs. Maylie)

With these words, she (Maylie) gave Oliver her (Maylie) purse, and he (Oliver) started off, without more delay, at the greatest speed he (Oliver) could muster.

Swiftly he (Oliver) ran across the fields, and down the little lanes which sometimes divided them: now almost hidden by the high corn on either side, and now emerging on an open field, where the mowers and haymakers were busy at their work: nor did he (Oliver) stop once, save now and then, for a few seconds, to recover breath, until he (Oliver) came, in a great heat, and covered with dust, on the little market-place of the market-town.

Here he (Oliver) paused, and looked about for the inn. There were a white bank, and a red brewery, and a yellow town-hall; and in one corner there was a large house, with all the wood about it painted green: before which was the sign of

`The George.' (he)
To this he (George) hastened, as soon as it caught his (George) eye.

He (George) spoke to a postboy who was dozing under the gateway; and who, after hearing what he (George) wanted, referred him (George) to the ostler; who after hearing all he (George) had to say again, referred him (George) to the landlord; who was a tall gentleman in a blue neckcloth, a white hat, drab breeches, and boots with tops to match, leaning against a pump by the stable-door, picking his (gentleman) teeth with a silver toothpick.

This gentleman walked with much deliberation into the bar to make out the bill: which took a long time making out: and after it was ready, and paid, a horse had to be saddled, and a man to be dressed, which took up ten good minutes more. Meanwhile Oliver was in such a desperate state of impatience and anxiety, that he (Oliver) felt as if he (Oliver) could have jumped upon the horse himself, and galloped away, full tear, to the next stage. At length, all was ready; and the little parcel having been handed up, with many injunctions and entreaties for its speedy delivery, the man set spurs to his (man) horse, and rattling over the uneven paving of the market-place, was out of the town, and galloping along the turnpike-road, in a couple of minutes.

As it was something to feel certain that assistance was sent for, and that no time had been lost, Oliver hurried up the inn-yard, with a somewhat lighter heart. He (Oliver) was turning out of the gateway when he (Oliver) accidently stumbled against a tall man wrapped in a cloak, who was at that moment coming out of the inn door.

`Hah!' (the man)
cried the man, fixing his (man) eyes on Oliver, and suddenly recoiling.
`What the devil's this?' (unknown)

`I beg your pardon, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver;
`I was in a great hurry to get home, and didn't see you were coming.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Death!' (the man)
muttered the man to himself, glaring at the boy with his (boy) large dark eyes.
`Who would have thought it! Grind him (boy) to ashes! He (boy)'d start up from a stone coffin, to come in my way!' (unknown)

`I am sorry,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
stammered Oliver, confused by the strange man's wild look.
`I hope I have not hurt you!' (the man)

`Rot you!' (the man)
murmured the man, in a horrible passion; between his (man) clenched teeth;
`if I had only had the courage to say the word, I might have been free of you in a night. Curses on your head, and black death on your heart, you imp! What are you doing here?' (the man)

The man shook his (man) fist, as he (man) uttered these words incoherently. He (man) advanced towards Oliver, as if with the intention of aiming a blow at him (Oliver), but fell violently on the ground: writhing and foaming, in a fit.

Oliver gazed, for a moment, at the struggles of the madman -LRB-for such he (Oliver) supposed him (Oliver) to be-RRB-; and then darted into the house for help. Having seen him (Oliver) safely carried into the hotel, he (Oliver) turned his (Oliver) face homewards, running as fast as he (Oliver) could, to make up for lost time: and recalling with a great deal of astonishment and some fear, the extraordinary behaviour of the person from whom he (Oliver) had just parted.

The circumstance did not dwell in his (Oliver) recollection long, however: for when he (Oliver) reached the cottage, there was enough to occupy his (Oliver) mind, and to drive all considerations of self completely from his (Oliver) memory.

Rose Maylie had rapidly grown worse; before mid-night she (Oliver) was delirious. A medical practitioner, who resided on the spot, was in constant attendance upon her (Oliver); and after first seeing the patient, he (patient) had taken Mrs. Maylie aside, and pronounced her (Maylie) disorder to be one of a most alarming nature.

`In fact,' (he)
he (patient) said,
`it would be little short of a miracle, if she (Maylie) recovered.' (he)

How often did Oliver start from his (Oliver) bed that night, and stealing out, with noiseless footstep, to the staircase, listen for the slightest sound from the sick chamber! How often did a tremble shake his (Oliver) frame, and cold drops of terror start upon his (Oliver) brow, when a sudden trampling of feet caused him (Oliver) to fear that something too dreadful to think of, had even then occurred! And what had been the fervency of all the prayers he (Oliver) had ever muttered, compared with those he (Oliver) poured forth, now, in the agony and passion of his (Oliver) supplication for the life and health of the gentle creature, who was tottering on the deep grave's verge!

Oh! the suspense, the fearful, acute suspense, of standing idly by while the life of one we dearly love, is trembling in the balance! Oh! the racking thoughts that crowd upon the mind, and make the heart beat violently, and the breath come thick, by the force of the images they conjure up before it; the desperate anxiety _to be doing something_ to relieve the pain, or lessen the danger, which we have no power to alleviate; the sinking of soul and spirit, which the sad remembrance of our helplessness produces; what tortures can equal these; what reflections or endeavours can, in the full tide and fever of the time, allay them!

Morning came; and the little cottage was lonely and still. People spoke in whispers; anxious faces appeared at the gate, from time to time; women and children went away in tears. All the livelong day, and for hours after it had grown dark, Oliver paced softly up and down the garden, raising his (Oliver) eyes every instant to the sick chamber, and shuddering to see the darkened window, looking as if death lay stretched inside. Late that night, Mr. Losberne arrived.

`It is hard,' (the doctor)
said the good doctor, turning away as he (doctor) spoke;
`so young; so much beloved; but there is very little hope.' (he)

Another morning. The sun shone brightly; as brightly as if it looked upon no misery or care; and, with every leaf and flower in full bloom about her (Oliver); with life, and health, and sounds and sights of joy, surrounding her (Oliver) on every side: the fair young creature lay, wasting fast. Oliver crept away to the old churchyard, and sitting down on one of the green mounds, wept and prayed for her (Oliver), in silence.

There was such peace and beauty in the scene; so much of brightness and mirth in the sunny landscape; such blithesome music in the songs of the summer birds; such freedom in the rapid flight of the rook, careering overhead; so much of life and joyousness in all; that, when the boy raised his (boy) aching eyes, and looked about, the thought instinctively occurred to him (boy), that this was not a time for death; that Rose could surely never die when humbler things were all so glad and gay; that graves were for cold and cheerless winter: not for sunlight and fragrance. He (boy) almost thought that shrouds were for the old and shrunken; and that they never wrapped the young and graceful form in their ghastly folds.

A knell from the church bell broke harshly on these youthful thoughts. Another! Again! It was tolling for the funeral service. A group of humble mourners entered the gate: wearing white favours; for the corpse was young. They stood uncovered by a grave; and there was a mother--a mother once--among the weeping train. But the sun shone brightly, and the birds sang on.

Oliver turned homeward, thinking on the many kindnesses he (Oliver) had received from the young lady, and wishing that the time could come again, that he (Oliver) might never cease showing her (lady) how grateful and attached he (Oliver) was. He (Oliver) had no cause for self-reproach on the score of neglect, or want of thought, for he (Oliver) had been devoted to her (lady) service; and yet a hundred little occasions rose up before him (Oliver), on which he (Oliver) fancied he (Oliver) might have been more zealous, and more earnest, and wished he (Oliver) had been. We need be careful how we deal with those about us, when every death carries to some small circle of survivors, thoughts of so much omitted, and so little done--of so many things forgotten, and so many more which might have been repaired! There is no remorse so deep as that which is unavailing; if we would be spared its tortures, let us remember this, in time.

When he (Oliver) reached home Mrs. Maylie was sitting in the little parlour. Oliver's heart sank at sight of her (Maylie); for she (Maylie) had never left the bedside of her (Maylie) niece; and he (Oliver) trembled to think what change could have driven her (Maylie) away. He (Oliver) learnt that she (Maylie) had fallen into a deep sleep, from which she (Maylie) would waken, either to recovery and life, or to bid them farewell, and die.

They sat, listening, and afraid to speak, for hours. The untasted meal was removed, with looks which showed that their thoughts were elsewhere, they watched the sun as he (Oliver) sank lower and lower, and, at length, cast over sky and earth those brilliant hues which herald his (Oliver) departure. Their quick ears caught the sound of an approaching footstep. They both involuntarily darted to the door, as Mr. Losberne entered.

`What of Rose?' (the lady)
cried the old lady.
`Tell me at once! I can bear it; anything but suspense! Oh, tell me! in the name of Heaven!' (unknown)

`You must compose yourself,' (the doctor)
said the doctor supporting her (Rose).
`Be calm, my dear ma'am, pray.' (unknown)

`Let me go, in God's name! My dear child! She (Rose) is dead! She (Rose) is dying!' (unknown)

`No!' (the doctor)
cried the doctor, passionately.
`As He (doctor) is good and merciful, she (Rose) will live to bless us all, for years to come.' (The lady)

The lady fell upon her (lady) knees, and tried to fold her (lady) hands together; but the energy which had supported her (lady) so long, fled up to Heaven with her (lady) first thanksgiving; and she (lady) sank into the friendly arms which were extended to receive her (lady).

CHAPTER XXXIV

CONTAINS SOME INTRODUCTORY PARTICULARS RELATIVE TO A YOUNG GENTLEMAN WHO NOW ARRIVES UPON THE SCENE; AND A NEW ADVENTURE WHICH HAPPENED TO OLIVER

It was almost too much happiness to bear. Oliver felt stunned and stupefied by the unexpected intelligence; he (Oliver) could not weep, or speak, or rest. He (Oliver) had scarcely the power of understanding anything that had passed, until, after a long ramble in the quiet evening air, a burst of tears came to his (Oliver) relief, and he (Oliver) seemed to awaken, all at once, to a full sense of the joyful change that had occurred, and the almost insupportable load of anguish which had been taken from his (Oliver) breast.

The night was fast closing in, when he (Oliver) returned homeward: laden with flowers which he (Oliver) had culled, with peculiar care, for the adornment of the sick chamber. As he (Oliver) walked briskly along the road, he (Oliver) heard behind him (Oliver), the noise of some vehicle, approaching at a furious pace. Looking round, he (Oliver) saw that it was a post-chaise, driven at great speed; and as the horses were galloping, and the road was narrow, he (Oliver) stood leaning against a gate until it should have passed him (Oliver).

As it dashed on, Oliver caught a glimpse of a man in a white nightcap, whose face seemed familiar to him (Oliver), although his (Oliver) view was so brief that he (Oliver) could not identify the person. In another second or two, the nightcap was thrust out of the chaise-window, and a stentorian voice bellowed to the driver to stop: which he (driver) did, as soon as he (driver) could pull up his (driver) horses. Then, the nightcap once again appeared: and the same voice called Oliver by his (Oliver) name.

`Here!' (unknown)
cried the voice.
`Oliver, what's the news? Miss Rose! Master O-li-ver!' (unknown)

`Is is you, Giles?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver, running up to the chaise-door.

Giles popped out his (Giles) nightcap again, preparatory to making some reply, when he (Giles) was suddenly pulled back by a young gentleman who occupied the other corner of the chaise, and who eagerly demanded what was the news.

`In a word!' (the gentleman)
cried the gentleman,
`Better or worse?' (the gentleman)

`Better--much better!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, hastily.

`Thank Heaven!' (the gentleman)
exclaimed the gentleman.
`You are sure?' (unknown)

`Quite, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`The change took place only a few hours ago; and Mr. Losberne says, that all danger is at an end.' (The gentleman)

The gentleman said not another word, but, opening the chaise-door, leaped out, and taking Oliver hurriedly by the arm, led him (Oliver) aside.

`You are quite certain? There is no possibility of any mistake on your part, my boy, is there?' (the gentleman)
demanded the gentleman in a tremulous voice.
`Do not deceive me, by awakening hopes that are not to be fulfilled.' (unknown)

`I would not for the world, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.
`Indeed you may believe me. Mr. Losberne's words were, that she (gentleman) would live to bless us all for many years to come. I heard him (Losberne) say so.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

The tears stood in Oliver's eyes as he (Oliver) recalled the scene which was the beginning of so much happiness; and the gentleman turned his (gentleman) face away, and remained silent, for some minutes. Oliver thought he (Oliver) heard him (Oliver) sob, more than once; but he (Oliver) feared to interrupt him (Oliver) by any fresh remark--for he (Oliver) could well guess what his (Oliver) feelings were--and so stood apart, feigning to be occupied with his (Oliver) nosegay.

All this time, Mr. Giles, with the white nightcap on, had been sitting on the steps of the chaise, supporting an elbow on each knee, and wiping his (Giles) eyes with a blue cotton pocket-handkerchief dotted with white spots. That the honest fellow had not been feigning emotion, was abundantly demonstrated by the very red eyes with which he (fellow) regarded the young gentleman, when he (fellow) turned round and addressed him (fellow).

`I think you had better go on to my mother's in the chaise, Giles,' (him)
said he (Giles).
`I would rather walk slowly on, so as to gain a little time before I see her (mother). You can say I am coming.' (he)

`I beg your pardon, Mr. Harry,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Giles: giving a final polish to his (Giles) ruffled countenance with the handkerchief;
`but if you would leave the postboy to say that, I should be very much obliged to you. It wouldn't be proper for the maids to see me in this state, sir; I should never have any more authority with them if they did.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`Well,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
rejoined Harry Maylie, smiling,
`you can do as you like. Let him (Maylie) go on with the luggage, if you wish it, and do you follow with us. Only first exchange that nightcap for some more appropriate covering, or we shall be taken for madmen.' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

Mr. Giles, reminded of his (Giles) unbecoming costume, snatched off and pocketed his (Giles) nightcap; and substituted a hat, of grave and sober shape, which he (Giles) took out of the chaise. This done, the postboy drove off; Giles, Mr. Maylie, and Oliver, followed at their leisure.

As they walked along, Oliver glanced from time to time with much interest and curiosity at the new comer. He (Oliver) seemed about five-and-twenty years of age, and was of the middle height; his (Oliver) countenance was frank and handsome; and his (Oliver) demeanor easy and prepossessing. Notwithstanding the difference between youth and age, he (Oliver) bore so strong a likeness to the old lady, that Oliver would have had no great difficulty in imagining their relationship, if he (Oliver) had not already spoken of her (lady) as his (Oliver) mother.

Mrs. Maylie was anxiously waiting to receive her (Maylie) son when he (Oliver) reached the cottage. The meeting did not take place without great emotion on both sides.

`Mother!' (the man)
whispered the young man;
`why did you not write before?' (the man)

`I did,' (the man)
replied Mrs. Maylie;
`but, on reflection, I determined to keep back the letter until I had heard Mr. Losberne's opinion.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`But why,' (the man)
said the young man,
`why run the chance of that occurring which so nearly happened? If Rose had--I cannot utter that word now--if this illness had terminated differently, how could you ever have forgiven yourself! How could I ever have know happiness again!' (the man)

`If that _had_ been the case, Harry,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie,
`I fear your happiness would have been effectually blighted, and that your arrival here, a day sooner or a day later, would have been of very, very little import.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`And who can wonder if it be so, mother?' (the man)
rejoined the young man;
`or why should I say, _if_?--It is--it is--you know it, mother--you must know it!' (the man)

`I know that she (mother) deserves the best and purest love the heart of man can offer,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie;
`I know that the devotion and affection of her (Maylie) nature require no ordinary return, but one that shall be deep and lasting. If I did not feel this, and know, besides, that a changed behaviour in one she (Maylie) loved would break her (Maylie) heart, I should not feel my task so difficult of performance, or have to encounter so many struggles in my own bosom, when I take what seems to me to be the strict line of duty.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`This is unkind, mother,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.
`Do you still suppose that I am a boy ignorant of my own mind, and mistaking the impulses of my own soul?' (unknown)

`I think, my dear son,' (Mrs. Maylie)
returned Mrs. Maylie, laying her (Maylie) hand upon his (son) shoulder,
`that youth has many generous impulses which do not last; and that among them are some, which, being gratified, become only the more fleeting. Above all, I think' (Mrs. Maylie)
said the lady, fixing her (lady) eyes on her (lady) son's face,
`that if an enthusiastic, ardent, and ambitious man marry a wife on whose name there is a stain, which, though it originate in no fault of hers, may be visited by cold and sordid people upon her (wife), and upon his (man) children also: and, in exact proportion to his (man) success in the world, be cast in his (man) teeth, and made the subject of sneers against him (man): he (man) may, no matter how generous and good his (man) nature, one day repent of the connection he (man) formed in early life. And she (wife) may have the pain of knowing that he (man) does so.' (son)

`Mother,' (the man)
said the young man, impatiently,
`he (man) would be a selfish brute, unworthy alike of the name of man and of the woman you describe, who acted thus.' (the man)

`You think so now, Harry,' (mother)
replied his (Harry) mother.

`And ever will!' (the man)
said the young man.
`The mental agony I have suffered, during the last two days, wrings from me the avowal to you of a passion which, as you well know, is not one of yesterday, nor one I have lightly formed. On Rose, sweet, gentle girl! my heart is set, as firmly as ever heart of man was set on woman. I have no thought, no view, no hope in life, beyond her (woman); and if you oppose me in this great stake, you take my peace and happiness in your hands, and cast them to the wind. Mother, think better of this, and of me, and do not disregard the happiness of which you seem to think so little.' (unknown)

`Harry,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie,
`it is because I think so much of warm and sensitive hearts, that I would spare them from being wounded. But we have said enough, and more than enough, on this matter, just now.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`Let it rest with Rose, then,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
interposed Harry.
`You will not press these overstrained opinions of yours, so far, as to throw any obstacle in my way?' (unknown)

`I will not,' (Mrs. Maylie)
rejoined Mrs. Maylie;
`but I would have you consider--' (Mrs. Maylie)

`I _have_ considered!' (Mrs. Maylie)
was the impatient reply;
`Mother, I have considered, years and years. I have considered, ever since I have been capable of serious reflection. My feelings remain unchanged, as they ever will; and why should I suffer the pain of a delay in giving them vent, which can be productive of no earthly good? No! Before I leave this place, Rose shall hear me.' (unknown)

`She (Rose) shall,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie.

`There is something in your manner, which would almost imply that she (Maylie) will hear me coldly, mother,' (the man)
said the young man.

`Not coldly,' (the lady)
rejoined the old lady;
`far from it.' (the lady)

`How then?' (the man)
urged the young man.
`She (lady) has formed no other attachment?' (unknown)

`No, indeed,' (mother)
replied his (man) mother;
`you have, or I mistake, too strong a hold on her (mother) affections already. What I would say,' (mother)
resumed the old lady, stopping her (lady) son as he (son) was about to speak,
`is this. Before you stake your all on this chance; before you suffer yourself to be carried to the highest point of hope; reflect for a few moments, my dear child, on Rose's history, and consider what effect the knowledge of her (Rose) doubtful birth may have on her (Rose) decision: devoted as she (Rose) is to us, with all the intensity of her (Rose) noble mind, and with that perfect sacrifice of self which, in all matters, great or trifling, has always been her (Rose) characteristic.' (he)

`What do you mean?' (unknown)

`That I leave you to discover,' (Mrs. Maylie)
replied Mrs. Maylie.
`I must go back to her (Maylie). God bless you!' (Mrs. Maylie)

`I shall see you again to-night?' (the man)
said the young man, eagerly.

`By and by,' (the lady)
replied the lady;
`when I leave Rose.' (the lady)

`You will tell her (Rose) I am here?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.

`Of course,' (Mrs. Maylie)
replied Mrs. Maylie.

`And say how anxious I have been, and how much I have suffered, and how I long to see her (Maylie). You will not refuse to do this, mother?' (unknown)

`No,' (the lady)
said the old lady;
`I will tell her (lady) all.' (the lady)
And pressing her (lady) son's hand, affectionately, she (lady) hastened from the room.

Mr. Losberne and Oliver had remained at another end of the apartment while this hurried conversation was proceeding. The former now held out his (Losberne) hand to Harry Maylie; and hearty salutations were exchanged between them. The doctor then communicated, in reply to multifarious questions from his (doctor) young friend, a precise account of his (doctor) patient's situation; which was quite as consolatory and full of promise, as Oliver's statement had encouraged him (Oliver) to hope; and to the whole of which, Mr. Giles, who affected to be busy about the luggage, listened with greedy ears.

`Have you shot anything particular, lately, Giles?' (the doctor)
inquired the doctor, when he (Giles) had concluded.

`Nothing particular, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Mr. Giles, colouring up to the eyes.

`Nor catching any thieves, nor identifying any house-breakers?' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

`None at all, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
replied Mr. Giles, with much gravity.

`Well,' (the doctor)
said the doctor,
`I am sorry to hear it, because you do that sort of thing admirably. Pray, how is Brittles?' (the doctor)

`The boy is very well, sir,' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
said Mr. Giles, recovering his (Giles) usual tone of patronage;
`and sends his (Giles) respectful duty, sir.' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

`That's well,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
`Seeing you here, reminds me, Mr. Giles, that on the day before that on which I was called away so hurriedly, I executed, at the request of your good mistress, a small commission in your favour. Just step into this corner a moment, will you?' (Mr. Giles/Giles)

Mr. Giles walked into the corner with much importance, and some wonder, and was honoured with a short whispering conference with the doctor, on the termination of which, he (doctor) made a great many bows, and retired with steps of unusual stateliness. The subject matter of this conference was not disclosed in the parlour, but the kitchen was speedily enlightened concerning it; for Mr. Giles walked straight thither, and having called for a mug of ale, announced, with an air of majesty, which was highly effective, that it had pleased his (Giles) mistress, in consideration of his (Giles) gallant behaviour on the occasion of that attempted robbery, to deposit, in the local savings-bank, the sum of five-and-twenty pounds, for his (Giles) sole use and benefit. At this, the two women-servants lifted up their hands and eyes, and supposed that Mr. Giles, pulling out his (Giles) shirt-frill, replied,

`No, no' (Mr. Giles/Giles)
; and that if they observed that he (Giles) was at all haughty to his (Giles) inferiors, he (Giles) would thank them to tell him (Giles) so. And then he (Giles) made a great many other remarks, no less illustrative of his (Giles) humility, which were received with equal favour and applause, and were, withal, as original and as much to the purpose, as the remarks of great men commonly are.

Above stairs, the remainder of the evening passed cheerfully away; for the doctor was in high spirits; and however fatigued or thoughtful Harry Maylie might have been at first, he (Maylie) was not proof against the worthy gentleman's good humour, which displayed itself in a great variety of sallies and professional recollections, and an abundance of small jokes, which struck Oliver as being the drollest things he (Oliver) had ever heard, and caused him (Oliver) to laugh proportionately; to the evident satisfaction of the doctor, who laughed immoderately at himself, and made Harry laugh almost as heartily, by the very force of sympathy. So, they were as pleasant a party as, under the circumstances, they could well have been; and it was late before they retired, with light and thankful hearts, to take that rest of which, after the doubt and suspense they had recently undergone, they stood much in need.

Oliver rose next morning, in better heart, and went about his (Oliver) usual occupations, with more hope and pleasure than he (Oliver) had known for many days. The birds were once more hung out, to sing, in their old places; and the sweetest wild flowers that could be found, were once more gathered to gladden Rose with their beauty. The melancholy which had seemed to the sad eyes of the anxious boy to hang, for days past, over every object, beautiful as all were, was dispelled by magic. The dew seemed to sparkle more brightly on the green leaves; the air to rustle among them with a sweeter music; and the sky itself to look more blue and bright. Such is the influence which the condition of our own thoughts, exercise, even over the appearance of external objects. Men who look on nature, and their fellow-men, and cry that all is dark and gloomy, are in the right; but the sombre colours are reflections from their own jaundiced eyes and hearts. The real hues are delicate, and need a clearer vision.

It is worthy of remark, and Oliver did not fail to note it at the time, that his (Oliver) morning expeditions were no longer made alone. Harry Maylie, after the very first morning when he (Maylie) met Oliver coming laden home, was seized with such a passion for flowers, and displayed such a taste in their arrangement, as left his (Oliver) young companion far behind. If Oliver were behindhand in these respects, he (Oliver) knew where the best were to be found; and morning after morning they scoured the country together, and brought home the fairest that blossomed. The window of the young lady's chamber was opened now; for she (lady) loved to feel the rich summer air stream in, and revive her (lady) with its freshness; but there always stood in water, just inside the lattice, one particular little bunch, which was made up with great care, every morning. Oliver could not help noticing that the withered flowers were never thrown away, although the little vase was regularly replenished; nor, could he (Oliver) help observing, that whenever the doctor came into the garden, he (doctor) invariably cast his (doctor) eyes up to that particular corner, and nodded his (doctor) head most expressively, as he (doctor) set forth on his (doctor) morning's walk. Pending these observations, the days were flying by; and Rose was rapidly recovering.

Nor did Oliver's time hang heavy on his (Oliver) hands, although the young lady had not yet left her (lady) chamber, and there were no evening walks, save now and then, for a short distance, with Mrs. Maylie. He (Oliver) applied himself, with redoubled assiduity, to the instructions of the white-headed old gentleman, and laboured so hard that his (gentleman) quick progress surprised even himself. It was while he (gentleman) was engaged in this pursuit, that he (gentleman) was greatly startled and distressed by a most unexpected occurrence.

The little room in which he (gentleman) was accustomed to sit, when busy at his (gentleman) books, was on the ground-floor, at the back of the house. It was quite a cottage-room, with a lattice-window: around which were clusters of jessamine and honeysuckle, that crept over the casement, and filled the place with their delicious perfume. It looked into a garden, whence a wicket-gate opened into a small paddock; all beyond, was fine meadow-land and wood. There was no other dwelling near, in that direction; and the prospect it commanded was very extensive.

One beautiful evening, when the first shades of twilight were beginning to settle upon the earth, Oliver sat at this window, intent upon his (Oliver) books. He (Oliver) had been poring over them for some time; and, as the day had been uncommonly sultry, and he (Oliver) had exerted himself a great deal, it is no disparagement to the authors, whoever they may have been, to say, that gradually and by slow degrees, he (Oliver) fell asleep.

There is a kind of sleep that steals upon us sometimes, which, while it holds the body prisoner, does not free the mind from a sense of things about it, and enable it to ramble at its pleasure. So far as an overpowering heaviness, a prostration of strength, and an utter inability to control our thoughts or power of motion, can be called sleep, this is it; and yet, we have a consciousness of all that is going on about us, and, if we dream at such a time, words which are really spoken, or sounds which really exist at the moment, accommodate themselves with surprising readiness to our visions, until reality and imagination become so strangely blended that it is afterwards almost matter of impossibility to separate the two. Nor is this, the most striking phenomenon incidental to such a state. It is an undoubted fact, that although our senses of touch and sight be for the time dead, yet our sleeping thoughts, and the visionary scenes that pass before us, will be influenced and materially influenced, by the _mere silent presence_ of some external object; which may not have been near us when we closed our eyes: and of whose vicinity we have had no waking consciousness.

Oliver knew, perfectly well, that he (Oliver) was in his (Oliver) own little room; that his (Oliver) books were lying on the table before him (Oliver); that the sweet air was stirring among the creeping plants outside. And yet he (Oliver) was asleep. Suddenly, the scene changed; the air became close and confined; and he (Oliver) thought, with a glow of terror, that he (Oliver) was in the Jew's house again. There sat the hideous old man, in his (man) accustomed corner, pointing at him (man), and whispering to another man, with his (man) face averted, who sat beside him (man).

`Hush, my dear!' (he)
he (man) thought he (man) heard the Jew say;
`it is he (man), sure enough. Come away.' (the Jew)

`He (man)!' (the man)
the other man seemed to answer;
`could I mistake him (man), think you? If a crowd of ghosts were to put themselves into his (man) exact shape, and he (man) stood amongst them, there is something that would tell me how to point him (man) out. If you buried him (man) fifty feet deep, and took me across his (man) grave, I fancy I should know, if there wasn't a mark above it, that he (man) lay buried there?' (the man)

The man seemed to say this, with such dreadful hatred, that Oliver awoke with the fear, and started up.

Good Heaven! what was that, which sent the blood tingling to his (Oliver) heart, and deprived him (Oliver) of his (Oliver) voice, and of power to move! There--there--at the window--close before him (Oliver)--so close, that he (Oliver) could have almost touched him (Oliver) before he (Oliver) started back: with his (Oliver) eyes peering into the room, and meeting his (Oliver): there stood the Jew! And beside him (Oliver), white with rage or fear, or both, were the scowling features of the man who had accosted him (man) in the inn-yard.

It was but an instant, a glance, a flash, before his (man) eyes; and they were gone. But they had recognised him (man), and he (man) them; and their look was as firmly impressed upon his (man) memory, as if it had been deeply carved in stone, and set before him (man) from his (man) birth. He (man) stood transfixed for a moment; then, leaping from the window into the garden, called loudly for help.

CHAPTER XXXV

CONTAINING THE UNSATISFACTORY RESULT OF OLIVER'S ADVENTURE; AND A CONVERSATION OF SOME IMPORTANCE BETWEEN HARRY MAYLIE AND ROSE

When the inmates of the house, attracted by Oliver's cries, hurried to the spot from which they proceeded, they found him (Oliver), pale and agitated, pointing in the direction of the meadows behind the house, and scarcely able to articulate the words,

`The Jew! the Jew!' (him)

Mr. Giles was at a loss to comprehend what this outcry meant; but Harry Maylie, whose perceptions were something quicker, and who had heard Oliver's history from his (Oliver) mother, understood it at once.

`What direction did he (Oliver) take?' (he)
he (Oliver) asked, catching up a heavy stick which was standing in a corner.

`That,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, pointing out the course the man had taken;
`I missed them in an instant.' (the man)

`Then, they are in the ditch!' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.
`Follow! And keep as near me, as you can.' (he)
So saying, he (Harry) sprang over the hedge, and darted off with a speed which rendered it matter of exceeding difficulty for the others to keep near him (Harry).

Giles followed as well as he (Giles) could; and Oliver followed too; and in the course of a minute or two, Mr. Losberne, who had been out walking, and just then returned, tumbled over the hedge after them, and picking himself up with more agility than he (Losberne) could have been supposed to possess, struck into the same course at no contemptible speed, shouting all the while, most prodigiously, to know what was the matter.
