On they all went; nor stopped they once to breathe, until the leader, striking off into an angle of the field indicated by Oliver, began to search, narrowly, the ditch and hedge adjoining; which afforded time for the remainder of the party to come up; and for Oliver to communicate to Mr. Losberne the circumstances that had led to so vigorous a pursuit.

The search was all in vain. There were not even the traces of recent footsteps, to be seen. They stood now, on the summit of a little hill, commanding the open fields in every direction for three or four miles. There was the village in the hollow on the left; but, in order to gain that, after pursuing the track Oliver had pointed out, the men must have made a circuit of open ground, which it was impossible they could have accomplished in so short a time. A thick wood skirted the meadow-land in another direction; but they could not have gained that covert for the same reason.

`It must have been a dream, Oliver,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry Maylie.

`Oh no, indeed, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, shuddering at the very recollection of the old wretch's countenance;
`I saw him (Oliver) too plainly for that. I saw them both, as plainly as I see you now.' (the wretch)

`Who was the other?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
inquired Harry and Mr. Losberne, together.

`The very same man I told you of, who came so suddenly upon me at the inn,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver.
`We had our eyes fixed full upon each other; and I could swear to him (Oliver).' (unknown)

`They took this way?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
demanded Harry:
`are you sure?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

`As I am that the men were at the window,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, pointing down, as he (Oliver) spoke, to the hedge which divided the cottage-garden from the meadow.
`The tall man leaped over, just there; and the Jew, running a few paces to the right, crept through that gap.' (The gentlemen)

The two gentlemen watched Oliver's earnest face, as he (Oliver) spoke, and looking from him (Oliver) to each other, seemed to feel satisfied of the accuracy of what he (Oliver) said. Still, in no direction were there any appearances of the trampling of men in hurried flight. The grass was long; but it was trodden down nowhere, save where their own feet had crushed it. The sides and brinks of the ditches were of damp clay; but in no one place could they discern the print of men's shoes, or the slightest mark which would indicate that any feet had pressed the ground for hours before.

`This is strange!' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.

`Strange?' (the doctor)
echoed the doctor.
`Blathers and Duff, themselves, could make nothing of it.' (unknown)

Notwithstanding the evidently useless nature of their search, they did not desist until the coming on of night rendered its further prosecution hopeless; and even then, they gave it up with reluctance. Giles was dispatched to the different ale-houses in the village, furnished with the best description Oliver could give of the appearance and dress of the strangers. Of these, the Jew was, at all events, sufficiently remarkable to be remembered, supposing he (Oliver) had been seen drinking, or loitering about; but Giles returned without any intelligence, calculated to dispel or lessen the mystery.

On the next day, fresh search was made, and the inquiries renewed; but with no better success. On the day following, Oliver and Mr. Maylie repaired to the market-town, in the hope of seeing or hearing something of the men there; but this effort was equally fruitless. After a few days, the affair began to be forgotten, as most affairs are, when wonder, having no fresh food to support it, dies away of itself.

Meanwhile, Rose was rapidly recovering. She (Rose) had left her (Rose) room: was able to go out; and mixing once more with the family, carried joy into the hearts of all.

But, although this happy change had a visible effect on the little circle; and although cheerful voices and merry laughter were once more heard in the cottage; there was at times, an unwonted restraint upon some there: even upon Rose herself: which Oliver could not fail to remark. Mrs. Maylie and her (Maylie) son were often closeted together for a long time; and more than once Rose appeared with traces of tears upon her (Rose) face. After Mr. Losberne had fixed a day for his (Losberne) departure to Chertsey, these symptoms increased; and it became evident that something was in progress which affected the peace of the young lady, and of somebody else besides.

At length, one morning, when Rose was alone in the breakfast-parlour, Harry Maylie entered; and, with some hesitation, begged permission to speak with her (Rose) for a few moments.

`A few--a very few--will suffice, Rose,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said the young man, drawing his (man) chair towards her (Rose).
`What I shall have to say, has already presented itself to your mind; the most cherished hopes of my heart are not unknown to you, though from my lips you have not heard them stated.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

Rose had been very pale from the moment of his (man) entrance; but that might have been the effect of her (Rose) recent illness. She (Rose) merely bowed; and bending over some plants that stood near, waited in silence for him (man) to proceed.

`I--I--ought to have left here, before,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.

`You should, indeed,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose.
`Forgive me for saying so, but I wish you had.' (unknown)

`I was brought here, by the most dreadful and agonising of all apprehensions,' (the man)
said the young man;
`the fear of losing the one dear being on whom my every wish and hope are fixed. You had been dying; trembling between earth and heaven. We know that when the young, the beautiful, and good, are visited with sickness, their pure spirits insensibly turn towards their bright home of lasting rest; we know, Heaven help us! that the best and fairest of our kind, too often fade in blooming.' (the man)

There were tears in the eyes of the gentle girl, as these words were spoken; and when one fell upon the flower over which she (girl) bent, and glistened brightly in its cup, making it more beautiful, it seemed as though the outpouring of her (girl) fresh young heart, claimed kindred naturally, with the loveliest things in nature.

`A creature,' (kindred)
continued the young man, passionately,
`a creature as fair and innocent of guile as one of God's own angels, fluttered between life and death. Oh! who could hope, when the distant world to which she (girl) was akin, half opened to her (girl) view, that she (girl) would return to the sorrow and calamity of this! Rose, Rose, to know that you were passing away like some soft shadow, which a light from above, casts upon the earth; to have no hope that you would be spared to those who linger here; hardly to know a reason why you should be; to feel that you belonged to that bright sphere whither so many of the fairest and the best have winged their early flight; and yet to pray, amid all these consolations, that you might be restored to those who loved you--these were distractions almost too great to bear. They were mine, by day and night; and with them, came such a rushing torrent of fears, and apprehensions, and selfish regrets, lest you should die, and never know how devotedly I loved you, as almost bore down sense and reason in its course. You recovered. Day by day, and almost hour by hour, some drop of health came back, and mingling with the spent and feeble stream of life which circulated languidly within you, swelled it again to a high and rushing tide. I have watched you change almost from death, to life, with eyes that turned blind with their eagerness and deep affection. Do not tell me that you wish I had lost this; for it has softened my heart to all mankind.' (the man)

`I did not mean that,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, weeping;
`I only wish you had left here, that you might have turned to high and noble pursuits again; to pursuits well worthy of you.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`There is no pursuit more worthy of me: more worthy of the highest nature that exists: than the struggle to win such a heart as yours,' (the man)
said the young man, taking her (Rose) hand.
`Rose, my own dear Rose! For years--for years--I have loved you; hoping to win my way to fame, and then come proudly home and tell you it had been pursued only for you to share; thinking, in my daydreams, how I would remind you, in that happy moment, of the many silent tokens I had given of a boy's attachment, and claim your hand, as in redemption of some old mute contract that had been sealed between us! That time has not arrived; but here, with not fame won, and no young vision realised, I offer you the heart so long your own, and stake my all upon the words with which you greet the offer.' (unknown)

`Your behaviour has ever been kind and noble.' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, mastering the emotions by which she (Rose) was agitated.
`As you believe that I am not insensible or ungrateful, so hear my answer.' (unknown)

`It is, that I may endeavour to deserve you; it is, dear Rose?' (unknown)

`It is,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose,
`that you must endeavour to forget me; not as your old and dearly-attached companion, for that would wound me deeply; but, as the object of your love. Look into the world; think how many hearts you would be proud to gain, are there. Confide some other passion to me, if you will; I will be the truest, warmest, and most faithful friend you have.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

There was a pause, during which, Rose, who had covered her (Rose) face with one hand, gave free vent to her (Rose) tears. Harry still retained the other.

`And your reasons, Rose,' (he)
he (Harry) said, at length, in a low voice;
`your reasons for this decision?' (he)

`You have a right to know them,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
rejoined Rose.
`You can say nothing to alter my resolution. It is a duty that I must perform. I owe it, alike to others, and to myself.' (unknown)

`To yourself?' (unknown)

`Yes, Harry. I owe it to myself, that I, a friendless, portionless, girl, with a blight upon my name, should not give your friends reason to suspect that I had sordidly yielded to your first passion, and fastened myself, a clog, on all your hopes and projects. I owe it to you and yours, to prevent you from opposing, in the warmth of your generous nature, this great obstacle to your progress in the world.' (unknown)

`If your inclinations chime with your sense of duty--' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
Harry began.

`They do not,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose, colouring deeply.

`Then you return my love?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.
`Say but that, dear Rose; say but that; and soften the bitterness of this hard disappointment!' (unknown)

`If I could have done so, without doing heavy wrong to him (Harry) I loved,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
rejoined Rose,
`I could have--' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`Have received this declaration very differently?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Harry.
`Do not conceal that from me, at least, Rose.' (unknown)

`I could,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.
`Stay!' (she)
she (Rose) added, disengaging her (Rose) hand,
`why should we prolong this painful interview? Most painful to me, and yet productive of lasting happiness, notwithstanding; for it _will_ be happiness to know that I once held the high place in your regard which I now occupy, and every triumph you achieve in life will animate me with new fortitude and firmness. Farewell, Harry! As we have met to-day, we meet no more; but in other relations than those in which this conversation have placed us, we may be long and happily entwined; and may every blessing that the prayers of a true and earnest heart can call down from the source of all truth and sincerity, cheer and prosper you!' (she)

`Another word, Rose,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.
`Your reason in your own words. From your own lips, let me hear it!' (unknown)

`The prospect before you,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
answered Rose, firmly,
`is a brilliant one. All the honours to which great talents and powerful connections can help men in public life, are in store for you. But those connections are proud; and I will neither mingle with such as may hold in scorn the mother who gave me life; nor bring disgrace or failure on the son of her (mother) who has so well supplied that mother's place. In a word,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said the young lady, turning away, as her (lady) temporary firmness forsook her (lady),
`there is a stain upon my name, which the world visits on innocent heads. I will carry it into no blood but my own; and the reproach shall rest alone on me.' (her)

`One word more, Rose. Dearest Rose! one more!' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
cried Harry, throwing himself before her (Rose).
`If I had been less--less fortunate, the world would call it--if some obscure and peaceful life had been my destiny--if I had been poor, sick, helpless--would you have turned from me then? Or has my probable advancement to riches and honour, given this scruple birth?' (unknown)

`Do not press me to reply,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
answered Rose.
`The question does not arise, and never will. It is unfair, almost unkind, to urge it.' (unknown)

`If your answer be what I almost dare to hope it is,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
retorted Harry,
`it will shed a gleam of happiness upon my lonely way, and light the path before me. It is not an idle thing to do so much, by the utterance of a few brief words, for one who loves you beyond all else. Oh, Rose: in the name of my ardent and enduring attachment; in the name of all I have suffered for you, and all you doom me to undergo; answer me this one question!' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

`Then, if your lot had been differently cast,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
rejoined Rose;
`if you had been even a little, but not so far, above me; if I could have been a help and comfort to you in any humble scene of peace and retirement, and not a blot and drawback in ambitious and distinguished crowds; I should have been spared this trial. I have every reason to be happy, very happy, now; but then, Harry, I own I should have been happier.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

Busy recollections of old hopes, cherished as a girl, long ago, crowded into the mind of Rose, while making this avowal; but they brought tears with them, as old hopes will when they come back withered; and they relieved her (Rose).

`I cannot help this weakness, and it makes my purpose stronger,' (her)
said Rose, extending her (Rose) hand.
`I must leave you now, indeed.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`I ask one promise,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry.
`Once, and only once more,--say within a year, but it may be much sooner,--I may speak to you again on this subject, for the last time.' (unknown)

`Not to press me to alter my right determination,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose, with a melancholy smile;
`it will be useless.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`No,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry;
`to hear you repeat it, if you will--finally repeat it! I will lay at your feet, whatever of station of fortune I may possess; and if you still adhere to your present resolution, will not seek, by word or act, to change it.' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

`Then let it be so,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
rejoined Rose;
`it is but one pang the more, and by that time I may be enabled to bear it better.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

She (Rose) extended her (Rose) hand again. But the young man caught her (Rose) to his (man) bosom; and imprinting one kiss on her (Rose) beautiful forehead, hurried from the room.

CHAPTER XXXVI

IS A VERY SHORT ONE, AND MAY APPEAR OF NO GREAT IMPORTANCE IN ITS PLACE, BUT IT SHOULD BE READ NOTWITHSTANDING, AS A SEQUEL TO THE LAST, AND A KEY TO ONE THAT WILL FOLLOW WHEN ITS TIME ARRIVES

`And so you are resolved to be my travelling companion this morning; eh?' (the doctor)
said the doctor, as Harry Maylie joined him (Maylie) and Oliver at the breakfast-table.
`Why, you are not in the same mind or intention two half-hours together!' (unknown)

`You will tell me a different tale one of these days,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry, colouring without any perceptible reason.

`I hope I may have good cause to do so,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
replied Mr. Losberne;
`though I confess I don't think I shall. But yesterday morning you had made up your mind, in a great hurry, to stay here, and to accompany your mother, like a dutiful son, to the sea-side. Before noon, you announce that you are going to do me the honour of accompanying me as far as I go, on your road to London. And at night, you urge me, with great mystery, to start before the ladies are stirring; the consequence of which is, that young Oliver here is pinned down to his (Oliver) breakfast when he (Oliver) ought to be ranging the meadows after botanical phenomena of all kinds. Too bad, isn't it, Oliver?' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

`I should have been very sorry not to have been at home when you and Mr. Maylie went away, sir,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
rejoined Oliver.

`That's a fine fellow,' (the doctor)
said the doctor;
`you shall come and see me when you return. But, to speak seriously, Harry; has any communication from the great nobs produced this sudden anxiety on your part to be gone?' (the doctor)

`The great nobs,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
replied Harry,
`under which designation, I presume, you include my most stately uncle, have not communicated with me at all, since I have been here; nor, at this time of the year, is it likely that anything would occur to render necessary my immediate attendance among them.' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

`Well,' (the doctor fellow)
said the doctor,
`you are a queer fellow. But of course they will get you into parliament at the election before Christmas, and these sudden shiftings and changes are no bad preparation for political life. There's something in that. Good training is always desirable, whether the race be for place, cup, or sweepstakes.' (the doctor fellow)

Harry Maylie looked as if he (Maylie) could have followed up this short dialogue by one or two remarks that would have staggered the doctor not a little; but he (doctor) contented himself with saying,

`We shall see,' (he)
and pursued the subject no farther. The post-chaise drove up to the door shortly afterwards; and Giles coming in for the luggage, the good doctor bustled out, to see it packed.

`Oliver,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry Maylie, in a low voice,
`let me speak a word with you.' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

Oliver walked into the window-recess to which Mr. Maylie beckoned him (Maylie); much surprised at the mixture of sadness and boisterous spirits, which his (Maylie) whole behaviour displayed.

`You can write well now?' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
said Harry, laying his (Harry) hand upon his (Harry) arm.

`I hope so, sir,' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)
replied Oliver.

`I shall not be at home again, perhaps for some time; I wish you would write to me--say once a fort-night: every alternate Monday: to the General Post Office in London. Will you?' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Oh! certainly, sir; I shall be proud to do it,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
exclaimed Oliver, greatly delighted with the commission.

`I should like to know how--how my mother and Miss Maylie are,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said the young man;
`and you can fill up a sheet by telling me what walks you take, and what you talk about, and whether she (Maylie)--they, I mean--seem happy and quite well. You understand me?' (the man)

`Oh! quite, sir, quite,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver.

`I would rather you did not mention it to them,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Harry, hurrying over his (Harry) words;
`because it might make my mother anxious to write to me oftener, and it is a trouble and worry to her (mother). Let it be a secret between you and me; and mind you tell me everything! I depend upon you.' (Harry/Harry Maylie/HARRY MAYLIE)

Oliver, quite elated and honoured by a sense of his (Oliver) importance, faithfully promised to be secret and explicit in his (Oliver) communications. Mr. Maylie took leave of him (Maylie), with many assurances of his (Maylie) regard and protection.

The doctor was in the chaise; Giles -LRB-who, it had been arranged, should be left behind-RRB- held the door open in his (Giles) hand; and the women-servants were in the garden, looking on. Harry cast one slight glance at the latticed window, and jumped into the carriage.

`Drive on!' (he)
he (Harry) cried,
`hard, fast, full gallop! Nothing short of flying will keep pace with me, to-day.' (he)

`Halloa!' (the doctor)
cried the doctor, letting down the front glass in a great hurry, and shouting to the postillion;
`something very short of flying will keep pace with _me_. Do you hear?' (the postillion)

Jingling and clattering, till distance rendered its noise inaudible, and its rapid progress only perceptible to the eye, the vehicle wound its way along the road, almost hidden in a cloud of dust: now wholly disappearing, and now becoming visible again, as intervening objects, or the intricacies of the way, permitted. It was not until even the dusty cloud was no longer to be seen, that the gazers dispersed.

And there was one looker-on, who remained with eyes fixed upon the spot where the carriage had disappeared, long after it was many miles away; for, behind the white curtain which had shrouded her (its) from view when Harry raised his (Harry) eyes towards the window, sat Rose herself.

`He (Harry) seems in high spirits and happy,' (she)
she (Rose) said, at length.
`I feared for a time he (Harry) might be otherwise. I was mistaken. I am very, very glad.' (she)

Tears are signs of gladness as well as grief; but those which coursed down Rose's face, as she (Rose) sat pensively at the window, still gazing in the same direction, seemed to tell more of sorrow than of joy.

CHAPTER XXXVII

IN WHICH THE READER MAY PERCEIVE A CONTRAST, NOT UNCOMMON IN MATRIMONIAL CASES

Mr. Bumble sat in the workhouse parlour, with his (Bumble) eyes moodily fixed on the cheerless grate, whence, as it was summer time, no brighter gleam proceeded, than the reflection of certain sickly rays of the sun, which were sent back from its cold and shining surface. A paper fly-cage dangled from the ceiling, to which he (Bumble) occasionally raised his (Bumble) eyes in gloomy thought; and, as the heedless insects hovered round the gaudy net-work, Mr. Bumble would heave a deep sigh, while a more gloomy shadow overspread his (Bumble) countenance. Mr. Bumble was meditating; it might be that the insects brought to mind, some painful passage in his (Bumble) own past life.

Nor was Mr. Bumble's gloom the only thing calculated to awaken a pleasing melancholy in the bosom of a spectator. There were not wanting other appearances, and those closely connected with his (spectator) own person, which announced that a great change had taken place in the position of his (spectator) affairs. The laced coat, and the cocked hat; where were they? He (spectator) still wore knee-breeches, and dark cotton stockings on his (spectator) nether limbs; but they were not _the_ breeches. The coat was wide-skirted; and in that respect like _the_ coat, but, oh how different! The mighty cocked hat was replaced by a modest round one. Mr. Bumble was no longer a beadle.

There are some promotions in life, which, independent of the more substantial rewards they offer, require peculiar value and dignity from the coats and waistcoats connected with them. A field-marshal has his (Bumble) uniform; a bishop his (Bumble) silk apron; a counsellor his (Bumble) silk gown; a beadle his (Bumble) cocked hat. Strip the bishop of his (Bumble) apron, or the beadle of his (Bumble) hat and lace; what are they? Men. Mere men. Dignity, and even holiness too, sometimes, are more questions of coat and waistcoat than some people imagine.

Mr. Bumble had married Mrs. Corney, and was master of the workhouse. Another beadle had come into power. On him (beadle) the cocked hat, gold-laced coat, and staff, had all three descended.

`And to-morrow two months it was done!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, with a sigh.
`It seems a age.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble might have meant that he (Bumble) had concentrated a whole existence of happiness into the short space of eight weeks; but the sigh--there was a vast deal of meaning in the sigh.

`I sold myself,' (he)
said Mr. Bumble, pursuing the same train of relection,
`for six teaspoons, a pair of sugar-tongs, and a milk-pot; with a small quantity of second-hand furniture, and twenty pound in money. I went very reasonable. Cheap, dirt cheap!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Cheap!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
cried a shrill voice in Mr. Bumble's ear:
`you would have been dear at any price; and dear enough I paid for you, Lord above knows that!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble turned, and encountered the face of his (Bumble) interesting consort, who, imperfectly comprehending the few words she (Bumble) had overheard of his (Bumble) complaint, had hazarded the foregoing remark at a venture.

`Mrs. Bumble, ma'am!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, with a sentimental sternness.

`Well!' (the lady)
cried the lady.

`Have the goodness to look at me,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, fixing his (Bumble) eyes upon her (Bumble). -LRB-If she (Bumble) stands such a eye as that,' said Mr. Bumble to himself,
`she (Bumble) can stand anything. It is a eye I never knew to fail with paupers. If it fails with her (Bumble), my power is gone.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
-RRB-

Whether an exceedingly small expansion of eye be sufficient to quell paupers, who, being lightly fed, are in no very high condition; or whether the late Mrs. Corney was particularly proof against eagle glances; are matters of opinion. The matter of fact, is, that the matron was in no way overpowered by Mr. Bumble's scowl, but, on the contrary, treated it with great disdain, and even raised a laugh thereat, which sounded as though it were genuine.

On hearing this most unexpected sound, Mr. Bumble looked, first incredulous, and afterwards amazed. He (Bumble) then relapsed into his (Bumble) former state; nor did he (Bumble) rouse himself until his (Bumble) attention was again awakened by the voice of his (Bumble) partner.

`Are you going to sit snoring there, all day?' (Mrs. Bumble)
inquired Mrs. Bumble.

`I am going to sit here, as long as I think proper, ma'am,' (Mrs. Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble;
`and although I was _not_ snoring, I shall snore, gape, sneeze, laugh, or cry, as the humour strikes me; such being my prerogative.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`_Your_ prerogative!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
sneered Mrs. Bumble, with ineffable contempt.

`I said the word, ma'am,' (Mrs. Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`The prerogative of a man is to command.' (unknown)

`And what's the prerogative of a woman, in the name of Goodness?' (Mr. Corney)
cried the relict of Mr. Corney deceased.

`To obey, ma'am,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
thundered Mr. Bumble.
`Your late unfortunate husband should have taught it you; and then, perhaps, he (Bumble) might have been alive now. I wish he (Bumble) was, poor man!' (Mrs. Bumble)

Mrs. Bumble, seeing at a glance, that the decisive moment had now arrived, and that a blow struck for the mastership on one side or other, must necessarily be final and conclusive, no sooner heard this allusion to the dead and gone, than she (Bumble) dropped into a chair, and with a loud scream that Mr. Bumble was a hard-hearted brute, fell into a paroxysm of tears.

But, tears were not the things to find their way to Mr. Bumble's soul; his (Bumble) heart was waterproof. Like washable beaver hats that improve with rain, his (Bumble) nerves were rendered stouter and more vigorous, by showers of tears, which, being tokens of weakness, and so far tacit admissions of his (Bumble) own power, pleased and exalted him (Bumble). He (Bumble) eyed his (Bumble) good lady with looks of great satisfaction, and begged, in an encouraging manner, that she (lady) should cry her (lady) hardest: the exercise being looked upon, by the faculty, as strongly conducive to health.

`It opens the lungs, washes the countenance, exercises the eyes, and softens down the temper,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`So cry away.' (he)

As he (Bumble) discharged himself of this pleasantry, Mr. Bumble took his (Bumble) hat from a peg, and putting it on, rather rakishly, on one side, as a man might, who felt he (man) had asserted his (man) superiority in a becoming manner, thrust his (man) hands into his (man) pockets, and sauntered towards the door, with much ease and waggishness depicted in his (man) whole appearance.

Now, Mrs. Corney that was, had tried the tears, because they were less troublesome than a manual assault; but, she (Corney) was quite prepared to make trial of the latter mode of proceeding, as Mr. Bumble was not long in discovering.

The first proof he (Bumble) experienced of the fact, was conveyed in a hollow sound, immediately succeeded by the sudden flying off of his (Bumble) hat to the opposite end of the room. This preliminary proceeding laying bare his (Bumble) head, the expert lady, clasping him (Bumble) tightly round the throat with one hand, inflicted a shower of blows -LRB-dealt with singular vigour and dexterity-RRB- upon it with the other. This done, she (lady) created a little variety by scratching his (Bumble) face, and tearing his (Bumble) hair; and, having, by this time, inflicted as much punishment as she (lady) deemed necessary for the offence, she (lady) pushed him (Bumble) over a chair, which was luckily well situated for the purpose: and defied him (Bumble) to talk about his (Bumble) prerogative again, if he (Bumble) dared.

`Get up!' (Mrs. Bumble)
said Mrs. Bumble, in a voice of command.
`And take yourself away from here, unless you want me to do something desperate.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble rose with a very rueful countenance: wondering much what something desperate might be. Picking up his (Bumble) hat, he (Bumble) looked towards the door.

`Are you going?' (Mrs. Bumble)
demanded Mrs. Bumble.

`Certainly, my dear, certainly,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble, making a quicker motion towards the door.
`I didn't intend to--I'm going, my dear! You are so very violent, that really I--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

At this instant, Mrs. Bumble stepped hastily forward to replace the carpet, which had been kicked up in the scuffle. Mr. Bumble immediately darted out of the room, without bestowing another thought on his (Bumble) unfinished sentence: leaving the late Mrs. Corney in full possession of the field.

Mr. Bumble was fairly taken by surprise, and fairly beaten. He (Bumble) had a decided propensity for bullying: derived no inconsiderable pleasure from the exercise of petty cruelty; and, consequently, was -LRB-it is needless to say-RRB- a coward. This is by no means a disparagement to his (coward) character; for many official personages, who are held in high respect and admiration, are the victims of similar infirmities. The remark is made, indeed, rather in his (coward) favour than otherwise, and with a view of impressing the reader with a just sense of his (coward) qualifications for office.

But, the measure of his (coward) degradation was not yet full. After making a tour of the house, and thinking, for the first time, that the poor-laws really were too hard on people; and that men who ran away from their wives, leaving them chargeable to the parish, ought, in justice to be visited with no punishment at all, but rather rewarded as meritorious individuals who had suffered much; Mr. Bumble came to a room where some of the female paupers were usually employed in washing the parish linen: when the sound of voices in conversation, now proceeded.

`Hem!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, summoning up all his (Bumble) native dignity.
`These women at least shall continue to respect the prerogative. Hallo! hallo there! What do you mean by this noise, you hussies?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

With these words, Mr. Bumble opened the door, and walked in with a very fierce and angry manner: which was at once exchanged for a most humiliated and cowering air, as his (Bumble) eyes unexpectedly rested on the form of his (Bumble) lady wife.

`My dear,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble,
`I didn't know you were here.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Didn't know I was here!' (Mrs. Bumble)
repeated Mrs. Bumble.
`What do _you_ do here?' (unknown)

`I thought they were talking rather too much to be doing their work properly, my dear,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble: glancing distractedly at a couple of old women at the wash-tub, who were comparing notes of admiration at the workhouse-master's humility.

`_You_ thought they were talking too much?' (women)
said Mrs. Bumble.
`What business is it of yours?' (unknown)

`Why, my dear--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
urged Mr. Bumble submissively.

`What business is it of yours?' (Mrs. Bumble)
demanded Mrs. Bumble, again.

`It's very true, you're matron here, my dear,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
submitted Mr. Bumble;
`but I thought you mightn't be in the way just then.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`I'll tell you what, Mr. Bumble,' (lady)
returned his (Bumble) lady.
`We don't want any of your interference. You're a great deal too fond of poking your nose into things that don't concern you, making everybody in the house laugh, the moment your back is turned, and making yourself look like a fool every hour in the day. Be off; come!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

Mr. Bumble, seeing with excruciating feelings, the delight of the two old paupers, who were tittering together most rapturously, hesitated for an instant. Mrs. Bumble, whose patience brooked no delay, caught up a bowl of soap-suds, and motioning him (Bumble) towards the door, ordered him (Bumble) instantly to depart, on pain of receiving the contents upon his (Bumble) portly person.

What could Mr. Bumble do? He (Bumble) looked dejectedly round, and slunk away; and, as he (Bumble) reached the door, the titterings of the paupers broke into a shrill chuckle of irrepressible delight. It wanted but this. He (Bumble) was degraded in their eyes; he (Bumble) had lost caste and station before the very paupers; he (Bumble) had fallen from all the height and pomp of beadleship, to the lowest depth of the most snubbed hen-peckery.

`All in two months!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, filled with dismal thoughts.
`Two months! No more than two months ago, I was not only my own master, but everybody else's, so far as the porochial workhouse was concerned, and now!--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

It was too much. Mr. Bumble boxed the ears of the boy who opened the gate for him (Bumble) -LRB-for he (Bumble) had reached the portal in his (Bumble) reverie-RRB-; and walked, distractedly, into the street.

He (Bumble) walked up one street, and down another, until exercise had abated the first passion of his (Bumble) grief; and then the revulsion of feeling made him (Bumble) thirsty. He (Bumble) passed a great many public-houses; but, at length paused before one in a by-way, whose parlour, as he (Bumble) gathered from a hasty peep over the blinds, was deserted, save by one solitary customer. It began to rain, heavily, at the moment. This determined him (Bumble). Mr. Bumble stepped in; and ordering something to drink, as he (Bumble) passed the bar, entered the apartment into which he (Bumble) had looked from the street.

The man who was seated there, was tall and dark, and wore a large cloak. He (man) had the air of a stranger; and seemed, by a certain haggardness in his (man) look, as well as by the dusty soils on his (man) dress, to have travelled some distance. He (man) eyed Bumble askance, as he (man) entered, but scarcely deigned to nod his (man) head in acknowledgment of his (man) salutation.

Mr. Bumble had quite dignity enough for two; supposing even that the stranger had been more familiar: so he (Bumble) drank his (Bumble) gin-and-water in silence, and read the paper with great show of pomp and circumstance.

It so happened, however: as it will happen very often, when men fall into company under such circumstances: that Mr. Bumble felt, every now and then, a powerful inducement, which he (Bumble) could not resist, to steal a look at the stranger: and that whenever he (stranger) did so, he (stranger) withdrew his (stranger) eyes, in some confusion, to find that the stranger was at that moment stealing a look at him (stranger). Mr. Bumble's awkwardness was enhanced by the very remarkable expression of the stranger's eye, which was keen and bright, but shadowed by a scowl of distrust and suspicion, unlike anything he (Bumble) had ever observed before, and repulsive to behold.

When they had encountered each other's glance several times in this way, the stranger, in a harsh, deep voice, broke silence.

`Were you looking for me,' (he)
he (stranger) said,
`when you peered in at the window?' (he)

`Not that I am aware of, unless you're Mr.--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
Here Mr. Bumble stopped short; for he (Bumble) was curious to know the stranger's name, and thought in his (Bumble) impatience, he (Bumble) might supply the blank.

`I see you were not,' (he)
said the stranger; an expression of quiet sarcasm playing about his (stranger) mouth;
`or you have known my name. You don't know it. I would recommend you not to ask for it.' (the stranger expression)

`I meant no harm, young man,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
observed Mr. Bumble, majestically.

`And have done none,' (the stranger)
said the stranger.

Another silence succeeded this short dialogue: which was again broken by the stranger.

`I have seen you before, I think?' (the stranger)
said he (stranger).
`You were differently dressed at that time, and I only passed you in the street, but I should know you again. You were beadle here, once; were you not?' (unknown)

`I was,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, in some surprise;
`porochial beadle.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`Just so,' (unknown)
rejoined the other, nodding his (Bumble) head.
`It was in that character I saw you. What are you now?' (unknown)

`Master of the workhouse,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble, slowly and impressively, to check any undue familiarity the stranger might otherwise assume.
`Master of the workhouse, young man!' (unknown)

`You have the same eye to your own interest, that you always had, I doubt not?' (the stranger)
resumed the stranger, looking keenly into Mr. Bumble's eyes, as he (Bumble) raised them in astonishment at the question.

`Don't scruple to answer freely, man. I know you pretty well, you see.' (unknown)

`I suppose, a married man,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, shading his (Bumble) eyes with his (Bumble) hand, and surveying the stranger, from head to foot, in evident perplexity,
`is not more averse to turning an honest penny when he (stranger) can, than a single one. Porochial officers are not so well paid that they can afford to refuse any little extra fee, when it comes to them in a civil and proper manner.' (the stranger)

The stranger smiled, and nodded his (stranger) head again: as much to say, he (stranger) had not mistaken his (stranger) man; then rang the bell.

`Fill this glass again,' (he)
he (stranger) said, handing Mr. Bumble's empty tumbler to the landlord.
`Let it be strong and hot. You like it so, I suppose?' (unknown)

`Not too strong,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, with a delicate cough.

`You understand what that means, landlord!' (the stranger)
said the stranger, drily.

The host smiled, disappeared, and shortly afterwards returned with a steaming jorum: of which, the first gulp brought the water into Mr. Bumble's eyes.

`Now listen to me,' (the stranger)
said the stranger, after closing the door and window.
`I came down to this place, to-day, to find you out; and, by one of those chances which the devil throws in the way of his (devil) friends sometimes, you walked into the very room I was sitting in, while you were uppermost in my mind. I want some information from you. I don't ask you to give it for nothing, slight as it is. Put up that, to begin with.' (the stranger)

As he (devil) spoke, he (devil) pushed a couple of sovereigns across the table to his (devil) companion, carefully, as though unwilling that the chinking of money should be heard without. When Mr. Bumble had scrupulously examined the coins, to see that they were genuine, and had put them up, with much satisfaction, in his (Bumble) waistcoat-pocket, he (Bumble) went on:

`Carry your memory back--let me see--twelve years, last winter.' (he)

`It's a long time,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble.
`Very good. I've done it.' (unknown)

`The scene, the workhouse.' (unknown)

`Good!' (unknown)

`And the time, night.' (unknown)

`Yes.' (unknown)

`And the place, the crazy hole, wherever it was, in which miserable drabs brought forth the life and health so often denied to themselves--gave birth to puling children for the parish to rear; and hid their shame, rot 'em in the grave!' (unknown)

`The lying-in room, I suppose?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, not quite following the stranger's excited description.

`Yes,' (the stranger)
said the stranger.
`A boy was born there.' (the stranger)

`A many boys,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
observed Mr. Bumble, shaking his (Bumble) head, despondingly.

`A murrain on the young devils!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
cried the stranger; `I speak of one; a meek-looking, pale-faced boy, who was apprenticed down here, to a coffin-maker--I wish he (boy) had made his (boy) coffin, and screwed his (boy) body in it--and who afterwards ran away to London, as it was supposed.

`Why, you mean Oliver! Young Twist!' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble;
`I remember him (Bumble), of course. There wasn't a obstinater young rascal--' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

`It's not of him (Bumble) I want to hear; I've heard enough of him (Bumble),' (the stranger)
said the stranger, stopping Mr. Bumble in the outset of a tirade on the subject of poor Oliver's vices.
`It's of a woman; the hag that nursed his (Oliver) mother. Where is she (mother)?' (unknown)

`Where is she (mother)?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, whom the gin-and-water had rendered facetious.
`It would be hard to tell. There's no midwifery there, whichever place she (mother)'s gone to; so I suppose she (mother)'s out of employment, anyway.' (unknown)

`What do you mean?' (the stranger)
demanded the stranger, sternly.

`That she (mother) died last winter,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble.

The man looked fixedly at him (Bumble) when he (Bumble) had given this information, and although he (Bumble) did not withdraw his (Bumble) eyes for some time afterwards, his (Bumble) gaze gradually became vacant and abstracted, and he (Bumble) seemed lost in thought. For some time, he (Bumble) appeared doubtful whether he (Bumble) ought to be relieved or disappointed by the intelligence; but at length he (Bumble) breathed more freely; and withdrawing his (Bumble) eyes, observed that it was no great matter. With that he (Bumble) rose, as if to depart.

But Mr. Bumble was cunning enough; and he (Bumble) at once saw that an opportunity was opened, for the lucrative disposal of some secret in the possession of his (Bumble) better half. He (Bumble) well remembered the night of old Sally's death, which the occurrences of that day had given him (Bumble) good reason to recollect, as the occasion on which he (Bumble) had proposed to Mrs. Corney; and although that lady had never confided to him (Bumble) the disclosure of which she (lady) had been the solitary witness, he (witness) had heard enough to know that it related to something that had occurred in the old woman's attendance, as workhouse nurse, upon the young mother of Oliver Twist. Hastily calling this circumstance to mind, he (Twist) informed the stranger, with an air of mystery, that one woman had been closeted with the old harridan shortly before she (woman) died; and that she (woman) could, as he (Twist) had reason to believe, throw some light on the subject of his (Twist) inquiry.

`How can I find her (woman)?' (the stranger)
said the stranger, thrown off his (stranger) guard; and plainly showing that all his (stranger) fears -LRB-whatever they were-RRB- were aroused afresh by the intelligence.

`Only through me,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
rejoined Mr. Bumble.

`When?' (the stranger)
cried the stranger, hastily.

`To-morrow,' (unknown)
rejoined Bumble.

`At nine in the evening,' (the stranger)
said the stranger, producing a scrap of paper, and writing down upon it, an obscure address by the water-side, in characters that betrayed his (stranger) agitation;
`at nine in the evening, bring her (stranger) to me there. I needn't tell you to be secret. It's your interest.' (characters)

With these words, he (stranger) led the way to the door, after stopping to pay for the liquor that had been drunk. Shortly remarking that their roads were different, he (stranger) departed, without more ceremony than an emphatic repetition of the hour of appointment for the following night.

On glancing at the address, the parochial functionary observed that it contained no name. The stranger had not gone far, so he (stranger) made after him (stranger) to ask it.

`What do you want?' (the man)
cried the man, turning quickly round, as Bumble touched him (Bumble) on the arm.
`Following me?' (unknown)

`Only to ask a question,' (unknown)
said the other, pointing to the scrap of paper.
`What name am I to ask for?' (unknown)

`Monks!' (the man)
rejoined the man; and strode hastily, away.

CHAPTER XXXVIII

CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF WHAT PASSED BETWEEN MR. AND MRS. BUMBLE, AND MR. MONKS, AT THEIR NOCTURNAL INTERVIEW

It was a dull, close, overcast summer evening. The clouds, which had been threatening all day, spread out in a dense and sluggish mass of vapour, already yielded large drops of rain, and seemed to presage a violent thunder-storm, when Mr. and Mrs. Bumble, turning out of the main street of the town, directed their course towards a scattered little colony of ruinous houses, distant from it some mile and a-half, or thereabouts, and erected on a low unwholesome swamp, bordering upon the river.

They were both wrapped in old and shabby outer garments, which might, perhaps, serve the double purpose of protecting their persons from the rain, and sheltering them from observation. The husband carried a lantern, from which, however, no light yet shone; and trudged on, a few paces in front, as though--the way being dirty--to give his (husband) wife the benefit of treading in his (husband) heavy footprints. They went on, in profound silence; every now and then, Mr. Bumble relaxed his (Bumble) pace, and turned his (Bumble) head as if to make sure that his (Bumble) helpmate was following; then, discovering that she (wife) was close at his (Bumble) heels, he (Bumble) mended his (Bumble) rate of walking, and proceeded, at a considerable increase of speed, towards their place of destination.

This was far from being a place of doubtful character; for it had long been known as the residence of none but low ruffians, who, under various pretences of living by their labour, subsisted chiefly on plunder and crime. It was a collection of mere hovels: some, hastily built with loose bricks: others, of old worm-eaten ship-timber: jumbled together without any attempt at order or arrangement, and planted, for the most part, within a few feet of the river's bank. A few leaky boats drawn up on the mud, and made fast to the dwarf wall which skirted it: and here and there an oar or coil of rope: appeared, at first, to indicate that the inhabitants of these miserable cottages pursued some avocation on the river; but a glance at the shattered and useless condition of the articles thus displayed, would have led a passer-by, without much difficulty, to the conjecture that they were disposed there, rather for the preservation of appearances, than with any view to their being actually employed.

In the heart of this cluster of huts; and skirting the river, which its upper stories overhung; stood a large building, formerly used as a manufactory of some kind. It had, in its day, probably furnished employment to the inhabitants of the surrounding tenements. But it had long since gone to ruin. The rat, the worm, and the action of the damp, had weakened and rotted the piles on which it stood; and a considerable portion of the building had already sunk down into the water; while the remainder, tottering and bending over the dark stream, seemed to wait a favourable opportunity of following its old companion, and involving itself in the same fate.

It was before this ruinous building that the worthy couple paused, as the first peal of distant thunder reverberated in the air, and the rain commenced pouring violently down.

`The place should be somewhere here,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Bumble, consulting a scrap of paper he (Bumble) held in his (Bumble) hand.

`Halloa there!' (unknown)
cried a voice from above.

Following the sound, Mr. Bumble raised his (Bumble) head and descried a man looking out of a door, breast-high, on the second story.

`Stand still, a minute,' (unknown)
cried the voice;
`I'll be with you directly.' (unknown)
With which the head disappeared, and the door closed.

`Is that the man?' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
asked Mr. Bumble's good lady.

Mr. Bumble nodded in the affirmative.

`Then, mind what I told you,' (the matron)
said the matron:
`and be careful to say as little as you can, or you'll betray us at once.' (the matron)

Mr. Bumble, who had eyed the building with very rueful looks, was apparently about to express some doubts relative to the advisability of proceeding any further with the enterprise just then, when he (Bumble) was prevented by the appearance of Monks: who opened a small door, near which they stood, and beckoned them inwards.

`Come in!' (he)
he (Bumble) cried impatiently, stamping his (Bumble) foot upon the ground.
`Don't keep me here!' (The woman)

The woman, who had hesitated at first, walked boldly in, without any other invitation. Mr. Bumble, who was ashamed or afraid to lag behind, followed: obviously very ill at ease and with scarcely any of that remarkable dignity which was usually his (Bumble) chief characteristic.

`What the devil made you stand lingering there, in the wet?' (Monks)
said Monks, turning round, and addressing Bumble, after he (Bumble) had bolted the door behind them.

`We--we were only cooling ourselves,' (him)
stammered Bumble, looking apprehensively about him (Bumble).

`Cooling yourselves!' (Monks)
retorted Monks.
`Not all the rain that ever fell, or ever will fall, will put as much of hell's fire out, as a man can carry about with him (man). You won't cool yourself so easily; don't think it!' (Monks)

With this agreeable speech, Monks turned short upon the matron, and bent his (man) gaze upon her (matron), till even she (matron), who was not easily cowed, was fain to withdraw her (matron) eyes, and turn them towards the ground.

`This is the woman, is it?' (Monks)
demanded Monks.

`Hem! That is the woman,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
replied Mr. Bumble, mindful of his (Bumble) wife's caution.

`You think women never can keep secrets, I suppose?' (the matron)
said the matron, interposing, and returning, as she (matron) spoke, the searching look of Monks.

`I know they will always keep _one_ till it's found out,' (Monks)
said Monks.

`And what may that be?' (the matron)
asked the matron.

`The loss of their own good name,' (Monks)
replied Monks.
`So, by the same rule, if a woman's a party to a secret that might hang or transport her (woman), I'm not afraid of her (woman) telling it to anybody; not I! Do you understand, mistress?' (unknown)

`No,' (the matron)
rejoined the matron, slightly colouring as she (matron) spoke.

`Of course you don't!' (Monks)
said Monks.
`How should you?' (companions)

Bestowing something half-way between a smile and a frown upon his (their) two companions, and again beckoning them to follow him (their), the man hastened across the apartment, which was of considerable extent, but low in the roof. He (their) was preparing to ascend a steep staircase, or rather ladder, leading to another floor of warehouses above: when a bright flash of lightning streamed down the aperture, and a peal of thunder followed, which shook the crazy building to its centre.

`Hear it!' (he)
he (their) cried, shrinking back.
`Hear it! Rolling and crashing on as if it echoed through a thousand caverns where the devils were hiding from it. I hate the sound!' (He)

He (their) remained silent for a few moments; and then, removing his (their) hands suddenly from his (their) face, showed, to the unspeakable discomposure of Mr. Bumble, that it was much distorted and discoloured.

`These fits come over me, now and then,' (Monks)
said Monks, observing his (Bumble) alarm;
`and thunder sometimes brings them on. Don't mind me now; it's all over for this once.' (Monks)

Thus speaking, he (Bumble) led the way up the ladder; and hastily closing the window-shutter of the room into which it led, lowered a lantern which hung at the end of a rope and pulley passed through one of the heavy beams in the ceiling: and which cast a dim light upon an old table and three chairs that were placed beneath it.

`Now,' (Monks)
said Monks, when they had all three seated themselves,
`the sooner we come to our business, the better for all. The woman know what it is, does she (woman)?' (Monks)

The question was addressed to Bumble; but his (woman) wife anticipated the reply, by intimating that she (wife) was perfectly acquainted with it.

`He (woman) is right in saying that you were with this hag the night she (wife) died; and that she (wife) told you something--' (the matron)

`About the mother of the boy you named,' (the matron)
replied the matron interrupting him (boy).
`Yes.' (unknown)

`The first question is, of what nature was her (matron) communication?' (Monks)
said Monks.

`That's the second,' (the woman)
observed the woman with much deliberation.
`The first is, what may the communication be worth?' (unknown)

`Who the devil can tell that, without knowing of what kind it is?' (Monks)
asked Monks.

`Nobody better than you, I am persuaded,' (Mrs. Bumble)
answered Mrs. Bumble: who did not want for spirit, as her (Bumble) yoke-fellow could abundantly testify.

`Humph!' (Monks)
said Monks significantly, and with a look of eager inquiry;
`there may be money's worth to get, eh?' (Monks)

`Perhaps there may,' (unknown)
was the composed reply.

`Something that was taken from her (Bumble),' (Monks)
said Monks.
`Something that she (Bumble) wore. Something that--' (Mrs. Bumble)

`You had better bid,' (Mrs. Bumble)
interrupted Mrs. Bumble.
`I have heard enough, already, to assure me that you are the man I ought to talk to.' (Mrs. Bumble)

Mr. Bumble, who had not yet been admitted by his (Bumble) better half into any greater share of the secret than he (Bumble) had originally possessed, listened to this dialogue with outstretched neck and distended eyes: which he (Bumble) directed towards his (Bumble) wife and Monks, by turns, in undisguised astonishment; increased, if possible, when the latter sternly demanded, what sum was required for the disclosure.

`What's it worth to you?' (the woman)
asked the woman, as collectedly as before.

`It may be nothing; it may be twenty pounds,' (Monks)
replied Monks.
`Speak out, and let me know which.' (unknown)

`Add five pounds to the sum you have named; give me five-and-twenty pounds in gold,' (the woman)
said the woman;
`and I'll tell you all I know. Not before.' (the woman)

`Five-and-twenty pounds!' (Monks)
exclaimed Monks, drawing back.

`I spoke as plainly as I could,' (Monks)
replied Mrs. Bumble.
`It's not a large sum, either.' (unknown)

`Not a large sum for a paltry secret, that may be nothing when it's told!' (Monks)
cried Monks impatiently;
`and which has been lying dead for twelve years past or more!' (Monks)

`Such matters keep well, and, like good wine, often double their value in course of time,' (the matron)
answered the matron, still preserving the resolute indifference she (matron) had assumed.
`As to lying dead, there are those who will lie dead for twelve thousand years to come, or twelve million, for anything you or I know, who will tell strange tales at last!' (unknown)

`What if I pay it for nothing?' (Monks)
asked Monks, hesitating.

`You can easily take it away again,' (the matron)
replied the matron.
`I am but a woman; alone here; and unprotected.' (the matron)

`Not alone, my dear, nor unprotected, neither,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
submitted Mr. Bumble, in a voice tremulous with fear:
`_I_ am here, my dear. And besides,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
said Mr. Bumble, his (Bumble) teeth chattering as he (Bumble) spoke,
`Mr. Monks is too much of a gentleman to attempt any violence on porochial persons. Mr. Monks is aware that I am not a young man, my dear, and also that I am a little run to seed, as I may say; bu he (Monks) has heerd: I say I have no doubt Mr. Monks has heerd, my dear: that I am a very determined officer, with very uncommon strength, if I'm once roused. I only want a little rousing; that's all.' (he)

As Mr. Bumble spoke, he (Bumble) made a melancholy feint of grasping his (Bumble) lantern with fierce determination; and plainly showed, by the alarmed expression of every feature, that he (Bumble) _did_ want a little rousing, and not a little, prior to making any very warlike demonstration: unless, indeed, against paupers, or other person or persons trained down for the purpose.

`You are a fool,' (Mrs. Bumble)
said Mrs. Bumble, in reply;
`and had better hold your tongue.' (Mrs. Bumble)

`He (fool) had better have cut it out, before he (fool) came, if he (fool) can't speak in a lower tone,' (Monks)
said Monks, grimly.
`So! He (fool)'s your husband, eh?' (unknown)

`He (fool) my husband!' (the matron)
tittered the matron, parrying the question.

`I thought as much, when you came in,' (the matron)
rejoined Monks, marking the angry glance which the lady darted at her (lady) spouse as she (lady) spoke.
`So much the better; I have less hesitation in dealing with two people, when I find that there's only one will between them. I'm in earnest. See here!' (He)

He (fool) thrust his (fool) hand into a side-pocket; and producing a canvas bag, told out twenty-five sovereigns on the table, and pushed them over to the woman.

`Now,' (he)
he (fool) said,
`gather them up; and when this cursed peal of thunder, which I feel is coming up to break over the house-top, is gone, let's hear your story.' (he)

The thunder, which seemed in fact much nearer, and to shiver and break almost over their heads, having subsided, Monks, raising his (fool) face from the table, bent forward to listen to what the woman should say. The faces of the three nearly touched, as the two men leant over the small table in their eagerness to hear, and the woman also leant forward to render her (woman) whisper audible. The sickly rays of the suspended lantern falling directly upon them, aggravated the paleness and anxiety of their countenances: which, encircled by the deepest gloom and darkness, looked ghastly in the extreme.

`When this woman, that we called old Sally, died,' (the matron)
the matron began,
`she (matron) and I were alone.' (the matron)

`Was there no one by?' (Monks)
asked Monks, in the same hollow whisper;
`No sick wretch or idiot in some other bed? No one who could hear, and might, by possibility, understand?' (Monks)

`Not a soul,' (the woman)
replied the woman;
`we were alone. _I_ stood alone beside the body when death came over it.' (the woman)

`Good,' (Monks)
said Monks, regarding her (woman) attentively.
`Go on.' (unknown)

`She (woman) spoke of a young creature,' (the matron)
resumed the matron,
`who had brought a child into the world some years before; not merely in the same room, but in the same bed, in which she (matron) then lay dying.' (the matron)

`Ay?' (Monks)
said Monks, with quivering lip, and glancing over his (lip) shoulder,
`Blood! How things come about!' (lip)

`The child was the one you named to him (lip) last night,' (the matron)
said the matron, nodding carelessly towards her (matron) husband;
`the mother this nurse had robbed.' (husband)

`In life?' (Monks)
asked Monks.

`In death,' (the woman)
replied the woman, with something like a shudder.
`She (woman) stole from the corpse, when it had hardly turned to one, that which the dead mother had prayed her (mother), with her (mother) last breath, to keep for the infant's sake.' (unknown)

`She (mother) sold it,' (Monks)
cried Monks, with desperate eagerness;
`did she (mother) sell it? Where? When? To whom? How long before?' (Monks)

`As she (mother) told me, with great difficulty, that she (mother) had done this,' (the matron)
said the matron,
`she (matron) fell back and died.' (the matron)

`Without saying more?' (Monks)
cried Monks, in a voice which, from its very suppression, seemed only the more furious.
`It's a lie! I'll not be played with. She (matron) said more. I'll tear the life out of you both, but I'll know what it was.' (unknown)

`She (matron) didn't utter another word,' (the woman)
said the woman, to all appearance unmoved -LRB-as Mr. Bumble was very far from being-RRB- by the strange man's violence;
`but she (woman) clutched my gown, violently, with one hand, which was partly closed; and when I saw that she (woman) was dead, and so removed the hand by force, I found it clasped a scrap of dirty paper.' (the man)

`Which contained--' (Monks)
interposed Monks, stretching forward.

`Nothing,' (the woman)
replied the woman;
`it was a pawnbroker's duplicate.' (the woman)

`For what?' (Monks)
demanded Monks.

`In good time I'll tell you.' (the woman)
said the woman.
`I judge that she (woman) had kept the trinket, for some time, in the hope of turning it to better account; and then had pawned it; and had saved or scraped together money to pay the pawnbroker's interest year by year, and prevent its running out; so that if anything came of it, it could still be redeemed. Nothing had come of it; and, as I tell you, she (woman) died with the scrap of paper, all worn and tattered, in her (woman) hand. The time was out in two days; I thought something might one day come of it too; and so redeemed the pledge.' (the woman)

`Where is it now?' (Monks)
asked Monks quickly.

`_There_,' (Monks)
replied the woman. And, as if glad to be relieved of it, she (woman) hastily threw upon the table a small kid bag scarcely large enough for a French watch, which Monks pouncing upon, tore open with trembling hands. It contained a little gold locket: in which were two locks of hair, and a plain gold wedding-ring.

`It has the word ``Agnes'' engraved on the inside,' (the woman)
said the woman.

`There is a blank left for the surname; and then follows the date; which is within a year before the child was born. I found out that.' (unknown)

`And this is all?' (Monks)
said Monks, after a close and eager scrutiny of the contents of the little packet.

`All,' (the woman)
replied the woman.

Mr. Bumble drew a long breath, as if he (Bumble) were glad to find that the story was over, and no mention made of taking the five-and-twenty pounds back again; and now he (Bumble) took courage to wipe the perspiration which had been trickling over his (Bumble) nose, unchecked, during the whole of the previous dialogue.

`I know nothing of the story, beyond what I can guess at,' (he)
said his (Bumble) wife addressing Monks, after a short silence;
`and I want to know nothing; for it's safer not. But I may ask you two questions, may I?' (Monks)

`You may ask,' (Monks)
said Monks, with some show of surprise;
`but whether I answer or not is another question.' (Monks)

`--Which makes three,' (Monks)
observed Mr. Bumble, essaying a stroke of facetiousness.

`Is that what you expected to get from me?' (the matron)
demanded the matron.

`It is,' (Monks)
replied Monks.
`The other question?' (unknown)

`What do you propose to do with it? Can it be used against me?' (unknown)

`Never,' (Monks either)
rejoined Monks;
`nor against me either. See here! But don't move a step forward, or your life is not worth a bulrush.' (Monks either)

With these words, he (Bumble) suddenly wheeled the table aside, and pulling an iron ring in the boarding, threw back a large trap-door which opened close at Mr. Bumble's feet, and caused that gentleman to retire several paces backward, with great precipitation.

`Look down,' (Monks)
said Monks, lowering the lantern into the gulf.
`Don't fear me. I could have let you down, quietly enough, when you were seated over it, if that had been my game.' (the matron)

Thus encouraged, the matron drew near to the brink; and even Mr. Bumble himself, impelled by curiousity, ventured to do the same. The turbid water, swollen by the heavy rain, was rushing rapidly on below; and all other sounds were lost in the noise of its plashing and eddying against the green and slimy piles. There had once been a water-mill beneath; the tide foaming and chafing round the few rotten stakes, and fragments of machinery that yet remained, seemed to dart onward, with a new impulse, when freed from the obstacles which had unavailingly attempted to stem its headlong course.

`If you flung a man's body down there, where would it be to-morrow morning?' (Monks)
said Monks, swinging the lantern to and fro in the dark well.

`Twelve miles down the river, and cut to pieces besides,' (Monks)
replied Bumble, recoiling at the thought.

Monks drew the little packet from his (man) breast, where he (man) had hurriedly thrust it; and tying it to a leaden weight, which had formed a part of some pulley, and was lying on the floor, dropped it into the stream. It fell straight, and true as a die; clove the water with a scarcely audible splash; and was gone.

The three looking into each other's faces, seemed to breathe more freely.

`There!' (Monks)
said Monks, closing the trap-door, which fell heavily back into its former position.
`If the sea ever gives up its dead, as books say it will, it will keep its gold and silver to itself, and that trash among it. We have nothing more to say, and may break up our pleasant party.' (unknown)

`By all means,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
observed Mr. Bumble, with great alacrity.

`You'll keep a quiet tongue in your head, will you?' (Monks)
said Monks, with a threatening look.
`I am not afraid of your wife.' (Monks)

`You may depend upon me, young man,' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)
answered Mr. Bumble, bowing himself gradually towards the ladder, with excessive politeness.
`On everybody's account, young man; on my own, you know, Mr. Monks.' (unknown)

`I am glad, for your sake, to hear it,' (Monks)
remarked Monks.
`Light your lantern! And get away from here as fast as you can.' (Mr. Bumble/Bumble)

It was fortunate that the conversation terminated at this point, or Mr. Bumble, who had bowed himself to within six inches of the ladder, would infallibly have pitched headlong into the room below. He (Bumble) lighted his (Bumble) lantern from that which Monks had detached from the rope, and now carried in his (Bumble) hand; and making no effort to prolong the discourse, descended in silence, followed by his (Bumble) wife. Monks brought up the rear, after pausing on the steps to satisfy himself that there were no other sounds to be heard than the beating of the rain without, and the rushing of the water.

They traversed the lower room, slowly, and with caution; for Monks started at every shadow; and Mr. Bumble, holding his (Bumble) lantern a foot above the ground, walked not only with remarkable care, but with a marvellously light step for a gentleman of his (gentleman) figure: looking nervously about him (gentleman) for hidden trap-doors. The gate at which they had entered, was softly unfastened and opened by Monks; merely exchanging a nod with their mysterious acquaintance, the married couple emerged into the wet and darkness outside.

They were no sooner gone, than Monks, who appeared to entertain an invincible repugnance to being left alone, called to a boy who had been hidden somewhere below. Bidding him (boy) go first, and bear the light, he (boy) returned to the chamber he (boy) had just quitted.

CHAPTER XXXIX

INTRODUCES SOME RESPECTABLE CHARACTERS WITH WHOM THE READER IS ALREADY ACQUAINTED, AND SHOWS HOW MONKS AND THE JEW LAID THEIR WORTHY HEADS TOGETHER

On the evening following that upon which the three worthies mentioned in the last chapter, disposed of their little matter of business as therein narrated, Mr. William Sikes, awakening from a nap, drowsily growled forth an inquiry what time of night it was.

The room in which Mr. Sikes propounded this question, was not one of those he (Sikes) had tenanted, previous to the Chertsey expedition, although it was in the same quarter of the town, and was situated at no great distance from his (Sikes) former lodgings. It was not, in appearance, so desirable a habitation as his (Sikes) old quarters: being a mean and badly-furnished apartment, of very limited size; lighted only by one small window in the shelving roof, and abutting on a close and dirty lane. Nor were there wanting other indications of the good gentleman's having gone down in the world of late: for a great scarcity of furniture, and total absence of comfort, together with the disappearance of all such small moveables as spare clothes and linen, bespoke a state of extreme poverty; while the meagre and attenuated condition of Mr. Sikes himself would have fully confirmed these symptoms, if they had stood in any need of corroboration.

The housebreaker was lying on the bed, wrapped in his (Sikes) white great-coat, by way of dressing-gown, and displaying a set of features in no degree improved by the cadaverous hue of illness, and the addition of a soiled nightcap, and a stiff, black beard of a week's growth. The dog sat at the bedside: now eyeing his (Sikes) master with a wistful look, and now pricking his (Sikes) ears, and uttering a low growl as some noise in the street, or in the lower part of the house, attracted his (Sikes) attention. Seated by the window, busily engaged in patching an old waistcoat which formed a portion of the robber's ordinary dress, was a female: so pale and reduced with watching and privation, that there would have been considerable difficulty in recognising her (female) as the same Nancy who has already figured in this tale, but for the voice in which she (female) replied to Mr. Sikes's question.

`Not long gone seven,' (the girl)
said the girl.
`How do you feel to-night, Bill?' (unknown)

`As weak as water,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Mr. Sikes, with an imprecation on his (Sikes) eyes and limbs.
`Here; lend us a hand, and let me get off this thundering bed anyhow.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Illness had not improved Mr. Sikes's temper; for, as the girl raised him (Sikes) up and led him (Sikes) to a chair, he (Sikes) muttered various curses on her (girl) awkwardness, and struck her (girl).

`Whining are you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Come! Don't stand snivelling there. If you can't do anything better than that, cut off altogether. D'ye hear me?' (unknown)

`I hear you,' (the girl)
replied the girl, turning her (girl) face aside, and forcing a laugh.
`What fancy have you got in your head now?' (unknown)

`Oh! you've thought better of it, have you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes, marking the tear which trembled in her (girl) eye.
`All the better for you, you have.' (unknown)

`Why, you don't mean to say, you'd be hard upon me to-night, Bill,' (the girl)
said the girl, laying her (girl) hand upon his (Bill) shoulder.

`No!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Mr. Sikes.
`Why not?' (unknown)

`Such a number of nights,' (the girl number)
said the girl, with a touch of woman's tenderness, which communicated something like sweetness of tone, even to her (girl) voice:
`such a number of nights as I've been patient with you, nursing and caring for you, as if you had been a child: and this the first that I've seen you like yourself; you wouldn't have served me as you did just now, if you'd thought of that, would you? Come, come; say you wouldn't.' (woman)

`Well, then,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Mr. Sikes,
`I wouldn't. Why, damme, now, the girls's whining again!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`It's nothing,' (the girl)
said the girl, throwing herself into a chair.
`Don't you seem to mind me. It'll soon be over.' (unknown)

`What'll be over?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
demanded Mr. Sikes in a savage voice.
`What foolery are you up to, now, again? Get up and bustle about, and don't come over me with your woman's nonsense.' (unknown)

At any other time, this remonstrance, and the tone in which it was delivered, would have had the desired effect; but the girl being really weak and exhausted, dropped her (girl) head over the back of the chair, and fainted, before Mr. Sikes could get out a few of the appropriate oaths with which, on similar occasions, he (Sikes) was accustomed to garnish his (Sikes) threats. Not knowing, very well, what to do, in this uncommon emergency; for Miss Nancy's hysterics were usually of that violent kind which the patient fights and struggles out of, without much assistance; Mr. Sikes tried a little blasphemy: and finding that mode of treatment wholly ineffectual, called for assistance.

`What's the matter here, my dear?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, looking in.

`Lend a hand to the girl, can't you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes impatiently.
`Don't stand chattering and grinning at me!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

With an exclamation of surprise, Fagin hastened to the girl's assistance, while Mr. John Dawkins -LRB-otherwise the Artful Dodger-RRB-, who had followed his (Dawkins) venerable friend into the room, hastily deposited on the floor a bundle with which he (Dawkins) was laden; and snatching a bottle from the grasp of Master Charles Bates who came close at his (Bates) heels, uncorked it in a twinkling with his (Bates) teeth, and poured a portion of its contents down the patient's throat: previously taking a taste, himself, to prevent mistakes.

`Give her (girl) a whiff of fresh air with the bellows, Charley,' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)
said Mr. Dawkins;
`and you slap her (girl) hands, Fagin, while Bill undoes the petticuts.' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)

These united restoratives, administered with great energy: especially that department consigned to Master Bates, who appeared to consider his (Bates) share in the proceedings, a piece of unexampled pleasantry: were not long in producing the desired effect. The girl gradually recovered her (girl) senses; and, staggering to a chair by the bedside, hid her (girl) face upon the pillow: leaving Mr. Sikes to confront the new comers, in some astonishment at their unlooked-for appearance.

`Why, what evil wind has blowed you here?' (he)
he (Sikes) asked Fagin.

`No evil wind at all, my dear, for evil winds blow nobody any good; and I've brought something good with me, that you'll be glad to see. Dodger, my dear, open the bundle; and give Bill the little trifles that we spent all our money on, this morning.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

In compliance with Mr. Fagin's request, the Artful untied this bundle, which was of large size, and formed of an old table-cloth; and handed the articles it contained, one by one, to Charley Bates: who placed them on the table, with various encomiums on their rarity and excellence.

`Sitch a rabbit pie, Bill,' (gentleman)
exclaimed that young gentleman, disclosing to view a huge pasty;
`sitch delicate creeturs, with sitch tender limbs, Bill, that the wery bones melt in your mouth, and there's no occasion to pick 'em; half a pound of seven and six-penny green, so precious strong that if you mix it with biling water, it'll go nigh to blow the lid of the tea-pot off; a pound and a half of moist sugar that the niggers didn't work at all at, afore they got it up to sitch a pitch of goodness,--oh no! Two half-quartern brans; pound of best fresh; piece of double Glo`ster; and, to wind up all, some of the richest sort you ever lushed!' (gentleman)

Uttering this last panegyric, Master Bates produced, from one of his (Bates) extensive pockets, a full-sized wine-bottle, carefully corked; while Mr. Dawkins, at the same instant, poured out a wine-glassful of raw spirits from the bottle he (Dawkins) carried: which the invalid tossed down his (Dawkins) throat without a moment's hesitation.

`Ah!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, rubbing his (Fagin) hands with great satisfaction.
`You'll do, Bill; you'll do now.' (unknown)

`Do!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
exclaimed Mr. Sikes;
`I might have been done for, twenty times over, afore you'd have done anything to help me. What do you mean by leaving a man in this state, three weeks and more, you false-hearted wagabond?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Only hear him (man), boys!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, shrugging his (Fagin) shoulders.
`And us come to bring him (Fagin) all these beau-ti-ful things.' (unknown)

`The things is well enough in their way,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
observed Mr. Sikes: a little soothed as he (Sikes) glanced over the table; `but what have you got to say for yourself, why you should leave me here, down in the mouth, health, blunt, and everything else; and take no more notice of me, all this mortal time, than if I was that
`ere dog.--Drive him (Sikes) down, Charley!' (I)

`I never see such a jolly dog as that,' (Master)
cried Master Bates, doing as he (Bates) was desired.
`Smelling the grub like a old lady a going to market! He (Bates)'d make his (Bates) fortun' (dog)
on the stage that dog would, and rewive the drayma besides.'

`Hold your din,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, as the dog retreated under the bed: still growling angrily.
`What have you got to say for yourself, you withered old fence, eh?' (unknown)

`I was away from London, a week and more, my dear, on a plant,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`And what about the other fortnight?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
demanded Sikes.
`What about the other fortnight that you've left me lying here, like a sick rat in his (Sikes) hole?' (unknown)

`I couldn't help it, Bill. I can't go into a long explanation before company; but I couldn't help it, upon my honour.' (unknown)

`Upon your what?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes, with excessive disgust.
`Here! Cut me off a piece of that pie, one of you boys, to take the taste of that out of my mouth, or it'll choke me dead.' (unknown)

`Don't be out of temper, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
urged Fagin, submissively.
`I have never forgot you, Bill; never once.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`No! I'll pound it that you han't,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, with a bitter grin.
`You've been scheming and plotting away, every hour that I have laid shivering and burning here; and Bill was to do this; and Bill was to do that; and Bill was to do it all, dirt cheap, as soon as he (Bill) got well: and was quite poor enough for your work. If it hadn't been for the girl, I might have died.' (unknown)

`There now, Bill,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
