remonstrated Fagin, eagerly catching at the word.
`If it hadn't been for the girl! Who but poor ould Fagin was the means of your having such a handy girl about you?' (unknown)

`He (Fagin) says true enough there!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy, coming hastily forward.
`Let him (Fagin) be; let him (Fagin) be.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

Nancy's appearance gave a new turn to the conversation; for the boys, receiving a sly wink from the wary old Jew, began to ply her (Nancy) with liquor: of which, however, she (Nancy) took very sparingly; while Fagin, assuming an unusual flow of spirits, gradually brought Mr. Sikes into a better temper, by affecting to regard his (Sikes) threats as a little pleasant banter; and, moreover, by laughing very heartily at one or two rough jokes, which, after repeated applications to the spirit-bottle, he (Sikes) condescended to make.

`It's all very well,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Mr. Sikes;
`but I must have some blunt from you to-night.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`I haven't a piece of coin about me,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied the Jew.

`Then you've got lots at home,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
retorted Sikes;
`and I must have some from there.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Lots!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, holding up is hands.
`I haven't so much as would--' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`I don't know how much you've got, and I dare say you hardly know yourself, as it would take a pretty long time to count it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes;
`but I must have some to-night; and that's flat.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Well, well,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, with a sigh,
`I'll send the Artful round presently.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`You won't do nothing of the kind,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
rejoined Mr. Sikes.
`The Artful's a deal too artful, and would forget to come, or lose his (Sikes) way, or get dodged by traps and so be perwented, or anything for an excuse, if you put him (Sikes) up to it. Nancy shall go to the ken and fetch it, to make all sure; and I'll lie down and have a snooze while she (Nancy)'s gone.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

After a great deal of haggling and squabbling, Fagin beat down the amount of the required advance from five pounds to three pounds four and sixpence: protesting with many solemn asseverations that that would only leave him (Fagin) eighteen-pence to keep house with; Mr. Sikes sullenly remarking that if he (Sikes) couldn't get any more he (Sikes) must accompany him (Sikes) home; with the Dodger and Master Bates put the eatables in the cupboard. The Jew then, taking leave of his (Jew) affectionate friend, returned homeward, attended by Nancy and the boys: Mr. Sikes, meanwhile, flinging himself on the bed, and composing himself to sleep away the time until the young lady's return.

In due course, they arrived at Fagin's abode, where they found Toby Crackit and Mr. Chitling intent upon their fifteenth game at cribbage, which it is scarcely necessary to say the latter gentleman lost, and with it, his (gentleman) fifteenth and last sixpence: much to the amusement of his (gentleman) young friends. Mr. Crackit, apparently somewhat ashamed at being found relaxing himself with a gentleman so much his (gentleman) inferior in station and mental endowments, yawned, and inquiring after Sikes, took up his (Sikes) hat to go.

`Has nobody been, Toby?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
asked Fagin.

`Not a living leg,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
answered Mr. Crackit, pulling up his (Crackit) collar;
`it's been as dull as swipes. You ought to stand something handsome, Fagin, to recompense me for keeping house so long. Damme, I'm as flat as a juryman; and should have gone to sleep, as fast as Newgate, if I hadn't had the good natur' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
to amuse this youngster. Horrid dull, I'm blessed if I an't!'

With these and other ejaculations of the same kind, Mr. Toby Crackit swept up his (Crackit) winnings, and crammed them into his (Crackit) waistcoat pocket with a haughty air, as though such small pieces of silver were wholly beneath the consideration of a man of his (man) figure; this done, he (man) swaggered out of the room, with so much elegance and gentility, that Mr. Chitling, bestowing numerous admiring glances on his (Chitling) legs and boots till they were out of sight, assured the company that he (Chitling) considered his (Chitling) acquaintance cheap at fifteen sixpences an interview, and that he (Chitling) didn't value his (Chitling) losses the snap of his (Chitling) little finger.

`Wot a rum chap you are, Tom!' (Master Bates)
said Master Bates, highly amused by this declaration.

`Not a bit of it,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
replied Mr. Chitling.
`Am I, Fagin?' (unknown)

`A very clever fellow, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, patting him (Fagin) on the shoulder, and winking to his (Fagin) other pupils.

`And Mr. Crackit is a heavy swell; an't he (Crackit), Fagin?' (Tom/Tom White)
asked Tom.

`No doubt at all of that, my dear.' (unknown)

`And it is a creditable thing to have his (Fagin) acquaintance; an't it, Fagin?' (Tom/Tom White)
pursued Tom.

`Very much so, indeed, my dear. They're only jealous, Tom, because he (Tom) won't give it to them.' (unknown)

`Ah!' (Tom/Tom White)
cried Tom, triumphantly,
`that's where it is! He (Tom) has cleaned me out. But I can go and earn some more, when I like; can't I, Fagin?' (Tom/Tom White)

`To be sure you can, and the sooner you go the better, Tom; so make up your loss at once, and don't lose any more time. Dodger! Charley! It's time you were on the lay. Come! It's near ten, and nothing done yet.' (the boys)

In obedience to this hint, the boys, nodding to Nancy, took up their hats, and left the room; the Dodger and his (Dodger) vivacious friend indulging, as they went, in many witticisms at the expense of Mr. Chitling; in whose conduct, it is but justice to say, there was nothing very conspicuous or peculiar: inasmuch as there are a great number of spirited young bloods upon town, who pay a much higher price than Mr. Chitling for being seen in good society: and a great number of fine gentlemen -LRB-composing the good society aforesaid-RRB- who established their reputation upon very much the same footing as flash Toby Crackit.

`Now,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, when they had left the room,
`I'll go and get you that cash, Nancy. This is only the key of a little cupboard where I keep a few odd things the boys get, my dear. I never lock up my money, for I've got none to lock up, my dear--ha! ha! ha!--none to lock up. It's a poor trade, Nancy, and no thanks; but I'm fond of seeing the young people about me; and I bear it all, I bear it all. Hush!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
he (my) said, hastily concealing the key in his (my) breast;
`who's that? Listen!' (he)

The girl, who was sitting at the table with her (girl) arms folded, appeared in no way interested in the arrival: or to care whether the person, whoever he (my) was, came or went: until the murmur of a man's voice reached her (girl) ears. The instant she (girl) caught the sound, she (girl) tore off her (girl) bonnet and shawl, with the rapidity of lightning, and thrust them under the table. The Jew, turning round immediately afterwards, she (girl) muttered a complaint of the heat: in a tone of languor that contrasted, very remarkably, with the extreme haste and violence of this action: which, however, had been unobserved by Fagin, who had his (Fagin) back towards her (girl) at the time.

`Bah!' (he)
he (Fagin) whispered, as though nettled by the interruption;
`it's the man I expected before; he (man)'s coming downstairs. Not a word about the money while he (man)'s here, Nance. He (man) won't stop long. Not ten minutes, my dear.' (he)

Laying his (man) skinny forefinger upon his (man) lip, the Jew carried a candle to the door, as a man's step was heard upon the stairs without. He (man) reached it, at the same moment as the visitor, who, coming hastily into the room, was close upon the girl before he (man) observed her (girl).

It was Monks.

`Only one of my young people,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, observing that Monks drew back, on beholding a stranger.
`Don't move, Nancy.' (The girl)

The girl drew closer to the table, and glancing at Monks with an air of careless levity, withdrew her (girl) eyes; but as he (Fagin) turned towards Fagin, she (girl) stole another look; so keen and searching, and full of purpose, that if there had been any bystander to observe the change, he (bystander) could hardly have believed the two looks to have proceeded from the same person.

`Any news?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin.

`Great.' (unknown)

`And--and--good?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
asked Fagin, hesitating as though he (Fagin) feared to vex the other man by being too sanguine.

`Not bad, any way,' (Monks)
replied Monks with a smile.
`I have been prompt enough this time. Let me have a word with you.' (Monks)

The girl drew closer to the table, and made no offer to leave the room, although she (girl) could see that Monks was pointing to her (girl). The Jew: perhaps fearing she (girl) might say something aloud about the money, if he (Jew) endeavoured to get rid of her (girl): pointed upward, and took Monks out of the room.

`Not that infernal hole we were in before,' (she)
she (girl) could hear the man say as they went upstairs. Fagin laughed; and making some reply which did not reach her (girl), seemed, by the creaking of the boards, to lead his (Fagin) companion to the second story.

Before the sound of their footsteps had ceased to echo through the house, the girl had slipped off her (girl) shoes; and drawing her (girl) gown loosely over her (girl) head, and muffling her (girl) arms in it, stood at the door, listening with breathless interest. The moment the noise ceased, she (girl) glided from the room; ascended the stairs with incredible softness and silence; and was lost in the gloom above.

The room remained deserted for a quarter of an hour or more; the girl glided back with the same unearthly tread; and, immediately afterwards, the two men were heard descending. Monks went at once into the street; and the Jew crawled upstairs again for the money. When he (Jew) returned, the girl was adjusting her (girl) shawl and bonnet, as if preparing to be gone.

`Why, Nance!' (the Jew)
exclaimed the Jew, starting back as he (Nance) put down the candle,
`how pale you are!' (he)

`Pale!' (the girl)
echoed the girl, shading her (girl) eyes with her (girl) hands, as if to look steadily at him (Nance).

`Quite horrible. What have you been doing to yourself?' (unknown)

`Nothing that I know of, except sitting in this close place for I don't know how long and all,' (the girl)
replied the girl carelessly.
`Come! Let me get back; that's a dear.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

With a sigh for every piece of money, Fagin told the amount into her (girl) hand. They parted without more conversation, merely interchanging a

`good-night.' (the girl)

When the girl got into the open street, she (girl) sat down upon a doorstep; and seemed, for a few moments, wholly bewildered and unable to pursue her (girl) way. Suddenly she (girl) arose; and hurrying on, in a direction quite opposite to that in which Sikes was awaiting her (girl) returned, quickened her (girl) pace, until it gradually resolved into a violent run. After completely exhausting herself, she (girl) stopped to take breath: and, as if suddenly recollecting herself, and deploring her (girl) inability to do something she (girl) was bent upon, wrung her (girl) hands, and burst into tears.

It might be that her (girl) tears relieved her (girl), or that she (girl) felt the full hopelessness of her (girl) condition; but she (girl) turned back; and hurrying with nearly as great rapidity in the contrary direction; partly to recover lost time, and partly to keep pace with the violent current of her (girl) own thoughts: soon reached the dwelling where she (girl) had left the housebreaker.

If she (girl) betrayed any agitation, when she (girl) presented herself to Mr. Sikes, he (Sikes) did not observe it; for merely inquiring if she (girl) had brought the money, and receiving a reply in the affirmative, he (Sikes) uttered a growl of satisfaction, and replacing his (Sikes) head upon the pillow, resumed the slumbers which her (girl) arrival had interrupted.

It was fortunate for her (girl) that the possession of money occasioned him (Sikes) so much employment next day in the way of eating and drinking; and withal had so beneficial an effect in smoothing down the asperities of his (Sikes) temper; that he (Sikes) had neither time nor inclination to be very critical upon her (girl) behaviour and deportment. That she (girl) had all the abstracted and nervous manner of one who is on the eve of some bold and hazardous step, which it has required no common struggle to resolve upon, would have been obvious to the lynx-eyed Fagin, who would most probably have taken the alarm at once; but Mr. Sikes lacking the niceties of discrimination, and being troubled with no more subtle misgivings than those which resolve themselves into a dogged roughness of behaviour towards everybody; and being, furthermore, in an unusually amiable condition, as has been already observed; saw nothing unusual in her (themselves) demeanor, and indeed, troubled himself so little about her (themselves), that, had her (themselves) agitation been far more perceptible than it was, it would have been very unlikely to have awakened his (Sikes) suspicions.

As that day closed in, the girl's excitement increased; and, when night came on, and she (girl) sat by, watching until the housebreaker should drink himself asleep, there was an unusual paleness in her (girl) cheek, and a fire in her (girl) eye, that even Sikes observed with astonishment.

Mr. Sikes being weak from the fever, was lying in bed, taking hot water with his (Sikes) gin to render it less inflammatory; and had pushed his (Sikes) glass towards Nancy to be replenished for the third or fourth time, when these symptoms first struck him (Sikes).

`Why, burn my body!' (the man)
said the man, raising himself on his (man) hands as he (man) stared the girl in the face.
`You look like a corpse come to life again. What's the matter?' (unknown)

`Matter!' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`Nothing. What do you look at me so hard for?' (unknown)

`What foolery is this?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
demanded Sikes, grasping her (girl) by the arm, and shaking her (girl) roughly.
`What is it? What do you mean? What are you thinking of?' (unknown)

`Of many things, Bill,' (the girl)
replied the girl, shivering, and as she (girl) did so, pressing her (girl) hands upon her (girl) eyes.
`But, Lord! What odds in that?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

The tone of forced gaiety in which the last words were spoken, seemed to produce a deeper impression on Sikes than the wild and rigid look which had preceded them.

`I tell you wot it is,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes;
`if you haven't caught the fever, and got it comin' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
on, now, there's something more than usual in the wind, and something dangerous too. You're not a-going to--. No, damme! you wouldn't do that!'

`Do what?' (the girl)
asked the girl.

`There ain't,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, fixing his (Sikes) eyes upon her (girl), and muttering the words to himself;
`there ain't a stauncher-hearted gal going, or I'd have cut her (gal) throat three months ago. She (gal)'s got the fever coming on; that's it.' (her)

Fortifying himself with this assurance, Sikes drained the glass to the bottom, and then, with many grumbling oaths, called for his (Sikes) physic. The girl jumped up, with great alacrity; poured it quickly out, but with her (girl) back towards him (Sikes); and held the vessel to his (Sikes) lips, while he (Sikes) drank off the contents.

`Now,' (the robber)
said the robber,
`come and sit aside of me, and put on your own face; or I'll alter it so, that you won't know it agin when you do want it.' (the robber)

The girl obeyed. Sikes, locking her (girl) hand in his (Sikes), fell back upon the pillow: turning his (Sikes) eyes upon her (girl) face. They closed; opened again; closed once more; again opened. He (Sikes) shifted his (Sikes) position restlessly; and, after dozing again, and again, for two or three minutes, and as often springing up with a look of terror, and gazing vacantly about him (Sikes), was suddenly stricken, as it were, while in the very attitude of rising, into a deep and heavy sleep. The grasp of his (Sikes) hand relaxed; the upraised arm fell languidly by his (Sikes) side; and he (Sikes) lay like one in a profound trance.

`The laudanum has taken effect at last,' (the girl)
murmured the girl, as she (girl) rose from the bedside.
`I may be too late, even now.' (she)

She (girl) hastily dressed herself in her (girl) bonnet and shawl: looking fearfully round, from time to time, as if, despite the sleeping draught, she (girl) expected every moment to feel the pressure of Sikes's heavy hand upon her (girl) shoulder; then, stooping softly over the bed, she (girl) kissed the robber's lips; and then opening and closing the room-door with noiseless touch, hurried from the house.

A watchman was crying half-past nine, down a dark passage through which she (girl) had to pass, in gaining the main thoroughfare.

`Has it long gone the half-hour?' (the girl)
asked the girl.

`It'll strike the hour in another quarter,' (the man)
said the man: raising his (man) lantern to her (girl) face.

`And I cannot get there in less than an hour or more,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
muttered Nancy: brushing swiftly past him (man), and gliding rapidly down the street.

Many of the shops were already closing in the back lanes and avenues through which she (Nancy) tracked her (Nancy) way, in making from Spitalfields towards the West-End of London. The clock struck ten, increasing her (Nancy) impatience. She (Nancy) tore along the narrow pavement: elbowing the passengers from side to side; and darting almost under the horses' heads, crossed crowded streets, where clusters of persons were eagerly watching their opportunity to do the like.

`The woman is mad!' (the people)
said the people, turning to look after her (woman) as she (woman) rushed away.

When she (woman) reached the more wealthy quarter of the town, the streets were comparatively deserted; and here her (woman) headlong progress excited a still greater curiosity in the stragglers whom she (woman) hurried past. Some quickened their pace behind, as though to see whither she (woman) was hastening at such an unusual rate; and a few made head upon her (woman), and looked back, surprised at her (woman) undiminished speed; but they fell off one by one; and when she (woman) neared her (woman) place of destination, she (woman) was alone.

It was a family hotel in a quiet but handsome street near Hyde Park. As the brilliant light of the lamp which burnt before its door, guided her (woman) to the spot, the clock struck eleven. She (woman) had loitered for a few paces as though irresolute, and making up her (woman) mind to advance; but the sound determined her (woman), and she (woman) stepped into the hall. The porter's seat was vacant. She (woman) looked round with an air of incertitude, and advanced towards the stairs.

`Now, young woman!' (a female)
said a smartly-dressed female, looking out from a door behind her (female),
`who do you want here?' (her)

`A lady who is stopping in this house,' (her)
answered the girl.

`A lady!' (the girl)
was the reply, accompanied with a scornful look.
`What lady?' (unknown)

`Miss Maylie,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy.

The young woman, who had by this time, noted her (woman) appearance, replied only by a look of virtuous disdain; and summoned a man to answer her (woman). To him (man), Nancy repeated her (Nancy) request.

`What name am I to say?' (the waiter)
asked the waiter.

`It's of no use saying any,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy.

`Nor business?' (the man)
said the man.

`No, nor that neither,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.
`I must see the lady.' (the girl)

`Come!' (the man)
said the man, pushing her (lady) towards the door.
`None of this. Take yourself off.' (unknown)

`I shall be carried out if I go!' (the girl)
said the girl violently;
`and I can make that a job that two of you won't like to do. Isn't there anybody here,' (the girl)
she (girl) said, looking round,
`that will see a simple message carried for a poor wretch like me?' (she)

This appeal produced an effect on a good-tempered-faced man-cook, who with some of the other servants was looking on, and who stepped forward to interfere.

`Take it up for her (girl), Joe; can't you?' (this person)
said this person.

`What's the good?' (the man)
replied the man.
`You don't suppose the young lady will see such as her (lady); do you?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

This allusion to Nancy's doubtful character, raised a vast quantity of chaste wrath in the bosoms of four housemaids, who remarked, with great fervour, that the creature was a disgrace to her (Nancy) sex; and strongly advocated her (Nancy) being thrown, ruthlessly, into the kennel.

`Do what you like with me,' (the girl)
said the girl, turning to the men again;
`but do what I ask you first, and I ask you to give this message for God Almighty's sake.' (the men)

The soft-hearted cook added his (cook) intercession, and the result was that the man who had first appeared undertook its delivery.

`What's it to be?' (the man)
said the man, with one foot on the stairs.

`That a young woman earnestly asks to speak to Miss Maylie alone,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy;
`and that if the lady will only hear the first word she (lady) has to say, she (lady) will know whether to hear her (lady) business, or to have her (lady) turned out of doors as an impostor.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`I say,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said the man,
`you're coming it strong!' (the man)

`You give the message,' (the girl)
said the girl firmly;
`and let me hear the answer.' (the girl)

The man ran upstairs. Nancy remained, pale and almost breathless, listening with quivering lip to the very audible expressions of scorn, of which the chaste housemaids were very prolific; and of which they became still more so, when the man returned, and said the young woman was to walk upstairs.

`It's no good being proper in this world,' (the housemaid)
said the first housemaid.

`Brass can do better than the gold what has stood the fire,' (unknown)
said the second.

The third contented herself with wondering

`what ladies was made of' (unknown)
; and the fourth took the first in a quartette of
`Shameful!' (unknown)
with which the Dianas concluded.

Regardless of all this: for she (housemaid) had weightier matters at heart: Nancy followed the man, with trembling limbs, to a small ante-chamber, lighted by a lamp from the ceiling. Here he (man) left her (Nancy), and retired.

CHAPTER XL

A STRANGE INTERVIEW, WHICH IS A SEQUEL TO THE LAST CHAMBER

The girl's life had been squandered in the streets, and among the most noisome of the stews and dens of London, but there was something of the woman's original nature left in her (woman) still; and when she (woman) heard a light step approaching the door opposite to that by which she (woman) had entered, and thought of the wide contrast which the small room would in another moment contain, she (woman) felt burdened with the sense of her (woman) own deep shame, and shrunk as though she (woman) could scarcely bear the presence of her (woman) with whom she (woman) had sought this interview.

But struggling with these better feelings was pride,--the vice of the lowest and most debased creatures no less than of the high and self-assured. The miserable companion of thieves and ruffians, the fallen outcast of low haunts, the associate of the scourings of the jails and hulks, living within the shadow of the gallows itself,--even this degraded being felt too proud to betray a feeble gleam of the womanly feeling which she (woman) thought a weakness, but which alone connected her (woman) with that humanity, of which her (woman) wasting life had obliterated so many, many traces when a very child.

She (woman) raised her (woman) eyes sufficiently to observe that the figure which presented itself was that of a slight and beautiful girl; then, bending them on the ground, she (girl) tossed her (girl) head with affected carelessness as she (girl) said:

`It's a hard matter to get to see you, lady. If I had taken offence, and gone away, as many would have done, you'd have been sorry for it one day, and not without reason either.' (she)

`I am very sorry if any one has behaved harshly to you,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose.
`Do not think of that. Tell me why you wished to see me. I am the person you inquired for.' (the girl)

The kind tone of this answer, the sweet voice, the gentle manner, the absence of any accent of haughtiness or displeasure, took the girl completely by surprise, and she (girl) burst into tears.

`Oh, lady, lady!' (she)
she (lady) said, clasping her (lady) hands passionately before her (lady) face,
`if there was more like you, there would be fewer like me,--there would--there would!' (she)

`Sit down,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, earnestly.
`If you are in poverty or affliction I shall be truly glad to relieve you if I can,--I shall indeed. Sit down.' (unknown)

`Let me stand, lady,' (the girl)
said the girl, still weeping,
`and do not speak to me so kindly till you know me better. It is growing late. Is--is--that door shut?' (the girl)

`Yes,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, recoiling a few steps, as if to be nearer assistance in case she (Rose) should require it.
`Why?' (unknown)

`Because,' (the girl)
said the girl,
`I am about to put my life and the lives of others in your hands. I am the girl that dragged little Oliver back to old Fagin's on the night he (Fagin) went out from the house in Pentonville.' (the girl)

`You!' (Rose Maylie)
said Rose Maylie.

`I, lady!' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`I am the infamous creature you have heard of, that lives among the thieves, and that never from the first moment I can recollect my eyes and senses opening on London streets have known any better life, or kinder words than they have given me, so help me God! Do not mind shrinking openly from me, lady. I am younger than you would think, to look at me, but I am well used to it. The poorest women fall back, as I make my way along the crowded pavement.' (the girl)

`What dreadful things are these!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, involuntarily falling from her (Rose) strange companion.

`Thank Heaven upon your knees, dear lady,' (the girl)
cried the girl,
`that you had friends to care for and keep you in your childhood, and that you were never in the midst of cold and hunger, and riot and drunkenness, and--and--something worse than all--as I have been from my cradle. I may use the word, for the alley and the gutter were mine, as they will be my deathbed.' (the girl)

`I pity you!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, in a broken voice.
`It wrings my heart to hear you!' (unknown)

`Heaven bless you for your goodness!' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.
`If you knew what I am sometimes, you would pity me, indeed. But I have stolen away from those who would surely murder me, if they knew I had been here, to tell you what I have overheard. Do you know a man named Monks?' (unknown)

`No,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.

`He (man) knows you,' (the girl)
replied the girl;
`and knew you were here, for it was by hearing him (man) tell the place that I found you out.' (the girl)

`I never heard the name,' (the girl)
said Rose.

`Then he (man) goes by some other amongst us,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl,
`which I more than thought before. Some time ago, and soon after Oliver was put into your house on the night of the robbery, I--suspecting this man--listened to a conversation held between him (man) and Fagin in the dark. I found out, from what I heard, that Monks--the man I asked you about, you know--' (the girl)

`Yes,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose,
`I understand.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`--That Monks,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
pursued the girl,
`had seen him (man) accidently with two of our boys on the day we first lost him (man), and had known him (man) directly to be the same child that he (man) was watching for, though I couldn't make out why. A bargain was struck with Fagin, that if Oliver was got back he (Oliver) should have a certain sum; and he (Oliver) was to have more for making him (Oliver) a thief, which this Monks wanted for some purpose of his (Oliver) own.' (the girl)

`For what purpose?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
asked Rose.

`He (Oliver) caught sight of my shadow on the wall as I listened, in the hope of finding out,' (the girl people)
said the girl;
`and there are not many people besides me that could have got out of their way in time to escape discovery. But I did; and I saw him (Oliver) no more till last night.' (the girl people)

`And what occurred then?' (unknown)

`I'll tell you, lady. Last night he (Oliver) came again. Again they went upstairs, and I, wrapping myself up so that my shadow would not betray me, again listened at the door. The first words I heard Monks say were these: ``So the only proofs of the boy's identity lie at the bottom of the river, and the old hag that received them from the mother is rotting in her (mother) coffin.'' They laughed, and talked of his (boy) success in doing this; and Monks, talking on about the boy, and getting very wild, said that though he (boy) had got the young devil's money safely now, he (boy)'d rather have had it the other way; for, what a game it would have been to have brought down the boast of the father's will, by driving him (father) through every jail in town, and then hauling him (father) up for some capital felony which Fagin could easily manage, after having made a good profit of him (Fagin) besides.' (unknown)

`What is all this!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.

`The truth, lady, though it comes from my lips,' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`Then, he (Fagin) said, with oaths common enough in my ears, but strange to yours, that if he (Fagin) could gratify his (Fagin) hatred by taking the boy's life without bringing his (Fagin) own neck in danger, he (Fagin) would; but, as he (Fagin) couldn't, he (Fagin)'d be upon the watch to meet him (Fagin) at every turn in life; and if he (Fagin) took advantage of his (Fagin) birth and history, he (Fagin) might harm him (Fagin) yet. ``In short, Fagin,'' he (Fagin) says, ``Jew as you are, you never laid such snares as I'll contrive for my young brother, Oliver.''' (unknown)

`His (Oliver) brother!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
exclaimed Rose.

`Those were his (Oliver) words,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy, glancing uneasily round, as she (Nancy) had scarcely ceased to do, since she (Nancy) began to speak, for a vision of Sikes haunted her (Nancy) perpetually.
`And more. When he (Sikes) spoke of you and the other lady, and said it seemed contrived by Heaven, or the devil, against him (devil), that Oliver should come into your hands, he (Oliver) laughed, and said there was some comfort in that too, for how many thousands and hundreds of thousands of pounds would you not give, if you had them, to know who your two-legged spaniel was.' (unknown)

`You do not mean,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, turning very pale,
`to tell me that this was said in earnest?' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`He (Oliver) spoke in hard and angry earnest, if a man ever did,' (the girl)
replied the girl, shaking her (girl) head.
`He (man) is an earnest man when his (man) hatred is up. I know many who do worse things; but I'd rather listen to them all a dozen times, than to that Monks once. It is growing late, and I have to reach home without suspicion of having been on such an errand as this. I must get back quickly.' (unknown)

`But what can I do?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.
`To what use can I turn this communication without you? Back! Why do you wish to return to companions you paint in such terrible colors? If you repeat this information to a gentleman whom I can summon in an instant from the next room, you can be consigned to some place of safety without half an hour's delay.' (unknown)

`I wish to go back,' (the girl)
said the girl.
`I must go back, because--how can I tell such things to an innocent lady like you?--because among the men I have told you of, there is one: the most desperate among them all; that I can't leave: no, not even to be saved from the life I am leading now.' (the girl)

`Your having interfered in this dear boy's behalf before,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose;
`your coming here, at so great a risk, to tell me what you have heard; your manner, which convinces me of the truth of what you say; your evident contrition, and sense of shame; all lead me to believe that you might yet be reclaimed. Oh!' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said the earnest girl, folding her (girl) hands as the tears coursed down her (girl) face,
`do not turn a deaf ear to the entreaties of one of your own sex; the first--the first, I do believe, who ever appealed to you in the voice of pity and compassion. Do hear my words, and let me save you yet, for better things.' (the girl)

`Lady,' (the girl)
cried the girl, sinking on her (Lady) knees,
`dear, sweet, angel lady, you _are_ the first that ever blessed me with such words as these, and if I had heard them years ago, they might have turned me from a life of sin and sorrow; but it is too late, it is too late!' (the girl)

`It is never too late,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose,
`for penitence and atonement.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`It is,' (the girl)
cried the girl, writhing in agony of her (girl) mind;
`I cannot leave him (it) now! I could not be his (it) death.' (the girl)

`Why should you be?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
asked Rose.

`Nothing could save him (it),' (the girl)
cried the girl.
`If I told others what I have told you, and led to their being taken, he (it) would be sure to die. He (it) is the boldest, and has been so cruel!' (unknown)

`Is it possible,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
cried Rose,
`that for such a man as this, you can resign every future hope, and the certainty of immediate rescue? It is madness.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`I don't know what it is,' (the girl)
answered the girl;
`I only know that it is so, and not with me alone, but with hundreds of others as bad and wretched as myself. I must go back. Whether it is God's wrath for the wrong I have done, I do not know; but I am drawn back to him (God) through every suffering and ill usage; and I should be, I believe, if I knew that I was to die by his (God) hand at last.' (the girl)

`What am I to do?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.
`I should not let you depart from me thus.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`You should, lady, and I know you will,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl, rising.
`You will not stop my going because I have trusted in your goodness, and forced no promise from you, as I might have done.' (unknown)

`Of what use, then, is the communication you have made?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose.
`This mystery must be investigated, or how will its disclosure to me, benefit Oliver, whom you are anxious to serve?' (unknown)

`You must have some kind gentleman about you that will hear it as a secret, and advise you what to do,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.

`But where can I find you again when it is necessary?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
asked Rose.
`I do not seek to know where these dreadful people live, but where will you be walking or passing at any settled period from this time?' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`Will you promise me that you will have my secret strictly kept, and come alone, or with the only other person that knows it; and that I shall not be watched or followed?' (the girl)
asked the girl.

`I promise you solemnly,' (the girl)
answered Rose.

`Every Sunday night, from eleven until the clock strikes twelve,' (the girl)
said the girl without hesitation,
`I will walk on London Bridge if I am alive.' (the girl)

`Stay another moment,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
interposed Rose, as the girl moved hurriedly towards the door.
`Think once again on your own condition, and the opportunity you have of escaping from it. You have a claim on me: not only as the voluntary bearer of this intelligence, but as a woman lost almost beyond redemption. Will you return to this gang of robbers, and to this man, when a word can save you? What fascination is it that can take you back, and make you cling to wickedness and misery? Oh! is there no chord in your heart that I can touch! Is there nothing left, to which I can appeal against this terrible infatuation!' (unknown)

`When ladies as young, and good, and beautiful as you are,' (the girl)
replied the girl steadily,
`give away your hearts, love will carry you all lengths--even such as you, who have home, friends, other admirers, everything, to fill them. When such as I, who have no certain roof but the coffinlid, and no friend in sickness or death but the hospital nurse, set our rotten hearts on any man, and let him (man) fill the place that has been a blank through all our wretched lives, who can hope to cure us? Pity us, lady--pity us for having only one feeling of the woman left, and for having that turned, by a heavy judgment, from a comfort and a pride, into a new means of violence and suffering.' (the girl)

`You will,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, after a pause,
`take some money from me, which may enable you to live without dishonesty--at all events until we meet again?' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`Not a penny,' (the girl)
replied the girl, waving her (girl) hand.

`Do not close your heart against all my efforts to help you,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, stepping gently forward.
`I wish to serve you indeed.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`You would serve me best, lady,' (the girl)
replied the girl, wringing her (girl) hands,
`if you could take my life at once; for I have felt more grief to think of what I am, to-night, than I ever did before, and it would be something not to die in the hell in which I have lived. God bless you, sweet lady, and send as much happiness on your head as I have brought shame on mine!' (the girl)

Thus speaking, and sobbing aloud, the unhappy creature turned away; while Rose Maylie, overpowered by this extraordinary interview, which had more the semblance of a rapid dream than an actual occurrence, sank into a chair, and endeavoured to collect her (lady) wandering thoughts.

CHAPTER XLI

CONTAINING FRESH DISCOVERIES, AND SHOWING THAT SUPRISES, LIKE MISFORTUNES, SELDOM COME ALONE

Her (lady) situation was, indeed, one of no common trial and difficulty. While she (lady) felt the most eager and burning desire to penetrate the mystery in which Oliver's history was enveloped, she (lady) could not but hold sacred the confidence which the miserable woman with whom she (woman) had just conversed, had reposed in her (woman), as a young and guileless girl. Her (girl) words and manner had touched Rose Maylie's heart; and, mingled with her (girl) love for her (girl) young charge, and scarcely less intense in its truth and fervour, was her (girl) fond wish to win the outcast back to repentance and hope.

They purposed remaining in London only three days, prior to departing for some weeks to a distant part of the coast. It was now midnight of the first day. What course of action could she (girl) determine upon, which could be adopted in eight-and-forty hours? Or how could she (girl) postpone the journey without exciting suspicion?

Mr. Losberne was with them, and would be for the next two days; but Rose was too well acquainted with the excellent gentleman's impetuosity, and foresaw too clearly the wrath with which, in the first explosion of his (gentleman) indignation, he (gentleman) would regard the instrument of Oliver's recapture, to trust him (Oliver) with the secret, when her (Rose) representations in the girl's behalf could be seconded by no experienced person. These were all reasons for the greatest caution and most circumspect behaviour in communicating it to Mrs. Maylie, whose first impulse would infallibly be to hold a conference with the worthy doctor on the subject. As to resorting to any legal adviser, even if she (Maylie) had known how to do so, it was scarcely to be thought of, for the same reason. Once the thought occurred to her (Maylie) of seeking assistance from Harry; but this awakened the recollection of their last parting, and it seemed unworthy of her (Maylie) to call him (Harry) back, when--the tears rose to her (Maylie) eyes as she (Maylie) pursued this train of reflection--he (Harry) might have by this time learnt to forget her (Maylie), and to be happier away.

Disturbed by these different reflections; inclining now to one course and then to another, and again recoiling from all, as each successive consideration presented itself to her (Maylie) mind; Rose passed a sleepless and anxious night. After more communing with herself next day, she (Rose) arrived at the desperate conclusion of consulting Harry.

`If it be painful to him (Harry),' (she)
she (Rose) thought,
`to come back here, how painful it will be to me! But perhaps he (Harry) will not come; he (Harry) may write, or he (Harry) may come himself, and studiously abstain from meeting me--he (Harry) did when he (Harry) went away. I hardly thought he (Harry) would; but it was better for us both.' (she)
And here Rose dropped the pen, and turned away, as though the very paper which was to be her (Rose) messenger should not see her (Rose) weep.

She (Rose) had taken up the same pen, and laid it down again fifty times, and had considered and reconsidered the first line of her (Rose) letter without writing the first word, when Oliver, who had been walking in the streets, with Mr. Giles for a body-guard, entered the room in such breathless haste and violent agitation, as seemed to betoken some new cause of alarm.

`What makes you look so flurried?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
asked Rose, advancing to meet him (Giles).

`I hardly know how; I feel as if I should be choked,' (him)
replied the boy.
`Oh dear! To think that I should see him (boy) at last, and you should be able to know that I have told you the truth!' (unknown)

`I never thought you had told us anything but the truth,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, soothing him (boy).
`But what is this?--of whom do you speak?' (unknown)

`I have seen the gentleman,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, scarcely able to articulate,
`the gentleman who was so good to me--Mr. Brownlow, that we have so often talked about.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

`Where?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
asked Rose.

`Getting out of a coach,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
replied Oliver, shedding tears of delight,
`and going into a house. I didn't speak to him (Oliver)--I couldn't speak to him (Oliver), for he (Oliver) didn't see me, and I trembled so, that I was not able to go up to him (Oliver). But Giles asked, for me, whether he (Giles) lived there, and they said he (Giles) did. Look here,' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
said Oliver, opening a scrap of paper,
`here it is; here's where he (Oliver) lives--I'm going there directly! Oh, dear me, dear me! What shall I do when I come to see him (Oliver) and hear him (Oliver) speak again!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

With her (Oliver) attention not a little distracted by these and a great many other incoherent exclamations of joy, Rose read the address, which was Craven Street, in the Strand. She (Rose) very soon determined upon turning the discovery to account.

`Quick!' (she)
she (Rose) said.
`Tell them to fetch a hackney-coach, and be ready to go with me. I will take you there directly, without a minute's loss of time. I will only tell my aunt that we are going out for an hour, and be ready as soon as you are.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)

Oliver needed no prompting to despatch, and in little more than five minutes they were on their way to Craven Street. When they arrived there, Rose left Oliver in the coach, under pretence of preparing the old gentleman to receive him (Oliver); and sending up her (Rose) card by the servant, requested to see Mr. Brownlow on very pressing business. The servant soon returned, to beg that she (Rose) would walk upstairs; and following him (Brownlow) into an upper room, Miss Maylie was presented to an elderly gentleman of benevolent appearance, in a bottle-green coat. At no great distance from whom, was seated another old gentleman, in nankeen breeches and gaiters; who did not look particularly benevolent, and who was sitting with his (gentleman) hands clasped on the top of a thick stick, and his (gentleman) chin propped thereupon.

`Dear me,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman, in the bottle-green coat, hastily rising with great politeness,
`I beg your pardon, young lady--I imagined it was some importunate person who--I beg you will excuse me. Be seated, pray.' (the gentleman)

`Mr. Brownlow, I believe, sir?' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, glancing from the other gentleman to the one who had spoken.

`That is my name,' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
`This is my friend, Mr. Grimwig. Grimwig, will you leave us for a few minutes?' (unknown)

`I believe,' (Miss Maylie)
interposed Miss Maylie,
`that at this period of our interview, I need not give that gentleman the trouble of going away. If I am correctly informed, he (gentleman) is cognizant of the business on which I wish to speak to you.' (Miss Maylie)

Mr. Brownlow inclined his (Brownlow) head. Mr. Grimwig, who had made one very stiff bow, and risen from his (Grimwig) chair, made another very stiff bow, and dropped into it again.

`I shall surprise you very much, I have no doubt,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Rose, naturally embarrassed;
`but you once showed great benevolence and goodness to a very dear young friend of mine, and I am sure you will take an interest in hearing of him (friend) again.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`Indeed!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.

`Oliver Twist you knew him (Brownlow) as,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose.

The words no sooner escaped her (Rose) lips, than Mr. Grimwig, who had been affecting to dip into a large book that lay on the table, upset it with a great crash, and falling back in his (Grimwig) chair, discharged from his (Grimwig) features every expression but one of unmitigated wonder, and indulged in a prolonged and vacant stare; then, as if ashamed of having betrayed so much emotion, he (Grimwig) jerked himself, as it were, by a convulsion into his (Grimwig) former attitude, and looking out straight before him (Grimwig) emitted a long deep whistle, which seemed, at last, not to be discharged on empty air, but to die away in the innermost recesses of his (Grimwig) stomach.

Mr. Browlow was no less surprised, although his (Browlow) astonishment was not expressed in the same eccentric manner. He (Browlow) drew his (Browlow) chair nearer to Miss Maylie's, and said,

`Do me the favour, my dear young lady, to leave entirely out of the question that goodness and benevolence of which you speak, and of which nobody else knows anything; and if you have it in your power to produce any evidence which will alter the unfavourable opinion I was once induced to entertain of that poor child, in Heaven's name put me in possession of it.' (Miss Maylie)

`A bad one! I'll eat my head if he (Browlow) is not a bad one,' (Miss Maylie)
growled Mr. Grimwig, speaking by some ventriloquial power, without moving a muscle of his (Grimwig) face.

`He (Grimwig) is a child of a noble nature and a warm heart,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
said Rose, colouring;
`and that Power which has thought fit to try him (Grimwig) beyond his (Grimwig) years, has planted in his (Grimwig) breast affections and feelings which would do honour to many who have numbered his (Grimwig) days six times over.' (Rose/Miss Rose)

`I'm only sixty-one,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
said Mr. Grimwig, with the same rigid face.
`And, as the devil's in it if this Oliver is not twelve years old at least, I don't see the application of that remark.' (unknown)

`Do not heed my friend, Miss Maylie,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`he (Brownlow) does not mean what he (Brownlow) says.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Yes, he (Brownlow) does,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
growled Mr. Grimwig.

`No, he (Grimwig) does not,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, obviously rising in wrath as he (Brownlow) spoke.

`He (Brownlow)'ll eat his (Brownlow) head, if he (Brownlow) doesn't,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
growled Mr. Grimwig.

`He (Grimwig) would deserve to have it knocked off, if he (Grimwig) does,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.

`And he (Brownlow)'d uncommonly like to see any man offer to do it,' (Mr. Grimwig/Grimwig/MR. GRIMWIG)
responded Mr. Grimwig, knocking his (Grimwig) stick upon the floor.

Having gone thus far, the two old gentlemen severally took snuff, and afterwards shook hands, according to their invariable custom.

`Now, Miss Maylie,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow,
`to return to the subject in which your humanity is so much interested. Will you let me know what intelligence you have of this poor child: allowing me to promise that I exhausted every means in my power of discovering him (Brownlow), and that since I have been absent from this country, my first impression that he (Brownlow) had imposed upon me, and had been persuaded by his (Brownlow) former associates to rob me, has been considerably shaken.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Rose, who had had time to collect her (Rose) thoughts, at once related, in a few natural words, all that had befallen Oliver since he (Oliver) left Mr. Brownlow's house; reserving Nancy's information for that gentleman's private ear, and concluding with the assurance that his (Brownlow) only sorrow, for some months past, had been not being able to meet with his (Brownlow) former benefactor and friend.

`Thank God!' (the gentleman)
said the old gentleman.
`This is great happiness to me, great happiness. But you have not told me where he (gentleman) is now, Miss Maylie. You must pardon my finding fault with you,--but why not have brought him (gentleman)?' (unknown)

`He (gentleman) is waiting in a coach at the door,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose.

`At this door!' (the gentleman)
cried the old gentleman. With which he (gentleman) hurried out of the room, down the stairs, up the coachsteps, and into the coach, without another word.

When the room-door closed behind him (coach), Mr. Grimwig lifted up his (Grimwig) head, and converting one of the hind legs of his (Grimwig) chair into a pivot, described three distinct circles with the assistance of his (Grimwig) stick and the table; sitting in it all the time. After performing this evolution, he (Grimwig) rose and limped as fast as he (Grimwig) could up and down the room at least a dozen times, and then stopping suddenly before Rose, kissed her (Rose) without the slightest preface.

`Hush!' (he)
he (Grimwig) said, as the young lady rose in some alarm at this unusual proceeding.
`Don't be afraid. I'm old enough to be your grandfather. You're a sweet girl. I like you. Here they are!' (he)

In fact, as he (grandfather) threw himself at one dexterous dive into his (grandfather) former seat, Mr. Brownlow returned, accompanied by Oliver, whom Mr. Grimwig received very graciously; and if the gratification of that moment had been the only reward for all her (girl) anxiety and care in Oliver's behalf, Rose Maylie would have been well repaid.

`There is somebody else who should not be forgotten, by the bye,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, ringing the bell.
`Send Mrs. Bedwin here, if you please.' (The housekeeper)

The old housekeeper answered the summons with all dispatch; and dropping a curtsey at the door, waited for orders.

`Why, you get blinder every day, Bedwin,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, rather testily.

`Well, that I do, sir,' (the lady)
replied the old lady.
`People's eyes, at my time of life, don't improve with age, sir.' (unknown)

`I could have told you that,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
rejoined Mr. Brownlow;
`but put on your glasses, and see if you can't find out what you were wanted for, will you?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

The old lady began to rummage in her (lady) pocket for her (lady) spectacles. But Oliver's patience was not proof against this new trial; and yielding to his (Oliver) first impulse, he (Oliver) sprang into her (lady) arms.

`God be good to me!' (the lady)
cried the old lady, embracing him (God);
`it is my innocent boy!' (him)

`My dear old nurse!' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
cried Oliver.

`He (Oliver) would come back--I knew he (Oliver) would,' (the lady)
said the old lady, holding him (Oliver) in her (lady) arms.
`How well he (Oliver) looks, and how like a gentleman's son he (Oliver) is dressed again! Where have you been, this long, long while? Ah! the same sweet face, but not so pale; the same soft eye, but not so sad. I have never forgotten them or his (Oliver) quiet smile, but have seen them every day, side by side with those of my own dear children, dead and gone since I was a lightsome young creature.' (Oliver/Oliver Twist/OLIVER)
Running on thus, and now holding Oliver from her (Oliver) to mark how he (Oliver) had grown, now clasping him (Oliver) to her (Oliver) and passing her (Oliver) fingers fondly through his (Oliver) hair, the good soul laughed and wept upon his (Oliver) neck by turns.

Leaving her (Oliver) and Oliver to compare notes at leisure, Mr. Brownlow led the way into another room; and there, heard from Rose a full narration of her (Rose) interview with Nancy, which occasioned him (Brownlow) no little surprise and perplexity. Rose also explained her (Rose) reasons for not confiding in her (Rose) friend Mr. Losberne in the first instance. The old gentleman considered that she (Rose) had acted prudently, and readily undertook to hold solemn conference with the worthy doctor himself. To afford him (doctor) an early opportunity for the execution of this design, it was arranged that he (doctor) should call at the hotel at eight o'clock that evening, and that in the meantime Mrs. Maylie should be cautiously informed of all that had occurred. These preliminaries adjusted, Rose and Oliver returned home.

Rose had by no means overrated the measure of the good doctor's wrath. Nancy's history was no sooner unfolded to him (Rose), than he (Rose) poured forth a shower of mingled threats and execrations; threatened to make her (Nancy) the first victim of the combined ingenuity of Messrs. Blathers and Duff; and actually put on his (Duff) hat preparatory to sallying forth to obtain the assistance of those worthies. And, doubtless, he (Duff) would, in this first outbreak, have carried the intention into effect without a moment's consideration of the consequences, if he (Duff) had not been restrained, in part, by corresponding violence on the side of Mr. Brownlow, who was himself of an irascible temperament, and party by such arguments and representations as seemed best calculated to dissuade him (Brownlow) from his (Brownlow) hotbrained purpose.

`Then what the devil is to be done?' (the doctor)
said the impetuous doctor, when they had rejoined the two ladies.
`Are we to pass a vote of thanks to all these vagabonds, male and female, and beg them to accept a hundred pounds, or so, apiece, as a trifling mark of our esteem, and some slight acknowledgment of their kindness to Oliver?' (unknown)

`Not exactly that,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
rejoined Mr. Brownlow, laughing;
`but we must proceed gently and with great care.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Gentleness and care,' (the doctor)
exclaimed the doctor.
`I'd send them one and all to--' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Never mind where,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
interposed Mr. Brownlow.
`But reflect whether sending them anywhere is likely to attain the object we have in view.' (unknown)

`What object?' (the doctor)
asked the doctor.

`Simply, the discovery of Oliver's parentage, and regaining for him (Oliver) the inheritance of which, if this story be true, he (Oliver) has been fraudulently deprived.' (unknown)

`Ah!' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
said Mr. Losberne, cooling himself with his (Losberne) pocket-handkerchief;
`I almost forgot that.' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

`You see,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
pursued Mr. Brownlow;
`placing this poor girl entirely out of the question, and supposing it were possible to bring these scoundrels to justice without compromising her (girl) safety, what good should we bring about?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Hanging a few of them at least, in all probability,' (the doctor)
suggested the doctor,
`and transporting the rest.' (the doctor)

`Very good,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow, smiling;
`but no doubt they will bring that about for themselves in the fulness of time, and if we step in to forestall them, it seems to me that we shall be performing a very Quixotic act, in direct opposition to our own interest--or at least to Oliver's, which is the same thing.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`How?' (the doctor)
inquired the doctor.

`Thus. It is quite clear that we shall have extreme difficulty in getting to the bottom of this mystery, unless we can bring this man, Monks, upon his (man) knees. That can only be done by stratagem, and by catching him (man) when he (man) is not surrounded by these people. For, suppose he (man) were apprehended, we have no proof against him (man). He (man) is not even -LRB-so far as we know, or as the facts appear to us-RRB- concerned with the gang in any of their robberies. If he (man) were not discharged, it is very unlikely that he (man) could receive any further punishment than being committed to prison as a rogue and vagabond; and of course ever afterwards his (man) mouth would be so obstinately closed that he (man) might as well, for our purposes, be deaf, dumb, blind, and an idiot.' (unknown)

`Then,' (the doctor)
said the doctor impetuously,
`I put it to you again, whether you think it reasonable that this promise to the girl should be considered binding; a promise made with the best and kindest intentions, but really--' (the doctor)

`Do not discuss the point, my dear young lady, pray,' (the doctor)
said Mr. Brownlow, interrupting Rose as she (Rose) was about to speak.
`The promise shall be kept. I don't think it will, in the slightest degree, interfere with our proceedings. But, before we can resolve upon any precise course of action, it will be necessary to see the girl; to ascertain from her (girl) whether she (girl) will point out this Monks, on the understanding that he (Brownlow) is to be dealt with by us, and not by the law; or, if she (girl) will not, or cannot do that, to procure from her (girl) such an account of his (Brownlow) haunts and description of his (Brownlow) person, as will enable us to identify him (Brownlow). She (girl) cannot be seen until next Sunday night; this is Tuesday. I would suggest that in the meantime, we remain perfectly quiet, and keep these matters secret even from Oliver himself.' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

Although Mr. Losberne received with many wry faces a proposal involving a delay of five whole days, he (Losberne) was fain to admit that no better course occurred to him (Losberne) just then; and as both Rose and Mrs. Maylie sided very strongly with Mr. Brownlow, that gentleman's proposition was carried unanimously.

`I should like,' (gentleman)
he (Brownlow) said,
`to call in the aid of my friend Grimwig. He (Grimwig) is a strange creature, but a shrewd one, and might prove of material assistance to us; I should say that he (Grimwig) was bred a lawyer, and quitted the Bar in disgust because he (Grimwig) had only one brief and a motion of course, in twenty years, though whether that is recommendation or not, you must determine for yourselves.' (he)

`I have no objection to your calling in your friend if I may call in mine,' (the doctor)
said the doctor.

`We must put it to the vote,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow,
`who may he (Brownlow) be?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`That lady's son, and this young lady's--very old friend,' (the doctor)
said the doctor, motioning towards Mrs. Maylie, and concluding with an expressive glance at her (Maylie) niece.

Rose blushed deeply, but she (Rose) did not make any audible objection to this motion -LRB-possibly she (Rose) felt in a hopeless minority-RRB-; and Harry Maylie and Mr. Grimwig were accordingly added to the committee.

`We stay in town, of course,' (Mrs. Maylie)
said Mrs. Maylie,
`while there remains the slightest prospect of prosecuting this inquiry with a chance of success. I will spare neither trouble nor expense in behalf of the object in which we are all so deeply interested, and I am content to remain here, if it be for twelve months, so long as you assure me that any hope remains.' (Mrs. Maylie)

`Good!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
rejoined Mr. Brownlow.
`And as I see on the faces about me, a disposition to inquire how it happened that I was not in the way to corroborate Oliver's tale, and had so suddenly left the kingdom, let me stipulate that I shall be asked no questions until such time as I may deem it expedient to forestall them by telling my own story. Believe me, I make this request with good reason, for I might otherwise excite hopes destined never to be realised, and only increase difficulties and disappointments already quite numerous enough. Come! Supper has been announced, and young Oliver, who is all alone in the next room, will have begun to think, by this time, that we have wearied of his (Oliver) company, and entered into some dark conspiracy to thrust him (Oliver) forth upon the world.' (the gentleman)

With these words, the old gentleman gave his (gentleman) hand to Mrs. Maylie, and escorted her (Maylie) into the supper-room. Mr. Losberne followed, leading Rose; and the council was, for the present, effectually broken up.

CHAPTER XLII

AN OLD ACQUAINTANCE OF OLIVER'S, EXHIBITING DECIDED MARKS OF GENIUS, BECOMES A PUBLIC CHARACTER IN THE METROPOLIS

Upon the night when Nancy, having lulled Mr. Sikes to sleep, hurried on her (Nancy) self-imposed mission to Rose Maylie, there advanced towards London, by the Great North Road, two persons, upon whom it is expedient that this history should bestow some attention.

They were a man and woman; or perhaps they would be better described as a male and female: for the former was one of those long-limbed, knock-kneed, shambling, bony people, to whom it is difficult to assign any precise age,--looking as they do, when they are yet boys, like undergrown men, and when they are almost men, like overgrown boys. The woman was young, but of a robust and hardy make, as she (woman) need have been to bear the weight of the heavy bundle which was strapped to her (woman) back. Her (woman) companion was not encumbered with much luggage, as there merely dangled from a stick which he (companion) carried over his (companion) shoulder, a small parcel wrapped in a common handkerchief, and apparently light enough. This circumstance, added to the length of his (companion) legs, which were of unusual extent, enabled him (companion) with much ease to keep some half-dozen paces in advance of his (companion) companion, to whom he (companion) occasionally turned with an impatient jerk of the head: as if reproaching her (woman) tardiness, and urging her (woman) to greater exertion.

Thus, they had toiled along the dusty road, taking little heed of any object within sight, save when they stepped aside to allow a wider passage for the mail-coaches which were whirling out of town, until they passed through Highgate archway; when the foremost traveller stopped and called impatiently to his (traveller) companion,

`Come on, can't yer? What a lazybones yer are, Charlotte.' (companion)

`It's a heavy load, I can tell you,' (the female)
said the female, coming up, almost breathless with fatigue.

`Heavy! What are yer talking about? What are yer made for?' (the traveller)
rejoined the male traveller, changing his (traveller) own little bundle as he (traveller) spoke, to the other shoulder.
`Oh, there yer are, resting again! Well, if yer ain't enough to tire anybody's patience out, I don't know what is!' (unknown)

`Is it much farther?' (the woman)
asked the woman, resting herself against a bank, and looking up with the perspiration streaming from her (woman) face.

`Much farther! Yer as good as there,' (him)
said the long-legged tramper, pointing out before him (traveller).
`Look there! Those are the lights of London.' (unknown)

`They're a good two mile off, at least,' (the woman)
said the woman despondingly.

`Never mind whether they're two mile off, or twenty,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah Claypole; for he (Claypole) it was;
`but get up and come on, or I'll kick yer, and so I give yer notice.' (he)

As Noah's red nose grew redder with anger, and as he (Noah) crossed the road while speaking, as if fully prepared to put his (Noah) threat into execution, the woman rose without any further remark, and trudged onward by his (Noah) side.

`Where do you mean to stop for the night, Noah?' (she)
she (woman) asked, after they had walked a few hundred yards.

`How should I know?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah, whose temper had been considerably impaired by walking.

`Near, I hope,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.

`No, not near,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Mr. Claypole.
`There! Not near; so don't think it.' (unknown)

`Why not?' (unknown)

`When I tell yer that I don't mean to do a thing, that's enough, without any why or because either,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Mr. Claypole with dignity.

`Well, you needn't be so cross,' (companion)
said his (Claypole) companion.

`A pretty thing it would be, wouldn't it to go and stop at the very first public-house outside the town, so that Sowerberry, if he (Sowerberry) come up after us, might poke in his (Sowerberry) old nose, and have us taken back in a cart with handcuffs on,' (companion)
said Mr. Claypole in a jeering tone. `No! I shall go and lose myself among the narrowest streets I can find, and not stop till we come to the very out-of-the-wayest house I can set eyes on.
`Cod, yer may thanks yer stars I've got a head; for if we hadn't gone, at first, the wrong road a purpose, and come back across country, yer'd have been locked up hard and fast a week ago, my lady. And serve yer right for being a fool.' (unknown)

`I know I ain't as cunning as you are,' (Charlotte)
replied Charlotte;
`but don't put all the blame on me, and say I should have been locked up. You would have been if I had been, any way.' (Charlotte)

`Yer took the money from the till, yer know yer did,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Mr. Claypole.

`I took it for you, Noah, dear,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
rejoined Charlotte.

`Did I keep it?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Mr. Claypole.

`No; you trusted in me, and let me carry it like a dear, and so you are,' (the lady)
said the lady, chucking him (Claypole) under the chin, and drawing her (lady) arm through his (Claypole).

This was indeed the case; but as it was not Mr. Claypole's habit to repose a blind and foolish confidence in anybody, it should be observed, in justice to that gentleman, that he (gentleman) had trusted Charlotte to this extent, in order that, if they were pursued, the money might be found on her (Charlotte): which would leave him (gentleman) an opportunity of asserting his (gentleman) innocence of any theft, and would greatly facilitate his (gentleman) chances of escape. Of course, he (gentleman) entered at this juncture, into no explanation of his (gentleman) motives, and they walked on very lovingly together.

In pursuance of this cautious plan, Mr. Claypole went on, without halting, until he (Claypole) arrived at the Angel at Islington, where he (Claypole) wisely judged, from the crowd of passengers and numbers of vehicles, that London began in earnest. Just pausing to observe which appeared the most crowded streets, and consequently the most to be avoided, he (Claypole) crossed into Saint John's Road, and was soon deep in the obscurity of the intricate and dirty ways, which, lying between Gray's Inn Lane and Smithfield, render that part of the town one of the lowest and worst that improvement has left in the midst of London.

Through these streets, Noah Claypole walked, dragging Charlotte after him (Claypole); now stepping into the kennel to embrace at a glance the whole external character of some small public-house; now jogging on again, as some fancied appearance induced him (Claypole) to believe it too public for his (Claypole) purpose. At length, he (Claypole) stopped in front of one, more humble in appearance and more dirty than any he (Claypole) had yet seen; and, having crossed over and surveyed it from the opposite pavement, graciously announced his (Claypole) intention of putting up there, for the night.

`So give us the bundle,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, unstrapping it from the woman's shoulders, and slinging it over his (Noah) own;
`and don't yer speak, except when yer spoke to. What's the name of the house--t-h-r--three what?' (the woman)

`Cripples,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.

`Three Cripples,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
repeated Noah,
`and a very good sign too. Now, then! Keep close at my heels, and come along.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
With these injunctions, he (Noah) pushed the rattling door with his (Noah) shoulder, and entered the house, followed by his (Noah) companion.

There was nobody in the bar but a young Jew, who, with his (Noah) two elbows on the counter, was reading a dirty newspaper. He (Noah) stared very hard at Noah, and Noah stared very hard at him (Noah).

If Noah had been attired in his (Noah) charity-boy's dress, there might have been some reason for the Jew opening his (Jew) eyes so wide; but as he (Jew) had discarded the coat and badge, and wore a short smock-frock over his (Jew) leathers, there seemed no particular reason for his (Jew) appearance exciting so much attention in a public-house.

`Is this the Three Cripples?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah.

`That is the dabe of this

`ouse,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew.

`A gentleman we met on the road, coming up from the country, recommended us here,' (the Jew)
said Noah, nudging Charlotte, perhaps to call her (Charlotte) attention to this most ingenious device for attracting respect, and perhaps to warn her (Charlotte) to betray no surprise.
`We want to sleep here to-night.' (unknown)

`I' (Barney)
b dot certaid you cad,' said Barney, who was the attendant sprite;
`but I'll idquire.' (Barney)

`Show us the tap, and give us a bit of cold meat and a drop of beer while yer inquiring, will yer?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.

Barney complied by ushering them into a small back-room, and setting the required viands before them; having done which, he (Noah) informed the travellers that they could be lodged that night, and left the amiable couple to their refreshment.

Now, this back-room was immediately behind the bar, and some steps lower, so that any person connected with the house, undrawing a small curtain which concealed a single pane of glass fixed in the wall of the last-named apartment, about five feet from its flooring, could not only look down upon any guests in the back-room without any great hazard of being observed -LRB-the glass being in a dark angle of the wall, between which and a large upright beam the observer had to thrust himself-RRB-, but could, by applying his (himself) ear to the partition, ascertain with tolerable distinctness, their subject of conversation. The landlord of the house had not withdrawn his (himself) eye from this place of espial for five minutes, and Barney had only just returned from making the communication above related, when Fagin, in the course of his (Fagin) evening's business, came into the bar to inquire after some of his (Fagin) young pupils.

`Hush!' (Barney)
said Barney:
`stradegers id the next roob.' (Barney)

`Strangers!' (the man)
repeated the old man in a whisper.

`Ah! Ad rub uds too,' (Barney)
added Barney.
`Frob the cuttry, but subthig in your way, or I' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
b bistaked.'

Fagin appeared to receive this communication with great interest.

Mounting a stool, he (Fagin) cautiously applied his (Fagin) eye to the pane of glass, from which secret post he (Fagin) could see Mr. Claypole taking cold beef from the dish, and porter from the pot, and administering homeopathic doses of both to Charlotte, who sat patiently by, eating and drinking at his (Claypole) pleasure.

`Aha!' (he)
he (Claypole) whispered, looking round to Barney,
`I like that fellow's looks. He (Barney)'d be of use to us; he (Barney) knows how to train the girl already. Don't make as much noise as a mouse, my dear, and let me hear 'em talk--let me hear 'em.' (Barney)

He (Barney) again applied his (Barney) eye to the glass, and turning his (Barney) ear to the partition, listened attentively: with a subtle and eager look upon his (Barney) face, that might have appertained to some old goblin.

`So I mean to be a gentleman,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Mr. Claypole, kicking out his (Claypole) legs, and continuing a conversation, the commencement of which Fagin had arrived too late to hear.
`No more jolly old coffins, Charlotte, but a gentleman's life for me: and, if yer like, yer shall be a lady.' (unknown)

`I should like that well enough, dear,' (Charlotte)
replied Charlotte;
`but tills ain't to be emptied every day, and people to get clear off after it.' (Charlotte)

'Tills be blowed!' said Mr. Claypole;

`there's more things besides tills to be emptied.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`What do you mean?' (companion)
asked his (Claypole) companion.

`Pockets, women's ridicules, houses, mail-coaches, banks!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Mr. Claypole, rising with the porter.

`But you can't do all that, dear,' (Charlotte)
said Charlotte.

`I shall look out to get into company with them as can,' (Charlotte)
replied Noah.
`They'll be able to make us useful some way or another. Why, you yourself are worth fifty women; I never see such a precious sly and deceitful creetur as yer can be when I let yer.' (unknown)

`Lor, how nice it is to hear yer say so!' (Charlotte)
exclaimed Charlotte, imprinting a kiss upon his (Noah) ugly face.

`There, that'll do: don't yer be too affectionate, in case I'm cross with yer,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, disengaging himself with great gravity.
`I should like to be the captain of some band, and have the whopping of 'em, and follering 'em about, unbeknown to themselves. That would suit me, if there was good profit; and if we could only get in with some gentleman of this sort, I say it would be cheap at that twenty-pound note you've got,--especially as we don't very well know how to get rid of it ourselves.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

After expressing this opinion, Mr. Claypole looked into the porter-pot with an aspect of deep wisdom; and having well shaken its contents, nodded condescendingly to Charlotte, and took a draught, wherewith he (Claypole) appeared greatly refreshed. He (Claypole) was meditating another, when the sudden opening of the door, and the appearance of a stranger, interrupted him (stranger).

The stranger was Mr. Fagin. And very amiable he (Fagin) looked, and a very low bow he (Fagin) made, as he (Fagin) advanced, and setting himself down at the nearest table, ordered something to drink of the grinning Barney.

`A pleasant night, sir, but cool for the time of year,' (Barney)
said Fagin, rubbing his (Fagin) hands.
`From the country, I see, sir?' (unknown)

`How do yer see that?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah Claypole.

`We have not so much dust as that in London,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, pointing from Noah's shoes to those of his (Fagin) companion, and from them to the two bundles.

`Yer a sharp feller,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.
`Ha! ha! only hear that, Charlotte!' (unknown)

`Why, one need be sharp in this town, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew, sinking his (Jew) voice to a confidential whisper;
`and that's the truth.' (the Jew)

Fagin followed up this remark by striking the side of his (Fagin) nose with his (Fagin) right forefinger,--a gesture which Noah attempted to imitate, though not with complete success, in consequence of his (Noah) own nose not being large enough for the purpose. However, Mr. Fagin seemed to interpret the endeavour as expressing a perfect coincidence with his (Fagin) opinion, and put about the liquor which Barney reappeared with, in a very friendly manner.

`Good stuff that,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
observed Mr. Claypole, smacking his (Claypole) lips.

`Dear!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`A man need be always emptying a till, or a pocket, or a woman's reticule, or a house, or a mail-coach, or a bank, if he (Fagin) drinks it regularly.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Mr. Claypole no sooner heard this extract from his (Claypole) own remarks than he (Claypole) fell back in his (Claypole) chair, and looked from the Jew to Charlotte with a countenance of ashy paleness and excessive terror.

`Don't mind me, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, drawing his (Fagin) chair closer.
`Ha! ha! it was lucky it was only me that heard you by chance. It was very lucky it was only me.' (unknown)

`I didn't take it,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
stammered Noah, no longer stretching out his (Noah) legs like an independent gentleman, but coiling them up as well as he (Noah) could under his (Noah) chair;
`it was all her (Charlotte) doing; yer've got it now, Charlotte, yer know yer have.' (he)

`No matter who's got it, or who did it, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, glancing, nevertheless, with a hawk's eye at the girl and the two bundles.
`I'm in that way myself, and I like you for it.' (unknown)

`In what way?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Mr. Claypole, a little recovering.

`In that way of business,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Fagin;
`and so are the people of the house. You've hit the right nail upon the head, and are as safe here as you could be. There is not a safer place in all this town than is the Cripples; that is, when I like to make it so. And I have taken a fancy to you and the young woman; so I've said the word, and you may make your minds easy.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Noah Claypole's mind might have been at ease after this assurance, but his (Claypole) body certainly was not; for he (Claypole) shuffled and writhed about, into various uncouth positions: eyeing his (Claypole) new friend meanwhile with mingled fear and suspicion.

`I'll tell you more,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, after he (Fagin) had reassured the girl, by dint of friendly nods and muttered encouragements.
