`I have got a friend that I think can gratify your darling wish, and put you in the right way, where you can take whatever department of the business you think will suit you best at first, and be taught all the others.' (the girl)

`Yer speak as if yer were in earnest,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.

`What advantage would it be to me to be anything else?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
inquired Fagin, shrugging his (Fagin) shoulders.
`Here! Let me have a word with you outside.' (unknown)

`There's no occasion to trouble ourselves to move,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, getting his (Noah) legs by gradual degrees abroad again.
`She (Noah)'ll take the luggage upstairs the while. Charlotte, see to them bundles.' (unknown)

This mandate, which had been delivered with great majesty, was obeyed without the slightest demur; and Charlotte made the best of her (Charlotte) way off with the packages while Noah held the door open and watched her (Charlotte) out.

`She (Charlotte)'s kept tolerably well under, ain't she (Charlotte)?' (he)
he (Noah) asked as he (Noah) resumed his (Noah) seat: in the tone of a keeper who had tamed some wild animal.

`Quite perfect,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Fagin, clapping him (Fagin) on the shoulder.
`You're a genius, my dear.' (unknown)

`Why, I suppose if I wasn't, I shouldn't be here,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`But, I say, she (Charlotte)'ll be back if yer lose time.' (unknown)

`Now, what do you think?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`If you was to like my friend, could you do better than join him (Fagin)?' (unknown)

`Is he (Fagin) in a good way of business; that's where it is!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
responded Noah, winking one of his (Noah) little eyes.

`The top of the tree; employs a power of hands; has the very best society in the profession.' (unknown)

`Regular town-maders?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Mr. Claypole.

`Not a countryman among 'em; and I don't think he (Claypole)'d take you, even on my recommendation, if he (Claypole) didn't run rather short of assistants just now,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin.

`Should I have to hand over?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, slapping his (Noah) breeches-pocket.

`It couldn't possibly be done without,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, in a most decided manner.

`Twenty pound, though--it's a lot of money!' (unknown)

`Not when it's in a note you can't get rid of,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
retorted Fagin.
`Number and date taken, I suppose? Payment stopped at the Bank? Ah! It's not worth much to him (Fagin). It'll have to go abroad, and he (Fagin) couldn't sell it for a great deal in the market.' (unknown)

`When could I see him (Fagin)?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah doubtfully.

`To-morrow morning.' (unknown)

`Where?' (unknown)

`Here.' (unknown)

`Um!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.
`What's the wages?' (unknown)

`Live like a gentleman--board and lodging, pipes and spirits free--half of all you earn, and half of all the young woman earns,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Mr. Fagin.

Whether Noah Claypole, whose rapacity was none of the least comprehensive, would have acceded even to these glowing terms, had he (Fagin) been a perfectly free agent, is very doubtful; but as he (Fagin) recollected that, in the event of his (Fagin) refusal, it was in the power of his (Fagin) new acquaintance to give him (Fagin) up to justice immediately -LRB-and more unlikely things had come to pass-RRB-, he (Fagin) gradually relented, and said he (Fagin) thought that would suit him (Fagin).

`But, yer see,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
observed Noah,
`as she (Claypole) will be able to do a good deal, I should like to take something very light.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`A little fancy work?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
suggested Fagin.

`Ah! something of that sort,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`What do you think would suit me now? Something not too trying for the strength, and not very dangerous, you know. That's the sort of thing!' (unknown)

`I heard you talk of something in the spy way upon the others, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`My friend wants somebody who would do that well, very much.' (unknown)

`Why, I did mention that, and I shouldn't mind turning my hand to it sometimes,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
rejoined Mr. Claypole slowly;
`but it wouldn't pay by itself, you know.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`That's true!' (the Jew)
observed the Jew, ruminating or pretending to ruminate.
`No, it might not.' (unknown)

`What do you think, then?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah, anxiously regarding him (Noah).
`Something in the sneaking way, where it was pretty sure work, and not much more risk than being at home.' (unknown)

`What do you think of the old ladies?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
asked Fagin.
`There's a good deal of money made in snatching their bags and parcels, and running round the corner.' (unknown)

`Don't they holler out a good deal, and scratch sometimes?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah, shaking his (Noah) head.
`I don't think that would answer my purpose. Ain't there any other line open?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`Stop!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, laying his (Fagin) hand on Noah's knee.
`The kinchin lay.' (unknown)

`What's that?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
demanded Mr. Claypole.

`The kinchins, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin,
`is the young children that's sent on errands by their mothers, with sixpences and shillings; and the lay is just to take their money away--they've always got it ready in their hands,--then knock 'em into the kennel, and walk off very slow, as if there were nothing else the matter but a child fallen down and hurt itself. Ha! ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Ha! ha!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
roared Mr. Claypole, kicking up his (Claypole) legs in an ecstasy.
`Lord, that's the very thing!' (unknown)

`To be sure it is,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin;
`and you can have a few good beats chalked out in Camden Town, and Battle Bridge, and neighborhoods like that, where they're always going errands; and you can upset as many kinchins as you want, any hour in the day. Ha! ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

With this, Fagin poked Mr. Claypole in the side, and they joined in a burst of laughter both long and loud.

`Well, that's all right!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, when he (Noah) had recovered himself, and Charlotte had returned.
`What time to-morrow shall we say?' (unknown)

`Will ten do?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
asked Fagin, adding, as Mr. Claypole nodded assent,
`What name shall I tell my good friend.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`Mr. Bolter,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah, who had prepared himself for such emergency.
`Mr. Morris Bolter. This is Mrs. Bolter.' (unknown)

`Mrs. Bolter's humble servant,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, bowing with grotesque politeness.
`I hope I shall know her (Bolter) better very shortly.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Do you hear the gentleman, Charlotte?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
thundered Mr. Claypole.

`Yes, Noah, dear!' (Mrs. Bolter)
replied Mrs. Bolter, extending her (Bolter) hand.

`She (Bolter) calls me Noah, as a sort of fond way of talking,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
said Mr. Morris Bolter, late Claypole, turning to Fagin.
`You understand?' (unknown)

`Oh yes, I understand--perfectly,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, telling the truth for once.
`Good-night! Good-night!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

With many adieus and good wishes, Mr. Fagin went his (Fagin) way. Noah Claypole, bespeaking his (Claypole) good lady's attention, proceeded to enlighten her (lady) relative to the arrangement he (Claypole) had made, with all that haughtiness and air of superiority, becoming, not only a member of the sterner sex, but a gentleman who appreciated the dignity of a special appointment on the kinchin lay, in London and its vicinity.

CHAPTER XLIII

WHEREIN IS SHOWN HOW THE ARTFUL DODGER GOT INTO TROUBLE

`And so it was you that was your own friend, was it?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Mr. Claypole, otherwise Bolter, when, by virtue of the compact entered into between them, he (Claypole) had removed next day to Fagin's house. ''Cod, I thought as much last night!'

`Every man's his (man) own friend, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, with his (Fagin) most insinuating grin.
`He (Fagin) hasn't as good a one as himself anywhere.' (unknown)

`Except sometimes,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
replied Morris Bolter, assuming the air of a man of the world.
`Some people are nobody's enemies but their own, yer know.' (unknown)

`Don't believe that,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`When a man's his (Fagin) own enemy, it's only because he (Fagin)'s too much his (Fagin) own friend; not because he (Fagin)'s careful for everybody but himself. Pooh! pooh! There ain't such a thing in nature.' (unknown)

`There oughn't to be, if there is,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
replied Mr. Bolter.

`That stands to reason. Some conjurers say that number three is the magic number, and some say number seven. It's neither, my friend, neither. It's number one.

`Ha! ha!' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
cried Mr. Bolter.
`Number one for ever.' (unknown)

`In a little community like ours, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, who felt it necessary to qualify this position,
`we have a general number one, without considering me too as the same, and all the other young people.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Oh, the devil!' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
exclaimed Mr. Bolter.

`You see,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
pursued Fagin, affecting to disregard this interruption,
`we are so mixed up together, and identified in our interests, that it must be so. For instance, it's your object to take care of number one--meaning yourself.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Certainly,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
replied Mr. Bolter.
`Yer about right there.' (unknown)

`Well! You can't take care of yourself, number one, without taking care of me, number one.' (unknown)

`Number two, you mean,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
said Mr. Bolter, who was largely endowed with the quality of selfishness.

`No, I don't!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
retorted Fagin.
`I'm of the same importance to you, as you are to yourself.' (unknown)

`I say,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
interrupted Mr. Bolter,
`yer a very nice man, and I'm very fond of yer; but we ain't quite so thick together, as all that comes to.' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)

`Only think,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, shrugging his (Fagin) shoulders, and stretching out his (Fagin) hands;
`only consider. You've done what's a very pretty thing, and what I love you for doing; but what at the same time would put the cravat round your throat, that's so very easily tied and so very difficult to unloose--in plain English, the halter!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Mr. Bolter put his (Bolter) hand to his (Bolter) neckerchief, as if he (Bolter) felt it inconveniently tight; and murmured an assent, qualified in tone but not in substance.

`The gallows,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
continued Fagin,
`the gallows, my dear, is an ugly finger-post, which points out a very short and sharp turning that has stopped many a bold fellow's career on the broad highway. To keep in the easy road, and keep it at a distance, is object number one with you.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Of course it is,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
replied Mr. Bolter.
`What do yer talk about such things for?' (unknown)

`Only to show you my meaning clearly,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, raising his (Jew) eyebrows.
`To be able to do that, you depend upon me. To keep my little business all snug, I depend upon you. The first is your number one, the second my number one. The more you value your number one, the more careful you must be of mine; so we come at last to what I told you at first--that a regard for number one holds us all together, and must do so, unless we would all go to pieces in company.' (unknown)

`That's true,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
rejoined Mr. Bolter, thoughtfully.
`Oh! yer a cunning old codger!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Mr. Fagin saw, with delight, that this tribute to his (Fagin) powers was no mere compliment, but that he (Fagin) had really impressed his (Fagin) recruit with a sense of his (Fagin) wily genius, which it was most important that he (Fagin) should entertain in the outset of their acquaintance. To strengthen an impression so desirable and useful, he (Fagin) followed up the blow by acquainting him (Fagin), in some detail, with the magnitude and extent of his (Fagin) operations; blending truth and fiction together, as best served his (Fagin) purpose; and bringing both to bear, with so much art, that Mr. Bolter's respect visibly increased, and became tempered, at the same time, with a degree of wholesome fear, which it was highly desirable to awaken.

`It's this mutual trust we have in each other that consoles me under heavy losses,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`My best hand was taken from me, yesterday morning.' (unknown)

`You don't mean to say he (Fagin) died?' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
cried Mr. Bolter.

`No, no,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin,
`not so bad as that. Not quite so bad.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`What, I suppose he (Fagin) was--' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Wanted,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
interposed Fagin.
`Yes, he (Fagin) was wanted.' (unknown)

`Very particular?' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
inquired Mr. Bolter.

`No,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin,
`not very. He (Fagin) was charged with attempting to pick a pocket, and they found a silver snuff-box on him (Fagin),--his (Fagin) own, my dear, his (Fagin) own, for he (Fagin) took snuff himself, and was very fond of it. They remanded him (Fagin) till to-day, for they thought they knew the owner. Ah! he (owner) was worth fifty boxes, and I'd give the price of as many to have him (owner) back. You should have known the Dodger, my dear; you should have known the Dodger.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Well, but I shall know him (Dodger), I hope; don't yer think so?' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
said Mr. Bolter.

`I'm doubtful about it,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, with a sigh.
`If they don't get any fresh evidence, it'll only be a summary conviction, and we shall have him (Fagin) back again after six weeks or so; but, if they do, it's a case of lagging. They know what a clever lad he (lad) is; he (lad)'ll be a lifer. They'll make the Artful nothing less than a lifer.' (unknown)

`What do you mean by lagging and a lifer?' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
demanded Mr. Bolter.
`What's the good of talking in that way to me; why don't yer speak so as I can understand yer?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin was about to translate these mysterious expressions into the vulgar tongue; and, being interpreted, Mr. Bolter would have been informed that they represented that combination of words,

`transportation for life,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
when the dialogue was cut short by the entry of Master Bates, with his (Bates) hands in his (Bates) breeches-pockets, and his (Bates) face twisted into a look of semi-comical woe.

`It's all up, Fagin,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley, when he (Fagin) and his (Fagin) new companion had been made known to each other.

`What do you mean?' (the gentleman)

`They've found the gentleman as owns the box; two or three more's a coming to

`dentify him (gentleman); and the Artful's booked for a passage out,' (the gentleman)
replied Master Bates.
`I must have a full suit of mourning, Fagin, and a hatband, to wisit him (Fagin) in, afore he (Fagin) sets out upon his (Fagin) travels. To think of Jack Dawkins--lummy Jack--the Dodger--the Artful Dodger--going abroad for a common twopenny-halfpenny sneeze-box! I never thought he (Dodger)'d a done it under a gold watch, chain, and seals, at the lowest. Oh, why didn't he (Dodger) rob some rich old gentleman of all his (Dodger) walables, and go out as a gentleman, and not like a common prig, without no honour nor glory!' (Master Bates)

With this expression of feeling for his (Dodger) unfortunate friend, Master Bates sat himself on the nearest chair with an aspect of chagrin and despondency.

`What do you talk about his (Bates) having neither honour nor glory for!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
exclaimed Fagin, darting an angry look at his (Fagin) pupil.
`Wasn't he (Fagin) always the top-sawyer among you all! Is there one of you that could touch him (Fagin) or come near him (Fagin) on any scent! Eh?' (unknown)

`Not one,' (Master Bates)
replied Master Bates, in a voice rendered husky by regret;
`not one.' (Master Bates)

`Then what do you talk of?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin angrily;
`what are you blubbering for?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

''Cause it isn't on the rec-ord, is it?' said Charley, chafed into perfect defiance of his (Charley) venerable friend by the current of his (Charley) regrets; ''cause it can't come out in the

`dictment; 'cause nobody will never know half of what he (Charley) was. How will he (Charley) stand in the Newgate Calendar? P'raps not be there at all. Oh, my eye, my eye, wot a blow it is!' (friend)

`Ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, extending his (Fagin) right hand, and turning to Mr. Bolter in a fit of chuckling which shook him (Bolter) as though he (Bolter) had the palsy;
`see what a pride they take in their profession, my dear. Ain't it beautiful?' (he)

Mr. Bolter nodded assent, and Fagin, after contemplating the grief of Charley Bates for some seconds with evident satisfaction, stepped up to that young gentleman and patted him (gentleman) on the shoulder.

`Never mind, Charley,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin soothingly;
`it'll come out, it'll be sure to come out. They'll all know what a clever fellow he (fellow) was; he (fellow)'ll show it himself, and not disgrace his (fellow) old pals and teachers. Think how young he (fellow) is too! What a distinction, Charley, to be lagged at his (Charley) time of life!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Well, it is a honour that is!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley, a little consoled.

`He (Charley) shall have all he (Charley) wants,' (the Jew)
continued the Jew.
`He (Charley) shall be kept in the Stone Jug, Charley, like a gentleman. Like a gentleman! With his (gentleman) beer every day, and money in his (gentleman) pocket to pitch and toss with, if he (gentleman) can't spend it.' (unknown)

`No, shall he (gentleman) though?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
cried Charley Bates.

`Ay, that he (Bates) shall,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin,
`and we'll have a big-wig, Charley: one that's got the greatest gift of the gab: to carry on his (Charley) defence; and he (Charley) shall make a speech for himself too, if he (Charley) likes; and we'll read it all in the papers--``Artful Dodger--shrieks of laughter--here the court was convulsed''--eh, Charley, eh?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Ha! ha!' (Master Bates)
laughed Master Bates,
`what a lark that would be, wouldn't it, Fagin? I say, how the Artful would bother 'em wouldn't he (Fagin)?' (Master Bates)

`Would!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin.
`He (Fagin) shall--he (Fagin) will!' (unknown)

`Ah, to be sure, so he (Fagin) will,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
repeated Charley, rubbing his (Charley) hands.

`I think I see him (Charley) now,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
cried the Jew, bending his (Charley) eyes upon his (Charley) pupil.

`So do I,' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
cried Charley Bates.
`Ha! ha! ha! so do I. I see it all afore me, upon my soul I do, Fagin. What a game! What a regular game! All the big-wigs trying to look solemn, and Jack Dawkins addressing of 'em as intimate and comfortable as if he (Dawkins) was the judge's own son making a speech arter dinner--ha! ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

In fact, Mr. Fagin had so well humoured his (Fagin) young friend's eccentric disposition, that Master Bates, who had at first been disposed to consider the imprisoned Dodger rather in the light of a victim, now looked upon him (Dodger) as the chief actor in a scene of most uncommon and exquisite humour, and felt quite impatient for the arrival of the time when his (Dodger) old companion should have so favourable an opportunity of displaying his (Dodger) abilities.

`We must know how he (Dodger) gets on to-day, by some handy means or other,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`Let me think.' (unknown)

`Shall I go?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
asked Charley.

`Not for the world,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin.
`Are you mad, my dear, stark mad, that you'd walk into the very place where--No, Charley, no. One is enough to lose at a time.' (unknown)

`You don't mean to go yourself, I suppose?' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
said Charley with a humorous leer.

`That wouldn't quite fit,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin shaking his (Fagin) head.

`Then why don't you send this new cove?' (Master Bates)
asked Master Bates, laying his (Bates) hand on Noah's arm.
`Nobody knows him (Bates).' (unknown)

`Why, if he (Bates) didn't mind--' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
observed Fagin.

`Mind!' (Charley/Bates/Charley Bates)
interposed Charley.
`What should he (Charley) have to mind?' (unknown)

`Really nothing, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, turning to Mr. Bolter,
`really nothing.' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)

`Oh, I dare say about that, yer know,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
observed Noah, backing towards the door, and shaking his (Noah) head with a kind of sober alarm.
`No, no--none of that. It's not in my department, that ain't.' (unknown)

`Wot department has he (Noah) got, Fagin?' (Master Bates)
inquired Master Bates, surveying Noah's lank form with much disgust.
`The cutting away when there's anything wrong, and the eating all the wittles when there's everything right; is that his (Fagin) branch?' (unknown)

`Never mind,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
retorted Mr. Bolter;
`and don't yer take liberties with yer superiors, little boy, or yer'll find yerself in the wrong shop.' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)

Master Bates laughed so vehemently at this magnificent threat, that it was some time before Fagin could interpose, and represent to Mr. Bolter that he (Fagin) incurred no possible danger in visiting the police-office; that, inasmuch as no account of the little affair in which he (Fagin) had engaged, nor any description of his (Fagin) person, had yet been forwarded to the metropolis, it was very probable that he (Fagin) was not even suspected of having resorted to it for shelter; and that, if he (Fagin) were properly disguised, it would be as safe a spot for him (Fagin) to visit as any in London, inasmuch as it would be, of all places, the very last, to which he (Fagin) could be supposed likely to resort of his (Fagin) own free will.

Persuaded, in part, by these representations, but overborne in a much greater degree by his (Fagin) fear of Fagin, Mr. Bolter at length consented, with a very bad grace, to undertake the expedition. By Fagin's directions, he (Fagin) immediately substituted for his (Fagin) own attire, a waggoner's frock, velveteen breeches, and leather leggings: all of which articles the Jew had at hand. He (Jew) was likewise furnished with a felt hat well garnished with turnpike tickets; and a carter's whip. Thus equipped, he (Jew) was to saunter into the office, as some country fellow from Covent Garden market might be supposed to do for the gratification of his (Jew) curiousity; and as he (Jew) was as awkward, ungainly, and raw-boned a fellow as need be, Mr. Fagin had no fear but that he (Fagin) would look the part to perfection.

These arrangements completed, he (Fagin) was informed of the necessary signs and tokens by which to recognise the Artful Dodger, and was conveyed by Master Bates through dark and winding ways to within a very short distance of Bow Street. Having described the precise situation of the office, and accompanied it with copious directions how he (Bates) was to walk straight up the passage, and when he (Bates) got into the side, and pull off his (Bates) hat as he (Bates) went into the room, Charley Bates bade him (Bates) hurry on alone, and promised to bide his (Bates) return on the spot of their parting.

Noah Claypole, or Morris Bolter as the reader pleases, punctually followed the directions he (Bolter) had received, which--Master Bates being pretty well acquainted with the locality--were so exact that he (Bates) was enabled to gain the magisterial presence without asking any question, or meeting with any interruption by the way.

He (Bates) found himself jostled among a crowd of people, chiefly women, who were huddled together in a dirty frowsy room, at the upper end of which was a raised platform railed off from the rest, with a dock for the prisoners on the left hand against the wall, a box for the witnesses in the middle, and a desk for the magistrates on the right; the awful locality last named, being screened off by a partition which concealed the bench from the common gaze, and left the vulgar to imagine -LRB-if they could-RRB- the full majesty of justice.

There were only a couple of women in the dock, who were nodding to their admiring friends, while the clerk read some depositions to a couple of policemen and a man in plain clothes who leant over the table. A jailer stood reclining against the dock-rail, tapping his (jailer) nose listlessly with a large key, except when he (jailer) repressed an undue tendency to conversation among the idlers, by proclaiming silence; or looked sternly up to bid some woman

`Take that baby out,' (some woman)
when the gravity of justice was disturbed by feeble cries, half-smothered in the mother's shawl, from some meagre infant. The room smelt close and unwholesome; the walls were dirt-discoloured; and the ceiling blackened. There was an old smoky bust over the mantel-shelf, and a dusty clock above the dock--the only thing present, that seemed to go on as it ought; for depravity, or poverty, or an habitual acquaintance with both, had left a taint on all the animate matter, hardly less unpleasant than the thick greasy scum on every inanimate object that frowned upon it.

Noah looked eagerly about him (Noah) for the Dodger; but although there were several women who would have done very well for that distinguished character's mother or sister, and more than one man who might be supposed to bear a strong resemblance to his (man) father, nobody at all answering the description given him (man) of Mr. Dawkins was to be seen. He (Dawkins) waited in a state of much suspense and uncertainty until the women, being committed for trial, went flaunting out; and then was quickly relieved by the appearance of another prisoner who he (prisoner) felt at once could be no other than the object of his (prisoner) visit.

It was indeed Mr. Dawkins, who, shuffling into the office with the big coat sleeves tucked up as usual, his (Dawkins) left hand in his (Dawkins) pocket, and his (Dawkins) hat in his (Dawkins) right hand, preceded the jailer, with a rolling gait altogether indescribable, and, taking his (Dawkins) place in the dock, requested in an audible voice to know what he (Dawkins) was placed in that `ere disgraceful sitivation for.

`Hold your tongue, will you?' (the jailer)
said the jailer.

`I'm an Englishman, ain't I?' (the Dodger)
rejoined the Dodger.
`Where are my priwileges?' (unknown)

`You'll get your privileges soon enough,' (the jailer)
retorted the jailer,
`and pepper with 'em.' (the jailer)

`We'll see wot the Secretary of State for the Home Affairs has got to say to the beaks, if I don't,' (Mr. Dawkins/Mr. John Dawkins/John)
replied Mr. Dawkins.
`Now then! Wot is this here business? I shall thank the madg`strates to dispose of this here little affair, and not to keep me while they read the paper, for I've got an appointment with a genelman in the City, and as I am a man of my word and wery punctual in business matters, he (man)'ll go away if I ain't there to my time, and then pr`aps ther won't be an action for damage against them as kep me away. Oh no, certainly not!' (the Dodger)

At this point, the Dodger, with a show of being very particular with a view to proceedings to be had thereafter, desired the jailer to communicate

`the names of them two files as was on the bench.' (the jailer)
Which so tickled the spectators, that they laughed almost as heartily as Master Bates could have done if he (Bates) had heard the request.

`Silence there!' (the jailer)
cried the jailer.

`What is this?' (the magistrates)
inquired one of the magistrates.

`A pick-pocketing case, your worship.' (the magistrates)

`Has the boy ever been here before?' (unknown)

`He (boy) ought to have been, a many times,' (the jailer)
replied the jailer.
`He (jailer) has been pretty well everywhere else. _I_ know him (jailer) well, your worship.' (unknown)

`Oh! you know me, do you?' (unknown)
cried the Artful, making a note of the statement.
`Wery good. That's a case of deformation of character, any way.' (unknown)

Here there was another laugh, and another cry of silence.

`Now then, where are the witnesses?' (the clerk)
said the clerk.

`Ah! that's right,' (the Dodger)
added the Dodger.
`Where are they? I should like to see 'em.' (a policeman)

This wish was immediately gratified, for a policeman stepped forward who had seen the prisoner attempt the pocket of an unknown gentleman in a crowd, and indeed take a handkerchief therefrom, which, being a very old one, he (gentleman) deliberately put back again, after trying it on his (gentleman) own countenance. For this reason, he (gentleman) took the Dodger into custody as soon as he (Dodger) could get near him (Dodger), and the said Dodger, being searched, had upon his (Dodger) person a silver snuff-box, with the owner's name engraved upon the lid. This gentleman had been discovered on reference to the Court Guide, and being then and there present, swore that the snuff-box was his (gentleman), and that he (gentleman) had missed it on the previous day, the moment he (gentleman) had disengaged himself from the crowd before referred to. He (gentleman) had also remarked a young gentleman in the throng, particularly active in making his (gentleman) way about, and that young gentleman was the prisoner before him (gentleman).

`Have you anything to ask this witness, boy?' (the magistrate)
said the magistrate.

`I wouldn't abase myself by descending to hold no conversation with him (magistrate),' (the magistrate)
replied the Dodger.

`Have you anything to say at all?' (unknown)

`Do you hear his (Dodger) worship ask if you've anything to say?' (the jailer)
inquired the jailer, nudging the silent Dodger with his (Dodger) elbow.

`I beg your pardon,' (the Dodger)
said the Dodger, looking up with an air of abstraction.
`Did you redress yourself to me, my man?' (unknown)

`I never see such an out-and-out young wagabond, your worship,' (the officer)
observed the officer with a grin.
`Do you mean to say anything, you young shaver?' (unknown)

`No,' (the Dodger)
replied the Dodger, `not here, for this ain't the shop for justice: besides which, my attorney is a-breakfasting this morning with the Wice President of the House of Commons; but I shall have something to say elsewhere, and so will he (President), and so will a wery numerous and
`spectable circle of acquaintance as'll make them beaks wish they'd never been born, or that they'd got their footmen to hang 'em up to their own hat-pegs, afore they let 'em come out this morning to try it on upon me. I'll--' (he)

`There! He (acquaintance)'s fully committed!' (the clerk)
interposed the clerk.
`Take him (acquaintance) away.' (unknown)

`Come on,' (the jailer)
said the jailer.

`Oh ah! I'll come on,' (Dodger)
replied the Dodger, brushing his (Dodger) hat with the palm of his (Dodger) hand.
`Ah! -LRB-to the Bench-RRB- it's no use your looking frightened; I won't show you no mercy, not a ha`porth of it. _You'll_ pay for this, my fine fellers. I wouldn't be you for something! I wouldn't go free, now, if you was to fall down on your knees and ask me. Here, carry me off to prison! Take me away!' (the Dodger)

With these last words, the Dodger suffered himself to be led off by the collar; threatening, till he (Dodger) got into the yard, to make a parliamentary business of it; and then grinning in the officer's face, with great glee and self-approval.

Having seen him (officer) locked up by himself in a little cell, Noah made the best of his (Noah) way back to where he (Noah) had left Master Bates. After waiting here some time, he (Noah) was joined by that young gentleman, who had prudently abstained from showing himself until he (Noah) had looked carefully abroad from a snug retreat, and ascertained that his (Noah) new friend had not been followed by any impertinent person.

The two hastened back together, to bear to Mr. Fagin the animating news that the Dodger was doing full justice to his (Dodger) bringing-up, and establishing for himself a glorious reputation.

CHAPTER XLIV

THE TIME ARRIVES FOR NANCY TO REDEEM HER PLEDGE TO ROSE MAYLIE. SHE FAILS.

Adept as she (NANCY) was, in all the arts of cunning and dissimulation, the girl Nancy could not wholly conceal the effect which the knowledge of the step she (Nancy) had taken, wrought upon her (Nancy) mind. She (Nancy) remembered that both the crafty Jew and the brutal Sikes had confided to her (Nancy) schemes, which had been hidden from all others: in the full confidence that she (Nancy) was trustworthy and beyond the reach of their suspicion. Vile as those schemes were, desperate as were their originators, and bitter as were her (Nancy) feelings towards Fagin, who had led her (Nancy), step by step, deeper and deeper down into an abyss of crime and misery, whence was no escape; still, there were times when, even towards him (Fagin), she (Nancy) felt some relenting, lest her (Nancy) disclosure should bring him (Fagin) within the iron grasp he (Fagin) had so long eluded, and he (Fagin) should fall at last--richly as he (Fagin) merited such a fate--by her (Nancy) hand.

But, these were the mere wanderings of a mind unable wholly to detach itself from old companions and associations, though enabled to fix itself steadily on one object, and resolved not to be turned aside by any consideration. Her (Nancy) fears for Sikes would have been more powerful inducements to recoil while there was yet time; but she (Nancy) had stipulated that her (Nancy) secret should be rigidly kept, she (Nancy) had dropped no clue which could lead to his (Sikes) discovery, she (Nancy) had refused, even for his (Sikes) sake, a refuge from all the guilt and wretchedness that encompasses her (Nancy)--and what more could she (Nancy) do! She (Nancy) was resolved.

Though all her (Nancy) mental struggles terminated in this conclusion, they forced themselves upon her (Nancy), again and again, and left their traces too. She (Nancy) grew pale and thin, even within a few days. At times, she (Nancy) took no heed of what was passing before her (Nancy), or no part in conversations where once, she (Nancy) would have been the loudest. At other times, she (Nancy) laughed without merriment, and was noisy without a moment afterwards--she (Nancy) sat silent and dejected, brooding with her (Nancy) head upon her (Nancy) hands, while the very effort by which she (Nancy) roused herself, told, more forcibly than even these indications, that she (Nancy) was ill at ease, and that her (Nancy) thoughts were occupied with matters very different and distant from those in the course of discussion by her (Nancy) companions.

It was Sunday night, and the bell of the nearest church struck the hour. Sikes and the Jew were talking, but they paused to listen. The girl looked up from the low seat on which she (girl) crouched, and listened too. Eleven.

`An hour this side of midnight,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, raising the blind to look out and returning to his (Sikes) seat.
`Dark and heavy it is too. A good night for business this.' (unknown)

`Ah!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin.
`What a pity, Bill, my dear, that there's none quite ready to be done.' (unknown)

`You're right for once,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes gruffly.
`It is a pity, for I'm in the humour too.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin sighed, and shook his (Fagin) head despondingly.

`We must make up for lost time when we've got things into a good train. That's all I know,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

`That's the way to talk, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin, venturing to pat him (Fagin) on the shoulder.
`It does me good to hear you.' (unknown)

`Does you good, does it!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes.
`Well, so be it.' (unknown)

`Ha! ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
laughed Fagin, as if he (Fagin) were relieved by even this concession.
`You're like yourself to-night, Bill. Quite like yourself.' (unknown)

`I don't feel like myself when you lay that withered old claw on my shoulder, so take it away,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, casting off the Jew's hand.

`It make you nervous, Bill,--reminds you of being nabbed, does it?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, determined not to be offended.

`Reminds me of being nabbed by the devil,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
returned Sikes. `There never was another man with such a face as yours, unless it was your father, and I suppose _he (father)_ is singeing his (father) grizzled red beard by this time, unless you came straight from the old
`un without any father at all betwixt you; which I shouldn't wonder at, a bit.' (he)

Fagin offered no reply to this compliment: but, pulling Sikes by the sleeve, pointed his (Sikes) finger towards Nancy, who had taken advantage of the foregoing conversation to put on her (Nancy) bonnet, and was now leaving the room.

`Hallo!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes.
`Nance. Where's the gal going to at this time of night?' (unknown)

`Not far.' (unknown)

`What answer's that?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
retorted Sikes.
`Do you hear me?' (unknown)

`I don't know where,' (the girl)
replied the girl.

`Then I do,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, more in the spirit of obstinacy than because he (Sikes) had any real objection to the girl going where she (girl) listed.
`Nowhere. Sit down.' (unknown)

`I'm not well. I told you that before,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.
`I want a breath of air.' (the girl)

`Put your head out of the winder,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes.

`There's not enough there,' (the girl)
said the girl.
`I want it in the street.' (the girl)

`Then you won't have it,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes. With which assurance he (Sikes) rose, locked the door, took the key out, and pulling her (girl) bonnet from her (girl) head, flung it up to the top of an old press.
`There,' (the robber)
said the robber.
`Now stop quietly where you are, will you?' (unknown)

`It's not such a matter as a bonnet would keep me,' (the girl)
said the girl turning very pale.
`What do you mean, Bill? Do you know what you're doing?' (unknown)

`Know what I'm--Oh!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, turning to Fagin,
`she (girl)'s out of her (girl) senses, you know, or she (girl) daren't talk to me in that way.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`You'll drive me on the something desperate,' (the girl)
muttered the girl placing both hands upon her (girl) breast, as though to keep down by force some violent outbreak.
`Let me go, will you,--this minute--this instant.' (unknown)

`No!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

`Tell him (Sikes) to let me go, Fagin. He (Sikes) had better. It'll be better for him (Sikes). Do you hear me?' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
cried Nancy stamping her (Nancy) foot upon the ground.

`Hear you!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
repeated Sikes turning round in his (Sikes) chair to confront her (Nancy).
`Aye! And if I hear you for half a minute longer, the dog shall have such a grip on your throat as'll tear some of that screaming voice out. Wot has come over you, you jade! Wot is it?' (unknown)

`Let me go,' (the girl)
said the girl with great earnestness; then sitting herself down on the floor, before the door, she (girl) said,
`Bill, let me go; you don't know what you are doing. You don't, indeed. For only one hour--do--do!' (she)

`Cut my limbs off one by one!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, seizing her (girl) roughly by the arm,
`If I don't think the gal's stark raving mad. Get up.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Not till you let me go--not till you let me go--Never--never!' (the girl)
screamed the girl. Sikes looked on, for a minute, watching his (Sikes) opportunity, and suddenly pinioning her (girl) hands dragged her (girl), struggling and wrestling with him (Sikes) by the way, into a small room adjoining, where he (Sikes) sat himself on a bench, and thrusting her (girl) into a chair, held her (girl) down by force. She (girl) struggled and implored by turns until twelve o'clock had struck, and then, wearied and exhausted, ceased to contest the point any further. With a caution, backed by many oaths, to make no more efforts to go out that night, Sikes left her (girl) to recover at leisure and rejoined Fagin.

`Whew!' (the housebreaker)
said the housebreaker wiping the perspiration from his (Sikes) face.
`Wot a precious strange gal that is!' (unknown)

`You may say that, Bill,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin thoughtfully.
`You may say that.' (unknown)

`Wot did she (gal) take it into her (gal) head to go out to-night for, do you think?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
asked Sikes.
`Come; you should know her (gal) better than me. Wot does it mean?' (unknown)

`Obstinacy; woman's obstinacy, I suppose, my dear.' (unknown)

`Well, I suppose it is,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
growled Sikes.
`I thought I had tamed her (gal), but she (gal)'s as bad as ever.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Worse,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin thoughtfully.
`I never knew her (gal) like this, for such a little cause.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Nor I,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`I think she (gal)'s got a touch of that fever in her (gal) blood yet, and it won't come out--eh?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Like enough.' (unknown)

`I'll let her (gal) a little blood, without troubling the doctor, if she (gal)'s took that way again,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.

Fagin nodded an expressive approval of this mode of treatment.

`She (gal) was hanging about me all day, and night too, when I was stretched on my back; and you, like a blackhearted wolf as you are, kept yourself aloof,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`We was poor too, all the time, and I think, one way or other, it's worried and fretted her (gal); and that being shut up here so long has made her (gal) restless--eh?' (unknown)

`That's it, my dear,' (the Jew)
replied the Jew in a whisper.
`Hush!' (he)

As he (Jew) uttered these words, the girl herself appeared and resumed her (girl) former seat. Her (girl) eyes were swollen and red; she (girl) rocked herself to and fro; tossed her (girl) head; and, after a little time, burst out laughing.

`Why, now she (girl)'s on the other tack!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
exclaimed Sikes, turning a look of excessive surprise on his (Sikes) companion.

Fagin nodded to him (Fagin) to take no further notice just then; and, in a few minutes, the girl subsided into her (girl) accustomed demeanour. Whispering Sikes that there was no fear of her (girl) relapsing, Fagin took up his (Fagin) hat and bade him (Fagin) good-night. He (Fagin) paused when he (Fagin) reached the room-door, and looking round, asked if somebody would light him (Fagin) down the dark stairs.

`Light him (Fagin) down,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, who was filling his (Sikes) pipe.
`It's a pity he (Sikes) should break his (Sikes) neck himself, and disappoint the sight-seers. Show him (Sikes) a light.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

Nancy followed the old man downstairs, with a candle. When they reached the passage, he (man) laid his (man) finger on his (man) lip, and drawing close to the girl, said, in a whisper.

`What is it, Nancy, dear?' (unknown)

`What do you mean?' (the girl)
replied the girl, in the same tone.

`The reason of all this,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin.
`If _he (Fagin)_' (he)
--he (Fagin) pointed with his (Fagin) skinny fore-finger up the stairs--`is so hard with you -LRB-he (Fagin)'s a brute, Nance, a brute-beast-RRB-, why don't you--'

`Well?' (Nance)
said the girl, as Fagin paused, with his (Fagin) mouth almost touching her (girl) ear, and his (Fagin) eyes looking into hers.

`No matter just now. We'll talk of this again. You have a friend in me, Nance; a staunch friend. I have the means at hand, quiet and close. If you want revenge on those that treat you like a dog--like a dog! worse than his (Nance) dog, for he (Nance) humours him (Nance) sometimes--come to me. I say, come to me. He (Nance) is the mere hound of a day, but you know me of old, Nance.' (unknown)

`I know you well,' (the girl)
replied the girl, without manifesting the least emotion.
`Good-night.' (She)

She (girl) shrank back, as Fagin offered to lay his (Fagin) hand on hers, but said good-night again, in a steady voice, and, answering his (Fagin) parting look with a nod of intelligence, closed the door between them.

Fagin walked towards his (Fagin) home, intent upon the thoughts that were working within his (Fagin) brain. He (Fagin) had conceived the idea--not from what had just passed though that had tended to confirm him (Fagin), but slowly and by degrees--that Nancy, wearied of the housebreaker's brutality, had conceived an attachment for some new friend. Her (Nancy) altered manner, her (Nancy) repeated absences from home alone, her (Nancy) comparative indifference to the interests of the gang for which she (Nancy) had once been so zealous, and, added to these, her (Nancy) desperate impatience to leave home that night at a particular hour, all favoured the supposition, and rendered it, to him (friend) at least, almost matter of certainty. The object of this new liking was not among his (friend) myrmidons. He (friend) would be a valuable acquisition with such an assistant as Nancy, and must -LRB-thus Fagin argued-RRB- be secured without delay.

There was another, and a darker object, to be gained. Sikes knew too much, and his (Sikes) ruffian taunts had not galled Fagin the less, because the wounds were hidden. The girl must know, well, that if she (girl) shook him (Fagin) off, she (girl) could never be safe from his (Fagin) fury, and that it would be surely wreaked--to the maiming of limbs, or perhaps the loss of life--on the object of her (girl) more recent fancy.

`With a little persuasion,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
thought Fagin,
`what more likely than that she (girl) would consent to poison him (Fagin)? Women have done such things, and worse, to secure the same object before now. There would be the dangerous villain: the man I hate: gone; another secured in his (man) place; and my influence over the girl, with a knowledge of this crime to back it, unlimited.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

These things passed through the mind of Fagin, during the short time he (Fagin) sat alone, in the housebreaker's room; and with them uppermost in his (Fagin) thoughts, he (Fagin) had taken the opportunity afterwards afforded him (Fagin), of sounding the girl in the broken hints he (Fagin) threw out at parting. There was no expression of surprise, no assumption of an inability to understand his (Fagin) meaning. The girl clearly comprehended it. Her (girl) glance at parting showed _that_.

But perhaps she (girl) would recoil from a plot to take the life of Sikes, and that was one of the chief ends to be attained.

`How,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
thought Fagin, as he (Fagin) crept homeward,
`can I increase my influence with her (girl)? What new power can I acquire?' (he)

Such brains are fertile in expedients. If, without extracting a confession from herself, he (Fagin) laid a watch, discovered the object of her (girl) altered regard, and threatened to reveal the whole history to Sikes -LRB-of whom she (girl) stood in no common fear-RRB- unless she (girl) entered into his (Sikes) designs, could he (Sikes) not secure her (girl) compliance?

`I can,' (he)
said Fagin, almost aloud.
`She (girl) durst not refuse me then. Not for her (girl) life, not for her (girl) life! I have it all. The means are ready, and shall be set to work. I shall have you yet!' (He)

He (Fagin) cast back a dark look, and a threatening motion of the hand, towards the spot where he (Fagin) had left the bolder villain; and went on his (Fagin) way: busying his (Fagin) bony hands in the folds of his (Fagin) tattered garment, which he (Fagin) wrenched tightly in his (Fagin) grasp, as though there were a hated enemy crushed with every motion of his (Fagin) fingers.

CHAPTER XLV

NOAH CLAYPOLE IS EMPLOYED BY FAGIN ON A SECRET MISSION

The old man was up, betimes, next morning, and waited impatiently for the appearance of his (man) new associate, who after a delay that seemed interminable, at length presented himself, and commenced a voracious assault on the breakfast.

`Bolter,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, drawing up a chair and seating himself opposite Morris Bolter.

`Well, here I am,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
returned Noah.
`What's the matter? Don't yer ask me to do anything till I have done eating. That's a great fault in this place. Yer never get time enough over yer meals.' (unknown)

`You can talk as you eat, can't you?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, cursing his (Fagin) dear young friend's greediness from the very bottom of his (Fagin) heart.

`Oh yes, I can talk. I get on better when I talk,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, cutting a monstrous slice of bread.
`Where's Charlotte?' (unknown)

`Out,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`I sent her (Charlotte) out this morning with the other young woman, because I wanted us to be alone.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Oh!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah.
`I wish yer'd ordered her (woman) to make some buttered toast first. Well. Talk away. Yer won't interrupt me.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

There seemed, indeed, no great fear of anything interrupting him (Noah), as he (Noah) had evidently sat down with a determination to do a great deal of business.

`You did well yesterday, my dear,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`Beautiful! Six shillings and ninepence halfpenny on the very first day! The kinchin lay will be a fortune to you.' (unknown)

`Don't you forget to add three pint-pots and a milk-can,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
said Mr. Bolter.

`No, no, my dear. The pint-pots were great strokes of genius: but the milk-can was a perfect masterpiece.' (unknown)

`Pretty well, I think, for a beginner,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
remarked Mr. Bolter complacently.
`The pots I took off airy railings, and the milk-can was standing by itself outside a public-house. I thought it might get rusty with the rain, or catch cold, yer know. Eh? Ha! ha! ha!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin affected to laugh very heartily; and Mr. Bolter having had his (Bolter) laugh out, took a series of large bites, which finished his (Bolter) first hunk of bread and butter, and assisted himself to a second.

`I want you, Bolter,' (hunk)
said Fagin, leaning over the table,
`to do a piece of work for me, my dear, that needs great care and caution.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`I say,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Bolter,
`don't yer go shoving me into danger, or sending me any more o' (unknown)
yer police-offices. That don't suit me, that don't; and so I tell yer.'

`That's not the smallest danger in it--not the very smallest,' (the Jew)
said the Jew;
`it's only to dodge a woman.' (the Jew)

`An old woman?' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
demanded Mr. Bolter.

`A young one,' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)
replied Fagin.

`I can do that pretty well, I know,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Bolter.
`I was a regular cunning sneak when I was at school. What am I to dodge her (woman) for? Not to--' (Mr. Bolter/Morris Bolter/Mr. Morris Bolter)

`Not to do anything, but to tell me where she (woman) goes, who she (woman) sees, and, if possible, what she (woman) says; to remember the street, if it is a street, or the house, if it is a house; and to bring me back all the information you can.' (unknown)

`What'll yer give me?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked Noah, setting down his (Noah) cup, and looking his (Noah) employer, eagerly, in the face.

`If you do it well, a pound, my dear. One pound,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, wishing to interest him (Fagin) in the scent as much as possible.
`And that's what I never gave yet, for any job of work where there wasn't valuable consideration to be gained.' (unknown)

`Who is she (you)?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
inquired Noah.

`One of us.' (unknown)

`Oh Lor!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
cried Noah, curling up his (Noah) nose.
`Yer doubtful of her (you), are yer?' (unknown)

`She (you) has found out some new friends, my dear, and I must know who they are,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
replied Fagin.

`I see,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Noah.
`Just to have the pleasure of knowing them, if they're respectable people, eh? Ha! ha! ha! I'm your man.' (unknown)

`I knew you would be,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, elated by the success of his (Fagin) proposal.

`Of course, of course,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.
`Where is she (you)? Where am I to wait for her (you)? Where am I to go?' (unknown)

`All that, my dear, you shall hear from me. I'll point her (you) out at the proper time,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin.
`You keep ready, and leave the rest to me.' (the spy)

That night, and the next, and the next again, the spy sat booted and equipped in his (spy) carter's dress: ready to turn out at a word from Fagin. Six nights passed--six long weary nights--and on each, Fagin came home with a disappointed face, and briefly intimated that it was not yet time. On the seventh, he (Fagin) returned earlier, and with an exultation he (Fagin) could not conceal. It was Sunday.

`She (Fagin) goes abroad to-night,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin,
`and on the right errand, I'm sure; for she (Fagin) has been alone all day, and the man she (Fagin) is afraid of will not be back much before daybreak. Come with me. Quick!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Noah started up without saying a word; for the Jew was in a state of such intense excitement that it infected him (Noah). They left the house stealthily, and hurrying through a labyrinth of streets, arrived at length before a public-house, which Noah recognised as the same in which he (Noah) had slept, on the night of his (Noah) arrival in London.

It was past eleven o'clock, and the door was closed. It opened softly on its hinges as Fagin gave a low whistle. They entered, without noise; and the door was closed behind them.

Scarcely venturing to whisper, but substituting dumb show for words, Fagin, and the young Jew who had admitted them, pointed out the pane of glass to Noah, and signed to him (Noah) to climb up and observe the person in the adjoining room.

`Is that the woman?' (he)
he (Noah) asked, scarcely above his (Noah) breath.

Fagin nodded yes.

`I can't see her (woman) face well,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
whispered Noah. `She (woman) is looking down, and the candle is behind her (woman).

`Stay there,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
whispered Fagin. He (Fagin) signed to Barney, who withdrew. In an instant, the lad entered the room adjoining, and, under pretence of snuffing the candle, moved it in the required position, and, speaking to the girl, caused her (girl) to raise her (girl) face.

`I see her (girl) now,' (her)
cried the spy.

`Plainly?' (unknown)

`I should know her (girl) among a thousand.' (He)

He (spy) hastily descended, as the room-door opened, and the girl came out. Fagin drew him (Fagin) behind a small partition which was curtained off, and they held their breaths as she (girl) passed within a few feet of their place of concealment, and emerged by the door at which they had entered.

`Hist!' (the lad)
cried the lad who held the door.
`Dow.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

Noah exchanged a look with Fagin, and darted out.

`To the left,' (the lad)
whispered the lad;
`take the left had, and keep od the other side.' (the lad)

He (Fagin) did so; and, by the light of the lamps, saw the girl's retreating figure, already at some distance before him (Fagin). He (Fagin) advanced as near as he (Fagin) considered prudent, and kept on the opposite side of the street, the better to observe her (girl) motions. She (girl) looked nervously round, twice or thrice, and once stopped to let two men who were following close behind her (girl), pass on. She (girl) seemed to gather courage as she (girl) advanced, and to walk with a steadier and firmer step. The spy preserved the same relative distance between them, and followed: with his (spy) eye upon her (girl).

CHAPTER XLVI

THE APPOINTMENT KEPT

The church clocks chimed three quarters past eleven, as two figures emerged on London Bridge. One, which advanced with a swift and rapid step, was that of a woman who looked eagerly about her (woman) as though in quest of some expected object; the other figure was that of a man, who slunk along in the deepest shadow he (man) could find, and, at some distance, accommodated his (man) pace to hers: stopping when she (woman) stopped: and as she (woman) moved again, creeping stealthily on: but never allowing himself, in the ardour of his (man) pursuit, to gain upon her (woman) footsteps. Thus, they crossed the bridge, from the Middlesex to the Surrey shore, when the woman, apparently disappointed in her (woman) anxious scrutiny of the foot-passengers, turned back. The movement was sudden; but he (man) who watched her (woman), was not thrown off his (man) guard by it; for, shrinking into one of the recesses which surmount the piers of the bridge, and leaning over the parapet the better to conceal his (man) figure, he (man) suffered her (woman) to pass on the opposite pavement. When she (woman) was about the same distance in advance as she (woman) had been before, he (man) slipped quietly down, and followed her (woman) again. At nearly the centre of the bridge, she (woman) stopped. The man stopped too.

It was a very dark night. The day had been unfavourable, and at that hour and place there were few people stirring. Such as there were, hurried quickly past: very possibly without seeing, but certainly without noticing, either the woman, or the man who kept her (woman) in view. Their appearance was not calculated to attract the importunate regards of such of London's destitute population, as chanced to take their way over the bridge that night in search of some cold arch or doorless hovel wherein to lay their heads; they stood there in silence: neither speaking nor spoken to, by any one who passed.

A mist hung over the river, deepening the red glare of the fires that burnt upon the small craft moored off the different wharfs, and rendering darker and more indistinct the murky buildings on the banks. The old smoke-stained storehouses on either side, rose heavy and dull from the dense mass of roofs and gables, and frowned sternly upon water too black to reflect even their lumbering shapes. The tower of old Saint Saviour's Church, and the spire of Saint Magnus, so long the giant-warders of the ancient bridge, were visible in the gloom; but the forest of shipping below bridge, and the thickly scattered spires of churches above, were nearly all hidden from sight.

The girl had taken a few restless turns to and fro--closely watched meanwhile by her (girl) hidden observer--when the heavy bell of St. Paul's tolled for the death of another day. Midnight had come upon the crowded city. The palace, the night-cellar, the jail, the madhouse: the chambers of birth and death, of health and sickness, the rigid face of the corpse and the calm sleep of the child: midnight was upon them all.

The hour had not struck two minutes, when a young lady, accompanied by a grey-haired gentleman, alighted from a hackney-carriage within a short distance of the bridge, and, having dismissed the vehicle, walked straight towards it. They had scarcely set foot upon its pavement, when the girl started, and immediately made towards them.

They walked onward, looking about them with the air of persons who entertained some very slight expectation which had little chance of being realised, when they were suddenly joined by this new associate. They halted with an exclamation of surprise, but suppressed it immediately; for a man in the garments of a countryman came close up--brushed against them, indeed--at that precise moment.

`Not here,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said Nancy hurriedly,
`I am afraid to speak to you here. Come away--out of the public road--down the steps yonder!' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

As she (Nancy) uttered these words, and indicated, with her (Nancy) hand, the direction in which she (Nancy) wished them to proceed, the countryman looked round, and roughly asking what they took up the whole pavement for, passed on.

The steps to which the girl had pointed, were those which, on the Surrey bank, and on the same side of the bridge as Saint Saviour's Church, form a landing-stairs from the river. To this spot, the man bearing the appearance of a countryman, hastened unobserved; and after a moment's survey of the place, he (countryman) began to descend.

These stairs are a part of the bridge; they consist of three flights. Just below the end of the second, going down, the stone wall on the left terminates in an ornamental pilaster facing towards the Thames. At this point the lower steps widen: so that a person turning that angle of the wall, is necessarily unseen by any others on the stairs who chance to be above him (countryman), if only a step. The countryman looked hastily round, when he (countryman) reached this point; and as there seemed no better place of concealment, and, the tide being out, there was plenty of room, he (countryman) slipped aside, with his (countryman) back to the pilaster, and there waited: pretty certain that they would come no lower, and that even if he (countryman) could not hear what was said, he (countryman) could follow them again, with safety.

So tardily stole the time in this lonely place, and so eager was the spy to penetrate the motives of an interview so different from what he (spy) had been led to expect, that he (spy) more than once gave the matter up for lost, and persuaded himself, either that they had stopped far above, or had resorted to some entirely different spot to hold their mysterious conversation. He (spy) was on the point of emerging from his (spy) hiding-place, and regaining the road above, when he (spy) heard the sound of footsteps, and directly afterwards of voices almost close at his (spy) ear.

He (spy) drew himself straight upright against the wall, and, scarcely breathing, listened attentively.

`This is far enough,' (the gentleman)
said a voice, which was evidently that of the gentleman.
`I will not suffer the young lady to go any farther. Many people would have distrusted you too much to have come even so far, but you see I am willing to humour you.' (the gentleman)

`To humour me!' (the girl)
cried the voice of the girl whom he (gentleman) had followed.
`You're considerate, indeed, sir. To humour me! Well, well, it's no matter.' (unknown)

`Why, for what,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman in a kinder tone,
`for what purpose can you have brought us to this strange place? Why not have let me speak to you, above there, where it is light, and there is something stirring, instead of bringing us to this dark and dismal hole?' (the gentleman)

`I told you before,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy,
`that I was afraid to speak to you there. I don't know why it is,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
said the girl, shuddering,
`but I have such a fear and dread upon me to-night that I can hardly stand.' (the girl)

`A fear of what?' (the girl)
asked the gentleman, who seemed to pity her (girl).

`I scarcely know of what,' (the gentleman)
replied the girl.
`I wish I did. Horrible thoughts of death, and shrouds with blood upon them, and a fear that has made me burn as if I was on fire, have been upon me all day. I was reading a book to-night, to wile the time away, and the same things came into the print.' (the girl)

`Imagination,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman, soothing her (girl).

`No imagination,' (the girl)
replied the girl in a hoarse voice.
`I'll swear I saw ``coffin'' written in every page of the book in large black letters,--aye, and they carried one close to me, in the streets to-night.' (unknown)

`There is nothing unusual in that,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
`They have passed me often.' (unknown)

`_Real ones_,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.
`This was not.' (the listener)

There was something so uncommon in her (girl) manner, that the flesh of the concealed listener crept as he (listener) heard the girl utter these words, and the blood chilled within him (listener). He (listener) had never experienced a greater relief than in hearing the sweet voice of the young lady as she (lady) begged her (lady) to be calm, and not allow herself to become the prey of such fearful fancies.

`Speak to her (lady) kindly,' (the lady)
said the young lady to her (lady) companion.
`Poor creature! She (lady) seems to need it.' (unknown)

`Your haughty religious people would have held their heads up to see me as I am to-night, and preached of flames and vengeance,' (the girl)
cried the girl.
`Oh, dear lady, why ar'n't those who claim to be God's own folks as gentle and as kind to us poor wretches as you, who, having youth, and beauty, and all that they have lost, might be a little proud instead of so much humbler?' (unknown)

`Ah!' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
`A Turk turns his (Turk) face, after washing it well, to the East, when he (Turk) says his (Turk) prayers; these good people, after giving their faces such a rub against the World as to take the smiles off, turn with no less regularity, to the darkest side of Heaven. Between the Mussulman and the Pharisee, commend me to the first!' (the gentleman)

These words appeared to be addressed to the young lady, and were perhaps uttered with the view of affording Nancy time to recover herself. The gentleman, shortly afterwards, addressed himself to her (Nancy).

`You were not here last Sunday night,' (he)
he (gentleman) said.

`I couldn't come,' (he)
replied Nancy;
`I was kept by force.' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)

`By whom?' (unknown)

`Him (gentleman) that I told the young lady of before.' (unknown)

`You were not suspected of holding any communication with anybody on the subject which has brought us here to-night, I hope?' (the gentleman)
asked the old gentleman.

`No,' (the girl)
replied the girl, shaking her (girl) head.
`It's not very easy for me to leave him (gentleman) unless he (gentleman) knows why; I couldn't give him (gentleman) a drink of laudanum before I came away.' (unknown)

`Did he (gentleman) awake before you returned?' (the gentleman)
inquired the gentleman.

`No; and neither he (gentleman) nor any of them suspect me.' (unknown)

`Good,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
`Now listen to me.' (unknown)

`I am ready,' (the girl)
replied the girl, as he (gentleman) paused for a moment.

`This young lady,' (the gentleman)
the gentleman began,
`has communicated to me, and to some other friends who can be safely trusted, what you told her (lady) nearly a fortnight since. I confess to you that I had doubts, at first, whether you were to be implicitly relied upon, but now I firmly believe you are.' (the gentleman)

`I am,' (the girl)
said the girl earnestly.

`I repeat that I firmly believe it. To prove to you that I am disposed to trust you, I tell you without reserve, that we propose to extort the secret, whatever it may be, from the fear of this man Monks. But if--if--' (the girl)
said the gentleman,
`he (gentleman) cannot be secured, or, if secured, cannot be acted upon as we wish, you must deliver up the Jew.' (the gentleman)

`Fagin,' (the girl)
cried the girl, recoiling.

`That man must be delivered up by you,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.

`I will not do it! I will never do it!' (the gentleman)
replied the girl.
`Devil that he (Devil) is, and worse than devil as he (devil) has been to me, I will never do that.' (unknown)

`You will not?' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman, who seemed fully prepared for this answer.

`Never!' (the girl)
returned the girl.

`Tell me why?' (unknown)

`For one reason,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl firmly,
`for one reason, that the lady knows and will stand by me in, I know she (lady) will, for I have her (lady) promise: and for this other reason, besides, that, bad life as he (gentleman) has led, I have led a bad life too; there are many of us who have kept the same courses together, and I'll not turn upon them, who might--any of them--have turned upon me, but didn't, bad as they are.' (the girl)

`Then,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman, quickly, as if this had been the point he (gentleman) had been aiming to attain;
`put Monks into my hands, and leave him (gentleman) to me to deal with.' (he)

`What if he (gentleman) turns against the others?' (unknown)

`I promise you that in that case, if the truth is forced from him (gentleman), there the matter will rest; there must be circumstances in Oliver's little history which it would be painful to drag before the public eye, and if the truth is once elicited, they shall go scot free.' (unknown)

`And if it is not?' (the girl)
suggested the girl.

`Then,' (the gentleman)
pursued the gentleman,
`this Fagin shall not be brought to justice without your consent. In such a case I could show you reasons, I think, which would induce you to yield it.' (the gentleman)

`Have I the lady's promise for that?' (the girl)
asked the girl.

`You have,' (Rose/Miss Rose)
replied Rose.
`My true and faithful pledge.' (unknown)

`Monks would never learn how you knew what you do?' (the girl)
said the girl, after a short pause.

`Never,' (the gentleman)
replied the gentleman.
`The intelligence should be brought to bear upon him (gentleman), that he (gentleman) could never even guess.' (unknown)

`I have been a liar, and among liars from a little child,' (the girl)
said the girl after another interval of silence,
`but I will take your words.' (the girl)

After receiving an assurance from both, that she (girl) might safely do so, she (girl) proceeded in a voice so low that it was often difficult for the listener to discover even the purport of what she (girl) said, to describe, by name and situation, the public-house whence she (girl) had been followed that night. From the manner in which she (girl) occasionally paused, it appeared as if the gentleman were making some hasty notes of the information she (girl) communicated. When she (girl) had thoroughly explained the localities of the place, the best position from which to watch it without exciting observation, and the night and hour on which Monks was most in the habit of frequenting it, she (girl) seemed to consider for a few moments, for the purpose of recalling his (gentleman) features and appearances more forcibly to her (girl) recollection.

`He (gentleman) is tall,' (the girl man stout)
said the girl,
`and a strongly made man, but not stout; he (man) has a lurking walk; and as he (man) walks, constantly looks over his (man) shoulder, first on one side, and then on the other. Don't forget that, for his (man) eyes are sunk in his (man) head so much deeper than any other man's, that you might almost tell him (man) by that alone. His (man) face is dark, like his (man) hair and eyes; and, although he (man) can't be more than six or eight and twenty, withered and haggard. His (man) lips are often discoloured and disfigured with the marks of teeth; for he (man) has desperate fits, and sometimes even bites his (man) hands and covers them with wounds--why did you start?' (the girl man stout)
said the girl, stopping suddenly.

The gentleman replied, in a hurried manner, that he (gentleman) was not conscious of having done so, and begged her (girl) to proceed.

`Part of this,' (the girl)
said the girl,
`I have drawn out from other people at the house I tell you of, for I have only seen him (gentleman) twice, and both times he (gentleman) was covered up in a large cloak. I think that's all I can give you to know him (gentleman) by. Stay though,' (the girl)
she (girl) added.
`Upon his (gentleman) throat: so high that you can see a part of it below his (gentleman) neckerchief when he (gentleman) turns his (gentleman) face: there is--' (unknown)

`A broad red mark, like a burn or scald?' (the gentleman)
cried the gentleman.

`How's this?' (the girl)
said the girl.
`You know him (gentleman)!' (The lady)

The young lady uttered a cry of surprise, and for a few moments they were so still that the listener could distinctly hear them breathe.

`I think I do,' (the listener)
said the gentleman, breaking silence.
`I should by your description. We shall see. Many people are singularly like each other. It may not be the same.' (the gentleman silence)

As he (gentleman) expressed himself to this effect, with assumed carelessness, he (gentleman) took a step or two nearer the concealed spy, as the latter could tell from the distinctness with which he (gentleman) heard him (gentleman) mutter,

`It must be he (gentleman)!' (him)

`Now,' (he)
he (gentleman) said, returning: so it seemed by the sound: to the spot where he (gentleman) had stood before,
`you have given us most valuable assistance, young woman, and I wish you to be the better for it. What can I do to serve you?' (he)

`Nothing,' (Nancy/Miss Nancy/NANCY)
replied Nancy.

`You will not persist in saying that,' (the gentleman)
rejoined the gentleman, with a voice and emphasis of kindness that might have touched a much harder and more obdurate heart.
`Think now. Tell me.' (unknown)

`Nothing, sir,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl, weeping.
`You can do nothing to help me. I am past all hope, indeed.' (unknown)

`You put yourself beyond its pale,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.
`The past has been a dreary waste with you, of youthful energies mis-spent, and such priceless treasures lavished, as the Creator bestows but once and never grants again, but, for the future, you may hope. I do not say that it is in our power to offer you peace of heart and mind, for that must come as you seek it; but a quiet asylum, either in England, or, if you fear to remain here, in some foreign country, it is not only within the compass of our ability but our most anxious wish to secure you. Before the dawn of morning, before this river wakes to the first glimpse of day-light, you shall be placed as entirely beyond the reach of your former associates, and leave as utter an absence of all trace behind you, as if you were to disappear from the earth this moment. Come! I would not have you go back to exchange one word with any old companion, or take one look at any old haunt, or breathe the very air which is pestilence and death to you. Quit them all, while there is time and opportunity!' (unknown)

`She (you) will be persuaded now,' (the lady)
cried the young lady.
`She (you) hesitates, I am sure.' (unknown)

`I fear not, my dear,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman.

`No sir, I do not,' (the girl)
replied the girl, after a short struggle.
`I am chained to my old life. I loathe and hate it now, but I cannot leave it. I must have gone too far to turn back,--and yet I don't know, for if you had spoken to me so, some time ago, I should have laughed it off. But,' (the girl)
she (girl) said, looking hastily round,
`this fear comes over me again. I must go home.' (she)

`Home!' (the lady)
repeated the young lady, with great stress upon the word.

`Home, lady,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl.
`To such a home as I have raised for myself with the work of my whole life. Let us part. I shall be watched or seen. Go! Go! If I have done you any service all I ask is, that you leave me, and let me go my way alone.' (unknown)

`It is useless,' (the gentleman)
said the gentleman, with a sigh.
`We compromise her (lady) safety, perhaps, by staying here. We may have detained her (lady) longer than she (lady) expected already.' (unknown)

`Yes, yes,' (the girl)
urged the girl.
`You have.' (unknown)

`What,' (the lady)
cried the young lady,
`can be the end of this poor creature's life!' (the lady)

`What!' (the girl)
repeated the girl.
`Look before you, lady. Look at that dark water. How many times do you read of such as I who spring into the tide, and leave no living thing, to care for, or bewail them. It may be years hence, or it may be only months, but I shall come to that at last.' (unknown)

`Do not speak thus, pray,' (the lady)
returned the young lady, sobbing.

`It will never reach your ears, dear lady, and God forbid such horrors should!' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`Good-night, good-night!' (The gentleman)

The gentleman turned away.

`This purse,' (the lady)
cried the young lady.
`Take it for my sake, that you may have some resource in an hour of need and trouble.' (unknown)

`No!' (the girl)
replied the girl.
`I have not done this for money. Let me have that to think of. And yet--give me something that you have worn: I should like to have something--no, no, not a ring--your gloves or handkerchief--anything that I can keep, as having belonged to you, sweet lady. There. Bless you! God bless you. Good-night, good-night!' (the girl)

The violent agitation of the girl, and the apprehension of some discovery which would subject her (girl) to ill-usage and violence, seemed to determine the gentleman to leave her (girl), as she (girl) requested.

The sound of retreating footsteps were audible and the voices ceased.

The two figures of the young lady and her (lady) companion soon afterwards appeared upon the bridge. They stopped at the summit of the stairs.

`Hark!' (the lady)
cried the young lady, listening.
`Did she (lady) call! I thought I heard her (lady) voice.' (unknown)

`No, my love,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow, looking sadly back.
