`She (lady) has not moved, and will not till we are gone.' (Rose Maylie)

Rose Maylie lingered, but the old gentleman drew her (lady) arm through his (gentleman), and led her (lady), with gentle force, away. As they disappeared, the girl sunk down nearly at her (girl) full length upon one of the stone stairs, and vented the anguish of her (girl) heart in bitter tears.

After a time she (girl) arose, and with feeble and tottering steps ascended the street. The astonished listener remained motionless on his (listener) post for some minutes afterwards, and having ascertained, with many cautious glances round him (listener), that he (listener) was again alone, crept slowly from his (listener) hiding-place, and returned, stealthily and in the shade of the wall, in the same manner as he (listener) had descended.

Peeping out, more than once, when he (listener) reached the top, to make sure that he (listener) was unobserved, Noah Claypole darted away at his (Claypole) utmost speed, and made for the Jew's house as fast as his (Claypole) legs would carry him (Claypole).

CHAPTER XLVII

FATAL CONSEQUENCES

It was nearly two hours before day-break; that time which in the autumn of the year, may be truly called the dead of night; when the streets are silent and deserted; when even sounds appear to slumber, and profligacy and riot have staggered home to dream; it was at this still and silent hour, that Fagin sat watching in his (Fagin) old lair, with face so distorted and pale, and eyes so red and blood-shot, that he (Fagin) looked less like a man, than like some hideous phantom, moist from the grave, and worried by an evil spirit.

He (Fagin) sat crouching over a cold hearth, wrapped in an old torn coverlet, with his (Fagin) face turned towards a wasting candle that stood upon a table by his (Fagin) side. His (Fagin) right hand was raised to his (Fagin) lips, and as, absorbed in thought, he (Fagin) hit his (Fagin) long black nails, he (Fagin) disclosed among his (Fagin) toothless gums a few such fangs as should have been a dog's or rat's.

Stretched upon a mattress on the floor, lay Noah Claypole, fast asleep. Towards him (Claypole) the old man sometimes directed his (man) eyes for an instant, and then brought them back again to the candle; which with a long-burnt wick drooping almost double, and hot grease falling down in clots upon the table, plainly showed that his (man) thoughts were busy elsewhere.

Indeed they were. Mortification at the overthrow of his (man) notable scheme; hatred of the girl who had dared to palter with strangers; and utter distrust of the sincerity of her (girl) refusal to yield him (man) up; bitter disappointment at the loss of his (man) revenge on Sikes; the fear of detection, and ruin, and death; and a fierce and deadly rage kindled by all; these were the passionate considerations which, following close upon each other with rapid and ceaseless whirl, shot through the brain of Fagin, as every evil thought and blackest purpose lay working at his (Fagin) heart.

He (Fagin) sat without changing his (Fagin) attitude in the least, or appearing to take the smallest heed of time, until his (Fagin) quick ear seemed to be attracted by a footstep in the street.

`At last,' (he)
he (Fagin) muttered, wiping his (Fagin) dry and fevered mouth.
`At last!' (he)

The bell rang gently as he (Fagin) spoke. He (Fagin) crept upstairs to the door, and presently returned accompanied by a man muffled to the chin, who carried a bundle under one arm. Sitting down and throwing back his (man) outer coat, the man displayed the burly frame of Sikes.

`There!' (he)
he (Sikes) said, laying the bundle on the table.
`Take care of that, and do the most you can with it. It's been trouble enough to get; I thought I should have been here, three hours ago.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin laid his (Fagin) hand upon the bundle, and locking it in the cupboard, sat down again without speaking. But he (Fagin) did not take his (Fagin) eyes off the robber, for an instant, during this action; and now that they sat over against each other, face to face, he (Fagin) looked fixedly at him (Fagin), with his (Fagin) lips quivering so violently, and his (Fagin) face so altered by the emotions which had mastered him (Fagin), that the housebreaker involuntarily drew back his (Fagin) chair, and surveyed him (Fagin) with a look of real affright.

`Wot now?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes.
`Wot do you look at a man so for?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin raised his (Fagin) right hand, and shook his (Fagin) trembling forefinger in the air; but his (Fagin) passion was so great, that the power of speech was for the moment gone.

`Damme!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, feeling in his (Sikes) breast with a look of alarm.
`He (Sikes)'s gone mad. I must look to myself here.' (unknown)

`No, no,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Fagin, finding his (Fagin) voice.
`It's not--you're not the person, Bill. I've no--no fault to find with you.' (unknown)

`Oh, you haven't, haven't you?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, looking sternly at him (Sikes), and ostentatiously passing a pistol into a more convenient pocket.
`That's lucky--for one of us. Which one that is, don't matter.' (unknown)

`I've got that to tell you, Bill,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, drawing his (Fagin) chair nearer,
`will make you worse than me.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

`Aye?' (the robber)
returned the robber with an incredulous air.
`Tell away! Look sharp, or Nance will think I'm lost.' (unknown)

`Lost!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin.
`She (Sikes) has pretty well settled that, in her (Sikes) own mind, already.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

Sikes looked with an aspect of great perplexity into the Jew's face, and reading no satisfactory explanation of the riddle there, clenched his (Sikes) coat collar in his (Sikes) huge hand and shook him (Sikes) soundly.

`Speak, will you!' (he)
he (Sikes) said;
`or if you don't, it shall be for want of breath. Open your mouth and say wot you've got to say in plain words. Out with it, you thundering old cur, out with it!' (he)

`Suppose that lad that's laying there--' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
Fagin began.

Sikes turned round to where Noah was sleeping, as if he (Sikes) had not previously observed him (Sikes).

`Well!' (he)
he (Sikes) said, resuming his (Sikes) former position.

`Suppose that lad,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
pursued Fagin,
`was to peach--to blow upon us all--first seeking out the right folks for the purpose, and then having a meeting with 'em in the street to paint our likenesses, describe every mark that they might know us by, and the crib where we might be most easily taken. Suppose he (Fagin) was to do all this, and besides to blow upon a plant we've all been in, more or less--of his (Fagin) own fancy; not grabbed, trapped, tried, earwigged by the parson and brought to it on bread and water,--but of his (Fagin) own fancy; to please his (Fagin) own taste; stealing out at nights to find those most interested against us, and peaching to them. Do you hear me?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried the Jew, his (Jew) eyes flashing with rage.
`Suppose he (Jew) did all this, what then?' (unknown)

`What then!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes; with a tremendous oath.
`If he (Sikes) was left alive till I came, I'd grind his (Sikes) skull under the iron heel of my boot into as many grains as there are hairs upon his (Sikes) head.' (unknown)

`What if I did it!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin almost in a yell.
`I, that knows so much, and could hang so many besides myself!' (unknown)

`I don't know,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes, clenching his (Sikes) teeth and turning white at the mere suggestion. `I'd do something in the jail that
`ud get me put in irons; and if I was tried along with you, I'd fall upon you with them in the open court, and beat your brains out afore the people. I should have such strength,' (I)
muttered the robber, poising his (robber) brawny arm,
`that I could smash your head as if a loaded waggon had gone over it.' (the robber)

`You would?' (unknown)

`Would I!' (the housebreaker)
said the housebreaker.
`Try me.' (unknown)

`If it was Charley, or the Dodger, or Bet, or--' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`I don't care who,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
replied Sikes impatiently.
`Whoever it was, I'd serve them the same.' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)

Fagin looked hard at the robber; and, motioning him (Fagin) to be silent, stooped over the bed upon the floor, and shook the sleeper to rouse him (Fagin). Sikes leant forward in his (Sikes) chair: looking on with his (Sikes) hands upon his (Sikes) knees, as if wondering much what all this questioning and preparation was to end in.

`Bolter, Bolter! Poor lad!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, looking up with an expression of devilish anticipation, and speaking slowly and with marked emphasis.
`He (Fagin)'s tired--tired with watching for her (Fagin) so long,--watching for _her (Fagin)_, Bill.' (unknown)

`Wot d'ye mean?' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
asked Sikes, drawing back.

Fagin made no answer, but bending over the sleeper again, hauled him (Fagin) into a sitting posture. When his (Fagin) assumed name had been repeated several times, Noah rubbed his (Noah) eyes, and, giving a heavy yawn, looked sleepily about him (Noah).

`Tell me that again--once again, just for him (Noah) to hear,' (the Jew)
said the Jew, pointing to Sikes as he (Sikes) spoke.

`Tell yer what?' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
asked the sleepy Noah, shaking himself pettishly.

`That about-- _Nancy_,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, clutching Sikes by the wrist, as if to prevent his (Fagin) leaving the house before he (Fagin) had heard enough.
`You followed her (Nancy)?' (unknown)

`Yes.' (unknown)

`To London Bridge?' (unknown)

`Yes.' (unknown)

`Where she (Nancy) met two people.' (unknown)

`So she (Nancy) did.' (unknown)

`A gentleman and a lady that she (Nancy) had gone to of her (Nancy) own accord before, who asked her (Nancy) to give up all her (Nancy) pals, and Monks first, which she (Nancy) did--and to describe him (Fagin), which she (Nancy) did--and to tell her (Nancy) what house it was that we meet at, and go to, which she (Nancy) did--and where it could be best watched from, which she (Nancy) did--and what time the people went there, which she (Nancy) did. She (Nancy) did all this. She (Nancy) told it all every word without a threat, without a murmur--she (Nancy) did--did she (Nancy) not?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, half mad with fury.

`All right,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah, scratching his (Noah) head.
`That's just what it was!' (unknown)

`What did they say, about last Sunday?' (unknown)

`About last Sunday!' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah, considering.
`Why I told yer that before.' (unknown)

`Again. Tell it again!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, tightening his (Fagin) grasp on Sikes, and brandishing his (Sikes) other hand aloft, as the foam flew from his (Sikes) lips.

`They asked her (Nancy),' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah, who, as he (Noah) grew more wakeful, seemed to have a dawning perception who Sikes was,
`they asked her (Nancy) why she (Nancy) didn't come, last Sunday, as she (Nancy) promised. She (Nancy) said she (Nancy) couldn't.' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)

`Why--why? Tell him (Sikes) that.' (unknown)

`Because she (Nancy) was forcibly kept at home by Bill, the man she (Nancy) had told them of before,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
replied Noah.

`What more of him (Noah)?' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin.
`What more of the man she (Nancy) had told them of before? Tell him (Fagin) that, tell him (Fagin) that.' (unknown)

`Why, that she (Nancy) couldn't very easily get out of doors unless he (Fagin) knew where she (Nancy) was going to,' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)
said Noah;
`and so the first time she (Nancy) went to see the lady, she (Nancy)--ha! ha! ha! it made me laugh when she (Nancy) said it, that it did--she (Nancy) gave him (Noah) a drink of laudanum.' (Noah/Mr. Claypole/Noah Claypole)

`Hell's fire!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes, breaking fiercely from the Jew.
`Let me go!' (the man)

Flinging the old man from him (man), he (man) rushed from the room, and darted, wildly and furiously, up the stairs.

`Bill, Bill!' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
cried Fagin, following him (Fagin) hastily.
`A word. Only a word.' (him)

The word would not have been exchanged, but that the housebreaker was unable to open the door: on which he (Fagin) was expending fruitless oaths and violence, when the Jew came panting up.

`Let me out,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes.
`Don't speak to me; it's not safe. Let me out, I say!' (unknown)

`Hear me speak a word,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
rejoined Fagin, laying his (Fagin) hand upon the lock.
`You won't be--' (unknown)

`Well,' (unknown)
replied the other.

`You won't be--too--violent, Bill?' (the men)

The day was breaking, and there was light enough for the men to see each other's faces. They exchanged one brief glance; there was a fire in the eyes of both, which could not be mistaken.

`I mean,' (Fagin/Mr. Fagin/MR. FAGIN)
said Fagin, showing that he (Fagin) felt all disguise was now useless,
`not too violent for safety. Be crafty, Bill, and not too bold.' (he)

Sikes made no reply; but, pulling open the door, of which Fagin had turned the lock, dashed into the silent streets.

Without one pause, or moment's consideration; without once turning his (Fagin) head to the right or left, or raising his (Fagin) eyes to the sky, or lowering them to the ground, but looking straight before him (Fagin) with savage resolution: his (Fagin) teeth so tightly compressed that the strained jaw seemed starting through his (Fagin) skin; the robber held on his (Fagin) headlong course, nor muttered a word, nor relaxed a muscle, until he (Fagin) reached his (Fagin) own door. He (Fagin) opened it, softly, with a key; strode lightly up the stairs; and entering his (Fagin) own room, double-locked the door, and lifting a heavy table against it, drew back the curtain of the bed.

The girl was lying, half-dressed, upon it. He (Fagin) had roused her (girl) from her (girl) sleep, for she (girl) raised herself with a hurried and startled look.

`Get up!' (the man)
said the man.

`It is you, Bill!' (the girl)
said the girl, with an expression of pleasure at his (Bill) return.

`It is,' (unknown)
was the reply.
`Get up.' (the man)

There was a candle burning, but the man hastily drew it from the candlestick, and hurled it under the grate. Seeing the faint light of early day without, the girl rose to undraw the curtain.

`Let it be,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, thrusting his (Sikes) hand before her (girl).
`There's enough light for wot I've got to do.' (unknown)

`Bill,' (the girl)
said the girl, in the low voice of alarm,
`why do you look like that at me!' (the girl)

The robber sat regarding her (girl), for a few seconds, with dilated nostrils and heaving breast; and then, grasping her (girl) by the head and throat, dragged her (girl) into the middle of the room, and looking once towards the door, placed his (robber) heavy hand upon her (girl) mouth.

`Bill, Bill!' (the girl)
gasped the girl, wrestling with the strength of mortal fear,--`I--I won't scream or cry--not once--hear me--speak to me--tell me what I have done!'

`You know, you she (girl) devil!' (the robber)
returned the robber, suppressing his (devil) breath.
`You were watched to-night; every word you said was heard.' (unknown)

`Then spare my life for the love of Heaven, as I spared yours,' (the girl)
rejoined the girl, clinging to him (devil).
`Bill, dear Bill, you cannot have the heart to kill me. Oh! think of all I have given up, only this one night, for you. You _shall_ have time to think, and save yourself this crime; I will not loose my hold, you cannot throw me off. Bill, Bill, for dear God's sake, for your own, for mine, stop before you spill my blood! I have been true to you, upon my guilty soul I have!' (The man)

The man struggled violently, to release his (man) arms; but those of the girl were clasped round his (man), and tear her (girl) as he (man) would, he (man) could not tear them away.

`Bill,' (the girl)
cried the girl, striving to lay her (girl) head upon his (Bill) breast,
`the gentleman and that dear lady, told me to-night of a home in some foreign country where I could end my days in solitude and peace. Let me see them again, and beg them, on my knees, to show the same mercy and goodness to you; and let us both leave this dreadful place, and far apart lead better lives, and forget how we have lived, except in prayers, and never see each other more. It is never too late to repent. They told me so--I feel it now--but we must have time--a little, little time!' (the girl)

The housebreaker freed one arm, and grasped his (them) pistol. The certainty of immediate detection if he (them) fired, flashed across his (them) mind even in the midst of his (them) fury; and he (them) beat it twice with all the force he (them) could summon, upon the upturned face that almost touched his (them) own.

She (them) staggered and fell: nearly blinded with the blood that rained down from a deep gash in her (them) forehead; but raising herself, with difficulty, on her (them) knees, drew from her (them) bosom a white handkerchief--Rose Maylie's own--and holding it up, in her (them) folded hands, as high towards Heaven as her (them) feeble strength would allow, breathed one prayer for mercy to her (them) Maker.

It was a ghastly figure to look upon. The murderer staggering backward to the wall, and shutting out the sight with his (murderer) hand, seized a heavy club and struck her (them) down.

CHAPTER XLVIII

THE FLIGHT OF SIKES

Of all bad deeds that, under cover of the darkness, had been committed within wide London's bounds since night hung over it, that was the worst. Of all the horrors that rose with an ill scent upon the morning air, that was the foulest and most cruel.

The sun--the bright sun, that brings back, not light alone, but new life, and hope, and freshness to man--burst upon the crowded city in clear and radiant glory. Through costly-coloured glass and paper-mended window, through cathedral dome and rotten crevice, it shed its equal ray. It lighted up the room where the murdered woman lay. It did. He (man) tried to shut it out, but it would stream in. If the sight had been a ghastly one in the dull morning, what was it, now, in all that brilliant light!

He (man) had not moved; he (man) had been afraid to stir. There had been a moan and motion of the hand; and, with terror added to rage, he (man) had struck and struck again. Once he (man) threw a rug over it; but it was worse to fancy the eyes, and imagine them moving towards him (man), than to see them glaring upward, as if watching the reflection of the pool of gore that quivered and danced in the sunlight on the ceiling. He (man) had plucked it off again. And there was the body--mere flesh and blood, no more--but such flesh, and so much blood!

He (man) struck a light, kindled a fire, and thrust the club into it. There was hair upon the end, which blazed and shrunk into a light cinder, and, caught by the air, whirled up the chimney. Even that frightened him (man), sturdy as he (man) was; but he (man) held the weapon till it broke, and then piled it on the coals to burn away, and smoulder into ashes. He (man) washed himself, and rubbed his (man) clothes; there were spots that would not be removed, but he (man) cut the pieces out, and burnt them. How those stains were dispersed about the room! The very feet of the dog were bloody.

All this time he (man) had, never once, turned his (man) back upon the corpse; no, not for a moment. Such preparations completed, he (man) moved, backward, towards the door: dragging the dog with him (man), lest he (man) should soil his (man) feet anew and carry out new evidence of the crime into the streets. He (man) shut the door softly, locked it, took the key, and left the house.

He (man) crossed over, and glanced up at the window, to be sure that nothing was visible from the outside. There was the curtain still drawn, which she (man) would have opened to admit the light she (man) never saw again. It lay nearly under there. _He (man)_ knew that. God, how the sun poured down upon the very spot!

The glance was instantaneous. It was a relief to have got free of the room. He (God) whistled on the dog, and walked rapidly away.

He (God) went through Islington; strode up the hill at Highgate on which stands the stone in honour of Whittington; turned down to Highgate Hill, unsteady of purpose, and uncertain where to go; struck off to the right again, almost as soon as he (Whittington) began to descend it; and taking the foot-path across the fields, skirted Caen Wood, and so came on Hampstead Heath. Traversing the hollow by the Vale of Heath, he (Heath) mounted the opposite bank, and crossing the road which joins the villages of Hampstead and Highgate, made along the remaining portion of the heath to the fields at North End, in one of which he (Heath) laid himself down under a hedge, and slept.

Soon he (Heath) was up again, and away,--not far into the country, but back towards London by the high-road--then back again--then over another part of the same ground as he (Heath) already traversed--then wandering up and down in fields, and lying on ditches' brinks to rest, and starting up to make for some other spot, and do the same, and ramble on again.

Where could he (Heath) go, that was near and not too public, to get some meat and drink? Hendon. That was a good place, not far off, and out of most people's way. Thither he (Heath) directed his (Heath) steps,--running sometimes, and sometimes, with a strange perversity, loitering at a snail's pace, or stopping altogether and idly breaking the hedges with a stick. But when he (Heath) got there, all the people he (Heath) met--the very children at the doors--seemed to view him (Heath) with suspicion. Back he (Heath) turned again, without the courage to purchase bit or drop, though he (Heath) had tasted no food for many hours; and once more he (Heath) lingered on the Heath, uncertain where to go.

He (Heath) wandered over miles and miles of ground, and still came back to the old place. Morning and noon had passed, and the day was on the wane, and still he (Heath) rambled to and fro, and up and down, and round and round, and still lingered about the same spot. At last he (Heath) got away, and shaped his (Heath) course for Hatfield.

It was nine o'clock at night, when the man, quite tired out, and the dog, limping and lame from the unaccustomed exercise, turned down the hill by the church of the quiet village, and plodding along the little street, crept into a small public-house, whose scanty light had guided them to the spot. There was a fire in the tap-room, and some country-labourers were drinking before it.

They made room for the stranger, but he (stranger) sat down in the furthest corner, and ate and drank alone, or rather with his (stranger) dog: to whom he (stranger) cast a morsel of food from time to time.

The conversation of the men assembled here, turned upon the neighbouring land, and farmers; and when those topics were exhausted, upon the age of some old man who had been buried on the previous Sunday; the young men present considering him (man) very old, and the old men present declaring him (man) to have been quite young--not older, one white-haired grandfather said, than he (grandfather) was--with ten or fifteen year of life in him (grandfather) at least--if he (grandfather) had taken care; if he (grandfather) had taken care.

There was nothing to attract attention, or excite alarm in this. The robber, after paying his (robber) reckoning, sat silent and unnoticed in his (robber) corner, and had almost dropped asleep, when he (robber) was half wakened by the noisy entrance of a new comer.

This was an antic fellow, half pedlar and half mountebank, who travelled about the country on foot to vend hones, strops, razors, washballs, harness-paste, medicine for dogs and horses, cheap perfumery, cosmetics, and such-like wares, which he (fellow) carried in a case slung to his (fellow) back. His (fellow) entrance was the signal for various homely jokes with the countrymen, which slackened not until he (fellow) had made his (fellow) supper, and opened his (fellow) box of treasures, when he (fellow) ingeniously contrived to unite business with amusement.

`And what be that stoof? Good to eat, Harry?' (a countryman)
asked a grinning countryman, pointing to some composition-cakes in one corner.

`This,' (the fellow composition)
said the fellow, producing one,
`this is the infallible and invaluable composition for removing all sorts of stain, rust, dirt, mildew, spick, speck, spot, or spatter, from silk, satin, linen, cambric, cloth, crape, stuff, carpet, merino, muslin, bombazeen, or woollen stuff. Wine-stains, fruit-stains, beer-stains, water-stains, paint-stains, pitch-stains, any stains, all come out at one rub with the infallible and invaluable composition. If a lady stains her (lady) honour, she (lady) has only need to swallow one cake and she (lady)'s cured at once--for it's poison. If a gentleman wants to prove this, he (gentleman) has only need to bolt one little square, and he (gentleman) has put it beyond question--for it's quite as satisfactory as a pistol-bullet, and a great deal nastier in the flavour, consequently the more credit in taking it. One penny a square. With all these virtues, one penny a square!' (the fellow composition)

There were two buyers directly, and more of the listeners plainly hesitated. The vendor observing this, increased in loquacity.

`It's all bought up as fast as it can be made,' (the fellow)
said the fellow.
`There are fourteen water-mills, six steam-engines, and a galvanic battery, always a-working upon it, and they can't make it fast enough, though the men work so hard that they die off, and the widows is pensioned directly, with twenty pound a-year for each of the children, and a premium of fifty for twins. One penny a square! Two half-pence is all the same, and four farthings is received with joy. One penny a square! Wine-stains, fruit-stains, beer-stains, water-stains, paint-stains, pitch-stains, mud-stains, blood-stains! Here is a stain upon the hat of a gentleman in company, that I'll take clean out, before he (gentleman) can order me a pint of ale.' (unknown)

`Hah!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes starting up.
`Give that back.' (unknown)

`I'll take it clean out, sir,' (the man)
replied the man, winking to the company,
`before you can come across the room to get it. Gentlemen all, observe the dark stain upon this gentleman's hat, no wider than a shilling, but thicker than a half-crown. Whether it is a wine-stain, fruit-stain, beer-stain, water-stain, paint-stain, pitch-stain, mud-stain, or blood-stain--' (the man)

The man got no further, for Sikes with a hideous imprecation overthrew the table, and tearing the hat from him (Sikes), burst out of the house.

With the same perversity of feeling and irresolution that had fastened upon him (Sikes), despite himself, all day, the murderer, finding that he (murderer) was not followed, and that they most probably considered him (murderer) some drunken sullen fellow, turned back up the town, and getting out of the glare of the lamps of a stage-coach that was standing in the street, was walking past, when he (murderer) recognised the mail from London, and saw that it was standing at the little post-office. He (murderer) almost knew what was to come; but he (murderer) crossed over, and listened.

The guard was standing at the door, waiting for the letter-bag. A man, dressed like a game-keeper, came up at the moment, and he (man) handed him (man) a basket which lay ready on the pavement.

`That's for your people,' (the guard)
said the guard. `Now, look alive in there, will you. Damn that
`ere bag, it warn't ready night afore last; this won't do, you know!' (unknown)

`Anything new up in town, Ben?' (unknown)
asked the game-keeper, drawing back to the window-shutters, the better to admire the horses.

`No, nothing that I knows on,' (the man)
replied the man, pulling on his (man) gloves.
`Corn's up a little. I heerd talk of a murder, too, down Spitalfields way, but I don't reckon much upon it.' (unknown)

`Oh, that's quite true,' (a gentleman)
said a gentleman inside, who was looking out of the window.
`And a dreadful murder it was.' (unknown)

`Was it, sir?' (the guard)
rejoined the guard, touching his (guard) hat.
`Man or woman, pray, sir?' (unknown)

`A woman,' (the gentleman)
replied the gentleman.
`It is supposed--' (the coachman)

`Now, Ben,' (the coachman)
replied the coachman impatiently.

`Damn that

`ere bag,' (the guard)
said the guard;
`are you gone to sleep in there?' (the guard)

`Coming!' (the office keeper)
cried the office keeper, running out.

`Coming,' (the guard)
growled the guard. `Ah, and so's the young
`ooman of property that's going to take a fancy to me, but I don't know when. Here, give hold. All ri--ight!' (the coach)

The horn sounded a few cheerful notes, and the coach was gone.

Sikes remained standing in the street, apparently unmoved by what he (Sikes) had just heard, and agitated by no stronger feeling than a doubt where to go. At length he (Sikes) went back again, and took the road which leads from Hatfield to St. Albans.

He (Hatfield) went on doggedly; but as he (Hatfield) left the town behind him (Hatfield), and plunged into the solitude and darkness of the road, he (Hatfield) felt a dread and awe creeping upon him (Hatfield) which shook him (Hatfield) to the core. Every object before him (Hatfield), substance or shadow, still or moving, took the semblance of some fearful thing; but these fears were nothing compared to the sense that haunted him (Hatfield) of that morning's ghastly figure following at his (Hatfield) heels. He (Hatfield) could trace its shadow in the gloom, supply the smallest item of the outline, and note how stiff and solemn it seemed to stalk along. He (Hatfield) could hear its garments rustling in the leaves, and every breath of wind came laden with that last low cry. If he (Hatfield) stopped it did the same. If he (Hatfield) ran, it followed--not running too: that would have been a relief: but like a corpse endowed with the mere machinery of life, and borne on one slow melancholy wind that never rose or fell.

At times, he (Hatfield) turned, with desperate determination, resolved to beat this phantom off, though it should look him (Hatfield) dead; but the hair rose on his (Hatfield) head, and his (Hatfield) blood stood still, for it had turned with him (Hatfield) and was behind him (Hatfield) then. He (Hatfield) had kept it before him (Hatfield) that morning, but it was behind now--always. He (Hatfield) leaned his (Hatfield) back against a bank, and felt that it stood above him (Hatfield), visibly out against the cold night-sky. He (Hatfield) threw himself upon the road--on his (Hatfield) back upon the road. At his (Hatfield) head it stood, silent, erect, and still--a living grave-stone, with its epitaph in blood.

Let no man talk of murderers escaping justice, and hint that Providence must sleep. There were twenty score of violent deaths in one long minute of that agony of fear.

There was a shed in a field he (man) passed, that offered shelter for the night. Before the door, were three tall poplar trees, which made it very dark within; and the wind moaned through them with a dismal wail. He (man) _could not_ walk on, till daylight came again; and here he (man) stretched himself close to the wall--to undergo new torture.

For now, a vision came before him (man), as constant and more terrible than that from which he (man) had escaped. Those widely staring eyes, so lustreless and so glassy, that he (man) had better borne to see them than think upon them, appeared in the midst of the darkness: light in themselves, but giving light to nothing. There were but two, but they were everywhere. If he (man) shut out the sight, there came the room with every well-known object--some, indeed, that he (man) would have forgotten, if he (man) had gone over its contents from memory--each in its accustomed place. The body was in _its_ place, and its eyes were as he (man) saw them when he (man) stole away. He (man) got up, and rushed into the field without. The figure was behind him (man). He (man) re-entered the shed, and shrunk down once more. The eyes were there, before he (man) had laid himself along.

And here he (man) remained in such terror as none but he (man) can know, trembling in every limb, and the cold sweat starting from every pore, when suddenly there arose upon the night-wind the noise of distant shouting, and the roar of voices mingled in alarm and wonder. Any sound of men in that lonely place, even though it conveyed a real cause of alarm, was something to him (man). He (man) regained his (man) strength and energy at the prospect of personal danger; and springing to his (man) feet, rushed into the open air.

The broad sky seemed on fire. Rising into the air with showers of sparks, and rolling one above the other, were sheets of flame, lighting the atmosphere for miles round, and driving clouds of smoke in the direction where he (man) stood. The shouts grew louder as new voices swelled the roar, and he (man) could hear the cry of Fire! mingled with the ringing of an alarm-bell, the fall of heavy bodies, and the crackling of flames as they twined round some new obstacle, and shot aloft as though refreshed by food. The noise increased as he (man) looked. There were people there--men and women--light, bustle. It was like new life to him (man). He (man) darted onward--straight, headlong--dashing through brier and brake, and leaping gate and fence as madly as his (man) dog, who careered with loud and sounding bark before him (man).

He (man) came upon the spot. There were half-dressed figures tearing to and fro, some endeavouring to drag the frightened horses from the stables, others driving the cattle from the yard and out-houses, and others coming laden from the burning pile, amidst a shower of falling sparks, and the tumbling down of red-hot beams. The apertures, where doors and windows stood an hour ago, disclosed a mass of raging fire; walls rocked and crumbled into the burning well; the molten lead and iron poured down, white hot, upon the ground. Women and children shrieked, and men encouraged each other with noisy shouts and cheers. The clanking of the engine-pumps, and the spirting and hissing of the water as it fell upon the blazing wood, added to the tremendous roar. He (children) shouted, too, till he (children) was hoarse; and flying from memory and himself, plunged into the thickest of the throng. Hither and thither he (children) dived that night: now working at the pumps, and now hurrying through the smoke and flame, but never ceasing to engage himself wherever noise and men were thickest. Up and down the ladders, upon the roofs of buildings, over floors that quaked and trembled with his (children) weight, under the lee of falling bricks and stones, in every part of that great fire was he (children); but he (children) bore a charmed life, and had neither scratch nor bruise, nor weariness nor thought, till morning dawned again, and only smoke and blackened ruins remained.

This mad excitement over, there returned, with ten-fold force, the dreadful consciousness of his (children) crime. He (children) looked suspiciously about him (children), for the men were conversing in groups, and he (children) feared to be the subject of their talk. The dog obeyed the significant beck of his (children) finger, and they drew off, stealthily, together. He (children) passed near an engine where some men were seated, and they called to him (children) to share in their refreshment. He (children) took some bread and meat; and as he (children) drank a draught of beer, heard the firemen, who were from London, talking about the murder.

`He (children) has gone to Birmingham, they say,' (He)
said one:
`but they'll have him (children) yet, for the scouts are out, and by to-morrow night there'll be a cry all through the country.' (He)

He (children) hurried off, and walked till he (children) almost dropped upon the ground; then lay down in a lane, and had a long, but broken and uneasy sleep. He (children) wandered on again, irresolute and undecided, and oppressed with the fear of another solitary night.

Suddenly, he (children) took the desperate resolution to going back to London.

`There's somebody to speak to there, at all event,' (he)
he (children) thought.
`A good hiding-place, too. They'll never expect to nab me there, after this country scent. Why can't I lie by for a week or so, and, forcing blunt from Fagin, get abroad to France? Damme, I'll risk it.' (he)

He (Fagin) acted upon this impulse without delay, and choosing the least frequented roads began his (Fagin) journey back, resolved to lie concealed within a short distance of the metropolis, and, entering it at dusk by a circuitous route, to proceed straight to that part of it which he (Fagin) had fixed on for his (Fagin) destination.

The dog, though. If any description of him (Fagin) were out, it would not be forgotten that the dog was missing, and had probably gone with him (Fagin). This might lead to his (Fagin) apprehension as he (Fagin) passed along the streets. He (Fagin) resolved to drown him (Fagin), and walked on, looking about for a pond: picking up a heavy stone and tying it to his (Fagin) handkerchief as he (Fagin) went.

The animal looked up into his (Fagin) master's face while these preparations were making; whether his (Fagin) instinct apprehended something of their purpose, or the robber's sidelong look at him (Fagin) was sterner than ordinary, he (Fagin) skulked a little farther in the rear than usual, and cowered as he (Fagin) came more slowly along. When his (Fagin) master halted at the brink of a pool, and looked round to call him (Fagin), he (Fagin) stopped outright.

`Do you hear me call? Come here!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
cried Sikes.

The animal came up from the very force of habit; but as Sikes stooped to attach the handkerchief to his (Sikes) throat, he (Sikes) uttered a low growl and started back.

`Come back!' (the robber)
said the robber.

The dog wagged his (robber) tail, but moved not. Sikes made a running noose and called him (Sikes) again.

The dog advanced, retreated, paused an instant, and scoured away at his (Sikes) hardest speed.

The man whistled again and again, and sat down and waited in the expectation that he (Sikes) would return. But no dog appeared, and at length he (Sikes) resumed his (Sikes) journey.

CHAPTER XLIX

MONKS AND MR. BROWNLOW AT LENGTH MEET. THEIR CONVERSATION, AND THE INTELLIGENCE THAT INTERRUPTS IT

The twilight was beginning to close in, when Mr. Brownlow alighted from a hackney-coach at his (Brownlow) own door, and knocked softly. The door being opened, a sturdy man got out of the coach and stationed himself on one side of the steps, while another man, who had been seated on the box, dismounted too, and stood upon the other side. At a sign from Mr. Brownlow, they helped out a third man, and taking him (man) between them, hurried him (man) into the house. This man was Monks.

They walked in the same manner up the stairs without speaking, and Mr. Brownlow, preceding them, led the way into a back-room. At the door of this apartment, Monks, who had ascended with evident reluctance, stopped. The two men looked at the old gentleman as if for instructions.

`He (gentleman) knows the alternative,' (Mr. Browlow)
said Mr. Browlow.
`If he (Browlow) hesitates or moves a finger but as you bid him (Browlow), drag him (Browlow) into the street, call for the aid of the police, and impeach him (Browlow) as a felon in my name.' (unknown)

`How dare you say this of me?' (Monks)
asked Monks.

`How dare you urge me to it, young man?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow, confronting him (Brownlow) with a steady look.
`Are you mad enough to leave this house? Unhand him (Brownlow). There, sir. You are free to go, and we to follow. But I warn you, by all I hold most solemn and most sacred, that instant will have you apprehended on a charge of fraud and robbery. I am resolute and immoveable. If you are determined to be the same, your blood be upon your own head!' (unknown)

`By what authority am I kidnapped in the street, and brought here by these dogs?' (Monks)
asked Monks, looking from one to the other of the men who stood beside him (I).

`By mine,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow.
`Those persons are indemnified by me. If you complain of being deprived of your liberty--you had power and opportunity to retrieve it as you came along, but you deemed it advisable to remain quiet--I say again, throw yourself for protection on the law. I will appeal to the law too; but when you have gone too far to recede, do not sue to me for leniency, when the power will have passed into other hands; and do not say I plunged you down the gulf into which you rushed, yourself.' (Monks)

Monks was plainly disconcerted, and alarmed besides. He (your) hesitated.

`You will decide quickly,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, with perfect firmness and composure.
`If you wish me to prefer my charges publicly, and consign you to a punishment the extent of which, although I can, with a shudder, foresee, I cannot control, once more, I say, for you know the way. If not, and you appeal to my forbearance, and the mercy of those you have deeply injured, seat yourself, without a word, in that chair. It has waited for you two whole days.' (Monks)

Monks muttered some unintelligible words, but wavered still.

`You will be prompt,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.
`A word from me, and the alternative has gone for ever.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Still the man hesitated.

`I have not the inclination to parley,' (the man)
said Mr. Brownlow,
`and, as I advocate the dearest interests of others, I have not the right.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Is there--' (Monks)
demanded Monks with a faltering tongue,--`is there--no middle course?'

`None.' (Monks)

Monks looked at the old gentleman, with an anxious eye; but, reading in his (gentleman) countenance nothing but severity and determination, walked into the room, and, shrugging his (gentleman) shoulders, sat down.

`Lock the door on the outside,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow to the attendants,
`and come when I ring.' (the attendants)

The men obeyed, and the two were left alone together.

`This is pretty treatment, sir,' (Monks)
said Monks, throwing down his (Brownlow) hat and cloak,
`from my father's oldest friend.' (Monks)

`It is because I was your father's oldest friend, young man,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
returned Mr. Brownlow;
`it is because the hopes and wishes of young and happy years were bound up with him (Brownlow), and that fair creature of his (Brownlow) blood and kindred who rejoined her (my) God in youth, and left me here a solitary, lonely man: it is because he (man) knelt with me beside his (man) only sisters' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
death-bed when he (man) was yet a boy, on the morning that would--but Heaven willed otherwise--have made her (my) my young wife; it is because my seared heart clung to him (man), from that time forth, through all his (man) trials and errors, till he (man) died; it is because old recollections and associations filled my heart, and even the sight of you brings with it old thoughts of him (man); it is because of all these things that I am moved to treat you gently now--yes, Edward Leeford, even now--and blush for your unworthiness who bear the name.'

`What has the name to do with it?' (companion)
asked the other, after contemplating, half in silence, and half in dogged wonder, the agitation of his (Leeford) companion.
`What is the name to me?' (unknown)

`Nothing,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow,
`nothing to you. But it was _hers_, and even at this distance of time brings back to me, an old man, the glow and thrill which I once felt, only to hear it repeated by a stranger. I am very glad you have changed it--very--very.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`This is all mighty fine,' (Monks)
said Monks -LRB-to retain his (stranger) assumed designation-RRB- after a long silence, during which he (stranger) had jerked himself in sullen defiance to and fro, and Mr. Brownlow had sat, shading his (Brownlow) face with his (Brownlow) hand.
`But what do you want with me?' (unknown)

`You have a brother,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, rousing himself:
`a brother, the whisper of whose name in your ear when I came behind you in the street, was, in itself, almost enough to make you accompany me hither, in wonder and alarm.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I have no brother,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Monks.
`You know I was an only child. Why do you talk to me of brothers? You know that, as well as I.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Attend to what I do know, and you may not,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.
`I shall interest you by and by. I know that of the wretched marriage, into which family pride, and the most sordid and narrowest of all ambition, forced your unhappy father when a mere boy, you were the sole and most unnatural issue.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I don't care for hard names,' (Monks)
interrupted Monks with a jeering laugh.
`You know the fact, and that's enough for me.' (unknown)

`But I also know,' (the gentleman)
pursued the old gentleman,
`the misery, the slow torture, the protracted anguish of that ill-assorted union. I know how listlessly and wearily each of that wretched pair dragged on their heavy chain through a world that was poisoned to them both. I know how cold formalities were succeeded by open taunts; how indifference gave place to dislike, dislike to hate, and hate to loathing, until at last they wrenched the clanking bond asunder, and retiring a wide space apart, carried each a galling fragment, of which nothing but death could break the rivets, to hide it in new society beneath the gayest looks they could assume. Your mother succeeded; she (mother) forgot it soon. But it rusted and cankered at your father's heart for years.' (the gentleman)

`Well, they were separated,' (Monks)
said Monks,
`and what of that?' (Monks)

`When they had been separated for some time,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
returned Mr. Brownlow,
`and your mother, wholly given up to continental frivolities, had utterly forgotten the young husband ten good years her (mother) junior, who, with prospects blighted, lingered on at home, he (husband) fell among new friends. This circumstance, at least, you know already.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Not I,' (Monks)
said Monks, turning away his (husband) eyes and beating his (husband) foot upon the ground, as a man who is determined to deny everything.
`Not I.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Your manner, no less than your actions, assures me that you have never forgotten it, or ceased to think of it with bitterness,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
returned Mr. Brownlow.
`I speak of fifteen years ago, when you were not more than eleven years old, and your father but one-and-thirty--for he (father) was, I repeat, a boy, when _his (father)_ father ordered him (father) to marry. Must I go back to events which cast a shade upon the memory of your parent, or will you spare it, and disclose to me the truth?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I have nothing to disclose,' (Monks)
rejoined Monks.
`You must talk on if you will.' (unknown)

`These new friends, then,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow,
`were a naval officer retired from active service, whose wife had died some half-a-year before, and left him (Brownlow) with two children--there had been more, but, of all their family, happily but two survived. They were both daughters; one a beautiful creature of nineteen, and the other a mere child of two or three years old.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`What's this to me?' (Monks)
asked Monks.

`They resided,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, without seeming to hear the interruption,
`in a part of the country to which your father in his (father) wandering had repaired, and where he (father) had taken up his (father) abode. Acquaintance, intimacy, friendship, fast followed on each other. Your father was gifted as few men are. He (father) had his (father) sister's soul and person. As the old officer knew him (officer) more and more, he (officer) grew to love him (officer). I would that it had ended there. His (officer) daughter did the same.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

The old gentleman paused; Monks was biting his (gentleman) lips, with his (gentleman) eyes fixed upon the floor; seeing this, he (gentleman) immediately resumed:

`The end of a year found him (gentleman) contracted, solemnly contracted, to that daughter; the object of the first, true, ardent, only passion of a guileless girl.' (he)

`Your tale is of the longest,' (Monks)
observed Monks, moving restlessly in his (gentleman) chair.

`It is a true tale of grief and trial, and sorrow, young man,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
returned Mr. Brownlow,
`and such tales usually are; if it were one of unmixed joy and happiness, it would be very brief. At length one of those rich relations to strengthen whose interest and importance your father had been sacrificed, as others are often--it is no uncommon case--died, and to repair the misery he (father) had been instrumental in occasioning, left him (father) his (father) panacea for all griefs--Money. It was necessary that he (father) should immediately repair to Rome, whither this man had sped for health, and where he (man) had died, leaving his (man) affairs in great confusion. He (man) went; was seized with mortal illness there; was followed, the moment the intelligence reached Paris, by your mother who carried you with her (mother); he (man) died the day after her (mother) arrival, leaving no will--_no will_--so that the whole property fell to her (mother) and you.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

At this part of the recital Monks held his (man) breath, and listened with a face of intense eagerness, though his (man) eyes were not directed towards the speaker. As Mr. Brownlow paused, he (Brownlow) changed his (Brownlow) position with the air of one who has experienced a sudden relief, and wiped his (Brownlow) hot face and hands.

`Before he (Brownlow) went abroad, and as he (Brownlow) passed through London on his (Brownlow) way,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, slowly, and fixing his (Brownlow) eyes upon the other's face,
`he (Brownlow) came to me.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`I never heard of that,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
interrupted Monks in a tone intended to appear incredulous, but savouring more of disagreeable surprise.

`He (Brownlow) came to me, and left with me, among some other things, a picture--a portrait painted by himself--a likeness of this poor girl--which he (Brownlow) did not wish to leave behind, and could not carry forward on his (Brownlow) hasty journey. He (Brownlow) was worn by anxiety and remorse almost to a shadow; talked in a wild, distracted way, of ruin and dishonour worked by himself; confided to me his (Brownlow) intention to convert his (Brownlow) whole property, at any loss, into money, and, having settled on his (Brownlow) wife and you a portion of his (Brownlow) recent acquisition, to fly the country--I guessed too well he (Brownlow) would not fly alone--and never see it more. Even from me, his (Brownlow) old and early friend, whose strong attachment had taken root in the earth that covered one most dear to both--even from me he (Brownlow) withheld any more particular confession, promising to write and tell me all, and after that to see me once again, for the last time on earth. Alas! _That_ was the last time. I had no letter, and I never saw him (Brownlow) more.' (unknown)

`I went,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, after a short pause,
`I went, when all was over, to the scene of his (Brownlow)--I will use the term the world would freely use, for worldly harshness or favour are now alike to him (Brownlow)--of his (Brownlow) guilty love, resolved that if my fears were realised that erring child should find one heart and home to shelter and compassionate her (I). The family had left that part a week before; they had called in such trifling debts as were outstanding, discharged them, and left the place by night. Why, or whither, none can tell.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

Monks drew his (Brownlow) breath yet more freely, and looked round with a smile of triumph.

`When your brother,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow, drawing nearer to the other's chair,
`When your brother: a feeble, ragged, neglected child: was cast in my way by a stronger hand than chance, and rescued by me from a life of vice and infamy--' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`What?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
cried Monks.

`By me,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.
`I told you I should interest you before long. I say by me--I see that your cunning associate suppressed my name, although for ought he (associate) knew, it would be quite strange to your ears. When he (associate) was rescued by me, then, and lay recovering from sickness in my house, his (associate) strong resemblance to this picture I have spoken of, struck me with astonishment. Even when I first saw him (associate) in all his (associate) dirt and misery, there was a lingering expression in his (associate) face that came upon me like a glimpse of some old friend flashing on one in a vivid dream. I need not tell you he (associate) was snared away before I knew his (associate) history--' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Why not?' (Monks)
asked Monks hastily.

`Because you know it well.' (unknown)

`I!' (unknown)

`Denial to me is vain,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow.
`I shall show you that I know more than that.' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`You--you--can't prove anything against me,' (Monks)
stammered Monks.
`I defy you to do it!' (Monks)

`We shall see,' (the gentleman)
returned the old gentleman with a searching glance.
`I lost the boy, and no efforts of mine could recover him (boy). Your mother being dead, I knew that you alone could solve the mystery if anybody could, and as when I had last heard of you you were on your own estate in the West Indies--whither, as you well know, you retired upon your mother's death to escape the consequences of vicious courses here--I made the voyage. You had left it, months before, and were supposed to be in London, but no one could tell where. I returned. Your agents had no clue to your residence. You came and went, they said, as strangely as you had ever done: sometimes for days together and sometimes not for months: keeping to all appearance the same low haunts and mingling with the same infamous herd who had been your associates when a fierce ungovernable boy. I wearied them with new applications. I paced the streets by night and day, but until two hours ago, all my efforts were fruitless, and I never saw you for an instant.' (the gentleman)

`And now you do see me,' (Monks)
said Monks, rising boldly,
`what then? Fraud and robbery are high-sounding words--justified, you think, by a fancied resemblance in some young imp to an idle daub of a dead man's Brother! You don't even know that a child was born of this maudlin pair; you don't even know that.' (Monks)

`I _did not_,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow, rising too;
`but within the last fortnight I have learnt it all. You have a brother; you know it, and him (brother). There was a will, which your mother destroyed, leaving the secret and the gain to you at her (mother) own death. It contained a reference to some child likely to be the result of this sad connection, which child was born, and accidentally encountered by you, when your suspicions were first awakened by his (brother) resemblance to your father. You repaired to the place of his (brother) birth. There existed proofs--proofs long suppressed--of his (brother) birth and parentage. Those proofs were destroyed by you, and now, in your own words to your accomplice the Jew, ''_the only proofs of the boy's identity lie at the bottom of the river, and the old hag that received them from the mother is rotting in her (mother) coffin_.'' Unworthy son, coward, liar,--you, who hold your councils with thieves and murderers in dark rooms at night,--you, whose plots and wiles have brought a violent death upon the head of one worth millions such as you,--you, who from your cradle were gall and bitterness to your own father's heart, and in whom all evil passions, vice, and profligacy, festered, till they found a vent in a hideous disease which had made your face an index even to your mind--you, Edward Leeford, do you still brave me!' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`No, no, no!' (the coward)
returned the coward, overwhelmed by these accumulated charges.

`Every word!' (the gentleman word)
cried the gentleman,
`every word that has passed between you and this detested villain, is known to me. Shadows on the wall have caught your whispers, and brought them to my ear; the sight of the persecuted child has turned vice itself, and given it the courage and almost the attributes of virtue. Murder has been done, to which you were morally if not really a party.' (the gentleman word)

`No, no,' (no Monks)
interposed Monks.
`I--I knew nothing of that; I was going to inquire the truth of the story when you overtook me. I didn't know the cause. I thought it was a common quarrel.' (unknown)

`It was the partial disclosure of your secrets,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
replied Mr. Brownlow.
`Will you disclose the whole?' (unknown)

`Yes, I will.' (unknown)

`Set your hand to a statement of truth and facts, and repeat it before witnesses?' (unknown)

`That I promise too.' (unknown)

`Remain quietly here, until such a document is drawn up, and proceed with me to such a place as I may deem most advisable, for the purpose of attesting it?' (unknown)

`If you insist upon that, I'll do that also,' (Monks)
replied Monks.

`You must do more than that,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow.
`Make restitution to an innocent and unoffending child, for such he (Brownlow) is, although the offspring of a guilty and most miserable love. You have not forgotten the provisions of the will. Carry them into execution so far as your brother is concerned, and then go where you please. In this world you need meet no more.' (Monks)

While Monks was pacing up and down, meditating with dark and evil looks on this proposal and the possibilities of evading it: torn by his (brother) fears on the one hand and his (brother) hatred on the other: the door was hurriedly unlocked, and a gentleman -LRB-Mr. Losberne-RRB- entered the room in violent agitation.

`The man will be taken,' (he)
he (man) cried.
`He (man) will be taken to-night!' (unknown)

`The murderer?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
asked Mr. Brownlow.

`Yes, yes,' (unknown)
replied the other.
`His (Brownlow) dog has been seen lurking about some old haunt, and there seems little doubt that his (Brownlow) master either is, or will be, there, under cover of the darkness. Spies are hovering about in every direction. I have spoken to the men who are charged with his (Brownlow) capture, and they tell me he (Brownlow) cannot escape. A reward of a hundred pounds is proclaimed by Government to-night.' (unknown)

`I will give fifty more,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow,
`and proclaim it with my own lips upon the spot, if I can reach it. Where is Mr. Maylie?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`Harry? As soon as he (Maylie) had seen your friend here, safe in a coach with you, he (Maylie) hurried off to where he (Maylie) heard this,' (the doctor)
replied the doctor,
`and mounting his (Maylie) horse sallied forth to join the first party at some place in the outskirts agreed upon between them.' (the doctor)

`Fagin,' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
said Mr. Brownlow;
`what of him (Brownlow)?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)

`When I last heard, he (Brownlow) had not been taken, but he (Brownlow) will be, or is, by this time. They're sure of him (Brownlow).' (unknown)

`Have you made up your mind?' (Mr. Brownlow/MR. BROWNLOW/Brownlow)
asked Mr. Brownlow, in a low voice, of Monks.

`Yes,' (he)
he (Brownlow) replied.
`You--you--will be secret with me?' (unknown)

`I will. Remain here till I return. It is your only hope of safety.' (unknown)

They left the room, and the door was again locked.

`What have you done?' (the doctor)
asked the doctor in a whisper.

`All that I could hope to do, and even more. Coupling the poor girl's intelligence with my previous knowledge, and the result of our good friend's inquiries on the spot, I left him (friend) no loophole of escape, and laid bare the whole villainy which by these lights became plain as day. Write and appoint the evening after to-morrow, at seven, for the meeting. We shall be down there, a few hours before, but shall require rest: especially the young lady, who _may_ have greater need of firmness than either you or I can quite foresee just now. But my blood boils to avenge this poor murdered creature. Which way have they taken?' (unknown)

`Drive straight to the office and you will be in time,' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)
replied Mr. Losberne.
`I will remain here.' (Mr. Losberne/Losberne)

The two gentlemen hastily separated; each in a fever of excitement wholly uncontrollable.

CHAPTER L

THE PURSUIT AND ESCAPE

Near to that part of the Thames on which the church at Rotherhithe abuts, where the buildings on the banks are dirtiest and the vessels on the river blackest with the dust of colliers and the smoke of close-built low-roofed houses, there exists the filthiest, the strangest, the most extraordinary of the many localities that are hidden in London, wholly unknown, even by name, to the great mass of its inhabitants.

To reach this place, the visitor has to penetrate through a maze of close, narrow, and muddy streets, thronged by the roughest and poorest of waterside people, and devoted to the traffic they may be supposed to occasion. The cheapest and least delicate provisions are heaped in the shops; the coarsest and commonest articles of wearing apparel dangle at the salesman's door, and stream from the house-parapet and windows. Jostling with unemployed labourers of the lowest class, ballast-heavers, coal-whippers, brazen women, ragged children, and the raff and refuse of the river, he (salesman) makes his (salesman) way with difficulty along, assailed by offensive sights and smells from the narrow alleys which branch off on the right and left, and deafened by the clash of ponderous waggons that bear great piles of merchandise from the stacks of warehouses that rise from every corner. Arriving, at length, in streets remoter and less-frequented than those through which he (salesman) has passed, he (salesman) walks beneath tottering house-fronts projecting over the pavement, dismantled walls that seem to totter as he (salesman) passes, chimneys half crushed half hesitating to fall, windows guarded by rusty iron bars that time and dirt have almost eaten away, every imaginable sign of desolation and neglect.

In such a neighborhood, beyond Dockhead in the Borough of Southwark, stands Jacob's Island, surrounded by a muddy ditch, six or eight feet deep and fifteen or twenty wide when the tide is in, once called Mill Pond, but known in the days of this story as Folly Ditch. It is a creek or inlet from the Thames, and can always be filled at high water by opening the sluices at the Lead Mills from which it took its old name. At such times, a stranger, looking from one of the wooden bridges thrown across it at Mill Lane, will see the inhabitants of the houses on either side lowering from their back doors and windows, buckets, pails, domestic utensils of all kinds, in which to haul the water up; and when his (stranger) eye is turned from these operations to the houses themselves, his (stranger) utmost astonishment will be excited by the scene before him (stranger). Crazy wooden galleries common to the backs of half a dozen houses, with holes from which to look upon the slime beneath; windows, broken and patched, with poles thrust out, on which to dry the linen that is never there; rooms so small, so filthy, so confined, that the air would seem too tainted even for the dirt and squalor which they shelter; wooden chambers thrusting themselves out above the mud, and threatening to fall into it--as some have done; dirt-besmeared walls and decaying foundations; every repulsive lineament of poverty, every loathsome indication of filth, rot, and garbage; all these ornament the banks of Folly Ditch.

In Jacob's Island, the warehouses are roofless and empty; the walls are crumbling down; the windows are windows no more; the doors are falling into the streets; the chimneys are blackened, but they yield no smoke. Thirty or forty years ago, before losses and chancery suits came upon it, it was a thriving place; but now it is a desolate island indeed. The houses have no owners; they are broken open, and entered upon by those who have the courage; and there they live, and there they die. They must have powerful motives for a secret residence, or be reduced to a destitute condition indeed, who seek a refuge in Jacob's Island.

In an upper room of one of these houses--a detached house of fair size, ruinous in other respects, but strongly defended at door and window: of which house the back commanded the ditch in manner already described--there were assembled three men, who, regarding each other every now and then with looks expressive of perplexity and expectation, sat for some time in profound and gloomy silence. One of these was Toby Crackit, another Mr. Chitling, and the third a robber of fifty years, whose nose had been almost beaten in, in some old scuffle, and whose face bore a frightful scar which might probably be traced to the same occasion. This man was a returned transport, and his (man) name was Kags.

`I wish,' (Kags)
said Toby turning to Mr. Chitling,
`that you had picked out some other crib when the two old ones got too warm, and had not come here, my fine feller.' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)

`Why didn't you, blunder-head!' (Kags)
said Kags.

`Well, I thought you'd have been a little more glad to see me than this,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
replied Mr. Chitling, with a melancholy air.

`Why, look`e, young gentleman,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby,
`when a man keeps himself so very ex-clusive as I have done, and by that means has a snug house over his (Toby) head with nobody a prying and smelling about it, it's rather a startling thing to have the honour of a wisit from a young gentleman -LRB-however respectable and pleasant a person he (gentleman) may be to play cards with at conweniency-RRB- circumstanced as you are.' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

`Especially, when the exclusive young man has got a friend stopping with him (friend), that's arrived sooner than was expected from foreign parts, and is too modest to want to be presented to the Judges on his (friend) return,' (Mr.)
added Mr. Kags.

There was a short silence, after which Toby Crackit, seeming to abandon as hopeless any further effort to maintain his (Crackit) usual devil-may-care swagger, turned to Chitling and said,

`When was Fagin took then?' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

`Just at dinner-time--two o'clock this afternoon. Charley and I made our lucky up the wash-us chimney, and Bolter got into the empty water-butt, head downwards; but his (Charley) legs were so precious long that they stuck out at the top, and so they took him (Charley) too.' (unknown)

`And Bet?' (unknown)

`Poor Bet! She (Crackit) went to see the Body, to speak to who it was,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
replied Chitling, his (Chitling) countenance falling more and more,
`and went off mad, screaming and raving, and beating her (Crackit) head against the boards; so they put a strait-weskut on her (Crackit) and took her (Crackit) to the hospital--and there she (Crackit) is.' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)

`Wot's come of young Bates?' (Kags)
demanded Kags.

`He (Bates) hung about, not to come over here afore dark, but he (Bates)'ll be here soon,' (unknown)
replied Chitling.
`There's nowhere else to go to now, for the people at the Cripples are all in custody, and the bar of the ken--I went up there and see it with my own eyes--is filled with traps.' (unknown)

`This is a smash,' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
observed Toby, biting his (Toby) lips.
`There's more than one will go with this.' (unknown)

`The sessions are on,' (Kags)
said Kags:
`if they get the inquest over, and Bolter turns King's evidence: as of course he (King) will, from what he (King)'s said already: they can prove Fagin an accessory before the fact, and get the trial on on Friday, and he (Fagin)'ll swing in six days from this, by G--!' (Kags)

`You should have heard the people groan,' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)
said Chitling;
`the officers fought like devils, or they'd have torn him (Chitling) away. He (Chitling) was down once, but they made a ring round him (Chitling), and fought their way along. You should have seen how he (Chitling) looked about him (Chitling), all muddy and bleeding, and clung to them as if they were his (Chitling) dearest friends. I can see 'em now, not able to stand upright with the pressing of the mob, and draggin him (Chitling) along amongst 'em; I can see the people jumping up, one behind another, and snarling with their teeth and making at him (Chitling); I can see the blood upon his (Chitling) hair and beard, and hear the cries with which the women worked themselves into the centre of the crowd at the street corner, and swore they'd tear his (Chitling) heart out!' (Mr. Chitling/Chitling)

The horror-stricken witness of this scene pressed his (Chitling) hands upon his (Chitling) ears, and with his (Chitling) eyes closed got up and paced violently to and fro, like one distracted.

While he (Chitling) was thus engaged, and the two men sat by in silence with their eyes fixed upon the floor, a pattering noise was heard upon the stairs, and Sikes's dog bounded into the room. They ran to the window, downstairs, and into the street. The dog had jumped in at an open window; he (Sikes) made no attempt to follow them, nor was his (Sikes) master to be seen.

`What's the meaning of this?' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
said Toby when they had returned.
`He (Toby) can't be coming here. I--I--hope not.' (unknown)

`If he (Toby) was coming here, he (Toby)'d have come with the dog,' (Kags)
said Kags, stooping down to examine the animal, who lay panting on the floor.
`Here! Give us some water for him (Toby); he (Toby) has run himself faint.' (unknown)

`He (Toby)'s drunk it all up, every drop,' (the dog)
said Chitling after watching the dog some time in silence.
`Covered with mud--lame--half blind--he (Toby) must have come a long way.' (unknown)

`Where can he (Toby) have come from!' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)
exclaimed Toby.
`He (Toby)'s been to the other kens of course, and finding them filled with strangers come on here, where he (Toby)'s been many a time and often. But where can he (Toby) have come from first, and how comes he (Toby) here alone without the other!' (unknown)

`He (Toby)' (the murderer)
---LRB-none of them called the murderer by his (murderer) old name-RRB---`He (murderer) can't have made away with himself. What do you think?' said Chitling.

Toby shook his (Toby) head.

`If he (Toby) had,' (Kags)
said Kags, `the dog
`ud want to lead us away to where he (Toby) did it. No. I think he (Toby)'s got out of the country, and left the dog behind. He (Toby) must have given him (Toby) the slip somehow, or he (Toby) wouldn't be so easy.' (the dog)

This solution, appearing the most probable one, was adopted as the right; the dog, creeping under a chair, coiled himself up to sleep, without more notice from anybody.

It being now dark, the shutter was closed, and a candle lighted and placed upon the table. The terrible events of the last two days had made a deep impression on all three, increased by the danger and uncertainty of their own position. They drew their chairs closer together, starting at every sound. They spoke little, and that in whispers, and were as silent and awe-stricken as if the remains of the murdered woman lay in the next room.

They had sat thus, some time, when suddenly was heard a hurried knocking at the door below.

`Young Bates,' (Kags)
said Kags, looking angrily round, to check the fear he (Bates) felt himself.

The knocking came again. No, it wasn't he (Bates). He (Bates) never knocked like that.

Crackit went to the window, and shaking all over, drew in his (Bates) head. There was no need to tell them who it was; his (Bates) pale face was enough. The dog too was on the alert in an instant, and ran whining to the door.

`We must let him (Bates) in,' (he)
he (Bates) said, taking up the candle.

`Isn't there any help for it?' (the man)
asked the other man in a hoarse voice.

`None. He (man) _must_ come in.' (unknown)

`Don't leave us in the dark,' (Kags)
said Kags, taking down a candle from the chimney-piece, and lighting it, with such a trembling hand that the knocking was twice repeated before he (man) had finished.

Crackit went down to the door, and returned followed by a man with the lower part of his (Crackit) face buried in a handkerchief, and another tied over his (Crackit) head under his (Crackit) hat. He (Crackit) drew them slowly off. Blanched face, sunken eyes, hollow cheeks, beard of three days' growth, wasted flesh, short thick breath; it was the very ghost of Sikes.

He (Sikes) laid his (Sikes) hand upon a chair which stood in the middle of the room, but shuddering as he (Sikes) was about to drop into it, and seeming to glance over his (Sikes) shoulder, dragged it back close to the wall--as close as it would go--and ground it against it--and sat down.

Not a word had been exchanged. He (Sikes) looked from one to another in silence. If an eye were furtively raised and met his (Sikes), it was instantly averted. When his (Sikes) hollow voice broke silence, they all three started. They seemed never to have heard its tones before.

`How came that dog here?' (he)
he (Sikes) asked.

`Alone. Three hours ago.' (unknown)

`To-night's paper says that Fagin's took. Is it true, or a lie?' (unknown)

`True.' (unknown)

They were silent again.

`Damn you all!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, passing his (Sikes) hand across his (Sikes) forehead.

`Have you nothing to say to me?' (nobody)

There was an uneasy movement among them, but nobody spoke.

`You that keep this house,' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, turning his (Sikes) face to Crackit,
`do you mean to sell me, or to let me lie here till this hunt is over?' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

`You may stop here, if you think it safe,' (the person)
returned the person addressed, after some hesitation.

Sikes carried his (Sikes) eyes slowly up the wall behind him (Sikes): rather trying to turn his (Sikes) head than actually doing it: and said,

`Is--it--the body--is it buried?' (him)

They shook their heads.

`Why isn't it!' (he)
he (Sikes) retorted with the same glance behind him (Sikes).
`Wot do they keep such ugly things above the ground for?--Who's that knocking?' (Toby/Toby Crackit/Mr. Crackit)

Crackit intimated, by a motion of his (Crackit) hand as he (Crackit) left the room, that there was nothing to fear; and directly came back with Charley Bates behind him (Bates). Sikes sat opposite the door, so that the moment the boy entered the room he (Sikes) encountered his (Sikes) figure.

`Toby,' (the boy)
said the boy falling back, as Sikes turned his (Sikes) eyes towards him (Sikes),
`why didn't you tell me this, downstairs?' (him)

There had been something so tremendous in the shrinking off of the three, that the wretched man was willing to propitiate even this lad. Accordingly he (man) nodded, and made as though he (man) would shake hands with him (man).

`Let me go into some other room,' (the boy)
said the boy, retreating still farther.

`Charley!' (Sikes/Mr. Sikes/Mr. William Sikes)
said Sikes, stepping forward.
`Don't you--don't you know me?' (unknown)

`Don't come nearer me,' (the boy)
answered the boy, still retreating, and looking, with horror in his (boy) eyes, upon the murderer's face.
`You monster!' (The man)

The man stopped half-way, and they looked at each other; but Sikes's eyes sunk gradually to the ground.

`Witness you three,' (the boy)
cried the boy shaking his (boy) clenched fist, and becoming more and more excited as he (boy) spoke.
`Witness you three--I'm not afraid of him (boy)--if they come here after him (boy), I'll give him (boy) up; I will. I tell you out at once. He (boy) may kill me for it if he (boy) likes, or if he (boy) dares, but if I am here I'll give him (boy) up. I'd give him (boy) up if he (boy) was to be boiled alive. Murder! Help! If there's the pluck of a man among you three, you'll help me. Murder! Help! Down with him (man)!' (the boy)

Pouring out these cries, and accompanying them with violent gesticulation, the boy actually threw himself, single-handed, upon the strong man, and in the intensity of his (man) energy and the suddenness of his (man) surprise, brought him (man) heavily to the ground.

The three spectators seemed quite stupefied. They offered no interference, and the boy and man rolled on the ground together; the former, heedless of the blows that showered upon him (boy), wrenching his (boy) hands tighter and tighter in the garments about the murderer's breast, and never ceasing to call for help with all his (boy) might.

The contest, however, was too unequal to last long. Sikes had him (Sikes) down, and his (Sikes) knee was on his (Sikes) throat, when Crackit pulled him (Crackit) back with a look of alarm, and pointed to the window. There were lights gleaming below, voices in loud and earnest conversation, the tramp of hurried footsteps--endless they seemed in number--crossing the nearest wooden bridge. One man on horseback seemed to be among the crowd; for there was the noise of hoofs rattling on the uneven pavement. The gleam of lights increased; the footsteps came more thickly and noisily on. Then, came a loud knocking at the door, and then a hoarse murmur from such a multitude of angry voices as would have made the boldest quail.

`Help!' (the boy)
shrieked the boy in a voice that rent the air.

`He (boy)'s here! Break down the door!' (unknown)

`In the King's name,' (unknown)
